>that it's no more relevant to life today than a play by William
>>Shakespeare or some Greek tragedy.
>>


 Ahem!!!!! "Whereof one does not know, one should not speak"....And who do
we have today, pound for pound, who can match Aeschylus or
Shakespeare?Having taken a break from the list to write,read, and learn how
to spin, I don't think I could have read a more "tragic" human utterance.
Today's "relevant child" uses, on average, a daily working vocabulary of 300
words. Shakespeare's was over 50,000. As Pope indicated, Shakespeare said
things which had "oft been thought, but never so well expressed." his mind
invented many of the common metaphors that people use when trying to express
what they do not have words for, "but that's Greek to me."

  Shakespeare and Greek tragedy "not relevant"--Then I guess the sun or the
moon are no longer relevant, but "what's in a name anyway?" Or let's
see,exactly what part of human nature has changed in the last 600 or 2000
years??? That he (man) is greedy,
flawed,loving,hating,despairing,cunning,cruel, capable of acting only in
self interest, and divinely selfless, "the quintessence of dust."(Hamlet
ActII,scene ii,lines 312-319)...

 Consider a man who said, "If you cannot love, be silent"...(for)"all
creatures in this world exist through love, and lacking love,
lack all that may persist...or is yet to come."

 I am not as kind or insightful as Shakespeare, and for those who think
"independence Day" has something more to say about "aliens" than "The
Merchant of Venice"...I say, just be "silent."

Oh Yeah..I'm going out to my first party in a while..Syntonic(sp?)...If you see
and older raver...definately a Shakespeare type, I mean I teach "da
shit"..say Hi!! so I won't feel like an alien..you might be surprized...but,
then again, you'll find out sooner or later were all in disguise anyway and
only temporary residents of this planet....
                             
                              ...........SpinSilver  aka  Robertj from Monterey


  "Nothing is new under the sun"--

> The Bible has been interpreted accurately.  See the New International
> Version.  Not 100% accurately, of course, but closer to original intent
> than any other written translation to date.

Who is to determine what's accurate or not? The only person who  could
determine the accuracy of the Bible is someone who was there for the
entire thing. Old testament and new. Only person possible in your
"faith" is "god" him/herself. Summon that someone so that I recognize
him/her and have him/her tell me directly that everything in the Bible
is word-for-word true and I will believe! I do not share your faith, so
it's simply not good enough to tell me that some church elder told you
so, not even a gaggle of vatican-funded hermeneutic scholars... I've
already seen far too much evidence that your Church elders have sold
you a load of unbelievable bullshit (but then again, maybe you believe
in Santa Claus too). The fact that I'm supposed to have "faith" in said
bullshit makes me even more skeptical.

> Crystal-clear to me.  This simply refers to Jesus, who was the Word, a
> manifestation of the divine, and the architect of creation.  It's
> completely relevant to life today, because it speaks of the beginning of
> all that exists.

And if you had any background in Judaism or the Qabbala, you'd see that
"The Word" could easily have had completely different meaning from the
perspective of a different culture (trust me, in Hebrew it does). I
have a feeling the authors of "John" in the New Testamant were a lot
closer to that culture than you are, and a lot closer to it than the
authors of the "new international version". Chances are that nobody
alive today has even the foggiest of notions of the "correct"
interpretation of John 1:1 -- I'd say mine is just as valid as yours,
perhaps mine is more valid because I do not have the mirages of
Christian faith clouding my hermeneutic circle. 

> Shakespeare's plays and Greek tragedies contain many concepts that are also 
> relevant to life today.  The settings, no, but the stories, certainly.  In 
> light of this, it appears to me that your last statement in the top 
> paragraph of this e-mail is invalid.

Invalid appears to be a relative term.  All I was saying is that the
bible is full of stories just like classical literature -- parables
which you might find applicable to life, or might give some historical
evidence on the evolution of Judeo/Christian thought; you could even
look at it as a comedy of errors and remark on what a bunch of foolish
dipshits your apostles are. To me, the bible is more of a soap opera
and comic book than the "word of god" as interpreted by men. 

But unlike Shakespeare or a Greek tragedy, people don't go around 
stabbing out people's eyes because they took a Greek Tragedy literally
as a code of behavior and the word of God. Unfortunately, there's some
pretty ugly words in the bible that Christians (and Jews) are all too
happy to act out, which is why we WILL see Christians shooting abortion
clinic workers, which is why we WILL hear of Christians beating the
living daylights out of a "sodomite", which is why we WILL know
Christians that preach hate for others while claiming they Love. And
these same CHRISTIANS will *ALWAYS* go back to some widely held,
twisted Christian interpretation of the BIBLE to back up their crimes
against humanity.

Here's my original words -- note that nowhere did I say that
Shakespeare or Greek Tragedies were irrelevant to life today, just that
the  bible is "no more relevant to life today" than other works of
classic literature:
>Taking the bible for anything more
>than a piece of literature is also very misguided. The bible is more of
>a literary time-capsule of words that you cannot interpret accurately
>in this day and age (hermeneutics). Literal adherence to the words is
>folly -- most Christians interpret the bible freely already (where
>convenient). So feel free to read and interpret the Book, but remember
>that it's no more relevant to life today than a play by William
>Shakespeare or some Greek tragedy.

Niels Mayer (and any who care to read),

Here's a tirade or two of my own, no excerpts included.

Intrpreting the Bible and other such works:

Yes it can be interpretted `better'.  As we learn more about the
customs, language and literary techniques of ancient peoples (those who
wrote the bible, old and new testaments, and those who's religions gave
birth to the bible) we are better able to interpret their writings and
understand their meanings--literal and figurative.  There are people
out there (Christians among them as well as people with no religious
affiliations) doing just that.  Granted they're not the ones you
encounter in everyday life but they're there and their findings are
available though it's much easier to just write it all off as ramblings
of various religious types.  There's even literal interpretations which
don't deal with god(s) but beings who's powers forced our very early
ancestors to treat and refer to them as such.

We can also take into account facts we know or learn about the writers
(or those to whom such writing is attributed) and by comparing related
religious texts, myths, etc... to decipher what's what.  For example
(and here's a major paraphrase from Joseph Campbell who spent his life
(80+ years) studying the world's religions and myths and who wrote much
on the subject:

The New Testament makes mention of the Virgin inception, but only one
apostle mentions it (name forgotten) and he happend to be Greek from
whence such myths had been common place.  Next thing you know it's a
major part of some Christian religions.  What does this tell us?  God
wanted only 1 apostle to teach us this?  Jesus told only one in
secret?  A man interjected his own believe's when he was claiming to
write God's words?  We can't be sure, but I'd say we're a damn sight
closer to the truth.

Obviously, this isn't what you'll learn in churches, temples, etc.. but
it's out there to be learned if you're interested.  And if you want to
continually spout on about it, then I'd say you should be interested.

Personally, I'm interested in where we came from physically, culturally,
intellectually and spiritually (whatever that means) and therefor am
interested in these `interpretations' founded in less religiously
biased traditions.


Mis-Interpretations:

People have mis-interpreted everything from their dog's bark to the
Beatles songs and some of them have killed people because of it--the
Christians don't have a corner on the market.  I wont disagree with any
of the acts you've attributed to them, just want to point out this can
be said about just about every religion, culture, etc... you can think
of (obviously on a smaller scale).  The criminal in all this is
humankind--that greedy, selfish, animal granted (by devine intervention
or not) `intelligence'.


Determining Accuracy (of interpretations):

In the end YOU (each and every individual) must determine what makes the
most sense in any interpretation (including physcist's interpretations
about how the universe works).  The more informed you are, the better
you'll be able to decide.


Prejudice:

Again, whether or not more people have died/suffered in the name of
Christianity or not, whether or not most people claiming to be
Christian are morons who completely missed the boat, to say (as you
have) that ALL CHRISTIANS are like this or to be blamed for this is
somewhat out of character of your otherwise intelligient, informed and
coherent ramblings on the subject.  And to completely leave out all the
other religions in your condmenation seems like you're playing
favourites or are you just going after the easy targets--come on,
challenge yourself.


Finale:

As far as Christianity goes, I think of it as living one's life
according to the teachings ascribed to Jesus Christ (whether or not
they were his original ideas is irrelevant) not necesarily what one
could get from studying the acts of those claiming to be
Christian--most people I know who do so claim, completely missed the
boat and are exactly like the people Christ is said to have been
speaking out against--I'd have to say they're not Christian).  By this
token, a Christian is a Budhist, is a ...

Tim (not a practioner of any faith)

Hmmm...

It seems to me that Niels has several valid points, once I got past the
hostility.  Granted, the Christian religion has, in the name of God,
committed terrible acts, sometimes against their own flock (Spanish
Inquisition, anyone? anyone know any surviving Heugonots?).  But this
intolerance and hatred is not what Jesus Christ (whether he is fictitious
or not at this point is irrelvant - the impact remains the same) taught.
The doctrine he taught was one of compassion, mercy, and humility - it was
intended to replace the teachings of those before him, hence the "new
covenant" between man and god.  Jesus didn't spend time in the temple with
the Pharicees and other religious teachers. He spent his time with Lepers
and whores, if i recall.  Sounds forgiving enough to me. He went ballistic
when he came to the temple in Jeruselem only to find the corruption there
we find today in the religion.

All I am trying to point out is that, in ESSENCE, Christ was a proponent
of Peace, Unity, Love, and Respect. Religion is a tool of man to try to
(in purest form) explain the things we cannot understand. Somehow, though,
we managed to fuck that up as well as it has become a tool to manipulate
people.  Look at the Religious Right - nowhere does Christ propose hate,
ignorance, sexism, and racism as the path to "knowing God."  Buchanan,
Duke, and the rest of that flock are just dead wrong. they know nothing of
God, Love, Peace, or Understanding.

I feel that there are many roads to many truths, and ultimately people
have to follow what works best for them, and it is a trial-and-error
process - that is why so many of us get caught in a cycle that hinders
personal growth. The Taoists, Buddhists, Muslims, Christians, Wiccans,
Pagans, and any others all have a piece (some the same, some different) of
the puzzle, but I firmly believe that inside every one of us we have a
personal path just as valid as any one offered by an organized religion -
we just have to look for it.  Church never really did a whole lot
for me. Raving has helped me to get in touch with the personal truths that
I needed to find. To everyone a different path, I guess.

I am pretty sure my higher power lives around 140 bpm...

I'm only 20, so maybe I'm just full of youthful idealism (read: shit...),
but I am pretty sure that guy from Liverpool got it right when he said:

"all you need is love"

;)

giant steps,

da desert dweller

Chris Escarcega

There is a quote from one of the Gospels (can't remember where, don't have
time to look it up) where Jesus is hungry on the road and he finds a fig 
tree.  He's all happy and then discovers the fig tree has no figs on it 
(i would assume that a. it's not fig season or b. someone else ate em 
all).  So he damns the tree and says it will never have figs on it 
again.  Could someone please explain this in the context of his peace, 
love and generosity?

> There is a quote from one of the Gospels (can't remember where, don't have
> time to look it up) where Jesus is hungry on the road and he finds a fig 
> tree.  He's all happy and then discovers the fig tree has no figs on it 
> (i would assume that a. it's not fig season or b. someone else ate em 
> all).  So he damns the tree and says it will never have figs on it 
> again.  Could someone please explain this in the context of his peace, 
> love and generosity?
> 
> k
> 

o.k. - here's an attempt at deciphering this:

it isn't literal - it's figurative.  the fig tree is the ungenerous man,
who, having given to some, refuses to give more of himself to others as
they ask it of him.  the lesson is that we give of ourselves not from a
limited resource, but instead that as we give we are ourselves enriched
and have even more to share.  at least, that's how it's supposed to work.

otherwise, look out, cause jesus is a comin'.

wow, you'd almost think i was christian ... did i mentioned my theory that
jesus raved?
-matt.

|=======================================================================|
|                                                                       |
| _Query_ : How contrive not to waste one's time?                       |
|                                                                       |
| _Answer_: By being fully aware of it all the while.  Ways in which    |
|           this can be done: By spending one's days on an uneasy chair |
|           in a dentist's waiting-room; by remaining on one's balcony  |
|           all of a Sunday afternoon; by listening to lectures in a    |
|           language one doesn't know; by traveling by the longest and  |
|           least-convenient train routes, and of course standing all   |
|           the way; by lining up at the box-office of theaters and     |
|           and then not buying a seat; and so forth.                   |
|                                                                       |
|    - albert camus, _la peste_                                         |
|                                                                       |
|=======================================================================|

|=======================================================================|
|                                                                       |
| _Query_ : How contrive not to waste one's time?                       |
|                                                                       |
| _Answer_: By being fully aware of it all the while.  Ways in which    |
|           this can be done: By spending one's days on an uneasy chair |
|           in a dentist's waiting-room; by remaining on one's balcony  |
|           all of a Sunday afternoon; by listening to lectures in a    |
|           language one doesn't know; by traveling by the longest and  |
|           least-convenient train routes, and of course standing all   |
|           the way; by lining up at the box-office of theaters and     |
|           and then not buying a seat; and so forth.                   |
|                                                                       |
|    - albert camus, _la peste_                                         |
|                                                                       |
|=======================================================================|
-starchld@leland.stanford.edu--the mothership can be reached at 493-4099-

> I want to hear some feedback on this...
> 
> I've been going to parties for over 5 years now...I've been DJing off and
> on for almost 3...I think I've heard enough to know if a DJ is doing well
> or not so well on a particular night. At freedom, I heard 3 DJ's beginning
> with Dan, who were not having good nights. I'm not talking about
> deck-bumping...I'm talking about falling out of a mix- or poor record
> selection (songs that don't work together).
> 
> ALTHOUGH the music might have been good- meaning the songs were fresh, or
> whatever, did anybody notice the bad mixing? Or were people just into the
> music...or was the vibe cool enough that people didn't really care? I'm
> just wondering, b/c it seemed pretty obvious to all my friends that
> something was amiss...

I too noticed a few skips and mis-mixes last Saturday. As for the
skips, I thought it might have been caused by all the dust circulating
around, and interfering with the stylus. As for the mismixes, well...I
let it slide, because the music selections were very good, and the
vibe was really on. Had the event been in a more controlled
atmosphere, I may have been more critical about it. Sometimes I like
it if a DJ is experimenting with new material during a performance,
even if it means an occasional mismix.

> This isn't a diss on the gathering, the dj's or anyone who had a good time
> at the party...I'm just curious...

I've heard really excellent mixing from DJ Dan in the past, and am
looking forward to better sessions with him in the future.

Rave on,
-G-

Precedence: bulk

     
     A. The tree was growing in a mildly radioactive water table region.  
     Although travel through the region would not be considered harmful, 
     fruit grown there might have a high enough concentration to affect 
     young children.  He did it for the kids.
     
     B. Perhaps the all knowing understands how bad it hurts a fig tree to 
     bear fruit, and wanted to keep it from anymore trauma (having been 
     stripped of it's current fruit inventory).  He did it for the tree.
     
     C. Perhaps Jesus met the person who ate all the figs, and asked them 
     "did you eat all of the figs".  the person who ate all the figs lied 
     and said "No".  Jesus then taught the jerk a lesson by neutering his 
     fig tree.  He did it for the fool.
     
     D. The figs are a symbol of goats.  He did it for the goats.
     
     E. Figs are pretty ugly, and a lot of people passed by this tree.  In 
     the spirit of love and generosity, perhaps this could be considered an 
     "urban beautification project".  He did it for the people.
     
     


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Jesus liked figs
Author:  Karen Hardie <eidrah@vanbc.wimsey.com> at smtplink-acs
Date:    7/10/96 8:04 AM


There is a quote from one of the Gospels (can't remember where, don't have 
time to look it up) where Jesus is hungry on the road and he finds a fig 
tree.  He's all happy and then discovers the fig tree has no figs on it 
(i would assume that a. it's not fig season or b. someone else ate em 
all).  So he damns the tree and says it will never have figs on it 
again.  Could someone please explain this in the context of his peace, 
love and generosity?
     
k

well of course he said it cause it was fucking disrespectful and immature of 
that tree not to have figs when HE wanted some.
the tree can actually be quite grateful he didn't turn it into firewood.


if this should really be in the bible it would be one of the more harmless 
examples of stuff in there that makes me wonder, how in the world 
christians who *really* relate to the bible do get along with it. i mean, 
hey, when moses led his people into the promised land, according to the 
bible they literally butchered the inhabitants there alltogether in the most 
cruel way, for no other reason but because they took up space. 
and guess who said : 
an eye for an eye, and so on. guess who made long and detailed demands how 
he wanted his altar to be, with neat little golden flowers here and small 
ribbons there. well it was god himself.  according to the bible. 
you can take this literal, you can take it figural or sideways, 
it will never in any way be compatible with what is normally understood 
to be christian.  i take it the  concept of 
christianity is mainly determined by the new testament, which i haven't 
read yet and which seems to contain all the stuff about turning the other 
cheek and love your neighbor and let the children come to me, but finally: 
jesus is only one part of that holy trinity. how can one believe in one 
part and deny the others. so do you bible friends ignore the 
other parts, or are they simply not in there in the new international 
version?  
don't get me wrong, i don't have anything against religion, on the 
contrary i feel a certain inclination towards it, probably because my 
country is effectively atheistic and i can't help thinking that some 
people here will definitely fry in hell for their self-sufficient lack of 
spirituality. 
and the bible is kinda neat and kinda cool, but i can't understand how 
somebody can build ones belief on it or something.
i am really interested in getting informed, so if maybe eric could spare 
a few minutes or somebody??
thanks, and best wishes
ulrike

i think i figured it out - when god was young, he was into a more clubby
attitude, and everything had to 'just right' or god would get pissy.
he also was more concerned with his 'rep' and would have his followers
lay some sick shit on other tribes just so word would get around that
'god was in da house!'  later on, god chilled out and got more into trance
- he spent a long time hanging out in the far east and spawned off some
mean meditation trips.  then, he came back to his old club pals (who were
trying to get into 'roman-style' but weren't liking it too much) and
that's when he laid this whole new groove one them with jesus etc.  but
you can still see the remnants of the 'old-skool' god with stuff like that
regrettable fig-tree episode.

-matt.

p.s.
while we're talking figs ...
another nasty one to check out is (i think) elijah and elisha humping
their way around canaan on a donkey, when some kids started jeering at
these two crazy, raggedy guys - that pissed one of them off (elijah?)
and he cursed the tots - whereupon a she-bear came up and slew the kids.
what ever happened to 'kids will be kids'?

and this really is in the bible.

> 
> Alright.. we need a new thread.

We do?  Yeah, those wierd posts about Raving were really starting to
bother me.  Good thing I have a Delete key so I can filter that garbage out.
 
> Why is it that Ravers seem to identify with Aliens/symbols of Aliens?  Is it
> because we feel we are cultural aliens transcending society?  Or something else?

Nothing is going on.  Remain calm.

You have the good aliens, those that talk to us through the technology
we are creating.  The ones that are trying to induce global spiritual
trancendance that will eventually save the world.

You have the bad aliens, who are colonizing the Earth and raping its
resoucres, and they distract the natives by brainwashing them with
electronic media.  

Both use advanced technologies that few Humans understand.

> Is it just a fad?

No.  People have always been keenly interested in the unknown.  Those
that can explain the unknown can do cool things like punish Fig trees.

> Have we all been abducted?

No.  Remain calm.

> Who likes aliens?  (I do!)

Which ones?

Aliens are symbols for the unknown.  Aliens are symbols for those that
hold power over us.  Aliens are symbols for the beings that will someday
save us from (...whatever...).  The conspiracy is we are the 
conspiracy.

You may be interested in subscribing to abducted@schwa.org by sending a
message to:

majordomo@schwa.org

and including the word:

subscribe abducted

In the mean time, I highly recommend purchasing a Schwa Survival Kit,
available from Housewares (aliens make great marketing tools)... double
meaning.

-troy

ps: speaking of marketing, you can read some more of my thoughts on aliens
and raving on my home page, address below.

At 02:23 PM 7/10/96 -0700, you wrote:
>I secretly think that the Roland 303 is a piece of extraterrestrial
>technology.  I mean.. it's just not natural.
>
>Aaron

We all know that Technics 1200's are alien tech.  Someone posted this a
while back:

Oh yeah, technics turntables are actually satellite receptors that tap
into gaia-one and draw energy out through the conductive receptors in the
tone arm.  The disc (or vinyl/record/wax/UMMM THATS GOOD DRUGS 
I CAN KEEP FOREVER!) is actually like a key or access node into the massive 
amounts of energy in gaia-one.  The art of mixing comes from the dance the dj
must do in order to attract hyper dimensional space elves who are masters of
aligning musical energy.  The dance is done by holding your hand on the
pitch slider and moving it really slowly.  The elves decide when the beats
line up and you must put your faith in them.  Then if you take your time
and appeaze all the forces that be circling around the room as you mix, a
dimensional portal may be opened if the musics align properly (but nothing
will happen if they are not).  This dimensional portal gets created when
the energies flowing from one disc can find room to continue to flow as the
other disc gets louder.  If one disc pushes the other disc "off" it's river
of sound the effect is ruined.  Through this dimensional portal you have
direct access to the ear/energies of the gods and godessess of gaia (most
people call them aliens/angels)   Once you do this once they can reset your
internal compass so that your path goes to, hmmm, the happy place.  This is
how I mix.

  Watch out which records you play or you may end up in a dimensional of
beautiful busty bondage biker babes with bad additudes, whips and hmmm,
maybe I should just let you explore...

Okay, this falls into the category of Kinda Rave Related (KRR), so I 
thought I'd post it here first :)

I need someone to help with the graphics on a few rave/electronic music 
websites that I'm working on.  For example, one of the things I'm doing 
right now is Rampant Records webpage.  I need someone who can design good 
imagemaps - the kind you see where several pictures are seemlessly pasted 
together in a neat fashion.  I'm pretty good at logos, buttons, and small 
graphics, but I need someone who has DOPE PhotoShop skills :)

I posted this here first because I'd like to give everyone here a chance 
at this first.  I know there's a lot of graphics hotshots here (ie 
Mike Migurski :) that would probably fit this category.  This would give 
anyone an opportunity to work on some cool sites, get some exposure, and 
make a little money.  So if you're interested, please drop me a line, and 
if possible, some links to examples of your work.

John

>> > Why is it that Ravers seem to identify with Aliens/symbols of Aliens?

probably has somethng to do with the popularity of Alien Workshop skate
stuff (damn, they have some really hotshot graphic designers over there!).
Plus, they're a cool symbol of "other-worldliness." I try to stay away from
the whole alien/UFO thing in my work (pretty cliche) but I'm really tempted
sometimes... The alien head image is so simple and so expressive... and all
the cool visual jokes and analogies that go along with it... wow!

of course I'm looking at the question from an almost totally graphic POV.

-m.

Ok here's the scoop...


Techno is actually a language to commune with our extraterriteal brothers
(and sisters)... Apparently the "Darker" Aliens like slower beats (note the
rythmic "countdown" in ID4) while the "Lighter" otherworldly visitors perfer
faster, trancy tunes... Hence a light side and a dark side...
Now If you listen to the radio, you'll notice those hip hop commercal staions
have some deep bass thumping music... all pretty slow BPM standards.. It's
the hypnotic vive that's bring the bass to slower and slower beats.. soon it
will be a sloooow drooonee and the Dark ones will come....

But there is still hope!!! We, the underground, need to keep throwing illegal
parties, playing faster music (jungle, gabber, trance, happy hardcore...) to
mix up thier singnals.. Why do you think the police come enmasse to distrupt
our parties while so much REAL crime is being commited??? Cos' we're
interferring whit the "master plan"... We are the Rebels of the future
attempting to bring the sides (E.T's, that is) of the light to help and guide
us...

But Iv'e told too much now and I must go back into 'Lurker mode'...

(and to think some peole actually believe this...)

"dance with me..."
-Adam (In hiding)

In article <1.5.4.16.19960710200423.56e7d1a0@mail.inreach.com>,
A-RON <gutman@inreach.com> wrote:
> Why is it that Ravers seem to identify with Aliens/symbols of Aliens?  Is it
> because we feel we are cultural aliens transcending society?  Or something else?

My guess is that Raves attract "Wanderers".  What is a wanderer, you ask?  A
wanderer is an alien soul reincarnated onto this planet in human form.  This
isn't my idea, mind you, its a concept originated by the channeled entity
known as "Ra".  Whether or not you actually believe in channeled beings, the
concept itself is worth some thought.  I mean, if you believe in
reincarnation and the existance of ET's, as I do, its conceivable that ET's
could end up reincarnated in human souls.  Such individuals would have
common characteristics like:

       - a feeling of alienation from society
       - strong identification with UFO phenomena
       - a love for new technology
       - a call to service (RA sayz aliens are here to help)

Certainly, all the above are things that call or apply to Ravers.

Purple Tiger

ps It's been a while. I'm glad to be back.  Luv you all.

In article <Pine.SCO.3.91.960710075522.5112C-100000@vanbc.wimsey.com>,
Karen Hardie <eidrah@vanbc.wimsey.com> wrote:
> There is a quote from one of the Gospels (can't remember where, don't have
> time to look it up) where Jesus is hungry on the road and he finds a fig 
> tree.  He's all happy and then discovers the fig tree has no figs on it 
> (i would assume that a. it's not fig season or b. someone else ate em 
> all).  So he damns the tree and says it will never have figs on it 
> again.  Could someone please explain this in the context of his peace, 
> love and generosity?

If the son of god, the same guy who could walk on water, create an endless
loaf of bread, bring sight to the blind and raise Lazarus from the dead,
walked up to YOU and said, "Grow figs baby!", how could you not grow figs?
I wouldn't matter if you were a tree, a rock, or a Raver.

The only way you COULDN'T grow figs is if you said, "Bite me Jesus!  I'm a
devil lovin' spawn of Satan and you and that God guy can kiss my hairy
buttucks."  At that point, DAMN is a bit redundant.

More literally, if Jesus calls you into service of mankind, the only way you
wouldn't be able to do it is if you were totally and eternally damned.
The good news is that there are a bunch of other teachings in the bible that
no matter how bad a shape you are in, no matter how far back you've slid
from good, you can always come back.  The christ power, when it comes to the
human soul, is so powerful and so complete that he would never, ever have to
damn you just because there are no "figs" on your branches.

IMHO, this is one of those more powerful and pure christian teachings.  It
the sort of stuff that reforms hardened criminals and causes men and women
to dedicate their lives to the betterment of humanity.

PT - was a born-again pastor in training, now more of a taoist

On Wed, 10 Jul 1996, Purple Tiger wrote:

> My guess is that Raves attract "Wanderers".  What is a wanderer, you ask?  A
> wanderer is an alien soul reincarnated onto this planet in human form.  This
> isn't my idea, mind you, its a concept originated by the channeled entity
> known as "Ra".  Whether or not you actually believe in channeled beings, the
> concept itself is worth some thought.  I mean, if you believe in
> reincarnation and the existance of ET's, as I do, its conceivable that ET's
> could end up reincarnated in human souls.  Such individuals would have
> common characteristics like:
> 
>        - a feeling of alienation from society
>        - strong identification with UFO phenomena
>        - a love for new technology
>        - a call to service (RA sayz aliens are here to help)
>

> 
> Purple Tiger

 Wow. Your post has me Trippin'! I recall a very detached, surreal state
of mind I was in one time when I had the distinct impression that  I was
an energy projection (from the future/another dimension?) inhabiting a
body that was essientially like an enviromental space suit. The problem
was that the "suit" imposed it's concerns over mine and eventually I
forgot my purpose for being here (which I'm still am not sure on?). The
focal point of this experience was this radio-like contact that "home
base" was trying to reestablish with me.

 This was years before I discovered the concepts in the role-playing game
"Dream Spell", which deal with the ideas in the two above posts.

At 08:52 AM 7/9/96 -0700, Eric P. Peterson wrote:
>Another thing about pentagrams: they're representative of the Tempter only
>when they're upside-down, to symbolize a goat's head...

Pentagrams get a bum rap too.  Their association with "evil" is fairly recent.

I saw a book in a used bookstore in Palo Alto a while back.  It had a pentagram
emblazoned on it, pointing down.  What manner of sinister text could this be?

It was a geometry textbook, printed in 1903.  The pentagram contains the
golden ratio,
and has some other interesting properties as well  which is why it was the
symbol of
the ancient Pythagoreans, who picked it up (along with everything else) from the
Egyptians, where it has been (_very_ recently) traced back to before Ramses.

The difference between a pentagon and a pentagram is that one term switches
from real to imaginary.  Imaginary terms are what tone and rhythm are made of 
(When a simple exponential switches from real to imaginary, you get a sine
wave).

The difference between a pentagram pointing up and one pointing down
is not one between "good" and "evil".
It is the difference between stasis and motion.
You have all seen the picture of the pentagram superimposed on a human form
(the top point is by the head, the next are by the arms and the next the legs).
Now superimpose that pentagram on a DANCING human form!

The pentagram is a very appropriate symbol for the kind of magic that we
all experience when we're dancing and everything is going off.
It is time to reclaim it.
The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 10 21:54:30 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA25976; Wed, 10 Jul 1996 21:54:30 -0700
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA25970; Wed, 10 Jul 1996 21:54:26 -0700
Received: from well (surfpunk@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.5/8.7.5) with SMTP id VAA08713 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 10 Jul 1996 21:54:23 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Wed, 10 Jul 1996 21:54:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
Subject: Frequency 8: A Brief History
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9607102110.A5777-0100000@well>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


In early 1995 Kevon Banks (Funky Techno Tribe) introduced me to
Mike Robbins because he felt that we had similar musical tastes 
and ideas for a more "progressive" "spiritual" rave.
We did. And we wanted to keep it inexpensive and small.
That was easy, because neither of us had any money. :)

I owned a functional coffin, and Mike's roommate, Eric Newman had
two decent speakers.  Great! Let's have a party!  Where?  My small
studio apartment in Stinson Beach - let's keep it small and see 
where it goes!

What to call it?  From conversations Mike and I had about Navajo 
teachings of evolution and higher vibrational levels, the three of us
came up with FREQUENCY 8.  Mike became MARS, Eric became MysterE and
I'd always liked my unusual last name - Cyr (pronounced seer)

1st Party - 15 people, 2nd Party - Over 40 people and the walls were
sweating!  Still no money.  :(
What to do?  Rent a sound system (on my overtaxed credit card) and see
if we could keep it going.  I've lived in Stinson Beach for over 10
years, so, with the help of "locals" who've always preferred to remain
anonymous, we moved to the woods.  Over 100 people and we broke even!

We kept it up - every two weeks, all last summer into the fall 
advertising only on SFRaves and printing 200 flyers for friends.
When the weather got too dry, we moved to Red Rock Beach (my fantasy
fulfilled - playing with the waves in the early morning) AND we
had the BEST crowd!

3 or 4 guys hauling all that equipment down to the beach is never easy,
(MAJOR understatement) and hauling it up in the morning is even worse.
Adam G was always a major help.  Dino, too.

When the idea for the store came up, I neither had the money to invest or
the time, so, I chose to remain associated with the party only.

Life was good and we enjoyed inviting new people to play with us.
Along the way we lost several hundred dollars (out of my pocket)
but, we were sure I'd get it back some day.

July 1996 - After over 20 parties, I am told, indirectly, that I quit
Frequency 8.  I'm out.  I'm not playing this week.

This really sucks. And hurts. I spent so much time promoting, lugging
tons of equipment, losing money.  And neither Mike nor Eric has the honesty
to talk to me.  I've often asked you sfravers to support this party.
Not now.  How could I?

Jim Cyr
(surfpunk@well.com)

        My company, Virtual Sites is in need of 1 - 3 interns who can
        put in 10 - 20 hours a week learning/doing various tasks in a
        small ISP.  Virtual Sites primarily provides Web space to small
        and medium size companies but we also provide dedicated ISDN and
        Frame Relay connectivity to a number of firms.  You can visit our
        home page at http://www.v-site.net.  Some of the tasks that need to
        be done are:

                Web site installation.
                Web site maintenance
                Network Monitoring
                Web site authoring
                Customer Relations
                Network Engineering

        This is an intern position (basically we can't afford to pay
        a salery) but there are definite perks. You get to have plenty of
        webspace for your own projects, you get to learn an awful amount
        about the operation of the Internet and you get to meet and hang out
        with other kool raver types.  The Internships lat for 2 - 3 months,
        we can also work with your school if you want it to be work-study
        credit.


        If you are interested send some e-mail with a resume to
        webmaster@v-site.net Please put INTERNSHIP somewhere in the
        Subject header.



                                                geoffw

Regarding a collective unconscious, I happened to be using the bathroom
at Mantra and thinking this very thought (that feeling of unity 
consciousness) trying to put my thoughts into words when I looked
up and on the left hand wall among the various other graffiti messages
was the beautiful sentence, "I am swimming in a sea of souls". Also,
in an astrology report, the Neptune Transit portion says:

----
The planet Neptune in the current sky above us points to how we let go,
relax, and find that common thread -- communion. It is connected to our
imagination and our dreams too. Neptune can inspire us to share in a 
communion vision with others. "The dewdrop slips into the shining sea."

An appreciation for ideas and thoughts that are quite other-worldly 
is upon you. It is easy for you to love and be compassionate and to
value what life offers. You have a sense of unity and humanhood that 
will stay with you. A renewed set of values.

Insights into your deeper, more spiritual nature are available to you
during this period of time. You may be able to discover whole new areas
of your psyche or mind that have been closed up to now. Insights into
dreams and ideals.

A time to reach beyond the physical into the realm of myths and dreams.
You may have the sensation of being awake within your own dream, and 
reality may be like you dreamed it could be. This is a time for visions
and seeing the UNITY BEYOND DIFFERENCES.
----

I forgot to bring in the story called "The Promise" which was the
basis for last weeks "The Promise" party on Wednesday. I'll be sure
to bring it in next week and post it to sfraves.

Peace All!
John

Don't you think it would be hard to dance (both from female and male 
point of view)?  I personally don't have anything against nakedness (I 
did grow up in Croatia where nude beaches are a normal thing), but I am 
not sure if I would go to a naked rave....

Bad things about it
- could be cold
- body parts all over the place (maybe if there were see-through holders)
- some people would show up just to look at other naked people not to 
rave which would be not comfortable for some people 

Good things
- it could be pretty cool :)

P.S.  At Tribal Future there were some people that were naked - mud baths 
and hot tubs, but it wasn't planned - it was just natural and it was fun 
and normal - I think making it a planned thing would ruin the spontaneity

On Thu, 11 Jul 1996, David Ginsberg wrote:

> IBVA Technologies, Inc. Announces New Expansion Paks for Innovative
> Brainwave Control System
> 
> New York --July 5, 1996 -- IBVA Technologies, Inc., maker of the
> Interactive Brainwave Visual Analyzer (IBVA) system, announced today a
> set of Expansion Paks for its innovative brainwave control system. The
> IBVA system is a Macintosh-based electroencephalograph (EEG) featuring a
> one- or two-channel headband, wireless transmitter, receiver and
> brainwave analysis software that provides a direct mind-to-computer link.
> 
> The new Expansion Paks are add-on applications and hardware that will
> enable IBVA users to use their brainwaves to wirelessly control industry
> standard video games, virtual reality applications, and common household
> devices including CD players, VCRs, cable boxes, light switches, security
> systems, etc.
> 
> The 1 channel IBVA retails for $1,295 and the 2 channel IBVA retails for
> $2,295. To kick off the announcement of the new Expansion Paks, the 1
> channel IBVA is being offered to Evangelist members for $995 and the 2
> channel for $1,995 through July 31, 1996.
> 
> IBVA's New Expansion Paks include:
> 
> --Video Game Expansion Pak: Control Sony PlayStation, Sega Saturn or
> Super Nintendo with your brainwaves! The IBVA enhanced joystick for each
> platform retails for $280. And the deluxe edition for controlling all
> three platforms retails for $320.
> 
> --Virtual Reality Expansion Pak: This Pak connects to the i-glasses!
> system from Virtual i-O to bring brainwave interaction to virtual
> reality. The Virtual Reality Expansion Pak retails for $60.
> 
> --X-10 Expansion Pak: X-10 is a communications method that uses the
> electrical wiring already installed in most houses to send and receive
> signals to control lights, garage doors, security systems, etc. The IBVA
> X-10 software easily allows you to assign which X-10 devices will be
> controlled (or not) depending on the brainwave frequencies and voltages
> you assign. The X-10 Expansion Pak retails for $80.
> 
> -- Infra-Red Expansion Pak: This Pak includes the ultra-quality Celadon
> PIC-200 Infra-Red controller, IBVA IR Control software and the Mind
> OS(TM) CD-Player Control Module software that together will allow a user
> to place ordinary household devices such as CD players under the control
> of the IBVA system and your brain activity. The IBVA Infra-Red Expansion
> Pak retails for $480.
> 
> Learn more about the new Expansion Paks at IBVA's improved Web site. The
> Web site now offers comprehensive information on IBVA's advanced,
> brain-to-computer interface and software programs as well as downloadable
> screen shots from IBVA's Step 1 CD-ROM, which features brain-controllable
> multimedia movies, graphics and demo programs.
> 
> IBVA's World Wide Web address is:
> <http://www.opendoor.com/pagoda/ibva.html>.
> 
> IBVA Technologies, Inc. is headquartered at 249 East 48th St. New York,
> NY 10017 ph: 212/754-IBVA (4282); f: 212/759-5080.
>

Received: from [204.62.132.158] (olives.wired.com [204.62.132.158]) by wired.com (8.7.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id NAA14288; Thu, 11 Jul 1996 13:42:37 -0700 (PDT)

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 11 Jul 1996 13:48:51 -0800
To: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: olives@hotwired.com (Oliver Raskin)
Subject: Re: Looking for Bookslef Speakers (NRR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've got a pair of Cambridge Soundworks Model 7's ($260 for the pair when I
got 'em 2 yrs. ago)

These speakers _rock_.  They're really solidly built, come in nice
cabinets, and cover all the frequency ranges _really_ nicely.  Plus, they
come with a 5 year guarantee.  Check them out.

A word of advice, however...When you go into the store, the guys will take
you into a listening room and show you all their stuff, starting with their
top-of-the-line model first.  By the time you get down to the system you
can afford, you are terribly depressed and disappointed.  Don't be -- they
still sound awesome, but when compared to their best stuff (which is
_epic_, BTW) they kinda leave you wanting more.  This is an illusion.  The
model 7s are great for bedrooms and small to medium sized living rooms.

Oliver

Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960711143141.23717C-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

Precedence: bulk


The Millennium bug: experts see computer chaos in 2000

WASHINGTON - A technology industry group is painting a grim picture of the
potential havoc on computer
systems around the world from the so-called millennium bug. 

The failure of many computers to recognize the date 2000 properly could
disrupt vehicle traffic, paychecks,
benefit calculations, security systems and even weapons systems, the
Information Technology Association of
America said. 

Fixing the problem is going to cost businesses and governments literally
hundreds of billions of dollars, the
ITAA says. 

"I don't want to be in traffic, I don't want to be in an elevator in a
tall building, I don't want to be anywhere
computer dependent on Jan. 1, 2000," says Nancy Peters of Software AG, in
Darmstadt, Germany. 

The problem arose because computer programmers in the 1960s and 1970s -
when storage space was tight -
used two digits to represent a year instead of four, expecting the
programs to be obsolete before the millennium. 

Most computers, lacking human intuition, either think that "00" means 1900
or reject it completely as an invalid
date. 

Unless the problem is fixed, the U.S. Treasury will be unable to write
checks dated 2000 and computers will
reject birthdates in that year, Peters said Wednesday at an ITAA
presentation to members of Congress. 

City traffic signal systems, which depend on computers to tell them which
days fall on weekends and which days
are holidays, also would be in chaos, she says. 

Since Jan. 1, 2000, falls on a Saturday, the first workday will be Jan. 3. 

The problem is cropping up already. Some cash registers refuse to accept
credit cards with expiration dates in
2000. Employees type in 1999 instead. 

William Scully of Phoenix-based Viasoft said every company his firm
examined had major problems,
compounded by the fact that systems were interlinked and interdependent. 

"Systems are so intertwined that it's very difficult to touch one file,
application or system without having an
unanticipated effect somewhere else," he said. 

ITAA estimates the cost of fixing the millennium bug will be $300 billion
to $600 billion worldwide - based on
an estimated cost of 80 cents to $1 per line of new program code. That
would mean an average cost of $4 million
for an average-sized company. 

Recognizing the size of the problem, Nebraska has implemented a two-cent
per pack cigarette tax to pay for the
overhaul of the state's software. 

With demand for competent programmers already booming, "There are not
enough qualified people to help
everyone simultaneously," Scully says. 

The problem is not just confined to old mainframe computers. In a
demonstration for congressional staff, Peters
reset a personal computer's internal clock to just before midnight on Dec.
31, 1999. At the stroke of midnight,
the PC's clock jumped back 20 years and declared it was 1980. 

She said the PC's internal code was probably written after 1980, and the
programmer likely set 1980 as a start
date for the clock. 

She warned it was a dangerous experiment, because the outcome was
unpredictable and varied from PC to PC,
even resulting in the loss of all files in some cases. 

Despite recent calls from Congress for action, many U.S. agencies are only
in the planning stages of dealing with
the problem, Scully said. 

The most advanced federal agency, and perhaps the one with the biggest
problem, is the Social Security
Administration, which started work in 1989. 

For U.S. federal agencies, the millennium comes a little earlier. Fiscal
year 2000 begins on Oct. 1, 1999. 

Copyright, Reuters Ltd. All rights reserved

>>>Sorry for the wasted bandwith<<<<

I *AM* the self proclaimed speaker guru. Before you buy anything let me 
know to see what I can find for you. Here's my $.02

*Consumers beware: Like Oliver said, salespeople are sleazy, good for 
             nothing, would lie to their mom creatures (for the most
             part). Mail order has been known to screw people over 
             time and time again! Almost all speakers are sold at 50 
             pts. (100% markup), so if you don't get at least 25-30%
             off you are getting ripped off! And do not ever buy 
             extended waranties!

Cambridge Soundworks makes excellent speakers. Their biggest selling 
point to me is the fact that they were designed by Henry Kloss
(founder of AR, KLH, and Advent) and they are sold with less margin 
than most other speakers. But would still just rate them slightly
above average.

My personal favorite bookshelfs approx $200 pair 
(I have auditioned 100s of speakers in this price range)

Klipsch - KG1.5 Yes Yes Yes. These are the f**kin bomb! I love these
          speakers sooo much!!! Klipsch is known for designing ultra
          high efficient speakers with excellent bass and REAL wood
          veneer (Most other speakers in this price range are plastic
          laminate) The major benefit of these speakers is that since
          they are very efficient your amp will love you and you'll get
          more overall sound for your dollar. Pseudo-horn tweeter.
         
Paradigm - Titan $199 pr. Good, clean sound, excellent bass for size
           You won't find them at a regular retail store. 

Polk Audio - RT5 - (can't remember exact price) *NICE* top end! I love
             these speakers cuz they work great alone, and they kick
             ass if you add a sub in the future. They also integrate
             with Polk Audio's new Home Theater line. 

PLUR,

CT

Sorry John,

I said I'd do this after Freedom.  I guess I had to work or something... anyway,
here goes the (lovingly hand data entered) story from the flyers to last week's 
PROMISE.  The story's vibe matched the raves ... warm, beautiful, weird, loving 
and vast (yet somehow familiar).

Andy W

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE PROMISE

The call had gone out and they answered it from far and beyond.  Willingly they 
came, armed with their gift for changing frequencies and old hands at slipping 
undetected into dimensional realities.  But this mission would be dangerous and 
difficult and like none ever encountered.  Yet they came by the thousands and 
agreed to the conditions, for this would be the single greatest infiltration 
ever attempted at any one time.

They were trained and schooled, this hand picked group, for they were to enter a
planet so locked in the frequency of dark energy - so controlled by powerful 
forces, it would be akin to a suicide mission.  But the trouble-shooters, 
confident and challenged, still agreed to go knowing the importance of the 
mission, not only to the holographic universe this planet moved in, but to all 
other universes and galaxies interacting with it.

And so the plan began.  Before entering through the spiraled dimensional energy 
bands and into the planets vibrational field, each member was programmed with 
coded information of a so-called "past" that would be indigenous to the planet. 
The staging was complete even to the activation of amnesia as to who they really
were.  Their programmed "past" would then become "real" and the illusion of who 
they believed themselves to be would take over and stay imprinted until they 
were fully integrated onto the planet's surface.

They would become entrapped in the time bands of that space continuum and then 
begin to `believe they had already experienced years of association with many of
it's inhabitants.  However, there would always be a feeling they were different 
from others.  They would struggle with the pain of loneliness and alienation 
from their original surroundings and be driven by a strange sense of purpose - 
some mission they felt they had to complete where time was of the essence - and 
would drift in and out of their subconciousness like the gossamer thoughts of a 
fading dream.

They would arrive like the landing of paratroopers, and although inserted into 
different geographical areas, they would soon begin to meet with others of their
group as somehow their paths would cross and they would feel again the 
familiarity as friendships and associations began.  They had been assured of the
many reminders and clues that would surround them if they would search for them 
and the computerized information in the crystal instructors if they would learn 
to communicate within the limited vibrational bodies of dense matter they had 
taken on.

But the greatest danger of all, and one they had been forewarned of, would be 
that of becoming caught in the light sapping bands of frequency surrounding and 
infiltrating the planet's atmosphere.  They would feel the emotions of 
hopelessness and fear, despair and sadness, anger and rage, hate and sarcasm, 
power and greed and enveloped in the magnetic particles that carry these 
negative emotions they would wander lost and forgetful of their mission.  This 
was to be the greatest danger of all for the dichotomy was this necessity to 
experience these emotions for without this understanding they would be unable to
help the inhabitants of this dying planet.

The struggle would ever have to be that of "Waking up" and remembering who they 
were - light workers bringing knowledge and freedom to a peoples who were 
trapped.  Each member of this great and magnificent undertaking would be 
assigned a specific task.  A portion of this master plan would be coded into 
their DNA and, like cosmic mercenaries, they would blast their way through the 
dark.  But there would always be the danger of being recognized by those who did
not want to lose control of the planet, and efforts to destroy these light 
carriers would become the planetary directive of the dark forces.  Every 
programmed fear that had been implanted to protect the members as they 
integrated onto the planet would now be used to destroy them.  It would be the 
prophesied Armageddon.  The war between light and dark.

Once the group had landed, the 11:11 dimensional doorway would open.  They would
have approximately 20 earth years to complete their mission and return through 
the vortex.  Yes, they would learn to ride the emotional storm of Earth's 
frequency and feel the pain that held it crippled and it would be a challenge 
beyond anything they had yet encountered, but they would never be alone.  There 
would always be the means to communicate with those who had trained them and who
now stood by with hope and love.  And with envy from the skies they would watch 
by the thousands upon thousands as the unique and majestic drama unfolded on 
this blue-jeweled planet sparkling in a black star studded universe.  No, they 
would not be abandoned.  If they would only remember the promise they each 
carried in their hearts.  The promise given to them in the beginning...

    ... from this journey you shall return.

I just wanted to say that I'm for it for others (if that's what you're
into), but I can't dance naked. I'd look like such a dork dancing naked it
wouldn't be a good idea. I have to wear baggy clothes so the moves I do look
like something. People say that I know what I'm doing, but I really don't,
it must be the pants!

But I would be naked somewhere I wouldn't be dancing. . . 

Besides, where would you have a naked rave where there wouldn't be
spectators, police, and whoever else. 

Aryck

Subject: A Party For Those Who Throwem; Maybe....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

        I've been on SFR for a long time, it's coming up on almost 2 years.
For a long time I've wanted to say thank you; in a Brian DarknEs^2 kinda
way; to all the wonderful promoters; even the greedy ones = >.

        I, for a long time have thought about the possibility of throwing a
party for the people who throw parties, a huge and expensive undertaking,
because hey I'm Brian DarknEs^2 and I like doing thangs with a smigh of
class, style & originality.

        Ya know; something different, with different DJ's that we've never
heard of before; so that no one would have to work. May of these resources I
have access to already having friends all over the bloody planet, and it's
not even the money that stops me most of the time.

        It's the SFR popularity contest that seems to prevail on SFR, that
if your not popular; having views and beliefs that don't fit well with the
rest of the horde; your ideas are often rejected, and if accepted; not
supported. Support being defined as just showing up, sigh = (.

        I've never been a politician, and at 34 am not going to start, so I
guess it will never happen. No responses necessary to this I'm just bitchen
about SFR life out loud, ya know it's happened most of my life, but it still
kinda hurts just the same.

        Anyway, I have a dream, and if your interested in hearing it e-mail me.

        Thank me, I believe in myself.

Later
Brian

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

In the run up to the awesome Burning Man festival we have organised a 
Burning Man benefit rave. It is going to be held on Saturday July 
27th and we (together with the Burning Man organisation) are very 
excited about it. (see SFRaves calendar for further details) (also 
see the events section of the Burning Man web site).

them, does anyone have any suggestions as to the best 
stores/locations that we should have our flyers distributed from?

the word out about this up coming event - as it will no doubt be an 
awesome experience that no one would want to miss!

Your input would be most appreciated.

Hello,

Before I start this message, I would like to express that this note
(unaltered and taken from Mystr-E & MARS) is wholly in no way expressing my
opinions what so ever.  I hold all of the sound system families (Cloud
Factory, F-8, Harmony, Pacific, New Moon, Gateway, Liquid Grooves, Friends
and Family, belive me the list goes on and on...) closse and dear to my
heart. I also feel that although I do love Jim (As I love all my raver-kin)
and feel that this is quite a painful time for him, the other side of the
coin should be shown as well...

-Adam

So here it is...

__________________________________________________
A Response From Frequency-8:

-2PM, Sunday afternoon, Golden gate park 1993.
Michael Robbins and Eric Newman ventured off to a sunny daytime rave in
Golden Gate Park.  They arrived at the given location, to find that the
promoters who were throwing the event had lost thier permit and sound system.
 Mike and Eric owned a sound system and a garage at their home in the Sunset
District of S.F., so they offered to move the party there.
>From that point on they started thier own after hours "club" known as "Sunday
Joy".

-6 Months later, South of S.F., 15,000 Sq. Ft. wharehouse.
A rave is underway called NASHAMA, which is being thrown by Mike Robbins
(A.K.A. MARS). This was an old school underground with about 400 happy ravers
and also the event where Eric Newman spun for his first time at a rave
playing techno/trance (under the name Mystr-E).  These days were a success
for another 6months until MARS left for a quest for new music in Germany.

-Early 1995 MARS is distributing German trance music out of his home in SF.
Around the same time MARS is introduced to Jim Cyr through a mutual friend
(Kevin Banks/ Funky Techno Tribe). MARS, MYSTR-E & CYR all got together and
concluded that they wanted to get this german trance sound out in S.F.  They
all joined together and formed Frequency 8 (The name being created from MARS
experiencing a calling from the #8, and Mystr-E set on the idea of using the
word Frequency, which represents a wavelength). The name frequency stood
strong depite CYR's reluctancy towards it.  The events started off small and
grew into a tight family of people devoted to the trance conciousness.  These
events were being thrown for the love trance music, conciousness, and
gathering of people searching for something new.  Lots of hard work and time
were put into these events with very low profits being made.
It was apparent that one of the promoters / DJ CYR, was losing faith in F-8.

-Dec. 95' Full Moon Gathering in the forest.
Jim Cyr expresses his concern with the low profits, hard work, and little
time due to his professional carreer.  With 4 hours notice prior to this
event, CYR calls MARS & MYSTR-E, officialy resigning from Frequency-8 due to
the amount of stress that was being created for him by these events.  Thrown
off by CYR's cancellation, MARS and MYSTR-E driven by faith throw of the
event on thier own.

-Jan. 95' F-8 the record store has been open on Haight St. for a couple of
months.
MARS turned his home distribution into a retail record store devoted to the
trance scene. Trance music is becoming more popular, and the F-8 parties are
becoming more recognized for thier own sound.

-Frequency-8 1 Year Anneversary Gathering.
MARS and MYSTR-E invite CYR to play (D.J.) out of respect for the previous
hard times. The party was a success.

-Now. July 13th
Frequency-8 is throwing an outdoor trance event exposing a couple of new
trance DJ's to the scene.  CYR has been and always will be a good friend.
Because of his spontanious decision to resign from Frequency-8 and leaving us
completely short-handed, we are reluctant to work with him on a professional
level again.  When CYR contacted us regarding the upcoming event, the
situation he created for himself was explained, and he replied, "We've all
made our mistakes". 
Cyr will always be part of the Frequency-8 family.  We hope this clears up
any misunderstandings that may have been projected in the previous post on
SFRaves about Frequency-8

We apologize to the people who culdn't make it to our last event due to the
early sellout of tickets.  For people interested, there are still a small
amount of tickets available for our july 13th event.  For all thoses
anticipating the upcoming f-8 event, we're looking foward to seeing you under
the starry sky,

Keep up the faith,
Stay tuned in,
Sincerely,
                 MARS & MYSTR-E
____________________________
Transmitted from Computer Attic
SuperCenter:  (415) 363-8100
Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500
____________________________

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>
Subject: Dog fight at Light - Report
Cc: syntonic@orb.org
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The facts (or as close to facts as I can come):
______________________________________________
As some of you may have heard (and witnessed) there was a brief, but
semi-voilent, dog "fight" at the Light party this past weekend.  It wasn't
so much as a fight, as one dog attacking another dog and someone stepping
in and getting bitten in the process.

Word is the dog and the person bitten will be alright; they are both
recovering.  The dog had a pretty severe injury to it's left eye, not sure
if it will be blind or not.  It is a nice, cute small dog.  It was attacked
by a huskie, that had all necessary shots, thankfully.

The person who stepped in is an artisit and was bitten on his drawing hand,
with no insurance, but he will be alright.  He put his hands in to stop the
fight, I can't say whether that was wise or not.

It was an unfortunate incident in an otherwise perfect weekend.  It was out
of the control of the staff, happening in the heat of the day when most
people were in the shade, or down in the river.

Personal thoughts:
_________________

I own a kitten.  I would love to bring my kitten to parties, but dogs will
eat her.  That's an unfortunate thing of nature, animals love to chomp
other animals.

However, since i have had this cat I have had my ears open for "dog rough
housing" at outdoor parties.  (Truth be told, I have a "vicious dog
phobia," so I'm atune to it all the time.)  I can't say the report is good.
Almost every Sunset I've been to has had some instance of a viscious
(sounding) dog making aggressive moves on another dog.  People look
troubled, scared, and anxious when this happens.  Owners scramble and
pretend that they are in control.  They are not.

I agree with dog leash laws!  That is, I think dogs should be kept on some
sort of leash when in the presence of other animals.  I imagine it would be
much less painful to grab a leather strap than a snapping jaw, wouldn't it?

I don't have a dog, and would probably feel different about it if did.
Unless, of course, my sweet, cute, friendly puppy got chomped by a huskie.

I know this is futile, but please respect the fact there are some people
out there that aren't entirely comfortable with *all* dogs roaming the
grounds.  Now maybe we should have dog personality check points at the gate?

See ya!

Tony

Hey Jim,

BOHICA - Bend Over Here It Comes Again!

Sorry about your loss. I could carry on the story from the inception of the
store, but Mike and I are having some "differences", so I'll refrain from
expressing my feelings until everything is resolved.

As JSLee mentioned to Ethan a while ago, there are lots of people who get
taken advantage of in our community. Perhaps the key, however hard it might
be, is to not let others ruin your spirit for supporting the community you
love? 

>As an "sf" or just plain raver I think I should have the right to choose 
>which party I'd like to attend.  I've enjoyed the F-8 parties I've been to.
>I think personal experiences of others whether positive or negative shouldn't 
>be cast upon me.  I support the scene and hope that mabye you can let go of 
>past negativity and forgive.
>
>Take Care,
>
>Love, Carol

Fair enough, Carol, but sometimes pain is a hard thing to let go of. It'd be
nice to forgive the person you've trusted, once you've felt they've taken
advantage of you, but emotions tend to muck things up a bit. 

catch ya'll later...

Jonas

many times:

      ..... Whenever a cloud passes in front of the sun, you scream, "we're
all gonna die!"

      ..... You refer to any car larger than a Miata as "The Mother Ship."

         ...During a job interview you take off your shirt and say, "See?No
tentacles."

        ... You've built one of those alien Death Rays to heat up your pancakes.

        ... Your new pickup line: "Prepare to be Probed."

Dear All;

        A little while ago I called the Burning Man Hotline, and volunteered
my technical  and health care services, I got a call back today saying that
their interested.

        Oh my, the pale white club kid in the desert. My heritage being one
of Irish & Northern Italian decent, I'm the type of person whos doctor tells
him the minute they see me, "Brian your not going to go out in the sun are you."

        My weird, weird life that an old Native American friend told me too
embrace, and see where it takes you. No one ever told me that it was going
to take me to Hell, oh my. 

        Well, we still need to talk more, but I'm pretty much sold, so see
ya in the desert people; look for a brown, dried up human being; with the
title of Black Rock Ranger, no doubt resembling an Alien at that point. Hey
anyone have one of those bio-mechanical suits.

Peace
Brian

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 12 Jul 1996 14:00:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Magdalene L. Crowley" <maggie@CS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: Burning Man List <burnman-list@Chorus.COM>
Subject: Flyer for SOMAR show

[Here's an online version of the flyer for the SOMAR show
just in case you want to forward it around via e-mail]


                         BURNING MAN
                       project presents

                      HELL yes? HELL no!
           A Satirically Satanic Evening of Insanity

                A Pre-Desert Celebration Event
                 in the heart of San Francisco

                  SOMAR GALLERY & WAREHOUSE
                       934 Brannan St.
                    HOTline (415) 985-7471

                        4 Nights Only!
                     July 19, 20, 26, 27

                   Walk-thru Installations
                     Interactive Theater
                     Rituals w/out Dogma
               Mechanical and Robotic Creatures
                          Fine Arts
                      Musical Processions
                        Outdoor Garden
                     The 11th Burning Man


Enter a World where horror and hilarity are strangely intermingled -
and visions float in the darkness like fragments of a dream...

Descend with us through the outdoor GARDEN of unEARTHLY DELIGHTS
where Pyrotechnic Robots, Fire-Spitting Dancers, Mechanical Monsters
and The Waving Jesus frolic as you dodge the Minotaur eager to take
you to Satan's Throne!

The VESTIBULE of HELL distracts you with eye-popping artwork
and ~whoops~ you're in PURGATORY, where Sales Reps from HELCO* 
guide you up the towering Throne of Satan.  After the Soul Sucking
Machine, a Satanic Apache Priest and the Piggish and Wolfish Pope,
a live-mix video-projection maze brings you to yet another realm...

The GREAT HALL, where swarms of human-sized insects emerge from the
darkness, passing ominous eggs to luminous Angels on the bridge overhead.
Eerie Butoh Dancers slip through the pillars of MUDHENGE, the first
of many processions this evening.  Above, The BURNING MAN himself,
illuminated in neon, is flying from the rafters.

*HELCO, a supra-national conglomerate, has recently acquired
 Hell as the result of a hostile takeover, with Satan as paid
 spokesman.

Featured Artists:

SEEMEN            COLLAPSINGsilence     Ed Holmes 
Scott Jenerik     Dimension 7           Brent Bushnell
Magenta Crowe     Dream Circus          Paul Windsor
Crimson Rose      Danse Macabre         Synapse Prod
Sam Morris        Al Honig    Flash     Will Roger
Dale Scott        Steven Johnson        A. Leo Nash
Kim Black         Pepe Ozan   Josho     Michael Peppe


                         GOING TO HELL?
             Show starts at 8pm until 12 midnight
                        Admission is $10
   (to benefit The 1996 Burning Man Festival at Black Rock Desert
             - 100% supported by participants like you)

                   SOMAR is at 934 Brannan Street
        (between 8th and 9th Streets, South of Market, SF)

                http://www.istorm.com/burningman

I must say, the only message I got from the movie is:
It does not pay to look like Michael Jackson.

The other message I got was:
Young male albino's raised in cellars who have particularly high IQ's 
should stay away from electricity.

One other thing (the last) was:
When will Jeff Goldblum stop playing quirky scientific types?
(Actually he is a great actor and I love the roles he chooses to play.  
Always fun & interesting, even the one in this tearjerk movie called 
Powder.  )

Dearest Raver Love Bunnies,

I was going to say something seminal, but I forgot.

The Titan IV carbine was my baby one summer, that 
ol lox-rp1 coking problem.  My first ever DOE security
clearance, even.  Oh the injector test memories.  All
those engineers scrambling to bring me the instrument readouts
after she blew in the second second.  

And then wearing those goofy hardhats as we climbed around
the 3 story firing stand out behind the bunker 
in the granite quarry.

Come with me Boys!  

Those were the days.  I'm tempted to tell y'all about the
top secret space plane ... sorta surprising that didn't make 
it into the alien flick ... but honestly, I'm too scared.

After that czech born berkeley student increased the
US a-bomb tonnage by 20% with a single hydro calc, I burned
out.  Yup the pressure got to me.  Pride is a devil.

Oh yeah, now I remember -

   Saturday, July 13rd - Frequency-8 
   Saturday, July 13rd - 6 in da Mornin Productions presents _Ground Zero_
   Saturday, July 13rd - Pro-Soy presents _Chi_
   Saturday, July 13rd - blasthaus presents _the acid funk ball_
   Saturday, July 13rd - _Unlock the House_
   Saturday, July 13rd - the creators of Toontown, Carefree & Love Garage

How the hell do you pronounce that date?
Dave

>those engineers scrambling to bring me the instrument readouts
>after she blew in the second second.
>
>And then wearing those goofy hardhats as we climbed around
>the 3 story firing stand out behind the bunker
>in the granite quarry.
>
>Come with me Boys!
>
>Those were the days.  I'm tempted to tell y'all about the
>top secret space plane ... sorta surprising that didn't make
>it into the alien flick ... but honestly, I'm too scared.
>
>After that czech born berkeley student increased the
>US a-bomb tonnage by 20% with a single hydro calc, I burned
>out.  Yup the pressure got to me.  Pride is a devil.
>
>Oh yeah, now I remember -
>
>   Saturday, July 13rd - Frequency-8
>   Saturday, July 13rd - 6 in da Mornin Productions presents _Ground Zero_
>   Saturday, July 13rd - Pro-Soy presents _Chi_
>   Saturday, July 13rd - blasthaus presents _the acid funk ball_
>   Saturday, July 13rd - _Unlock the House_
>   Saturday, July 13rd - the creators of Toontown, Carefree & Love Garage
>
>How the hell do you pronounce that date?
>Dave

mean; the anticipation of a great party.   AAAHHHH....I revel in it!!

female type being attached to them.

maybe just normal to you guys, but quite outlandish to those who don't 
rave!!  Ahh the slack I get for having fun.....

last BP in May was where I met my first large group of sfravers, and I'm 
hoping to add more faces and personalities.  I just love human nature 
(most times, that is!!:)

forward to the end of September.  The 29th is my B-Day!  I'll be in The City
the 26th thru 31th.  Hope something major will be happening, I'm sure it
will...but back to my reason for posting.  There would not be any type of BP
party without actual, real Beautiful People.  And this means you!  One of
the most spectacular site a pair of human eyes can behold is a group of
loving, devoted, caring and determined individuals whom are sharing in that
'little' thing called Love!  Here's to you fantastic fam to shine onward and
outward at BP and bring the light just a little closer to home.  Remember,
as I know you will, the vibe at BP is caused by what's inside, not out!       
Love,

Troy

PS.  Don't forget to send the DJ's your 'inner' light while your there!!!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul 12 20:56:01 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA02966; Fri, 12 Jul 1996 20:56:01 -0700
