From: Clarityi@aol.com
X-Received: by emout08.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id OAA03792 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 10 Jul 1996 14:22:12 -0400
Date: Wed, 10 Jul 1996 14:22:12 -0400
Message-ID: <960710142207_234806203@emout08.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Introduction, Burning Man Info and some thoughts...
ReSent-Date: Fri, 12 Jul 1996 20:55:54 -0700 (PDT)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.93.960712205554.4320G@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
>
I'm not sure if I have ever properly introduced myself, however I have posted
Gateway events for awhile.  I'm from Sac originally and moved to the Bay Area
1 1/2
years ago. After a few full moon experiences(Thank you David Sarlin!), a
summer of sunsets, and a Gathering, I moved to this area with because it's
wonderful people and
opportunities.  I work with a group of friends which make up Gateway Systems
which create some local  indoor and outdoor events.  Some of you may
recognize me as the crazy girl with glasses handing out funny flyers at
various events.  Some of you may know my brother Mathew as well (we look a
great deal alike).  Hmmm.....  

Well with some rather sharp posting shrouding the Burning Man Project,  I
thought I would share some Burning Man developments.  Recently there was a
meeting with the different rave organizations (including  Ultraviolet,
Wicked, Gateway, Dimention 7 and SPAZ) and Burning Man Organizers for the
planning of the rave camp.  After last years semi-confusion the rave camp
this year is to be organized as a community with lots of space for everyones
camping, sounds (house, ambient, trance, goa, you name it), sound systems,
and styles.  The camping area as now planned is called the Techno Ghetto
which will be 2 miles South East out of the main camp area.  There will be
first aid, bathrooms, and personel with radios in our camp.  The camp will be
set up in a huge circle 400 yards wide with the center reserved for
bathrooms, first aid, and message board (to find out all that's happining).
The sound systems will be set up on the far outer area of the circle 200 yard
minimum apart facing out with the louder systems continuing to go out further
so everyone has their space.  The smaller ambient systems will face twards
the main camp.  Rave camping will be inside the circle behind the systems
outside of the facilities area.  All will be able to camp within the large
circle.  
 I would like to share some thoughts and feelings about Burning Man inside
and outside the rave camp.   Burning Man was introduced to me as an
experiment in temporary community building.  This is something many
soundsystems, and various groups do in special individual ways.  I see
Burning Man as an opportunity for all our individual efforts, communities and
energy to come together in an amazing place with amazing people without
compromising any person or groups style,  but celebrate and explore that
which
makes our community special in one circle of many different sounds and
lights, lasers, and creations.  It is not any one thing, moment, sound, song,
light, car, or person that makes Burning Man so amazing, but the effort and
creativity of all those things in one special place for a time, sharing, and
doing their own thing, but together.  Communication, respect, and creativity
are essential.  

 This event (although I recommed it to anyone)  is not for everyone.  A super
harsh environment where you have to bring everything makes you think and take
responsibility for yourself which some of us do regulary enough.   At the
meeting               for planning the rave camp we all had the opportunity
to meet the 3 main creators of The Burning Man project.  They are quite
amazing men.  They work hard most of the year
planning this event and continue to make it work with the local comunity in
the Black Rock Desert area.  That includes benefiting the local schools
(fundraising selling ice), local authorities, government and buisnesses.  BM
project is not just about raving, although it captures the sense of community
that we as raveheads share.  It is about creating, destroying, adventure,
burning, discovery of self,  community, nature, sanity, insanity, survival,
being a human being and love of life.  The rave community holds all these
values  and we are fortunate there is an large event that can house our
community as well as so many others.   For thousands, the BM Project is not
soley
about rave, but building a community where there is space for everything
there is not space for in every day society. The main camp this year will be
huge.  People from everywhere comming together.  Please remember that we as a
community are sharing and contributing to this gathering and are a part of a
greater community of individuals, not just ravers pounding it out in the
desert, but human beings. 

The Rave Camp area has it's own web page if your interested...
http://www.sirius.com/~shag/burn   
The BM Bulletin Board  <http://www.chorus.com/~eric/bm96/bbs.html>, is a
multi-use multimedia resource for locating rides, collaboratiors, and just
about anything else you can think of. 

For those who are not aware, it is important that all who wish to attend
register.  This event is completely supported by its attendants so there are
no corporate sponsorers etc. 

I took this from the BM '96 guide I recieved at the meeting...
Here is  a part of the Burning Man Description of community:

Burning man is an experiment in temporary community.  Because many people
only know a world shaped by institutions, social service workers and
commercial transactions, they may not even recognize the signs of a
community.  Here are a few indications:

Capacity.
Communities are built on the recognition of the unique abilities of every
member.  Commerce and the public service sector define us on the basis of
deficiency and need.

Collective Effort.
Community is cooperative; uniting us as varied members of one body.  When, by
contrast, we consume a sevice, we're made passive.  50 million people may
view a television program or consume a beverage in complete isolation from
one another.

Informality.
In the community, transactions of value take place without money, advertising
or hype.  Care emerges in place of structured service.

Stories.
In universities, people know through studies.  In businesses and
bureaucracies, people know by reports.  In communities, people know by
stories.

Celebration.
Community activities incorporate celebration, parties, and other social
events.  The line between work and play is blurred and the human nature of
everyday life becomes part of the way of work.  You will know that you are in
a community if you often hear laughter and singing.


This is all my tired brain can put together so late,  no, so early in the
morning.  Sorry this post goes in and out of my opinion and BM info. take or
leave what you like.  If you have any personal questions or comments for me
please send them to my private account.  BM is comming up fast so start
planning now and remember this is an opportunity to create freely in any way,
shape, or form and share it or just enjoy what others create too! Feel it-
Love! 
-Claire!

       So, you people like movies eh. Well, There are a couple movies that
make you have to watch them over and over again. Natural Born Killers is
more than just a movie about the nicest killers in the world, it's kind of a
big puzzle game that has to be put together in your perspective. Watch it
closely, on acid if possible, and pay attention to every little thing that
happens. There are sooo many things that happen in that movie that no one
knows about. I'm still figuring it out and I've watched it in the ???teenth
times. (Hint, look for the demons, and don't watch the characters).
       Also, a ton of people seem to be really into The Clockwork Orange. I
watched this movie a couple times and it's the kind of movie where you have
to see it like 5 or 10 times to understand it. Obviously, the writer of NBK
was influenced by this movie.
       And I kinda have a thing for Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory.
Willy Wonka is just the fu**** most pissed off guy I've ever seen, I wanna
be his friend!

       I haven't found  any others but I'mm looking, so keep an eye out.

Love yall

Aryck

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: mxman@illuminati.heald.edu (Aryck)
Subject: My little Indpendance Critique, n stuff
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

       Ok, I just watched the movie last night and I feel empty from it.
About the only real part I liked was the sound effects as that big tall
building got totaled by the alien electron beam particle fusion cannon
thing. It was pretty scary. The rest of the movie didn't really belong
there. I mean, why did that lady, her dog, and her kid survive being in a
tunnel as the entire tunnel and the contents of it were completely
destroyed. Why didn't the flames enter the doorway she was in? Why was there
sort of a love scene? Why was there the mad hatter for a research scientist?
Why was the acting sooo crappy? The special effects were too fake looking
(obviously budget problems). The little girl was cut but couldn't act for
shit. The fresh prince thought he was all bad cuz he punched out ONE alien
(somehow), while there were millions all over the place. The whole story
started out telling about all the diffirent countries, but only ended with
one, actually, one city. Whatever city it was? Whaty happenedc to the rest
of the US? How did our slow ass computer technology interface with their
obviously more advanced system? If we humans have 5$ software programs to
keep cpus clean from viruses, why don't aliens have something? I mean, they
are space travelers and all. How do the aliens fly thier ships with those
tentacles? How do they sit in their chairs? Why was the president usually
unprotected? Where was the secret service, the police, whoever? What was
that guys problem, the one with the scratchy voice and the edipus complex.
How did an Air force Jockey know about area 51 while the president had no clue?
       I don't know. I just think they hyped up the movie too much and
should have put more thought into it before they released it. It could have
been waaaaaay better. It was just too much of a joke. You can't have an
action space movie comedy romance sci-fi thriller movie. It just don't work.
       


      Also, I think Alice in Winderland is another Bad-Ass movie. Definately
recommended viewing. But  you have to pay very close attention.


Peace love and everything in between.

Aryck

Heyya all of ya's!

Ok, for all of you folks going to Beautiful People (or at least those 
of you who don't know me, cuz those of you who do already know what I 
look like!), I finally got my rave-wear down for the evening, so I 
hafta do my usual and post my description:

5'8" tall, shoulder-length brown hair, medium build.  I'll be wearing 
some nifty new stuff I found this week, shirt: shiny spandex shirt with 
a metallic swirly black & silver pattern on it.  pants: my regular 
comfy baggy old jeans.  shoes:  shiny silver tennies with black & gold 
sparkly shoe-laces! :)  And I always have a bunch of shit around my 
neck!  This usually consists of the following:  1 old-skool sfraves 
laminate (I hafta get around to adding the new one), 1 dayglo-orange 
Basics ticket from one of my favoritest parties of all time (remember 
that one wayne?), my FnF patch, and my little plastic people which hang 
on a neon-green shoelace covered in Sylvester-the-Cat heads.  I will 
also most likely have my trademark hot-pink glow-stick hanging around 
my neck too. 

So, all you sfravers I haven't met before, come up & say hi if you see 
me (of course, all you sfravers I *have* met before, don't bother! ;)  
I love meeting new sfravers, and there are a lot of new ones on the 
list I've not yet met.  So come up & say howdy, I won't bite (unless 
you want me to!)

Love,
Shawna

>       Also, a ton of people seem to be really into The Clockwork Orange. I
>watched this movie a couple times and it's the kind of movie where you have
>to see it like 5 or 10 times to understand it. Obviously, the writer of NBK
>was influenced by this movie.

Man, you should read the book by Anthony Burgess. Stanley Kubrick did a
great job with the movie, but the book has about 500 times more impact.
Only problem is that the book is written mostly in this really fucked up
slang that's like a new language. It comes with a glossary, but I had to
read it again right away to get all the stuff that I missed the first time.
Check it out.

Tim

RE:  how do you build a space plane?

Without revealing national secrets I think it is
safe to say that you need several pods protruding
from the plane, each with a few dozen miniature liquid
fueled ricket engines that can fire for a millisecond.
Hook it up to a computer and run it through its paces.
It's like the loudest machine gun you've ever heard.

I wish hard hats weren't so anti-fashion.  Otherwise,
I'd still be a rocket scientist.

fetch that flashlight lt. MS DOS - have you ever driven 
through an accidentally spilled liquid oxygen cloud?  Very
cool when your honda hits 200,000 rpm and then melts.  Thus 
all the sirens going off before each test.  Close off the roads 
and get _underground_ Now.

I've always been amazed with some feats of engineering.
It's so old school to not have a fucking clue but throw
a few 100g in fuel at the problem and you're bound to
stumble onto something that works.

kiss kiss,
Dave

Raver Kittys Come to ME.

I used to drive a motorcycle around Napa alot.
It was an upgrade from my bad-ass moped.  Any, I
loved riding around Napa - going to the little 
wineries.  All those curvy roads, there would
be literally hundreds of bikers, all kinds,
enjoying the day.

What did the harley guys call the japanese
bikes?  I forget, but it was something marginally
racist yet sorta funny and appropo.

My favorite bikers are the grandparent types
on the green with those sparkles built into the
paint giant touring deals - they would have a 4ft
tall windshield, built in stereo speakers, and
antennaes sticking out of their helmets so they
could keep in cb contact with the rest of the
caravan.

But that's really it, isn't it?  The contact. 
Every biker that passes another biker on the road
gives them the patented "wave".  A raised hand. 
A little "hello brother".

After they passed that damn helmet law, I sold my
bike.  It took me a couple months before I finally
stopped... I confused a lot of bikers trying to
wave at them from my VW.

Dave

This was a reply to one of my questions on how to see the info. that these
people have collected.  Their reply was:

>Right now (and you can check this periodically by fingering 
>ravedata@partnercomm.com) we've got about 2600 DJs with over 5200 
>occurances of them spinning across about 800 events.  We also gather info 
>on production companies (promoters), merchandise, etc.  Our database is 
>growing steadily (we just started on Jan 30, '96).  We print a "Rave 
>Phone book" (actually a listing of promoters grouped by state).

>We gather the information from flyers, 18 or so regional email lists, 
>people like yourself and an ocassional flyer in the mail.

I was just wondering if anyone knows how to see this stuff.  I don't know
how to finger!  Any help will be appreciated!

  WOW.

  As John K. said to me, words can't describe...

  That was a beautiful party with beautiful people and beautiful vibe and
beautiful music.  And it's still going, but I had to leave due to sore
face muscles from smiling so much :)

  You know how sometimes you're smiling, and you look at someone, and
they're smiling, and they notice you and they smile more, and so your
smile grows, and soon you have to look away or else become a puddle of
love-goo?  I didn't see any unhappy or negative people.  Everyone smiled
back at me.  Everyone who got a gift from me understood.  The love was
thick in the air.

  I am so glad I went to this event!  It was the excitement I saw in the
posts here that led me to decide to go (after working all day, yuck!) -
Thanks!  This was truly a once-in-a-lifetime affair.

  It was great to meet people, too.  I don't know who that I met is on
sfraves, except Robert (nice to finally meet you, however briefly!) and
the guy whose name starts with M and who is *really* into hugs - and yes,
this is how my brain works.

  And finally, a massive thank-you to Harmony for an awesome (and I really
mean I was awed!) rave.  Wow!

  Take care everyone!  See you around!

Nice to see some positive coverage of this world event in the local
Sunday paper (Examiner, pg A-9); a great photo of happy 
hands-in-the-air ravers with the following caption:

* * * *
Crowd shakes das booty at 'Love Parade'

A crowd of about 500,000 celebrate in front of the Brandenburg Gate
Saturday during Berlin's eight annual "Love Parade", making the event
one of the largest public gatherings in the city's post-war history.
A caravan of 40 trucks armed with booming sound systems that blasted
techno music led the huge parade through the center of the German capital.
Pollice reported no major trouble during the parade.  "It's about the
music, just a huge party," organizer Matthias Roeingh said. "there are
no political concepts."
* * * *

Lee

I'll start this off by saying, out of the countless number of raves that 
I've been to in the last four years, not one of the matched the vibe and 
enery of this BP party.  It was simply incredible.  Everyone I met was 
really happy, and always willing to give a good hug.  I wanted to thank 
Greg and the Harmony crew for throwing an great rave.  I also wanted to 
say hi to all of the SFR people that I met last night, like -E, Moonpup, 
Frying Dutchman, Nancy, Kay Cee (sp?), Ran @ Dionysus Dreams, David, 
R.Lunitic, Breadan, the guy how gave me the SFR laminate, and finaly to 
the guy wearing the burger king crown (I believe I rembered that many 
names).  Also a big hug to all of those other SFRavers that I met but 
can't remember.  I love you all.

Mattloaf

keeping it short, but...
Although there weren't quite as many huggly glowy ravers as I would have
liked, i had a really fun time at the caban/craig/sufi party last night.
Visuals were by Dim se7en , and covered two of the walls of the space, as
well as a hanging ..uh...mesh circle thing. Graphics were a little too 3d
modeled at first, but after w ehile it was just digital color patches,
which were great to dance in.

met aleph there, and dan , jon, catherine (if either of the last three are
on the list, drop me a line).
never really saw the drum circle happen, but the first set (live
instruments, even) was pretty amazing. Could have listened to them for much
much longer. I don't know who was DJing (craig?caban?) DATs, but the music
was good, and way way way many beats. Couldn't keep up after a while.
Oddesst part was I felt like I was the youngest one there. Felt like an
art-set kinda crowd. yeah, i guess, great time, just missed the sparkles :)
of you all.

take care
KcR,,

Yes the music at this ritual was amazing. If you like hard GOA trance this
was the place to be. My body could not take it after to long and I had to
leave early. I was lucky enough to get there early and see the drum circle
(what was not really a circle), and some amazing live music by Sufi. The
visual were great, specially the see through ciclinder hanging from the
ceiling on which projections looked 3-D. And all that without any chemical
enhancements. 

Hat's of to Adam for a great night. BTW, did anyone tape this? I would
love to get a copy of it.

catherine, right? Please tell her hi from me, she is a lot of fun.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 15 09:14:23 1996

Received: (from tsheets@localhost) by xanadu.cyborganic.net (8.7.5/8.7.1) id JAA26046 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 09:14:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199607151614.JAA26046@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: Chi
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 1996 09:14:21 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Chi was fun.  Located on the Stevenson alley, just south of market street,
in a medium-sized loft/warehouse location.  Upstairs Clair helped make a nice
chill area with carpeted floors, a shrine, and lots of candles and incense.
There were also flowers that seemed to be growing out of all the walls.
The ground level main room had plenty of sound, 2 video projections and
some other decorations that were cool.  You could hear the sound outside
in the alley pretty clearly, but I guess the spot was deep enough in the
city that no one really cared.  The music was on the faster, techno side.
It was spun well and by about 1am people were climbing the walls with energy.
They had big fans and open windows that kept the temp. very comfortable all
night.  Downstairs was another chill room with another soundsystem playing
ambient, slow funky stuff, and the Muppet Show Theme song.  There were lots
of pads and carpets downstairs too.  All and all the place was really
comfortable and clean.  We met lots of cool people there and the vibe
was pretty ripe all night.  Speaking of ripe, there was plenty of free
grapes, bananas and other fresssshhhhh froot all night.  The space never
got too crowded, which was nice.  The whole affair was pretty intimate and
fun.  It was interesting to see the Cloud Factory people (from Santa Cruz),
some Gateway people (from ebay) all partying it up in the heart of San
Francisco.

It was really nice having Sunset at a non-frequently used location.  Although
it seemed a little rough at first, once we threw our mats down and got
into the vibe we had a great time.  The weather held nicely and the clouds
never came over us (the power of positive energy) and the sunset across
the water was wonderful.  Good vibe while Doc Martin spun some groovy house.
Cops came, a helicopter circled, but I guess they figured breaking up this
party would be more trouble than it was worth... so they let it continue....
again, the power of postive energy :)

-troy

 I don't know why this wasn't posted on sfraves, but Mark Farina, 
Dubtribe, Thomas + many others put on a free show at the Bush street fair 
on Sunday, this being one of the rare cases where the French do have 
their shit together...or at least have far better taste than anyone who's 
been calling the shots at the Haight St.fair for the past 2 years.

 I had been planning on keeping a low profile this weekend but ended up 
hanging out w/ Sun & Mike Ross for most of the day. Street fairs are 
unique in that I party with people I normally wouldn't associate all that 
much with. I think that hanging out at raves, be it all ages or 21+, 
affects how I percieve myself & how much of an adult I choose to be in 
either making new interpersonal relationships or holding onto old ones. A 
part of me acts like "so long as God keeps giving me zits I'm staying 16" 
and the other part knows that one day I'm gonna be a 30 year old white 
guy with a bad haircut.

Stompy Stomp parties usually bring out a real colorful, real hip crowd. 
Almost none of which showed up on sunday, but the music was fun, old 
Chinease Moms smiled at me, dubtribe thumped, and people I didn't even 
know were buying me drinks. I'm glad I live in San Francisco.

Greetings Friends =)

I think I can safely say that it gives everyone involved much pleasure to
able to share with you the following:


      :^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:

                            Saturday, July 27, 1996

                               Friends & Family

      :^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:`?'-;-:^:


It's been a very long time since the last one and we are all totally
psyched. We hope that you can join is in celebrating this amazing community
we've all built together.

Details:

600 tickets will be available by *presale only* starting saturday july
20th, either from members of our group directly or from an as yet
unidentified publicly accessible source. As soon as we know where, we'll
let you know.

If you are out of the area and neither of these will work for you, you can
mail order them as well. Send a money order *and* a stamped, self-addressed
envelope,  to:

  FnF Tix
  1425 Santa Fe Ave.
  Berkeley, CA 94702

Ticket requests *must* be recieved no later than 7.20! No more than 4 tix
per order plz. Tix have a suggested donation of $5. As usual *everyone*
involved in this party is donating their time and energy free, and any
proceeds from the party will benefit a worthy cause. The last FnF
benefitted the Berkeley Emergency Food Project.

Much love and repsect to everyone working on Unity, the burning man
benefit, and especially to Malachy. Diversity is a good thing. In many
houses and under many roofs, we're all celebrating the same thing. Let the
good times roll.

take it easy
ethan

Here is some interesting news about the southern-california desert rave
movement.  It seems that people have sold their soul to to Fox for
a few bucks and at the same time killed the whole desert rave scene.
What a shame.

> 
> I first want to voice how incredibly PISSED OFF I AM AT SOME RAVERS!!!!
> 
> Fox knows EVERYTHING about our "underground" scene... including some very
> disturbing details about recent desert rave problems.  These problems we
> *thought* were contained and would never be discussed with the outside
> world, however, people just seem to enjoy blabbing about very serious
> situations... almost bragging that people get close to ODing at desert
> events.
> 
> ALSO!!!!!  WHO THE FUCK IS GIVING THEM ALL THIS VIDEO FOOTAGE!!!!  The Fox
> producer informed us that the only footage that he did NOT obtain from
> "stringers" (back stabbing parasites who think that they are ravers while
> they sell their videotapes to news for a small $s) was footage from the
> last Fox Undercover report on New Moon last November!  However, he says he
> has 15 hours of footage from 2-4 different sources from both New Moons,
> DUNE II and the June 1 FMG!
> 
> IF ANYONE KNOWS ANYONE WHO SHOT VIDEO AT THESE EVENTS... SMACK EM FOR ME!!!
> THEY HAVE KILLED THE ENTIRE DESERT RAVE FUTURE!  SHAME ON YOU!!!
> 
> 
> 
> OK.... calming now.... breathe deeply....
> 
> 
> The report will air this Tuesday evening and is supposed to be much more
> positive than the last Fox Undercover report on New Moon.  So far we have
> evaded an on-camera interview but have been able to voice our concerns and
> give the producer accurate background information.  We have not
> sensationalized the movement in any way... in fact, we made it seem kinda
> boring and hardly worth the 3 hour drives (I don't know if he bought that
> though).
> 
> 
> 
> In terms of legal desert raves (on public land) in the near future... IT
> AIN'T GONNA HAPPEN!!!!  This, of course, is all thanks to a few individuals
> who could not "babysit" themselves or keep their mouths shut.
> 
> 
> It seems that the more effort we put in trying to control the damage... the
> more damage is done.  According to a UPI wire release on Friday (thus the
> report on Fox friday nite) "an illegal desert rave party last Sat. (7/6-
> Stratosphere?) has FORCED several law enforcement agencies" to form a
> cooperative task force to "ILLIMINTATE" the desert rave problem.
> 
> 
> I have been told by the BLM not even bother trying to get permits for DUNE
> III cause they simply cannot indorse it.
> 
> 
> RESPONSILITYRESPECTACCOUNTABILITYEDUCATIONCOMMUNICATION!!!!
> 
> Kirk out!
> 
>

To all who went to Beautiful People: THANK YOU!!!  To those who decorated:
it was a delicious feast for the eyes :)  To those who smiled, shook my
hand, joined me in single or group hugs, gave me gifts (flowers, stickers,
food, water, and love): you warmed my heart and made it a wonderful time.
To those who made music: every second I heard great danceable stuff, and
thoroughly enjoyed it.
It was, in every way, beautiful.  A perfect family reunion after a bit of
self-imposed hibernation.

Still blissful, and still loving you all,

Eric P. (my nametag said 'E'ric)

Speaking of movies.....

I really want to see "Trainspotting" when it comes out in 1-2 weeks 
(can't remember).  It's about Scottish heroin addicts.  I read that the 
reason for the name of the movie is that Trainspotters do something that 
gives them structure to their life, but that it is ultimately quite 
worthless in a larger sense.  This is the analogy that they draw with 
heroin addicts.

Anyway, another reason I want to see it is the soundtrack which has great 
British artists on it including Leftfield and Underworld.

-KaySEE

Well, what can I add to this? BP was a magical experience, great vibe,
location,
beautiful people (beauty is on the inside!) and I finally got to meet some
of you (U know who U are!). It is reassuring to find out that I haven't been
mailing to some Turing machine, impersonating a bunch of SFRavers! ;-)
You people are the best, and it still fills me with awe that events like
this are happening all over the world and we (I) can blend into the scene
on either side of the ocean so smoothly. And thanks to the Harmony people,
(thanks for the personal assistance Greg) for putting so much effort into
this event, it really showed. This was a party as they are supposed to be,
everybody doing their thing and getting along fine. Too bad I sweated of
my SFRaves-sticker, the "clearance"-ones are still on my shirt though.
And Eric, thanks for stepping up to me and introducing me to some of the
SFRaves regulars, hope to see you all again out there in the near future...

The Fried Dutchman

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 1996 12:13:48 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: review: Oregon Country Faire
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This year's Oregon Country Faire was, as always, a magical event.  Those
OCF folfs know how to throw a party!  Arriving at the faire you're greeted
by smiling faces wishing you a happy faire and thanking you for coming.
Once inside, you enter a dreamworld that only those who've been to the
Faire can truly understand.  Everywhere I found myself surrounded with
beautiful, smiling, playful people.  There is something special about that
faire...

For those who haven't been, the faire is set in the woods west of Eugene,
on what is wetland during the non-summer months.  Large, wide trails loop
through the woods, with streams and rivers guiding the pathways.  The large
loops are lined with wooden booths, many of which have an upper level which
give the booth-holders a place to rest and watch the fairegoers pass by.
The booths are filled with beautiful handcafted artifacts and delcious
home-cooked, mostly organic food.  The whole place looks like the land of
the ewoks!  There are small clearings with stages, little nooks for chillin
with your favorite chellum, and of course the main stage, which is the
biggest open space at the faire, which is filled all day long with dancing
freaks like myself.  Thankfully the OCF has sprayers set up overhead at the
main stage which saved me from dehydration.  I danced like a muthafukka!

After the faire (in the evenings) there is camping at various sites (either
on-site, across the road, or within a couple miles), and drum-circles rage
all night, filling the air with a delightfully tribal feel as you make your
way from drum circle to drum circle.  Goodies abound and everyone is in
kindred spirits.  I always leave the faire with the feeling that human life
should be lived this way...there is a richness, a sense of community, a
sense of excitement in the air as if all of the region's tribes have
gathered for an annual summer gathering and you get to see many people who
you never see at any other time, but with whom you feel nonetheless a deep
kinship.

I heard the tempurature was aound 100, and I believe it, but as always
there was plenty of free water all around for drinking and spraying and
splashing, so the summer heat was enjoyable.  And it gave us all the more
reason to strip off most of our clothes and dance a thankful dance to the
divinities that make such a happening possible.

For anyone who's interested, the OCF website has some photos which might
add some color to my words:

http://www.efn.org/~ocf/

plur,

David

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~ ~~~ ~~ ~ ~
David Ginsberg
Student of Neurophenomenology and the Human Condition
University of California, Berkeley
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
<http://www.geocities.com/athens/2001>*New and improved website!*
....................................
The only real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking new landscapes
but in having new eyes. -Marcel Proust
~ ~ ~~ ~~~ ~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 15 12:34:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA08584; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 12:34:04 -0700
Received: from lettuce.salinas.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA08572; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 12:34:00 -0700
Received: (from drenalin@localhost) by lettuce.salinas.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) id LAA01534; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 11:43:57 -0700
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 1996 11:43:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: Scott Nelson <drenalin@lettuce.salinas.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Chi
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.960715113343.1411C-100000@lettuce.salinas.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thanks to everyone that came out.  It was definitely a great event!

Brief review:
	Sorry to anyone who showed up before 10 and had to wait while the 
sound was fixed.  That was when I was supposed to be spinning so if you 
were there early I was the one who played three songs to open!  The 
shortest set of my dj career, maybe one of the best ;)  Upstairs Blue 
opened with a nice set to get people grooving and then came the 
inTIMadator (aka Tim McKnew) who was punishing in the least with some 
great trancey tunes and got everyone pumped up for Deaks, who literally 
devastated the crowd, amazing set which left us sore but asking for more =)
Unfortunately I think everyone was to tired for Jon Williams and Cloud 
(aka Sabin) but they still played great sets!
	Downstairs Moshca opened, followed by James, then a brief ambient 
debut by MC^2, Maya played for a little while Tim and I were at Safeway 
buying them out of water. (we bought 20 gallons at the start of the night 
which ran out, so we bought 20 more, which pretty much depleted 
Safeway!), I got back and played some tunes, my roommate from Oregon, Jon 
got the whole ambient room grooving with some crazy tunes, he was the one 
who played the Muppet Show and some of the crazy samples.  I had a great 
time playing some slow stuff for about two hours, then Moscha came on 
again, finished out by Maya and Luke.  
	All in all no problems and a great vibe, it sounds like all of SF 
was getting off!  Heard great stuff about everything at Sunset, which was 
nice also!

love drenalin

ps thanks to Claire and Rob, all the cloud factory crew, and anyone else 
who helped, Jamie for donating the sound upstairs!  see ya'll soon!

                               http://www.ultima.org/WebWorks/
hyperreal staff - drenalin@hyperreal.com

yeah, but when the list becomes just a straight "I went to a rave last
night and heard a good set by so-and-so" it starts getting pretty dull... I
like the idea of being able to discuss alot of different stuff on the list;
provided it doesn't turn into a bitchy-i'm-right-you're-wrong argument like
some discussions (that people feel strongly about) tend to. Even if it's
just lighthearted chitchat... helps the workday go by when I'm getting lots
of amusing fluff and info in my mailbox all day... I know a LOT of people
on this list use it as a break from work...

-m.

Hello again,

    I forgot to include all of the upcoming party information in the 
last post. So hear it is!!!

    First, on Saturday July 20th, a very special friend of ours, whom I 
personally love dearly ;) , will be putting together her first party. 

                            -Family Circus-

It will be a FREE DAY PARTY, in the Santa Cruz area. It will start at 
1pm promptly.
                               
    Dj's will be:   Gerlando Piro  -  Supermonk  -  Matt Bailey 
                      John Carol  -  Shilo Maggi  -  Cloud

    Info for this party will be given on (408)457-spam. Call, it will 
be fun!!!               
                        

    
    Second, on Friday August 9th, 100 acre woods proudly present

                                 -HUNNY-
        
    This party will be in San Francisco, 10pm - 6am. This is another 
close a dear friend of ours putting together his first party. It will 
have a Winnie The Pooh theme, which should be... well... interesting! 
It is going to be a great production, and be a lot of fun!!!! 

        Dj's:     Gerlando Piro  -  Dutch  -  Greg 
                  Dj Dan  -  Cloud  -  Jon Williams   

    Info for this party will be posted on (415)263-4885. Call and get 
anyother info that I might have left out!


    
    Third, is the Harmony 3 year anniversary/ finale

    For three years the Harmony crew has been pooling our energy 
together to create some of the most memorable nights in our lives. We 
truley thank everyone who has supported us in the past and those who 
are still suporting us, even those who will support us. This will "most 
likely" be the last Harmony. I can't make any promises, cause there are 
a lot of people with a lot of emotions tied into the party who might 
not let it go. We'll see...

    There is not a whole lot of info for this event yet. But here is a 
general rundown. It's going to be a blast!!!


                          -September 14th-

    Starting @ 12 noon on Saturday, Knucklehead will be bringing down 
his BBQ for a pre-event / lunch / party. This will go until around 9pm 
when the anniversary event begins. (Dj's to be announced) The event 
will go all night, until early evening / late afternoon Sunday. You may 
bring tents, toys, food and water. But make sure you bring enough for 
the entire time you plan on staying, because cars are not allowed on 
the facilities. You will be bused from your car (which will be parked 
in a secured and lighted parking lot), to the event. Buses will run all 
day and night through the entire event, but you should plan on staying 
the entire time. Camping (tents, not motorhomes) is allowed and is 
recommended. This event   ----WILL BE PRESALE TICKETS---   Tickets will 
be a bit expensive(at least to us). Most likely $20, but every single 
dollar is being put into this event and it's going to be spectacular! 
Tickets will be sold at parties and other undeclared locations. There 
is a lot more info to be given, so keep posted.

    Well that's what is in the works for right now! See you soon! 

Peace and harmony,

Greg :)

Dear All;

        Could someone please tell me whether or not there is some kinda rule
out there that states a hetro man must initiate the conversation when 2
parties are attracted to one another.

        I for one am attracted to most of the womyn I meet and see, and with
regard to most of the womyn I'VE MET; very few are able to start the
conversation, they do other weird things however to get your attention,
except talk.

        Speaking from MY experience, I thought we where working on equality,
which seems to stop at dating & courtship. I know down to the last fiber of
my soul that any womyn can do anything any man can do, some even better. So
why do WE(men) have to do the chasing, it just annoys the hell out of me.

        Equality means to me doing everything a man does to court you, and
maybe more, cause the rest of the crap is just plain obvious to me. I guess
what I'm bitch 'in about, is that most of the womyn I'VE MET, not all womyn
seem to have absolutely no confidence with reagrd to taking the lead when it
comes courtship & dating. Hon, if you don't believe in yourself, why should
I believe, and or chase you.

        Serious, private responses welcome!!!!!!

Peace
Brian

friends.  This community is built by communication among people within the
rave scene.  I think we need more non-rave discussions to better grow as a

this message!

Tim Beauchamp wrote:
> 
> So where do `newbies' get to learn all these acronyms?  Obviously some
> are figured out fairly quickly (such as NRR) but there seem to be many
> more in use less frequently--do we have a dictionary of such terms?

	Here's a first version, I didn't find anything on the Web site.
	I'm sure I missed some... Please contribute!

------8<------8<-------
SFRaves Slang Dictionary

version 1.0

badass 
      very, very good (usually applying to people) 
bomb (the) 
      really good 
BSP 
      Blatant Self-Promotion 
BTW 
      By The Way 
candyflip 
      combining acid and ecstasy 
clubkid 
      self-explanatory 
dope 
      very good 
fresh 
      very good 
hippieflip 
      combining mushrooms and ecstasy 
hella/hecka 
      a lot of, very 
hippie crack 
      Nitrous 
IMO, IMHO 
      In My (Humble) Opinion 
nervous 
      bad, see "sketchy" 
NRR 
      Non-Rave Related 
peace! 
      "good-bye" 
phat 
      cool! (adjective, not an interjection) 
PLUR 
      Peace Love Union Respect 
ROTFL 
      Rolling On The Floor Laughing 
shit (the) 
      the best 
sick 
         1.very good (as in the best at something) 
         2.a good track; i.e. "that beat is sick!" 
sketchy 
      uncertain (a bad feeling about something); description of someone on speed; 
spin 
         1.what a dj does 
         2.smoking pot while drunk 
spun 
      coming down; not being able to sleep 
sweet 
      very good 
went off 
      was good, was "happening" 

Can you add to the list? 

Credits

      Nancy 
      Eric Peterson 
      and all the SFRaves people 
------8<------8<-------

Renaud

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 15 17:09:24 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA05985; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 17:09:24 -0700
Received: from netcom14.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA05978; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 17:09:19 -0700
Received: (from branka@localhost) by netcom14.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id RAA11846; Mon, 15 Jul 1996 17:09:03 -0700
Date: Mon, 15 Jul 1996 17:09:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Branka Cehic <branka@netcom.com>
Subject: E, parties etc.
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9607151720.A8627-0100000@netcom14>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I went to a small great party this weekend with bunch of my closest 
friends.  The party rocked and everything seemed pretty great.  Some 
people got sick on E and other stuff, but that happens everywhere.

Around 10am I found out that one of my best friends was rushed to the 
emergency room due to the seizure.   She took 3 hits of E, because 1st 
didn't do anything, from the 2nd she came down too fast and 3rd was what 
she needed (at least she thought).  After getting sick few times, looking 
pretty miserable, she had a seizure.  I wasn't there and I am sorry I 
didn't help my friends, because most of them were freaking out (not that 
I wouldn't, but I still feel bad for not being there).  She was 
unconscious for 15-20 min and she woke up in the ambulance not knowing 
what's happening.  

The doctor told her the reason she had a seizure was because her sodium 
level went too low.  Supposedly too much water diluted the sodium in her 
body and caused it to be too low.   
My friend is OK; she was released from the hospital in 4 hours after 
getting some IV.  The doctor said there were 4-5 cases like hers that 
happened the same night.

Maybe I am wrong for sharing this with the entire list, but I just want 
everybody to be careful and think about what they do and how they do it.  
Sometimes all of us get carried away and don't think too much about what 
can happen.  If you are taking stuff, please be careful, don't overdo it 
and make sure you have friends with you  (my friend was lucky she wasn't 
at a big party wondering around by herself).

Hugz,
Branka

P.S.  Great to hear so many of you had a great weekend.  Mine was almost 
great....

To: rw@softway.com, timb@nit.AirTouch.COM (Tim Beauchamp)
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM>

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

MX Missile
	Combining mushrooms and Ectasy
bogus
	bad, bullshit
Rad
	good, cool (see fresh, dope, badass)
Marathon set
	When a DJ spins for a very long time (AKA: The John Carel Death Set :)
Crate
	A box of records
Deck
	Turntable
Coffin
	Box holding the decks
Stack(s)
	Set(s) of speakers
Freak
	1. A complement
	2. An insult
Train Wreck
	When a DJ doesn't match the beats, thus creating a sound like a
trian 				coming through the walls.
Seamless Set
	When a DJ mixes very well, thus each record is seamlessly mixed
with the next.


Tone

> >	Here's a first version, I didn't find anything on the Web site.
> >	I'm sure I missed some... Please contribute!

Hey!  I think you forgot one that has been causing some trouble
as of late... :-)

Vibe - (i) n. - The feeling that is generated by a party.  Common
sources of the 'vibe' are music, people, and miscellaneous foreign
substances ;-)
USAGE : 'Da vibe at dat party was phat!' : translation : 'at the
rave, the feeling induced by the atmosphere was overall a very
good one'

(ii) n. - a musical instrument (see someones post from last weekend)
USAGE : 'That vibe player is very good' : translation : 'the person
playing that tube-shaped musical instrument is producing a calm,
harmonious sound'.

(iii) n. - something that you would buy at one of those seedy shops on
Market (you know the ones ;-).  Usually 2 AA batteries are sold
separately.
USAGE : 'I killed two packs of batteries in my vibe last nite' :
translation : 'I had a *VERY* good evening' :-)

- David

did I see you at Chi on Saturday?  That party was simply AWESOME!
I think Im going to like the scene around here... :-) :-) :-) :-)

recepient is usually pretty unreceptive to outside stimulus.

mental: deep, psychadelic, also see 'sick'

All,

Well there are various `heavy-duty' training drinks for before, during
and/or after an intense workout.  They have a variety of amino acids,
sugars, etc... for quick energy and/or muscle replenishing.  I assume
these are just a step above gatorade and the like.  I get 'em at
health/vitamin/supplement stores for about 2 - 3 bucks a piece.  So far
I've only managed to drink them the day after and they do seem to give
immediate relief to very sore muscles.  Ideally, (i.e., if I remeber
and/or can bring a couple into a party) I'd have some before and
during.  There are powder forms of these you could make for cheaper.

Of course, a good smoothie/smart drink bar at the party is always a
big plus (at least for those of us who can afford such).  And speaking
of which a HUGE thanks to whomever that was making drinks at BP--mine
was great and helped, though my aging body still collapsed far too
soon--some things just require a less natural solution.

Tim

On Mon, 15 Jul 1996, Mike Wolf wrote:

> At 03:15 PM 7/15/96 PST, you wrote:
> >
> >I thought this list was about Bay Area raves.  Not movie reviews,
> >computer problems and dog fights. I am not intending to insult anyone
> >but maybe another list should be started for non-rave related
> >discussion.  Not everyone has the time to read 50 posts a day.
> >
> Raving is just not about the music and the parties.  Its about community and
> friends.  This community is built by communication among people within the
> rave scene.  I think we need more non-rave discussions to better grow as a
> sub-culture or what ever anyone would like to call it.  It's not just
> parties, it unity, community and love!  No insult or aggression intended in
> this message!

Not to pick nits, but keep in mind that this is what raving is to *you* 

For some, it is primarily about the music and the parties. Also much of 
the discussion falls *way* outside the stated purpose of this list. I have 
asked a couple of times that sub lists be created because of the amount 
of divergence that has occured. Both times I have been told 'no.' 

The list has evolved(or devolved depending on your P.O.V.) and encompasses much 
more than parties and music. What I really would like to see is an updating of
the stated purpose of the list by the list owner(Hi Brian!) The original 
stated purpose(s) for the most part no longer seems to apply, and for 
someone newer to the list, who just got a copy of the stated purpose of 
the list, this could be very confusing.    

Myself, I stand guilty of being one of the "if you can't beat them, join 
them" crowd. But it would be nice to have some of the possible confusion 
cleared up.

                                        Black Adder

On Mon, 15 Jul 1996, Troy Sheets wrote:

> > I first want to voice how incredibly PISSED OFF I AM AT SOME RAVERS!!!!

Just so folks know; I videotape at some parties and my material IS NOT 
for sale. To Fox or anyone else. I use it for class projects, to teach 
myself video limits, for memories and to use for projections at future 
parties.


> > Fox knows EVERYTHING about our "underground" scene...

Well, I kinda doubt that ;)


> > including some very
> > disturbing details about recent desert rave problems.  These problems we
> > *thought* were contained and would never be discussed with the outside
> > world, however, people just seem to enjoy blabbing about very serious
> > situations... almost bragging that people get close to ODing at desert
> > events.
> > 
> > ALSO!!!!!  WHO THE FUCK IS GIVING THEM ALL THIS VIDEO FOOTAGE!!!! 


NOT ME!!!!!!!!

> > "stringers" (back stabbing parasites who think that they are ravers while
> > they sell their videotapes to news for a small $s) was footage from the

> > has 15 hours of footage from 2-4 different sources from both New Moons,

Subject: Another Harmony report (yawn)

Hi All!

 I had a great time at BP, my first SF party ever (well, except the 
Ravers in Wonderland party, but I worked there-not the same). I have 
never seen so many happy, sharing, genuinly nice people in my life!
Some favorite moments;

       -watching the Harmony banner (the outstretched figure with rings 
	around him) switch from full blown day glo (when the black lights 
	were on) to just a single pulsating ring when the b-lites went 
	off and the strobes came on.

       -THE MUSIC!!! Sometimes the BP and Harmony parties lack (for me) 
	intensity and the music sounded intensly beautiful and 
   	progressive. Especially the stuff Galen and Dutch were spinning.

       -playing "Larry the Lamppost" for the folks on the stairwell.

       -meeting SO many nice people!!!

       -watching Matt da Loaf become a puddle of happy goo ;) 
       
       -twirling my day-glo slinky in front of the black lites.

Some less favorite thangs;

       -The heat on the main dance floor. It was too much for me most of 
	the night. I'm glad I danced hard early on but really wanted to 
	dance later (especially while Dutch was spinning).

       -The power going out twice(?) during Dutch's set. :(

       -The ambient areas not being "fully" stocked with entertainment.



My thanks to the BP crew! This was a great night for me. Thanks to all I 
met; Matt da Loaf, Shawna ( ;) ), Jon/burgerking hat, Frying Dutchman, 
the Frenchman, R.Lunatic(thanks for the stickers!!), Wayne (thanks for 
the computer info), the guy who I talked to about the mayan calender, 
Jen, Greg, Carrie(sp?), Greg's female housemate, John (BP), Joey, Matt, Dan, 
Phillip (from Mantra), the Unity folks I met, Terry, and to a zillion 
other folks whom are slipping from my data bank at the moment.


Peace all, seeya at the next one!!


Ran


                                -=*=-
                                  ~

On Jul 15,  5:09pm, Branka Cehic wrote:
> Subject: E, parties etc.
[snip]
> Around 10am I found out that one of my best friends was rushed to the
> emergency room due to the seizure.   She took 3 hits of E, because 1st
> didn't do anything, from the 2nd she came down too fast and 3rd was what
> she needed (at least she thought).

Realizing that one rarely knows what one takes, you might be interested
in wether those 3 E's were the same type or that the last one was a
different one. I'm just surprised that the first 2 are apparently very
weak, while the 3rd knocked her out. That might influence your choice
of supplier.

> After getting sick few times, looking
> pretty miserable, she had a seizure.  I wasn't there and I am sorry I
> didn't help my friends, because most of them were freaking out (not that
> I wouldn't, but I still feel bad for not being there).  She was
> unconscious for 15-20 min and she woke up in the ambulance not knowing
> what's happening.
>
> The doctor told her the reason she had a seizure was because her sodium
> level went too low.  Supposedly too much water diluted the sodium in her
> body and caused it to be too low.

It's interesting to note that after all the scary stories about people
dying from dehydration some people are now overdoing the opposite, drinking
too much water (remember the autopsy reports posted here on E-related
deaths in England, one of them was a water overdose). So instead of the
sportdrinks, salt and whatever, one could maybe just stick to reasonable
amounts of water? And the dry mouth is unlikely to go away by drinking
water in my experience, candy/gum/fruit works fine.

> My friend is OK; she was released from the hospital in 4 hours after
> getting some IV.  The doctor said there were 4-5 cases like hers that
> happened the same night.

I'm happy to hear that. I'm still surprised by the sodium explanation
though, it seems to me that one would have to drink a _lot_ of water
to get to that point. I would think more of some of the other changes
induced in the body by E, like changes in heartbeat, glucose levels
etc. and the cirumstances in the place you are (oxygen, heat).

> Maybe I am wrong for sharing this with the entire list, but I just want
> everybody to be careful and think about what they do and how they do it.

That is very appropriate on this list. But then again, anybody can be
suprised since nobody really knows what they're taking and what for
instance long term effects might be (keep checking that short-term
memory, folks!)

> Sometimes all of us get carried away and don't think too much about what
> can happen.  If you are taking stuff, please be careful, don't overdo it
> and make sure you have friends with you  (my friend was lucky she wasn't
> at a big party wondering around by herself).

And for the promotors, make sure that there's somebody around who has some
limited medical knowledge = common practice at the larger raves in Holland
for instance.

> P.S.  Great to hear so many of you had a great weekend.  Mine was almost
> great....

See it as a great learning experience and be happy all ended well.

The Frying Dutchman

--

Yes Yes Yes....
F8 was a great party.  The music was very good the forest was wonderful and
the crowd was interesting.

Highs:
        -me, went a little crazy 
        -running through the pitch black forest with a small flash light,
         gave a great tunneling effect
        -getting lost agin but this time with some raving Russians
        -some girl doing a great glow stick dancy type swrily thing around my
         head
        -meeting some very open friendly people
        -dancing till the dj stopped
        -watching the morning sun slowly permeate the dense fog and forest
        -walking to the redrock beach the next day to rest
Lows:
        -large amounts of trash being left on the ground!!!!!!Lots of beer
cans          and bottles were all over the place the next morning.  Very
disgusted.
         I thought people would know better by now.
        -umm..................................... can't think of anything else.

F8 can throw a great party but I think with beautiful people happening the
same night, there just wasn't that magical touch from great people at this
party.  I still had a great time though.

Wolf.  


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 15 21:13:54 1996

From: Josh Kneubuhl <joshk@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Another Goddamn BP Review
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960715202707.3745C-100000@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Yes, another Beautiful People review!  So much for originality.

Found out about this one just in time - and whoop! there went my weekend 
plans...BP is definitely the kind of party you plan your weekend around...
I'm glad I have at least one raver friend who's as dedicated as I am 
(what's up, crazy K!) to go with at the last minute.

First time at this location.  I liked it!  Main rooms off of the street 
(less noise = less bustable), inside were two levels with multiple rooms, 
creating several chill areas (including a nice open-air area for the 
smokers), and of course, my home, the dancefloor.

As usual, Harmony's beautiful decorations transformed the place into a 
visaul candyland - Raver's Delight.  Rainbows of color washed over all of 
us, psychedelic mushrooms sprouted on the walls and dayglo clouds hung 
from the ceilings.  Superbright Elmos and teddy bears and other inanimate 
friends rode around happily on many ravers all night.  Blankets and 
pillows in the upstairs chill area were too comfortable, people oodled on 
them all night.  The sound and lasers were thick downstairs.  And I got 
pictures of it all!  I finally remembered to bring a camera along to our 
strange nocturnal world, though now I think I'm going to be camera-happy for 
a little while!  (Paul, you inspired me - but where were you?!  YOU would 
have eaten this party up!).

Extra big thank you's to everyone there for the megaPLUR.  This was the 
happiest bunch of people I've gotten to party with in a long time!  
Everywhere I was greeted with smiles and hellos.  I met so many people, 
which was a delightful pleasure for me, a serious speaker hound.  I wish 
I could name them all...

I did meet an older ex-hippie guy who had come to investigate this rave 
thing.  He sat in the chillroom and exclaimed, "people pay hundreds of 
dollars hoping for this in therapy!  This is great!"  I asked him how 
long he'd been at the party.  "Ten minutes!"  He was very curious, asked 
everyone around many questions (including, "what happens when there's 
fights?", "is there any uniformed security?"- very new to the scene!).  
He went down to the dancefloor but wouldn't leave the wall, however, 
because he was afraid to leave his stuff unguarded.  Hee hee!

On the dancefloor Adam the Lunatic was very entertaining.  With a huge 
cartoon checkered hat hiding his entire head, big baggy clothes flopping 
and dazzling glow sticks spinning, this "newbie" has turned into one of 
the crazier rave characters.  You go!  (But no way do I believe that you 
never danced before raving!!)

Fun!  See you all next at FF (or in the line for the tickets Saturday 
morning...)

Love, Nancy

So, random drug question. how come ketamine, a somewhat popular back-east rave drug,
and one that is hallucinogenic (feel free to argue about that statement)
, as well as having some serious alien experiences attatched to it,
is such a non-thing out here.

(by alien exp, i mean that _all_ of the people that I know who have used
it intesively  have described visiting different planets,
and many have felt that they have caught glipses of, or 
even come into contact with, alien lifeforms.)


is it a synthetic vs artificial thing?

Not that I really care, i just find it odd.

where did I buy my grammer anyway? Prolly the same Bazaar I bought mt 
spelling from.

take care

kcr

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

     All right people. Hyperreal has a drug archive. You can also find
numerous archives to read upon on any single drug you want (so there's no
reason in not knowing the dangers). 
     E, first off, is like alcohol in a way. Too much makes your body reject
(puke) it. E always makes you semi-DEhydrated. It makes your body use up
it's liquid stores to fuel itself and therefor you need to drink a lot of
water. You can't overhydrate yourself, and if you somehow did, there's
enough electrolytes in ordinary water to keep your bodies leveles balanced
(unless it's distilled). 
     When you sweat, your body uses its liquid to cool your skin. Salt comes
out through your pores with the water. Your body can become deprived of
sodium through sweating, but I'ver never heard of it being diluted. (that's
why you taste salty when you sweat).
     Also, Last year or so, I had a similar experience. Me and my girlfriend
(at the time), went to a rave and wanted some E. We weren't really
experienced much at all with it and bought some aspirin looking things from
some guy. He called them white tylenol, I whink it was. After about two
hours it didn't seem to be working. Me and my girly decided that we'd get
more, but from a diffirent person. I found the guy and got two of something
called Black Licorice. I took one but my girly didn't cuz she was afraid and
wanted to wait to see if it was cool or not. When I tasted it, it kinda made
my tongue tingle (sorta like licking a battery). I didn't know any better
and swallowed anyway. About an hour later I really didn't feel much else
than a kind of wirre that would come over me in waves like every 9 minutes.
Anna asked me if it was cool and I said "I guess" so she took hers. That
wasn't cool. About 45 minutes later, Anna started feeling sick. She went
into the bathroom, threw up, passed out, and I didn't know what to do. Damn
promoters just wanted to get her outside. ( I found out that the sales
manager for one of my racing sponsors was putting on the event). I helped
them outside and layed her down with my jacket as I ran 4-5 blocks down
broadway to get the car.
     Eventually We made it home. On the drive back I was seriously wired out
of my mind, and Anna was barely concious. I had too keep talking to her
(which wasn't a problem) so she wouldn't go to sleep. We ended up going to
my house and sleeping through the next two days. She ended up OK, but I've
learned from my mistakes.

      People, read the literature on the drugs you use. I don't want to see
any of our family get hurt. There are too many assholes out there selling
tore up ass shit to people who don't know any better. 

      Next time you want E, ask what kind it is. If they give you some name
other than Methylenedioxymethlamphetamine (MDMA), don't buy it. Same if they
don't know what it is. MDMA is usually yellow crystally or white powder.
What out for capsules, because you can't tell what's in it, but I trust them
more than anything else.

      Try and get whatever you want through someone you trust.

Love ya guyzzzz. . . 


Aryck

At 09:37 PM 7/15/96 -0700, kcroy wrote:
>So, random drug question. how come ketamine, a somewhat popular back-east
rave drug,
>and one that is hallucinogenic (feel free to argue about that statement)
>, as well as having some serious alien experiences attatched to it,
>is such a non-thing out here.
>
>(by alien exp, i mean that _all_ of the people that I know who have used
>it intesively  have described visiting different planets,
>and many have felt that they have caught glipses of, or 
>even come into contact with, alien lifeforms.)
>
>
>is it a synthetic vs artificial thing?
>


Well, Ketamine is a general anesthetic made by Parke Davis. The good news
is, if you get it in the sealed vial, you know its pure. The bad news is
most of the time its taken intermuscularly..meaning injected.  Although it
can be evaporated down to a powder, but that tends to be expensive. John
Lilly injected Ketamine up to 24 times a day over consecutive months without
(as he claimed) serious damage or difficulty.

For those who have done it, (and I have) they will tell you it is the most
intense psychedelic experiences they have ever had. Once the experience
starts,its  like doing a full summeralt, with a twist down into your
unconscious. But, the experience only lasts for about 20 minutes, and my
friend, the good doctor,
said to me, "go where IT wants to go, do not resist, panic or attempt to control
this." Kinda like the instructions for the old Outer Limits TV
program--"Something else has definately taken temporary control of your
telvision set"--This is not a "fun" drug---or something to do at a
party--although I did this once while lying down (that is recommended since
you lose any sense of your body) on the hillside at a Sunset in the Berkeley
Marina.

It is a titanic, exhilarating experience, and one which stretches the
meaning of reality or consciousness as you have known it.  This is not a
recommendation.  It is a warning not to do this casually or for fun.

About SYNTONIC....

It was great meeting Branka at the Syntonic party.  At first, when I didn't
see it listed on the calender, I was a little disappointed.  I hadn't been
out in about three months, and everyone seemed to be going to the "cool"
parties; BP, Freak-8,Unlock,Chi--But, somewhere across town a great house
party was given--for friends,by friends, by invitation only.  A nice loft,70
smilE faces, four J's playing for the Vibe---(But Biojeff was great--hear
him soon)  It truly was the spirit of ravin'...I got hugz and smiles from
everyone there...danced to the trance..

Bye the Bye...I came up to visit a friend who has been suffering for the
past four months from what is thought to be an over-exposure to E.. he has
shown symptoms usually associated exposure to toxic chemicals;
tingling,dizziness,etc.
This is just to say, that taking e repeatedly, in high concentrations, over
a few years, may lead to physical complications.  The good news is that my
friend has recovered.(almost) but, again....remember--you are not immortal,
nor are you invincible....

                  .............SpinSilver  aka   robertj from Monterey

Precedence: bulk

Ahhhh special K...
I don't know if I'd classify it as a hallucinogen (it's more of a
tranquilizer, being related to PCP), but the effects are slightly
psychedelic at higher doses. I think it's o.k. in moderation, but when a
lot of people are deep in k-holes at a party, it sort of detracts from
the overall dancefloor energy.  It's a chill and kick-it-on-back high,
but in excess it's as if one is dusted. From personal experience Special
K (at certian threshold doses) makes one so dissociated from their own
body that dancing or any coordinated movement is quite difficult. I've
fallen into a deep K-hole with several other hapless souls at an
afterhours or two when the music was sooooo good but we couldn't really
get up and groove until the K metabolized (an hour or so). It can be an
interesting experience if you don't mind being slightly-to-severely
incapacitated for a bit.
-- 
^      ^
@   @
   U
   O ....digdatbeat!
      Gregor Hoffman

psychadelics seems to have overlooked a rather significant one.

A few thoughts and warnings.

1. it isnt pcp. it isnt like pcp. Its still used in hospitals as a heavy
form of sedation.
2. don't buy shit off the street
3. its IM, not IV, if you are gonna take the hard route. IV could kill you.
4. NEVER NEVER NEVER NEVER NEVER mix alcohol and k. Unless you really enjoy
being deathly sick.
5. read some of that John Lilly character

There: Just a few words of advice from one of those straight-edged dc kids
who got to see a bunch of other people play their games on both the safe
and unsafe side of the fence.

I gots nothing more to say

Hi everybody,

The New Moon Collective is celebrating the new moon's first quarter with
an event to be held someplace in Marin- that's gonna be about an hour drive
away.  We hope to start the music around midnight, possibly earlier,
finishing up at some point after sunrise.  Possibly followed by an ambient
brunch for all at an East Bay location.

The Date:  July 20- that's Saturday!  

What to bring:  food and water, warm clothes, a flashlight, firewood,
cardboard to dance on, something for the altar, and lots of love!

For directions, call:  415-267-3076.

See you Saturday!

the New Moon and friends

http://hyperreal.com/raves/newmoon

It's SUPPOSED to come out this friday at exlusive theaters. My friend know
tha distributer and he's having problems selling it out, so it might be
postponed another week. I'm a total trainspotting freak and have read
everything Irvine Welsh has written (except his newest book exstacy which
JUST came out) and I highly recommend any of his books. I'm getting to the
age (finally) where there are popular writers who are in touch with our
generation. Though none of his books are about raving specifically, all of
them deal with it in some way, and the experiences are usually positively
protrayed. I know Irvine raves HARD in amsterdamn and Scotland (he says he
likes trance the best). Anyone else read any of his work??

i think sfr is a community, and is both a part of, and distinct
from the non-list community.
parety lists are available via the calandar and a number of partylines
not to mention flyers and word of mouth.
Mailing lists _are_ high volume, and _are_ a apain in the ass soetimes.
Thats just their nature. (well, not all of them, but SFR is a 
_vague_ list. raving includes everything from getting the party ready,
to whose going,
to what movie you are going to see afterwards while lsd is still dripping down 
your spinal column, to latest musik, etc...

and on top of all of that, for many of us, it's the people that help make
the parties beautiful, and thats what all these rants are about.

I think that if you really want to skim down your messages, just throw together
a kill filter to include 

NRR:

(yeah, yeah, im sure someone will throw the best party in the world called NNR:
but, whatever..)

I mean, i agree that there are a hell of a lot of 
threads here that make me want to blink this list out of existence, but thats the price for a 
a community voice. Sometimes the noise drowns out the signal.

I agree that many of these discussion need to go private _immediately_.
and i think people should be responsible about that. 


sorry for the bandwidth
take
care
kcroy

heya,
 thought some of you might find this funny :)



> >
> >This is a crazy story...
> >
> >------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> >I Like Monkeys
> >
> >The pet store was selling them for five cents a piece. I thought that odd
> >since they were normally a couple thousand. I decided not to look a gift
> >horse in the mouth. I bought 200. I like monkeys.
> >
> >I took my 200 monkeys home. I have a big car. I let one drive. His name
> >was Sigmund. He was retarded. In fact, none of them were too bright. They
> >kept punching themselves in the genitals. I laughed. Then they punched my
> >genitals. I stopped laughing.
> >
> >I herded them into my room. They didn't adapt very well to their new
> >environment. They would screech, hurl themselves off the couch at high
> >speeds and slam into the wall. Although humorous at first, the spectacle
> >lost its novelty halfway into its third hour.
> >
> >Two hours later I found out why all the monkeys were so inexpensive: they
> >all died. No apparent reason. They all just sorta dropped dead. Kinda
> >like when you buy a goldfish and it dies five hours later. Damn cheap
> >monkeys.
> >
> >I didn't know what to do. There were 200 dead monkeys lying all over my
> >room, on the bed, in the dresser, hanging from my bookcase. It looked
> >like I had 200 throw rugs.
> >
> >I tried to flush one down the toilet. It didn't work. It got stuck. Then
> >I had one dead, wet monkey and 199 dead, dry monkeys.
> >
> >I tried pretending they were just stuffed animals. That worked for a
> >while, that is until they began to decompose. It started to smell real bad.
> >
> >I had to pee but there was a dead monkey in the toilet and i didn't want
> >to call the plumber. I was embarrassed.
> >
> >I tried to slow down the decomposition by freezing them. Unfortunately,
> >there was only enough room for two monkeys at a time so I had to change
> >them every 30 seconds. I also had to eat all the food in the freezer so
> >it didn't all go bad.
> >
> >I tried burning them. Little did I know my bed was flammable. I had to
> >extinguish the fire.
> >
> >Then I had one dead, wet monkey in my toilet, two dead frozen monkeys in
> >my freezer, and 197 dead, charred monkeys in a pile on my bed. The odor
> >wasn't improving.
> >
> >I became agitated at my inability to dispose of my monkeys and to use the
> >bathroom. I severely beat one of my monkeys. I felt better.
> >
> >I tried throwing them away but the garbage man said that the city was not
> >allowed to dispose of charred primates. I told him I had a wet one. He
> >couldn't take that either. I didn't bother asking about the frozen ones.
> >
> >I finally arrived at a solution. I gave them out as Christmas gifts. My
> >friends didn't know quite what to say. They pretended that they liked
> >them but I could tell they were lying. Ingrates. So I punched them in the
> >genitals.
> >
> >I like monkeys.
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

A raver is someone with a particular vierw on life who has chosen to 
express his opinions through music and dance.  BUt there are obviously 
people out there who share the same thoughts and feelings as us but are 
not ravers (e.g. film makers etc).  BUt they and there ideas are still 
important and should therefore be discussed by this community along with 
other important topics such as politics, drugs, astronomy and anything 
else that tickes are fancy.
Tristan.

On Mon, 15 Jul 1996, Josh Kneubuhl wrote:

> 
> Yes, another Beautiful People review!  So much for originality.
> 
> Found out about this one just in time - and whoop! there went my weekend 
> plans...BP is definitely the kind of party you plan your weekend around...
> I'm glad I have at least one raver friend who's as dedicated as I am 
> (what's up, crazy K!) to go with at the last minute.
> 
> First time at this location.  I liked it!  Main rooms off of the street 
> (less noise = less bustable), inside were two levels with multiple rooms, 
> creating several chill areas (including a nice open-air area for the 
> smokers), and of course, my home, the dancefloor.
> 
> As usual, Harmony's beautiful decorations transformed the place into a 
> visaul candyland - Raver's Delight.  Rainbows of color washed over all of 
> us, psychedelic mushrooms sprouted on the walls and dayglo clouds hung 
> from the ceilings.  Superbright Elmos and teddy bears and other inanimate 
> friends rode around happily on many ravers all night.  Blankets and 
> pillows in the upstairs chill area were too comfortable, people oodled on 
> them all night.  The sound and lasers were thick downstairs.  And I got 
> pictures of it all!  I finally remembered to bring a camera along to our 
> strange nocturnal world, though now I think I'm going to be camera-happy for 
> a little while!  (Paul, you inspired me - but where were you?!  YOU would 
> have eaten this party up!).
> 
> Extra big thank you's to everyone there for the megaPLUR.  This was the 
> happiest bunch of people I've gotten to party with in a long time!  
> Everywhere I was greeted with smiles and hellos.  I met so many people, 
> which was a delightful pleasure for me, a serious speaker hound.  I wish 
> I could name them all...
> 
> I did meet an older ex-hippie guy who had come to investigate this rave 
> thing.  He sat in the chillroom and exclaimed, "people pay hundreds of 
> dollars hoping for this in therapy!  This is great!"  I asked him how 
> long he'd been at the party.  "Ten minutes!"  He was very curious, asked 
> everyone around many questions (including, "what happens when there's 
> fights?", "is there any uniformed security?"- very new to the scene!).  
> He went down to the dancefloor but wouldn't leave the wall, however, 
> because he was afraid to leave his stuff unguarded.  Hee hee!
> 
> On the dancefloor Adam the Lunatic was very entertaining.  With a huge 
> cartoon checkered hat hiding his entire head, big baggy clothes flopping 
> and dazzling glow sticks spinning, this "newbie" has turned into one of 
> the crazier rave characters.  You go!  (But no way do I believe that you 
> never danced before raving!!)
> 
> Fun!  See you all next at FF (or in the line for the tickets Saturday 
> morning...)
> 
> Love, Nancy
>

	Try DXM, it lasts at least as long as acid, if not longer. In my
case, tripping almost every day for a period of months, I had so much
residue built up into my system that if I did just slightly over my
normal dose I would in effect not come down for almost 24 hours (although I
would regain control of my voluntary muscles within 4 or 5 hours).

	Fun is subjective.

	I agree with that - I am a little surprised that people would do a
dissociative at a party. For me at least it is a very private thing -
something I do when I expect to just be able to chill and listen to
music or watch TV (before it kicks in so hard that outside stimuli become
irrelevant)...

Karen,

> I think the idea of using an animal trank to get high is silly .... also,
	Um, you forgot the ", IMHO" here -----------------------^

> from what i've heard, K gets you REALLY screwed up and i just don't like
> that sensation.  If i'm going to ingest something, I want it to be FUN,
	A valid choice for yourself...

> that sensation.  If i'm going to ingest something, I want it to be FUN,
> and this just seems like it'd be a little much.  Sitting around completely
	But do you think your definition of "fun" is the One True Fun?

> and this just seems like it'd be a little much.  Sitting around completely
> lost having conversations with things that aren't there isn't my scene. 
	Cool, another valid point I would support your right to have.

> 
> IMHO

	Sorry, but one little "IMHO" at the end isn't a blanket "cure-all".
I am _very_ into dissociatives like K, PCP, and DXM (they are my fave
substances, and even better they are NOT usually tested for on drug test) and
for me I can think of little that is MORE fun then being so under the
influence of something that your whole body is just _gone_ - you can't
feel yourself breathe, you can't feel your heart beat, you can feel yourself
stand up, sit down, feel what you are lying on, _nothing_. And the music
is just swelling inside your head and you begin to feel it, to feel like
you are flying through space in a waking dream. Now I would hardly take such
a dose before a rave, since at a rave I want to be able to move and on the
kinds of doses of K or DXM I take I literally _can't_ move even if I wanted
to, but as long as other people aren't like collapsing on the dance floor
I would never dis their choice of "fun"...

				Marisa
