Absolutely you are right - boyfriend wrong....

SOmeone was looking through the PDR and came upon Ketamine ( or Keteject or
similar trade name )... looking at side effects noticed that it caused
"paranoid delusions" - that's the ticket we want some of those... so a
number of people including lots of folks at Esalen ( a poplular Lilly
hangout )... tried it and tried it... It was perfectly legal especially
for an MD - which is why he called it vitamin K so as to not have it come
under direct drug enforcement scrutiny...
of course they all shot it as someone said not IV but IM.... I only heard of
people using it orally recently...

 And out of all that developed an increasing awareness of the solid state
beings and intelligence all around us - preparing to do battle with the
forces of carbon based life... boy are we in trouble ;-) (reference to Lilly
book )

Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic

Marisa Giancarla <marisaw@psiwa5.Syntex.Com> wrote:

> I am _very_ into dissociatives like K, PCP, and DXM (they are my fave
> substances, and even better they are NOT usually tested for on drug test) and
> for me I can think of little that is MORE fun then being so under the
> influence of something that your whole body is just _gone_ - you can't
> feel yourself breathe, you can't feel your heart beat, you can feel yourself
> stand up, sit down, feel what you are lying on, _nothing_. And the music
> is just swelling inside your head and you begin to feel it, to feel like
> you are flying through space in a waking dream.

Awesome!  Never had the opportunity to try any of the above but have
had similair experiences after a few days of artificially-induced sleep
deprivation followed by some quality muscle-relaxants/pain-killers
(with THC ever present of course).  Talk about melting into your
couch.

By the way, the sleep-depravation alone brought new-found understanding
of the various `saints' and other reliugious types who claimed to have
seen and spoken to God.  Granted, they tended to blend in starvation and
pain but then again, they didn't have amphetimens at their disposal.

> Now I would hardly take such
> a dose before a rave, since at a rave I want to be able to move and on the
> kinds of doses of K or DXM I take I literally _can't_ move even if I wanted
> to, but as long as other people aren't like collapsing on the dance floor
> I would never dis their choice of "fun"...

Thanks.  Now I prefer to be mobile too (at least for most of it).  But
my first rave-like expereince was a Wicked which I spent mostly in a
chair travelling the universe on the sound waves using the visuals on
occasion to set my course--the mushrooms and Dilaudid helped I'm sure!
I was hooked immediately though the dancing bug didn't grab me `till
later.

Tim

> > Well, Ketamine is a general anesthetic made by Parke Davis. The good news
> > is, if you get it in the sealed vial, you know its pure. The bad news is
> > most of the time its taken intermuscularly..meaning injected. Although it
> > can be evaporated down to a powder, but that tends to be expensive. John
> > Lilly injected Ketamine up to 24 times a day over consecutive months 
> >without (as he claimed) serious damage or difficulty.

> Marisa Giancarla <marisaw@psiwa5.Syntex.Com> wrote:
>
> > I am _very_ into dissociatives like K, PCP, and DXM (they are my fave
> > substances, and even better they are NOT usually tested for on drug test)

I wouldn't be too sure about PCP (which was quite popular in the States
for a while) and DXM (which is chemically related to morphine and thus
might show up in tests for heroin etc.). And DXM... that stuff left a
a very unpleasant taste in my mouth for 3 days (+ not sleeping for 48
hours while I had to work...). Some interesting effects when lying
down though....

> > for me I can think of little that is MORE fun then being so under the
> > influence of something that your whole body is just _gone_ - you can't
> > feel yourself breathe, you can't feel your heart beat, you can feel
yourself
> > stand up, sit down, feel what you are lying on, _nothing_. And the music
> > is just swelling inside your head and you begin to feel it, to feel like
> > you are flying through space in a waking dream.

To everybody his/her own indeed. However, I feel such experiences are better
done in the privacy of your own or a friends home. It can be quite
disturbing to people, say at a rave, to see somebody apparently
unconscious lying in a corner of the chill out or injecting themselves
with syringes (have witnessed both at raves).

> > Now I would hardly take such
> > a dose before a rave, since at a rave I want to be able to move and on the
> > kinds of doses of K or DXM I take I literally _can't_ move even if I wanted
> > to, but as long as other people aren't like collapsing on the dance floor
> > I would never dis their choice of "fun"...

Collapsing is sort of the end of the line, personally I draw the line at
people being approachable and still able to have some sort of coherent
conversation (at raves). Otherwise, what is the purpose of coming together
if everybody is on there own personal trip?

The Frying Dutchman




--

On Mon, 15 Jul 1996, Josh Kneubuhl wrote:

>
> Yes, another Beautiful People review!  So much for originality.
>
> Found out about this one just in time - and whoop! there went my weekend
> plans...BP is definitely the kind of party you plan your weekend around...
> I'm glad I have at least one raver friend who's as dedicated as I am
> (what's up, crazy K!) to go with at the last minute.
>
> First time at this location.  I liked it!  Main rooms off of the street
> (less noise = less bustable), inside were two levels with multiple rooms,
> creating several chill areas (including a nice open-air area for the
> smokers), and of course, my home, the dancefloor.
>
> As usual, Harmony's beautiful decorations transformed the place into a
> visaul candyland - Raver's Delight.  Rainbows of color washed over all of
> us, psychedelic mushrooms sprouted on the walls and dayglo clouds hung
> from the ceilings.  Superbright Elmos and teddy bears and other inanimate
> friends rode around happily on many ravers all night.  Blankets and
> pillows in the upstairs chill area were too comfortable, people oodled on
> them all night.  The sound and lasers were thick downstairs.  And I got
> pictures of it all!  I finally remembered to bring a camera along to our
> strange nocturnal world, though now I think I'm going to be camera-happy for
> a little while!  (Paul, you inspired me - but where were you?!  YOU would
> have eaten this party up!).
>
> Extra big thank you's to everyone there for the megaPLUR.  This was the
> happiest bunch of people I've gotten to party with in a long time!
> Everywhere I was greeted with smiles and hellos.  I met so many people,
> which was a delightful pleasure for me, a serious speaker hound.  I wish
> I could name them all...
>
> I did meet an older ex-hippie guy who had come to investigate this rave
> thing.  He sat in the chillroom and exclaimed, "people pay hundreds of
> dollars hoping for this in therapy!  This is great!"  I asked him how
> long he'd been at the party.  "Ten minutes!"  He was very curious, asked
> everyone around many questions (including, "what happens when there's
> fights?", "is there any uniformed security?"- very new to the scene!).
> He went down to the dancefloor but wouldn't leave the wall, however,
> because he was afraid to leave his stuff unguarded.  Hee hee!
>
> On the dancefloor Adam the Lunatic was very entertaining.  With a huge
> cartoon checkered hat hiding his entire head, big baggy clothes flopping
> and dazzling glow sticks spinning, this "newbie" has turned into one of
> the crazier rave characters.  You go!  (But no way do I believe that you
> never danced before raving!!)

is there a particular reason that the acme warehouse is *always* packed 
to dangerous proportions? i like the space, but i will not go to another 
party there without some limit on the number of people.

granted there's always risk, but acme has only *one* accessible exit, 
an obstructed and narrow traffic flow, a structure showing serious 
fatigue (e.g. floor jacks), and -last, but not least- at most two toilets. 
it's an accident (in both senses of the word) waiting to happen. during 
the last nye begin again there, my roommate says he saw occasional 
sparks from wiring in the back of the basement (as perspiration and 
other unidentified moisture consistently dripped through the ceiling).

besides, two square feet of space does not make for much dancing 
enjoyment. 

are we *that* hard up for spaces in the city? i do like the place; i just 
don't like the overcrowding. sounds more like someone's hard up for money.

jmar! adios.

Dear All;

        I was fiddling with the factory EQ on my new, used car's JBL sound
system. When I noticed the settings for Jazz were similar to the settings I
lock in for TECHNO. TECHNO being for the purpose of this discussion, all
styles of the music we listen to TRANCE, HOUSE ...etc. 

        The EQ setting for JAZZ basically resembled a V shaped waveform,
with the highs and lows up, and the mids down. These are the same setting
that I set the EQ for when I listen to TECHNO.

        I know nothing about JAZZ, and really can't, or haven't taken the
time to appreciate the genre or form of  music called JAZZ. I was just
wondering how, and if they are musically similar in structure.

        Also, I feel TRANCE is very similar to Classical Music due to it's
ability to provoke emotional reactions from it's listeners, as well as
produce tremenous imagery. I was also wondering if it was similar in
structure to Classical music?

        Another question about feelings; how does you TECHNO make you feel,
what does it make you see, or what imagery does it produce. Remember these
are feelings, there are no right or wrong answers here.

        It makes me feel harmonious with the planet, light, happy, positive,
powerful to name but a few, so how bout you, just curious and please try and
stick to FEELINGS. = >

Peace
Brian

ps This should satisfy those rave/techno only people.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 16 14:26:55 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA05461; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 14:26:55 -0700
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA05455; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 14:26:52 -0700
Received: from [206.79.2.36] ([206.79.2.36]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA24473; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 14:26:49 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v02130506ae11b60ed2b4@[206.79.2.36]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Tue, 16 Jul 1996 14:28:54 -0700
To: "THX1138" <THX1138@planet-jubip.com>
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: TECHNO, JAZZ, & CLASSICAL MUSIC.....
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>        Another question about feelings; how does you TECHNO make you feel,
>what does it make you see, or what imagery does it produce. Remember these
>are feelings, there are no right or wrong answers here.
>
>        It makes me feel harmonious with the planet, light, happy, positive,
>powerful to name but a few, so how bout you, just curious and please try and
>stick to FEELINGS. = >

depends...

when I listen to IDM (banco de gaia, the orb, etc.) i feel like I'm
floating. Drifting through the Galaxy, if you will =) . The imagery I get
is of physical emptiness, but total sensory immersion. Like I'm in the
middle of a giant empty stadium with all the amps on 11. (this one goes to
11, for when you want that extra kick. why not just make 10 the highest?
...uh... this one goes to 11.)

when I listen to GOA TRANCE or HARDTRANCE with a lot of buildups and
letdowns, I feel like I'm flying forward. I'm in a space full of "stuff,"
zooming around, between and through objects of huge proportions and good,
complex surface detail. It's a similar feeling to the one I used to get
when I'd play my Iron Maiden (Seventh Son of a Seventh Son, if you must
know) tapes on loud; which probably explains why I ran into a bunch of the
junior metalheads from HS at Freedom a few weeks ago... they're goaboys
now. =)

when I listen to AMBIENT (FSOL lifeforms a good one) I visualize nature.
Not *normal* nature though... it's changed somehow. There's *nature* stuff
happening, but it's mixed up; juxtaposed in a way that makes it
nonsensical. But nonsensical in a structured way. Like seeing a cow
upside-down in a waterfall with bubbles floating around; it doesn't make
sense but it seems right at the moment.

when I listen to JUNGLE or BREAKBEAT (prodigy's firestarter is *the shit*)
or TRIP HOP I just feel like dancing. I don't have any specific imagery
that goes with it, because I'm so intent on MOTION. I *feel* my physical
surroundings (both real and imagined =), rather than *observe* them.

when I listen to GABBER I feel like hitting things. But not in a really
destructive way; just sorta banging my fist into stuff to get some
aggression out.

when I listen to GERMAN HAPPY GABBER and HAPPY HARDCORE (marusha, memebers
of mayday) I feel like whistling. I visualize fluffy, poofy things bopping
around. Then I like to hit stuff (in a fluffy, poofy kind of way) when the
beat picks up.

when I listen to HOUSE I feel like changing CDs.


and, no, I don't do hallucinogens and I don't plan on starting anytime
soon. I don't get stoned often, I've only e'd once (loved it-- thanks Adam
=), and I only get drunk in social situations, so all this stuff is just
the product of an overactive imagination and years of walking the dog with
a walkman and immersing myself in thought.

-m.

>At 02:28 PM 7/16/96 -0700, you wrote:

>>when I listen to GOA TRANCE or HARDTRANCE with a lot of buildups and

>>zooming around, between and through objects of huge proportions and good,
>>complex surface detail. It's a similar feeling to the one I used to get
>>when I'd play my Iron Maiden (Seventh Son of a Seventh Son, if you must
>>know) tapes on loud; which probably explains why I ran into a bunch of the
>>junior metalheads from HS at Freedom a few weeks ago... they're goaboys
>>now. =)
>
>>when I listen to AMBIENT (FSOL lifeforms a good one) I visualize nature.
>>Not *normal* nature though... it's changed somehow. There's *nature* stuff
>>happening, but it's mixed up; juxtaposed in a way that makes it
>>nonsensical. But nonsensical in a structured way. Like seeing a cow
>>upside-down in a waterfall with bubbles floating around; it doesn't make
>>sense but it seems right at the moment.
>
>>when I listen to JUNGLE or BREAKBEAT (prodigy's firestarter is *the shit*)
>>or TRIP HOP I just feel like dancing. I don't have any specific imagery
>>that goes with it, because I'm so intent on MOTION. I *feel* my physical
>>surroundings (both real and imagined =), rather than *observe* them.
>
>>when I listen to GABBER I feel like hitting things. But not in a really
>>destructive way; just sorta banging my fist into stuff to get some

Ronald Knegtel <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU> wrote:

> 
> Collapsing is sort of the end of the line, personally I draw the line at
> people being approachable and still able to have some sort of coherent
> conversation (at raves). Otherwise, what is the purpose of coming together
> if everybody is on there own personal trip?
> 
My apologies before hand--if I'm incoherent the first time come back
later if it seems my conversation will make that big a difference.  I'm
rarely out of my head for too long.

Sometimes I just want the anonymity of a large gathering of people
whether you know any of them or not, whether you talk to any of them or
not, just having a good time.  Sometimes it's just the music or just
the trip.  For those times when you want to hang with some people,
there'll always be enough coherent people I should think, so those that
aren't shouldn't matter.

Personally, I draw the line at not being able to take care of yourself.  I
rarely need to be able to hold a coherent conversation for that.  And often
take better care of myself when I avoid coherent conversations.

Tim

 I've driven extensively in Boston, New York, and now SF. I think 
that while drivers in Boston and NY are very aggressive, and sometimes 
mean, they are doing it on purpose, and do have a certain degree of 
driving skill. They just choose to drive the way they do. In SF, I think 
many people just don't know what the hell they are doing. I have seen 
more people driving the wrong way up one way streets, making right turns 
from the left lane, and doing similarly stupid things here than I have 
anywhere else, ever. And when it rains, shit. There isn't a rainy day 
that I don't pass at least three wrecks on the way to work. Thank god it 
doesn't snow in SF, or this whole town would come together in one big 
crash right at Market Street.

-Dan

On Tue, 16 Jul 1996 elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com wrote:


>      SF drivers are the worst in the world!  I'm convinced people were sent 
>      to school to learn how to run red lights, NEVER use a turn signal, 
>      stop at all times in the middle of a street without any indication, 
>      totally forget that there are other drivers on the road, and  
>      horse-blinkers are a must!! Forgive my ranting, but drivers here scare 
>      me!
> 
>

Hello all.  I just recently moved out here from the east. I'd been living in Cincinnati,
Ohio.  Boring place overall.  Too conservative for me. :)

Anyway, I'm living in San Jose right now and was wondering if any of you know any
cool places to hang out or any cool stores. 

Also don't know that many people out here yet so I'm looking forward to meeting some

elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com wrote:
> 
>      SF drivers are the worst in the world!  

Actually, having just moved out here, the traffic and people's driving
doesn't seem that awful for a metrpolitan region of this size. I resided
in New England for a couple of years and Massachussetts drivers are, in
my opinion, some of the worst and scariest drivers in the contiguous
states. Driving in Boston is a nightmare, especially when the streets
are
blanketed in snow and ice.  I also lived in D.C for several years and
that is a city where people just fly through red lights (Hell, I used
to!) Traffic in and around the nation's capitol is just aggro/ whack. I
used to frequently drive home to DC from Fever (DJs  Scott Henry's &
Feelgoods' club project) in Baltimore in the early am hours and it was
really weird to come out after dancing all night and trying to drive in
a semi-relaxed mode (coming down off an E), while dealing with really
anxious and agitated commuter traffic!  All I can say is: if if you see
a car w/ diplomatic plates, watch out because unpredictable manuvers are
de rigeur. Try touring the Beltway around DC and you'll probably
consider SF a cakewalk.

Randy C Cone wrote:
> 
> Just so folks know; I videotape at some parties and my material IS NOT 
> for sale. To Fox or anyone else. I use it for class projects, to teach 
> myself video limits, for memories and to use for projections at future 
> parties.

	Mmmmmh, I'm pretty sure that your intentions are very pure, but,
	no way!, I just don't feel at ease when being tapped at a rave.

	I feel like videotapers are more "greedy," they "take" much more
	than they "give", they kinda put themselves "out" of the event by
	hiding behind a camera. Imagine more than 50% of the people at a 
	party trying to tape it... What? Everybody would just look stupid, 
	and the vibe would be ruined.

	So I _really_ dislike being shot at a rave. I don't really feel like 
	this in general, it's just that I don't feel it fits. Have you ever 
	seen rave pictures? Honestly it's not really great, neither is 
	footage... Is it? It seems like this material manage to get only 
	1/3 of the event; maybe is it because nobody has found a way to 
	catch Vibe on film yet ;)

	I don't have anything against videotapers, I just want to make
	sure with this post that they realize that some people (me included)
	are not at ease with the idea of their image being caught at a rave
	and thrown around the world (maybe not, but how can I know?)
	It's my liberty NOT to be tapped, right? But how can I enforce it?

	So please consider it twice before bringing your video stuff at a
	rave, thanx!
Renaud

>water. You can't overhydrate yourself, and if you somehow did, there's
>enough electrolytes in ordinary water to keep your bodies leveles balanced
>(unless it's distilled). 

Actually, you can.  There is such a thing called overhydration (water
toxicity) or too much water!  There was a case I recall in England where a
guy at a rave drank something like 4 gallons of water.  Apparantly, at that
point a condition called water toxicity reveals itself and the person
becomes seriously illin'. It is one of the few deaths that has occured in
the UG scene as an indirect result of E.

Anyone else heard of this?

Drenched,

Steve

On Mon, 15 Jul 1996 23:53:35 -0700, you wrote:

>--=====================_837495250==_
>Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
>
>     All right people. Hyperreal has a drug archive. You can also find
>numerous archives to read upon on any single drug you want (so there's no
>reason in not knowing the dangers). 
>     E, first off, is like alcohol in a way. Too much makes your body reject
>(puke) it. E always makes you semi-DEhydrated. It makes your body use up
>it's liquid stores to fuel itself and therefor you need to drink a lot of
>water. You can't overhydrate yourself, and if you somehow did, there's
>enough electrolytes in ordinary water to keep your bodies leveles balanced
>(unless it's distilled). 
Your information is out of date.  Ever hear of Leah Betts?  She and
other people in Britain have injured themselves and died from "water
poisoning".  It is becoming clear now that isotonic drinks (containing
sodium) are the way to go.
>     When you sweat, your body uses its liquid to cool your skin. Salt comes
>out through your pores with the water. Your body can become deprived of
>sodium through sweating, but I'ver never heard of it being diluted. (that's
>why you taste salty when you sweat).
>     Also, Last year or so, I had a similar experience. Me and my girlfriend
>(at the time), went to a rave and wanted some E. We weren't really
>experienced much at all with it and bought some aspirin looking things from
>some guy. He called them white tylenol, I whink it was. After about two
>hours it didn't seem to be working. Me and my girly decided that we'd get
>more, but from a diffirent person. I found the guy and got two of something
>called Black Licorice. I took one but my girly didn't cuz she was afraid and
>wanted to wait to see if it was cool or not. When I tasted it, it kinda made
>my tongue tingle (sorta like licking a battery). I didn't know any better
>and swallowed anyway. About an hour later I really didn't feel much else
>than a kind of wirre that would come over me in waves like every 9 minutes.
>Anna asked me if it was cool and I said "I guess" so she took hers. That
>wasn't cool. About 45 minutes later, Anna started feeling sick. She went
>into the bathroom, threw up, passed out, and I didn't know what to do. Damn
>promoters just wanted to get her outside. ( I found out that the sales
>manager for one of my racing sponsors was putting on the event). I helped
>them outside and layed her down with my jacket as I ran 4-5 blocks down
>broadway to get the car.
>     Eventually We made it home. On the drive back I was seriously wired out
>of my mind, and Anna was barely concious. I had too keep talking to her
>(which wasn't a problem) so she wouldn't go to sleep. We ended up going to
>my house and sleeping through the next two days. She ended up OK, but I've
>learned from my mistakes.
>
It may have been "good stuff" but your friend could be one of the
people who can't tolerate it.  
>      People, read the literature on the drugs you use. I don't want to see
>any of our family get hurt. There are too many assholes out there selling
>tore up ass shit to people who don't know any better. 
>
>      Next time you want E, ask what kind it is. If they give you some name
>other than Methylenedioxymethlamphetamine (MDMA), don't buy it. Same if they
>don't know what it is. MDMA is usually yellow crystally or white powder.
>What out for capsules, because you can't tell what's in it, but I trust them
>more than anything else.
>
Talking to some of them, you will find that almost all of them are
clueless about what they're selling and drugs in general.  Others will
lie.

>      Try and get whatever you want through someone you trust.
>
And that's still no guarantee of safety.
>Love ya guyzzzz. . .

There was the funny case of the stewardess on an airline that came up
for drug testing and drank some number of gallons of water to flush
her system ( because she had been told it would flush the drugs/residue
out ).... anyway after doing this and gaining altitude on a flight she
became so intoxicated and out of it that she had to be relieved of duty...
It made the papers...

Past the point she hit... intoxication can indeed become an even deadly
problem... proving that there's always too much of a even a good thing.

On Tue, 16 Jul 1996, Renaud Waldura wrote:

> Randy C Cone wrote:
> > 
> > Just so folks know; I videotape at some parties and my material IS NOT 
> > for sale. To Fox or anyone else. I use it for class projects, to teach 
> > myself video limits, for memories and to use for projections at future 
> > parties.
> 
> 	Mmmmmh, I'm pretty sure that your intentions are very pure, but,
> 	no way!, I just don't feel at ease when being tapped at a rave.
> 

Just ask me not to and I won't video tape you if I can help it.



> 	I feel like videotapers are more "greedy," they "take" much more
> 	than they "give", they kinda put themselves "out" of the event by
> 	hiding behind a camera. Imagine more than 50% of the people at a 
> 	party trying to tape it... What? Everybody would just look stupid, 
> 	and the vibe would be ruined.

Maybe we could throw a video tapers only party? What if all the video 
tapers were on ketamine? 
 In some ways I sympathise and agree with your position but again, video 
tapers are like any group of people; some good, some bad, most somewhere 
in the middle. Anyone who knows me much at all knows that I give a LOT 
to the scene (in my own limited way).


> 	So I _really_ dislike being shot at a rave. I don't really feel like 
> 	this in general, it's just that I don't feel it fits. Have you ever 
> 	seen rave pictures? Honestly it's not really great, neither is 
> 	footage... Is it? It seems like this material manage to get only 
> 	1/3 of the event; maybe is it because nobody has found a way to 
> 	catch Vibe on film yet ;)


I use to know some Dead Head tapers and one common thread was that the 
best shows are never taped. Kinda a post-romantic attitude if you ask me, 
but not totally without some merit. Actually, in video taping  only 
about 10 % (if that) gets used after editing (for most purposes other 
than family shots of the kids for instance). My perspective of shooting 
people is that I treat them roughly with the same respect they treat me. 
A courteous request for anonymity will be instantly met. However I feel 
very strongly that in public I can do whatever I want. If you are doing 
something in public that you feel should not be documented than perhaps 
you shouldn't be doing it in public (like comsuming drugs). This is a 
personal opinion of course and I'm willing to entertain different opinions 
on this. In general I try to respect others while capturing material that 
I can utilise for my artistic impulses.



> 	I don't have anything against videotapers, I just want to make
> 	sure with this post that they realize that some people (me included)
> 	are not at ease with the idea of their image being caught at a rave
> 	and thrown around the world (maybe not, but how can I know?)
> 	It's my liberty NOT to be tapped, right? But how can I enforce it?


Believe me, most video tapers are SO aware how much some people don't like 
being video taped. It is part of the thrill of doing it. And actually it 
is not your liberty (legally) to stop someone from video taping in the 
public arena. It is a free country, especially in the public arena. 
 I really feel that there should be an attempt at respect for people on 
each side of the camera. If you request that you, personally,  not be 
video taped and that person does so anyway I would encourage a like show 
of respect by throwing water or something on their camera (salt water is 
especially nasty to video cams ;) ) Squirt guns maybe? ;)






> 
> 	So please consider it twice before bringing your video stuff at a
> 	rave, thanx!
> Renaud
> 


I consider it many times and usually ask for permission from promoters 
before I bring my cam. Promoters can also support folks who feel this way 
by barring videotaping and discharging those wideo tapers  who don't 
comply.


Peace 


Ran

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 16 20:37:47 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA22927; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 20:37:47 -0700
Received: from lettuce.salinas.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA22909; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 20:37:43 -0700
Received: from 13474597.mcoe.k12.ca.us (silver.salinas.net [205.179.129.141]) by lettuce.salinas.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) with SMTP id TAA00429 for <SFRaves@Hyperreal.com>; Tue, 16 Jul 1996 19:47:21 -0700

X-Sender: silver@salinas.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: SFRaves@Hyperreal.com
From: "SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey'" <silver@salinas.net>
Subject: Computers,Anti-Technology Musings,(Long) sorta NRR....
Sender: owner-sfraves@Hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

And now for something entirely different....threadwise.....

Disclaimer: This is Long..and represents this afternoon's writings and
musings. Exit now, if you're not interested or think it is NRR. Thanks to
those who read. 

Since we're Geeks....an wedded to computer technology in our jobs and for
many of you in college.....I would welcome any feedback on my rantings and
ravings.

After writing a grant for 1.5 million dollars over a 5 year period, to
tranform a traditional high school, with much of it spent on new technology,
and teaching at the Junior College and High School levels..and a 10 year
believer in the promise of technology...I am now confounded and perplexed. 

Do the new technologies really improve
learning,(reading,writing,math,thinking) or are we just learning more and
more about new, expensive, and rapidly changing technologies? Is there some
strange paradox at work between learning and the increased dependence on
computers? What the computer giveth, does it also taketh away?

..I am thinking about putting together a talk, article or some consulting
services for the K-12 educational establishment.(This is the nuts and bolts
of that) Flame and Fire away at me if you wish...but I have been playing
devil's advocate with myself this morning...and the range of opinion, and
perspective of SFR is always interesting on any topic....or just tell me to
fuck off!!!

 I am going to assert heretically,(burn me at the stake) that K-12 schools
severely reduce the money expenditures spent on attempting to put computers
in every room, link every room to the internet, and that expending hugh
amounts of already limited resources of such rapidly changing technologies
is folly (evidence schools which still have Mac IIe labs and 286's)--

Evidence the new innovations and products featured in WIRED from month to
month!!If not provided by your company or school, how much of your equipment
is already obsolete?

Before money can be budgeted,teacher's trained, technology installed,
maintained,and students taught--the technology is obsolete, and it comes
from and industry that "plans obsolesence."(Windows 95,er, Windows 97 that
is!!!) 

Apple is announcing another 250 million dollar loss this quarter, putting
its total near a billion dollars lost. What effect would the collapse of
Apple have on k-12 schools which are largely Apple only schools.

My thesis is that money spent on this be limited to scaled-down Computer
Departments in K-12. The lion's share of money should be spent by
individuals, Junior Colleges,Technical Schools,Colleges, and the business
community itself.

 Neighborhood schools, given their current circumstances, and the increasing
rate of change and product development from the computer industry, will fall
further and further behind cutting edge developments. Their best efforts can
only appear as a "drop of green in a sea of red incarnadine."(Macbeth) 

Nevertheless, schools with vast amounts of technology have faired no better
on the SAT test, than schools with just pencils and books. Computers may not
simply extend or improve literacy. What do computers improve besides their
own use? They may, in fact, have replaced traditional literacy, with
electronic media...and so far, the effects on learning are not that
encouraging. 

While I am looking and studying this philosophically, I am approaching this
primarily for its pragmatic, cost-effectiveness to k-12 schools. After ten
years, billions of dollars, and millions of computers in schools....where is
the Magic Bullet?? Where is the Modern Miracle??????

In the wake of the Unabomber Manifesto, and other recent anti-technology
books; The Gutenberg Elegies by Sven Birkets, Amusing Ourselves to Death by
Neil Postman, and A is for Ox "The Collapse of Literacy and the Rise of
Violence in the Electronic Age,  by Barry Sanders......

.......I am wondering if those of us who so eagerly embraced the new
interactivity of computers,cd-roms,webs,hyperlinks,electronic books,etc..are
having any second thoughts about the "brave new world?"

Unlike the hippies, who embraced the Romantics for their back to the land,
filthy lucre($$$$), anti-government, anti-industrial
themes,Geeks,Nurdboys,and techno-ravers have hitched our wagons to the
progressive scientific materialism of the late 18th century; i.e.,a belief
that the end of all this scientific progress will be positive, and possibily
result in some form of utopian society or enlightened community. 

For man freed from physical labor,would be free to educate himself,create
abundant material wealth sufficient for all, and transform an adversarial
political system into a cooperative one. Does there seem to be a utopia at
the end of this technological tunnel? 

This is the Information Age isn't it...but people don't really seem to value
the information (paradox principle)  We seem more interested in the Messager
than the Message (paradox principle at work again.)

A brief look back at the history of the machine and it's technological
babies shows us that the writers and thinkers of each epoch heralded the
"new" gadget as the coming New Savior, a messiah or MAGIC BULLET to cure
every social ill.

I'm gonna fast-forward here, past the machine age to the Information
Age--The radio,the television, were thought to bring access to information,
once only reserved for the elite. Television,(once thought to provide the
common man with the equivalent of a college education, has trivialized
politics, and replaced high culture with entertainment only. Also, it has
replaced reading the paper as a major source of information. Newspaper
subscriptions are dropping, book sales are likewise falling.  In fact, the
computer and the net threaten to replace the printed word and the television
altogether. What are the possible consequences of that?

If you don't know, the US ranks last in literacy among industrialized
nations, while we have the greatest access to
libraries,newspapers,bookstores,television,
computers,(all manner of electronic media)--every accessment indicator says
that we are reading less, and know less as a general populace.(The paradox
principle)

We have the highest prison popluation, 80% of whom are illiterates. In the
area of public debate, we might be better served to address some gang
members,criminals, and drop-outs as illiterates to emphasize the problem,
for without literacy, one cannot be a functioning member of society.
                                1(Barry Sanders--A is for Ox)

 However, it appears, like the world of economics,  the rich are getting
richer, and the poor getting poorer, while the technological elite are
getting more skilled and educated, while the middle and lower class, are
less informed and unskilled.

So, is the computer of the 90's really the television of the 50's???Just
another diabolical gadget? In the past few days, it has been the technology
stocks that have triggered the 7-10% drop in value on the Dow. Nasdaq
(primarily tech) stocks dropped 15 per cent. Bill Gates stock holdings
dropped 200-300 million dollars in value. Wouldn't you like that problem??????

 Is the market losing its belief in sustained technological change and
unrelenting innovation.  Anybody for putting the Genie back in the bottle???
But since there is no going back, what does the future really hold in store
for us? How do you stop a runaway train anyway?

 I think, we just might be that we are more the by-product of the word, than
we are the result of biology and genetics.

                     SpinSilver..............somewhere lost in thought
                                             in monterey......robertj

  Hi all.
  I had a really bad commute home today, and I'm new to the area & haven't
got any friends to call and cry at.  I just need to get some stuff off my
shoulders.  This is a personal, NRR post.  Skip it if you don't care to
read about my feelings.
  Argh.  I take the CalTrain home, live in SF, work in Palo Alto.  I don't
mind the lengthy commute, it gives me time to read.  Anyway, today the
train was stopped just before Redwood City - a southbound train hit and
killed someone at that stop.  It broke my heart.  Then I tune into some of
the conversations and mutterings around me... people saying awful things
like "another fucking suicide..."  Everyone seemed to be focused on the
"delay" part of the announcement, rather than the "fatal" part.  Even if
it was a suicide, does that make it less tragic?  Don't people empathize
with the misery someone would have to feel to step in front of a train
moving 70mph?
  I was pretty much stunned, feeling deeply hurt and saddened.  And then
we started moving again, and one of the conductors was being a jerk,
shoving people around and bellowing... urgh.  And then, on the bus, there
were some young men sitting behind me being really insensitive.  One was
blaring some really awful music (I mean the lyrics, the message - I can't
judge the music, but there is no excuse for music that actively promotes
murder, racism, & the debasement of women)  The other was smoking crack.
I choose not to use drugs - I respect the choice of others to do so, and
don't mind being around them (how could I rave otherwise?) when they do.
But the second-hand smoke from crack is quite intoxicating.  I had no
desire for a confrontation, so I got off the bus.  Crack freaks me out.  I
would have been almost equally upset by someone smoking a cigarette or a
joint on a public bus, but probably wouldn't have felt the need to get
off & walk.  It strikes me as really insensitive to expose people to
dangerous side-effects of a drug, whatever that may be.  At a rave, I make
a conscious decision to allow myself to be exposed to such effects.  I
have made no such choice when I ride the city bus.
  Argh.  I just saw way more than my share of insensitive, cold, cynical
people on the way home from work today.  I don't get it - how can people
be so self-centered?  Doesn't it hurt to hear that a life has ended,
regardless of whose life?
  On a day like today, it's hard to cope emotionally without some support.
I could really use a hug or a couple of vibes in the right direction.
Someone to tell me I'm not crazy to feel hurt and upset by these things.
  Thanks...

: : J. David Lowe ::: dlowe@best.com ::: ai334@freenet.carleton.ca : :
:: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ ::::: ftp://ftp.best.com/web1/dlowe/ ::
 : : : : : : : : : finger for pgp key and geek code : : : : : : : : :

Subject: Re: TECHNO, JAZZ, & CLASSICAL MUSIC.....
In-Reply-To: <2.2.32.19960716204542.0073c9f8@sanfrancisco01.pop.internex.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960716225152.27640A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



  Seems to me that the main unity among all three is that they started 
out as dance music.
  Classical music came out of the confluence of two traditions: sacred
music, which helped carry the religious message of the service, and
secular music, which was dance music from the taverns to the courts.  A
lot of the names of movements of early classical music came from the
dance (gigue, bouree, chaconne, etc.).  But little by little, the "get up
and dance" part of classical music disappeared. There are still folks who
do classical waltz today; but it is professional ballet that carries on
most of the dance part of classical music.  Dancing to classical music,
however, isn't for the plain folks. If you got up during a classical
concert and started to boogie, you'd be thrown out or locked up. 
  Jazz had something like the same beginnings: the blue notes and rhythms
of spirituals worked their way into the early jazz played at brothels in
New Orleans. Then, with the advent of bebop in the 40s and 50s, folks
stopped dancing to jazz (Charlie Mingus used to tell people who started to
dance at his gigs to sit down, shut up, and listen). "You can't wiggle
your butt and really listen at the same time," John Handy once said. So,
though there are still folks who dance to jazz, jazz dance is becoming
more and more of a hobby form: something you learn because you're
interested in the genre, noty because it has a life of its own with broad
popular support. Jazz itself, like classical music, is in danger of
becoming a museum form: a tiny corner of the music world that can't
support itself without government and private grants to keep it alive. 
I hope this doesn't come to pass. Jazz is America's greatest contribution 
to the music of the human race, and deserves to survive on its own 
without institutional transfusions of cash.
  Techno seems to me to have been born without the sacred roots. Some 
trance and ambient seem at times to be headed in the cosmic direction; 
but the roots of the music are secular. Whether or not techno musicians 
can make music that appeals to people in future generations remains to be 
seen. If not.... then picture yourself as Gramps or Grandma in the year 
2050, with the young whippersnappers snickering, "Oh wow! That old-time 
techno is REALLY funny! Imagine people actually wanting to listen to 
thump-music for hours!"

At 08:44 PM 7/16/96 -0700, David Lowe wrote:
>the train was stopped just before Redwood City - a southbound train hit and
>killed someone at that stop.  It broke my heart.  Then I tune into some of
>the conversations and mutterings around me... people saying awful things
>like "another fucking suicide..."  Everyone seemed to be focused on the
>"delay" part of the announcement, rather than the "fatal" part.  Even if
>it was a suicide, does that make it less tragic?

It is a defense mechanism.  Most of them would be afraid to show any
significant emotion in such a public place.  Our culture vaues toughness so
very much more than openness and sharing.   Even more, many of them
are not really that sure that they could not end up in a similar situation.
(Is that what happens when you LOSE the rat race?)

>Don't people empathize with the misery someone would have to feel to step
>in front of a train moving 70mph?

They make remarks such as those to try to _avoid_ empathizing.

>  I was pretty much stunned, feeling deeply hurt and saddened.  And then
>we started moving again, and one of the conductors was being a jerk,
>shoving people around and bellowing... urgh.

That sounds like _his_ defense mechanism.  In some railroad people the sorrow
over these tragedies turns into anger.  Not excusable, but not typical either.
Caltrain conductors are mostly very nice and professional.

It's very hard on the engineer, of course.  All he can do is slam on the brakes
which will stop the train about half a mile later, blow the horn and watch.


Rave is an antidote for some of the conditions that make people jump in
front of trains.

A place of Peace and Unity, which to Love and Respect,
 to Be One's Self and to Be Loved and Respected As One's Self.
The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: RE: Videotaping 
To: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>, Renaud Waldura <rw@softway.com>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Some interesting points have been made on VideoTaping.  I think it was   
Heisenberg who first recognized this important scientific principle: to   
observe is to disturb.  In scientific circles, it means that any system   
you wish to observe is changed by virtue of the fact that you observe it.   
 In raves, it means that by trying to record the vibe, you can disturb   
it, even destroy it in the extreme case.  People can't let go when they   
know they are being observed, and a camera is the coldest of observers.

It's something to think about.  Videotaping a public event may be within   
the bounds of one's rights, but if many find it disturbing, then perhaps   
it's not within the bounds of courtesy.
 -Roy

Welcome David,

Sorry to hear that you had a bad rave day. My not so vast, yet pleasant experiences, have brought
me to the conclusion that the smaller parties are the best place to start; if the people and the
vibe are what your looking for. "New Moon",  "F&F", "Tribal Future",  "Sunset",  "F8" and our very own
"BBQ & beats" are a few that I would recommend. Try meeting up with a few of the "sfraves"
members at one of these or other parties. I have found them to be quite good company on various
outings. I think the "smaller space",  "fewer distractions" angle gives you a better chance to spot
,and consequently meet, some our local ravers. Then set ready to make your own vivacious vibe.


Take care,
                     Jason

To: "INTERNET:SteveOSac@aol.com" <SteveOSac@aol.com>

Good day,

>>I am very sad about our dear brother Matt Lanier's decision to leave the list.  I certainly hope he
>>recondiders his decision, and realizes the value of his input as a person and as a member of
>>his faith.  I am more sad about the passive tolerance and even support of such negative,
>>degrading and disrespectful posts such as those by our list mate Neils Mayer. 
>>I suppose I can now agree it be high time we take Todd's preverbial baseball bat to this thread
>>before any more damage is done.

>>pluR, StEvEo

I don't believe that we can expect others to act or react as we would like them to. PLUR is a 
wonderful concept I hope catches on; and I am trying day by day to incorporate it into my life.
But I don't see where it is always possible for me, with my beliefs, to practice it. Certains actions,
I think, deserve an opposite and not always equal reaction. This can empower people to affect my
actions: a weakness to be carefully monitored. But, I cannot let go of my instinct to react during
"extreme" situations. Especially if it is someone I care about. 

And then there are THOSE instances...man hits old lady in jaw and runs off with her purse....

Do you?
 
a]  watch him run off
b]  check to see if the victim is alright
c]  step on the gas pedal, knock him down, jump out and whack him as he tries again to flee

In this situation, and it was a real live one folks, I don't see how plur applies. 

I guess my point is that anything taken too far, even plur, can get ridiculous. 

This doesn't mean that we can't be civil and caring in our daily interactions with those around us;
to create for ourselves a better world in which to live. It's that whole "do unto others" thing.

Be kind and take care,
                                            Jason

P.S. It's difficult to come back to civilization after a week of camping bliss. IT'S not very civilized.

Subject: The Perils of Raving In The Summer

Dear All;

        It's that time of year again. I thought I would offer up a little
loving reminder. Hey, I want to go to raves; not funerals for my friends.

        From Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary:

        dehydration: 1. Removal of water from a substance. 2. Contrition
resulting
         from excessive loss of body fluid intake. Occurs when output of
fluid         
        exceeds fluid intake. May result from fluid deprivation, excess loss
of fluid,      
        reduction in total quantity of electrolytes, or injection of
hypertonic         
        solutions. 

        water intoxication: 1. Intoxication ingesting large quantities of
water or from 
        kidney disorders that reduce urinary output. Symptoms include headache, 
        dizziness, vomiting, convulsions and coma. Death may result.

        heat cramps: 1. Acute painful spasms of voluntary muscles following
hard 
        work in a hot environment without adequate fluid & salt intake; in 
        other words a rave.

        F.A: remove the patient to a cool place and give a salt solution
(1/4 tsp, or 1g 
        of table salt in a glass of water) by mouth. Repeat at 5 - 30 minute
intervals 
        until cramping stops.

        heat exhaustion: Acute reaction to heat exposure. Not the same as
heat         
        stroke.  See either attached heat.gif or heat.psd for a table of
differences

        heatstroke: 1. An acute & dangerous reaction to heat exposure.         
        Characterized by high body temperature, usually above 105 degrees F
(40.6 
        degrees C); cessation of sweating, headache, numbness;tingling and
        confusion prior to sudden delirium or coma; fast pulse; rapid
respiratory 
        rate; usually elevated blood pressure. The basic defect is failure
of the heat 
        regulating mechanisms of the body.

        TREATMENT: Effective therapy may save the patient's life. Without
delay, 
        the patient should be placed in a bathtub filled with ice water,
preferably 
        nude. This will not cause pain, shock, or cutaneous
vasoconstriction. The 
        patient's temperature will need to be monitored carefully. Remove
from bath 
        when temperature fall below 103 degree F (39.4 degrees C). If ice
water & 
        bathtub are not available, place wet sheets on nude body, fan
vigorously, 
        and massage the skin. The use of sedatives may be required to control 
        convulsions. Careful observation of patients for signs of fluid
imbalance and 
        renal failure will be required for several days.

        Remember to keep track of how much water you have consumed, and use
good, simple common sense. Please, please take care of yourselves; it starts
with you!!!!

Peace
Brian

" The funny thing about regret is...."

Well the funny thing about video taping is.... most people are shy or at
least affected by being taped BUT in my experience they love it when they
see themselves up on the large screen LATER..... (usually)

 Like Randy I also video tape as some events ( I'm a visual's guy after
all ) and occasionally people ( often who don't know me ) are at least
shy or at most paranoid about it... I'm always open to them asking me what
I'm up to and I'm personally very careful not to overextend my welcome and
very sensitive about not poking the camera into private moments like drug
taking, sexual experession etc..... further more I carefully edit before
I show anything....

  But then I sometimes tape because I love the scene not because I want to
expose it to harsh or unjust critism..... thus I act accordingly....

Mike

>guy at a rave drank something like 4 gallons of water.  Apparantly, at that
>point a condition called water toxicity reveals itself and the person

Just heard about an article in a UK rave publication that says they are
investigating the effects of E on the body's ability to regulate water
level and sodium levels.  Yes, you can drink too much water and bring your
sodium level so low you are in serious danger.  Plus, like all drugs, it
varies with the individual.

These are not toys to be taken lightly.

Precedence: bulk


> not that DXM is for everyone.
> i tried it a couple times, it just made me sick to my stomach for a while,
> then i felt like i was drunk and somewhat "floaty".
> 
	The "sick" feelings come from the nasty syrup that the DXM is
usually sold in, not from DXM itself. There are ways to extract the DXM
from the syrup to avoid this, if it is really a problem. Additionally,
many people don't take enough DXM to reach the interesting "plateaus",
and DXM is a VERY "dose centric" drug - taking a dose below one of the
thresholds will have significantly different effects than a dose of just
a little more that puts you over the threshold. You have to keep track of
the mg/kg ratio and taking the same amount as your friend who weighs 120lb
when you weigh 150lb isn't going to work.

	The fun stuff starts at 7.5mg/kg for most people, and I frequently
am taking it in the 11 to 13mg/kg range. This means, for example, that
I need to drink _3_ of the 4oz (30mg variety) bottles to reach that point.
ONE 4oz bottle is not enough for anyone to get interesting effects, unless
you weigh 90lb or something...

				Marisa

Tyrosine is good for catecholamine depletion..
Any drug that releases dopamine will make you feel tired afterward,
so stock up on tyrosine if you indulge.. Make sure you drink a lot of 
water too..  I have heard that dehydration is crucial in the England deaths..

best advice, stay away from anything you don't know intimately..

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 17 10:04:46 1996

Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id JAA29812 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 09:49:22 -0700
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 1996 09:49:22 -0700
Message-Id: <199607171649.JAA29812@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: SRR: Montel Williams and Ephedrine
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey, did anyone see the Montel Williams show last night?  (Or am I the only 
one who thrives on 5 hours of sleep?)  It was about the perils of ephedrine.

The guests:
        A couple who had lost their son after he suffered
        massive coronary failure.  He was a high school football
        player, 6'1", 200 lbs., athletic, and he had been taking 
        a dietary supplement that contained ephedrine.

        A pharmacologist.  A very fired up individual who was
        incensed over the rampant selling of ephedrine in 
        everything from dietary supplements to legal
        recreational substances.

        Two teenagers that took large doses of ephedrine to get
        high.

        A body builder who had been taking energy boosters
        containing ephedrine, and who had suffered a minor
        stroke and is still slightly brain damaged.

        AND...  The CEO of Herbal Exctasy (sp?), Sean something.

I gotta tell ya, Sean came off like a serious money grubbing jerk on this 
show.  He went on and on about how ephedrine in an herb like Ma Huang was 
far safer than the ephedrine found in "drugs".  He kept asserting that there 
was a distinction to be made between herbs and chemicals, as if the two have 
no connection.  He purported to have some kind of expertise in pharmacology 
but would not mention where he got this knowledge except to say he'd been to 
some private schools and talked to some people, none of which he would name. 
 He hid behind the wording on the packaging of his product, as if that 
absolved him of any responsibility.  He claimed ignorance of or refused to 
acknowledge

        1. anyone abusing his product by not following
           the directions and taking either too many or
           taking it too frequently, or both,
        2. anyone using the product below the age of 18,
        3. and any delitirious effects of Ma Huang.

He came on the show with a t-shirt on that had the phone number for ordering 
his product.  At one point he admitted to Montel that his primary motivation 
was to make money, and he began trying to make it look as though what he was 
doing, selling a potentially dangerous substance that wasn't literally 
illegal was in effect a battle for Constitutional integrity.  I imagine the 
next step would have been for him to wrap himself in an American flag and 
start singing the "Star Spangled Banner".

Give me a break.

Y'know, if you want to alter your state of mind with various substances, 
fine.  If you want to sell those substances, legal or illegal, whatever.  
But let's not kid ourselves.  Sean made a statement somewhere along the line 
that people have a right to be informed, but he's dodging the issue by 
avoiding the questions, fabricating factoids, and being disingenuous.

One of the things that griped me was his hiding behind the "herbs are safer" 
myth.  Folx, think about it:  Plants have varying levels of a given 
chemical.  But distill the target chemical out and you can at least control 
the dosage.  With Ma Huang, you don't really know how much or how little 
ephedrine there is in a set amount of the herb.  You could be taking a 
really large amount or a really small amount.  There's very little control 
there.  At least when it's distilled out there's some control over the 
amount being taken.  Not that I'm advocating the use of ephedrine.  
Personally I think it's nasty stuff.  It's fat soluble, so it has a very 
long half-life in the human body, allowing the substance to accrue in your 
system with regular usage until, although you're taking small amounts, the 
overall level in your system reaches an extremely high toxic level.  I'm 
just saying that "natural" doesn't mean safe.  Hemlock is natural and it 
will kill you.  Ephedrine occurs naturally in Ma Huang.  Extract it and what 
do you have?  Ephedrine.  Same chemical, same effects.  Period.  Same with 
caffiene.  Is caffiene better for you when it comes naturally in coffee than 
when you pick up caffiene tablets at Walgreens?  Or do both make you jittery 
and cause you to write long missives about jerks you see on late night TV?

Ok...  I'm laying off now.  But after seeing this guy on TV, I'm more 
convinced than ever that what we have in Sean is the typical dark side of 
the American success story: someone selling a product that's dangerous but 
not illegal for as long as they can get away with it because there's a huge 
market for it among those not bright enough to think for themselves.

Nuff said.

S

     You're all wet.  Although 'water toxicity' is possible, I think the 
     point is it's better to have a little too much than a little too 
     little.  Dancing, hot rooms, fans, excitement, and hot audio and video 
     equipment are all a good reason to be thirsty.  I guess if you find 
     yourself bloated and unable to move in a pile of empty Evian bottles 
     you've gone too far, but cool heads prevail.  Carry water with you, 
     and if your mouth feels dry, or it seems like a good idea, drink it.
     
     Andy
     
     I can just imagine the Burning Man headlines... Hundreds dehydrated 
     due to local San Francisco overhydration scare.  Film at 11.


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: dehydration + E
Author:  Steve Morgan <smorgan@best.com> at smtplink-acs
Date:    7/16/96 6:49 PM


     
     
>water. You can't overhydrate yourself, and if you somehow did, there's 
>enough electrolytes in ordinary water to keep your bodies leveles balanced 
>(unless it's distilled). 
     
Actually, you can.  There is such a thing called overhydration (water 
toxicity) or too much water!  There was a case I recall in England where a 
guy at a rave drank something like 4 gallons of water.  Apparantly, at that 
point a condition called water toxicity reveals itself and the person 
becomes seriously illin'. It is one of the few deaths that has occured in 
the UG scene as an indirect result of E.
     
Anyone else heard of this?
     
Drenched,
     
Steve

Greetings Friends =)

Barring any disasters at the printer, we will have FnF tickets available
this Saturday at the SFR BBQ and Beats gathering a well as at Sunset on
sunday. As usual they will be really nice flourescent laminates =)

I *strongly* encourage those of you that want tickets to get them at either
of these events, they may be gone my monday. Just ask soemone wearing one
of those flourescent smileys you've prolly been seeing, they can prolly
point you in the right direction =)

I also wanted to mention that this party will be a benefit for
hyperreal.com, the system this list runs on and indeed a bastion of
electronic music, rave and alternative culture not only locally but
worldwide. Unfortunately our budget for this party, with a a donation of
$5, is right at the break-even point. We will, therefore, have a donation
box at the party and I personally would encourage everyone to support this
amazing and ongoing project. Many, many thanks to Brian and to everyone
else that has made hyperreal what it is. Nice one.

love ya
ethan

At  7:58 PM 7/16/96 -0700, Randy C Cone wrote:
>On Tue, 16 Jul 1996, Renaud Waldura wrote:
>

>
>>       So I _really_ dislike being shot at a rave. I don't really feel like
>>       this in general, it's just that I don't feel it fits. Have you ever
>>       seen rave pictures? Honestly it's not really great, neither is
>>       footage... Is it? It seems like this material manage to get only
>>       1/3 of the event; maybe is it because nobody has found a way to
>>       catch Vibe on film yet ;)
>
I beg your pardon Renaud, I think some rave pictures are fantastic and
definately give some vibe of what raving is about. Unfortunately there are
not many good or great photographers in the rave scene. I don't mean to
toot my own horn here, but I think you should look at some photographs I
took at Sunset a  couple years ago (http://www.bigz.com).

>
>I use to know some Dead Head tapers and one common thread was that the
>best shows are never taped. Kinda a post-romantic attitude if you ask me,
>but not totally without some merit. Actually, in video taping  only
>about 10 % (if that) gets used after editing (for most purposes other
>than family shots of the kids for instance). My perspective of shooting
>people is that I treat them roughly with the same respect they treat me.
>A courteous request for anonymity will be instantly met. However I feel
>very strongly that in public I can do whatever I want. If you are doing
>something in public that you feel should not be documented than perhaps
>you shouldn't be doing it in public (like comsuming drugs). This is a
>personal opinion of course and I'm willing to entertain different opinions
>on this. In general I try to respect others while capturing material that
>I can utilise for my artistic impulses.
>
>
>
>>       I don't have anything against videotapers, I just want to make
>>       sure with this post that they realize that some people (me included)
>>       are not at ease with the idea of their image being caught at a rave
>>       and thrown around the world (maybe not, but how can I know?)
>>       It's my liberty NOT to be tapped, right? But how can I enforce it?
>
>
>Believe me, most video tapers are SO aware how much some people don't like
>being video taped. It is part of the thrill of doing it. And actually it
>is not your liberty (legally) to stop someone from video taping in the
>public arena. It is a free country, especially in the public arena.
> I really feel that there should be an attempt at respect for people on
>each side of the camera. If you request that you, personally,  not be
>video taped and that person does so anyway I would encourage a like show
>of respect by throwing water or something on their camera (salt water is
>especially nasty to video cams ;) ) Squirt guns maybe? ;)
>
>
>
>
>
>
>>
>>       So please consider it twice before bringing your video stuff at a
>>       rave, thanx!
>> Renaud
>>
>
>
>I consider it many times and usually ask for permission from promoters
>before I bring my cam. Promoters can also support folks who feel this way
>by barring videotaping and discharging those wideo tapers  who don't
>comply.
>
>
>Peace
>
>
>Ran
>
>
>                          -=*=-
>                            ~

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9606178376.AA837624695@smtplink.acer.com> from "Andy Wyszkowski" at Jul 16, 96 08:28:30 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
>      You're all wet.  Although 'water toxicity' is possible, I think the 
>      point is it's better to have a little too much than a little too 
>      little.  Dancing, hot rooms, fans, excitement, and hot audio and video 
>      equipment are all a good reason to be thirsty.  I guess if you find 
>      yourself bloated and unable to move in a pile of empty Evian bottles 
>      you've gone too far, but cool heads prevail.  Carry water with you, 
>      and if your mouth feels dry, or it seems like a good idea, drink it.
>      
>      Andy

Sure, a little too much is okay.  A little too little is okay too.  I think
what people are worried about here is a case where someone is feeling bad
because of too much of drug x or y or z and thinks "OK, I'll just hydrate
myself out of it."  

First of all, maybe this false confidence can mask a real problem, and
second of all, yes, there is the possibility of overhydration.  Water
seems so harmless, and I can see where someone could get into the 
"more is better" mind set  (Naw, not a raver, they never think that ;) )
and get him/herself into trouble.  So yeah, you've REALLY got to overdo
it to become overhydrated, but it's important that people know the
possibility exists. 

>      I can just imagine the Burning Man headlines... Hundreds dehydrated 
>      due to local San Francisco overhydration scare.  Film at 11.

Ack!  :)

Smiles,

	Chin

To: mtn-raves <mtn-raves@hyperreal.com>, hamm_j@motsat.sat.mot.com
Subject: Re: VPL: TAN: Thinkers Anonymous (fwd)

> > >     To all my Deep Thinking Friends:
> > >
> > > It started out innocently enough.  I began to think at parties now
> > > and then to loosen up.  Inevitably though, one thought led to
> > > another, and soon I was more  than just a social thinker.
> > >
> > > I began to think alone -"to relax," I told myself - but I knew it
> > > wasn't true. Thinking became more and more important to me, and
> > > finally I was thinking all the time.  I began to think on the job.
> > > I knew that thinking and employment don't mix, but I couldn't stop
> > > myself.
> > >
> > > I began to avoid friends at lunch time so I could read Thoreau and
> > > Kafka.  I would return to the office dizzied and confused, asking,
> > > "What is it exactly we are doing here?"
> > >
> > > Things weren't going so great at home either.  One evening I had
> > > turned off the TV and asked my wife about the meaning of life.  She
> > > spent that night at her mother's.
> > >
> > > I soon had a reputation as a heavy thinker.  One day the boss
> > > called me in.  He  said, "Skippy, I like you, and it hurts me to
> > > say this, but your thinking has become a real problem.  If you
> > > don't stop thinking on the job, you'll have to find another job."
> > > This gave me a lot to think about.
> > >
> > > I came home early after my conversation with my boss.  "Honey,"
> > > I confessed, "I've been thinking..."
> > > "I know you've been thinking," she said, "and I want a divorce!"
> > > "But Honey, surely it's not that serious."
> > > "It is serious," she said, lower lip a-quiver.  "You think as
> > > much as university professors, and university professors don't
> > > make any money, so if you keep on thinking we won't have any
> > > money!"
> > > "That's a faulty syllogism," I said impatiently, and she began
> > > to cry.  I'd had  enough.  "I'm going to the library," I snarled
> > > as I stomped out the door.
> > >
> > > I headed for the library, in the mood for some Nietzsche, with
> > > a PBS station on  the radio.  I roared into the parking lot and
> > > ran up to the big glass doors...they didn't open.  The library
> > > was closed.  To this day, I believe that a Higher Power was
> > > looking out for me that night.
> > >
> > > As I sank to the ground clawing at the unfeeling grass, whimpering
> > > for Zarathustra, a poster caught my eye.
> > > "Friend, is heavy thinking ruining your life?" it asked.  You
> > > probably recognize that line.  It comes from the standard Thinker's
> > > Anonymous poster.  Which is why I am what I am today: a recovering
> > > thinker.  I never miss a TA meeting.  At each meeting we watch a
> > > non-educational video; last week it was "Porky's."  Then we share
> > > experiences about how we avoided thinking since the  last meeting.
> > >
> > > I still have my job, and things are a lot better at home.  Life
> > > just seemed...easier, somehow, as soon as I stopped thinking.

Good day,

I think it's a great idea to try and capture the moment on film.  Precautions must be taken to keep
photos that may contain illegal activities from the public forum.  Beyond that, what's wrong with
trying to help remember all of the wonderful times we've had, and who we've had them with?
In the scope of history past, do you really think today's raver will end up trying to deny, at some
congressional subcommittee, that he or she inhaled?  If our rights to express ourselves freely
diminishes much more, these pictures may be the only evidence left to expouse the wonderous 
benefits of music and dance on the human psyche.

Take care,
                     Jason

P.S. Just finished looking at some of my camping trip photos...could that be substance abuse?!!

Actually, I have my own views to what is and is not a raver...

People who are " at parties hootin' at girls and selling bunk e's
and getting free feelies on the dance floor and taking advantage of
people..."  may Go to raves...  

I don't consider them as ravers tho...

A raver, to me expresses a certian degree of "awarness" which others may or
may not sense... Of the very few to whom I really discussed this with have
come to a same conclusion...  We, ravers, are not unlike monks or mystics
that gain thier insight through meditation,  frenzied dance, or just the
association of being in theour SFR community, gaining a concioussness and
communal awareness...

I 'party' every weekend, and in the early years I could relate to scannin the
crowd for "e-gals" or "crossing" (buying a large amt of E @ discounted price
and selling in 1 and 2's at value)...
But as time wore on I choose to which scene I assoicated with.  Being more
underground  and attached to the vibe...  
To me,  in 93 and 94 the scene probabibly had some of the most darkest
aspects of what ravers (just going out to get high and/or laid ect..) were,
and to my understanding this was fuled tremedously by the media...
And, in a way, that was good since it pushed us back into the underground... 


So,  I see thoes that Michal describes on a weekly basis as just flegling
scensters, trying to figure out which path to take and just hope that, in
time, they too might choose thier way...

Wiether thier way  be right or wrong,  light or dark it must be accepted...

"Dance with me.."

-Adam

Jason, bring those to the BBQ, I'd love to see them. What a week of camping
that was. It too bad we do that once a year, but then again we do enough
partying and camping for most of the year in that one week.

I wish everyone on the list could have been there. They would have had a
great time. Camping, party, live band, spinning some records. About 50
people showed and about half left 2 days later when it started to thunder
and rain  alittle. Seperated the true campers and partiers from the week.
It was great. Neither rain, hail, slush and mud didn't ruin it, it was a
blast!! Sitting at the campfire when it was raining was refreshing and not
at all cold. In fact it was nice and cool, maybe body temp.

Did the bear visit again on Monday or tues. Also when you come for the BBQ
can you bring may blue cooler that Steve borrowed and my power strip.

Tim (knucklehead)

Hey, why all the fuss over video taping at rave events?  As long as it does
not interfere with what we're trying to do there.  I mean, we're not ashamed
of who we are and what we do....right?  Sure, our gatherings are personal,
but indiscrete taping should not bother anyone.  Most would not even know it
was occuring.  So I ask again:  we're not ashamed of who we are and what
we're doing....right?  Perhaps, some are actually very reluctant to really
look at themselves afterall.

Being ashamed and breaking the law are tow different things.  I know many 
people that aren't ashamed of smoking pot and are very open about but 
that doesn't mean they want to be filmed partaking of illegal activites 
which could get them arrested?!  I do illegal things sometimes (I'd say 
everyone does but I'd get flamed ;) and I'm not ashamed of them, but I'd 
rather not have those moments/times be publicly accessible.

love drenalin

        "RE: Videotaping" (Jul 17,  2:05pm)
References: <199607172105.OAA26822@mail-gw.fsr.net>

Precedence: bulk

On Jul 17,  2:05pm, Wowser wrote:
> Subject: RE: Videotaping
> Hey, why all the fuss over video taping at rave events?  As long as it does
> not interfere with what we're trying to do there.  I mean, we're not ashamed
> of who we are and what we do....right?  Sure, our gatherings are personal,
> but indiscrete taping should not bother anyone.  Most would not even know it
> was occuring.  So I ask again:  we're not ashamed of who we are and what
> we're doing....right?

It's not really a matter of how we feel about what we do but what other
think and their actions. Your employer or familiy may have a very
different view on what we do and it may have dire consequences if they
would find this on the web. Since I know that in my line of work I'm
kind of limited to larger companies or universities to work at, I prefer
to be somewhat discrete towards them about what I do in my free time.
I feel that if we really want to change something in this world, people
like us should come to positions of power. I have no problem with them
lying about inhaling or whatever, as long as they use there position
for the good of all (unlike the famous non-inhaler). Being too open
about whatever illegal hobby one might have can be very harmful to
the individual, as well as to our scene, since it will not likely be
understood by the Hard Copy type of people...

> Perhaps, some are actually very reluctant to really
> look at themselves afterall.
>
> In Love for Truth,
>
> Troy
>-- End of excerpt from Wowser

The Frying Dutchman

--

Subject: Re: DXM
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

For reference, the one time I did the DXM thing, I ingested 6 ounces of that
lovely syrup we all know and love.  I weigh 135, and let me tell ya, I must
have reached one of those "threshholds".   5 hours of absolute seperation
from my body.  I could not possibly see taking it in any other environment
than a very DARK room, with plenty of music on a 7 disk changer.  Cover up
any lights including the little l.e.d.s on your stereo, they will make you
dizzy beyond comprehension.  Prepare to be completely immobile.
Try this one next time you robe: create an environment, choose your mode of
flight, butterfly wings work well, observe how your music completely changes
your environment as you explore it, measure by measure, song by song.
I can't say I have the urge to do it again, very draining, but I'm glad I
tried it.
-StEvEo

>What is "Trainspotting"?   ANd what does it mean?
>
>Crunchman

Trainspotting is the act of keeping track of Trains and what time they come
and go. It's also a term used to describe people who have to keep track of
all teh hot new singles being played. A trainspotter, for example, would be
the guy right in front of the dj's face asking him what what record
he/she's played right after they're done with the mix.
-peace- alex

Alex Ward
bwret@best.com                         May the Funk be with you...Always.

Ok, the important stuff first.
Thanks to everyone who responded to the BP pictures. The script was a 
total hack in the middle of the night that was completed in 23 seconds, 
but it works. So, please check http://www.lbl.gov/~kumar/bp and send me 
the picture descriptions/script bugs.

Secondly, Promise pictures are in the same format: 
http://www.lbl.gov/~kumar/promise
The promise story is there, lovingly typed in by Andy Wyszkowski.

Finally, my little BP review:

Hmm. Definitely a lot of house. even older-school house. sf never 
reminded me that much of st. louis before.

The last set in the morning, lots of breaks, sf never reminded me that 
much of columbia, mo before.

And all the beautiful people!! Definitely unique to this area. The people 
(even a puck i suppose) made this party really really great, and i thank 
everyone involved with getting this party going.

(oh yeah, the price tag reminded me of st. louis too ;)
some review, huh?
check out the promise pictures

On Wed, 17 Jul 1996, Chris Beaumont wrote:
> Tyrosine is good for catecholamine depletion..
> Any drug that releases dopamine will make you feel tired afterward,
> so stock up on tyrosine if you indulge.. Make sure you drink a lot of 
> water too..  I have heard that dehydration is crucial in the England deaths..

Chris,

I would appreciate a physiological explaination for your claim.  I really
offhand can't think of any, although I'm open to hearing any rationale you
can provide. And by the way, which drug are you referring to that releases
*dopamine*?

Please don't spread information if you really don't know.  And if you *do*
know, provide some references or at least a good explaination so that
people can respond intelligently (or reject it immediately).  Lots of
people without a medical background read this stuff and don't have a frame
of reference to interpret it in.

Thanks,
Paul

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
