     And one from the young and stupid over the counter psychoactive 
     files...
     
     Has anybody ever heard of people taking Marazine (the sea sickness 
     stuff with the green and yellow spiral on the cover) for psychedelic 
     effect?  When I was about 15, I took 16 pills and experienced...
     
     0:00       Took 16 in photo lab at 5th period
     
     1:20       Total Inability to Balance, stagerring like a drunken 
     moron.  Had to get out of my drafting class.  Deadhead desk partner 
     laughing hysterically at how hosed I am.
     
     2:00       Three years later, the bus gets there to take me home.
     
     2:45       Walking home I see my friend Nathan.  I go up to him and he 
     dissappears.
     
     3:00       After almost meeting some other imaginary friends, I 
     realize that I might be hallucinating.
     
     3:10       Oh great mom's home.  Mom notices... Dialated pupils, quick 
     pulse and breathing.  I told her I ran from the bus stop.  Feeling 
     flushed.
     
     3:20       Try to do homework.  Pens dissappearing.  Things moving 
     when I'm not looking.
     
     4:00       Try to watch TV... waaaay to much going on.  Three's 
     Company re-runs shockingly stupid.
     
     4:30       Try to sleep.  Close eyelids.  Wild animals are everywhere. 
      Closing eyes reveals bright warm colors and squishy flowing bodily 
     sensations.  I can't tell when my eyelids are closed or open, as 
     hallucinatory creatures are passing freely between the 'imaginary' 
     (eyes closed) and the 'real' (eyes open).  Put on VanHalen's 1984.  
     Too much.  Put on Peter Gabriel's So.  Much better.  All this time I 
     am experiencing disphoria, but no really negative or sanity 
     questioning effects.  In fact, this seem shockingly normal.  Only 
     annoying affect is the fact that things I need keep appearing, then 
     dissappearing after I try to touch them.
     
     Turned tape over several times.  I put my ear up to the wood members 
     of the bed to hear 'real sound' better.  Time goes to shit.  No clock 
     in my room, and I haven't looked at my watch in a long while.  Tiger 
     jumps through my window and out my door.  I ask my mom to come 
     upstairs.  She shows up, and we're talking as she stands in the door 
     way.  Then my mom walks in, and my other mom disappears and my mom 
     starts asking who I was talking to.  I'm really worried about how 
     worried my mom is, but I have no sense of concern for myself.  I 
     eventually go to sleep, after finding my stuffed tiger from my box of 
     shit I'm too cool to leave out anymore.  I dream of stones at the 
     bottom of a running river, and clouds, and a benevolent angel.  Strong 
     music throughout the dream sounds like end of 'I am the Walrus' by the 
     Beatles, with a little of that Ofra Haza quality thrown in.
     
     Next day, still feel weird.  Friends who told me about Marazine admit 
     the had never heard of somebody taking 16, but that 'someone they 
     knew' had taken 12.  Weirdness tapers off after a couple days.  
     Closest 'common' drug might be mescaline (never have done peyote 
     proper).  Seems like this would definitely be a set and setting 
     drug...
     
     Final disclaimer... I would never do it again, because of the 
     headaches I got for a couple weeks afterwards, and the dizzy spells I 
     get sometimes even now.  But it sure was funky...
     
     Andy W
     
     


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: DXM
Author:  SteveOSac@aol.com at smtplink-acs
Date:    7/17/96 2:50 PM


For reference, the one time I did the DXM thing, I ingested 6 ounces of that 
lovely syrup we all know and love.  I weigh 135, and let me tell ya, I must 
have reached one of those "threshholds".   5 hours of absolute seperation 
from my body.  I could not possibly see taking it in any other environment 
than a very DARK room, with plenty of music on a 7 disk changer.  Cover up 
any lights including the little l.e.d.s on your stereo, they will make you 
dizzy beyond comprehension.  Prepare to be completely immobile.
Try this one next time you robe: create an environment, choose your mode of 
flight, butterfly wings work well, observe how your music completely changes 
your environment as you explore it, measure by measure, song by song.
I can't say I have the urge to do it again, very draining, but I'm glad I 
tried it.
-StEvEo

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 17 17:15:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA25986; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 17:15:17 -0700
Received: from locusts.Berkeley.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA25954; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 17:15:11 -0700

From: "David L. Bayer" <dlb@typhoon-ether.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199607180015.RAA17438@locusts.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: NRR: Clarification on Wilderness medic course
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 1996 17:15:11 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 5480      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, just a quick clarification for those of you who either don't have a 
web browser or or too lazy to use it ;)

This course is a medic course aimed at teaching people the skills they 
will need if something goes wrong in the wilderness or a long way from 
EMS (which may mean long enough to require a lifeflight pickup or if an 
earthquake hits and wipes out all transportation in the East Bay). Here is 
Earthbound's description of the two offered classes:
 
Earthbound's Survival Medicine Class
       A class like no other in the world! Taught by a Special 
Forces medical officer, this class explores just what you can do when 
medical support simply is not a possiblity. 

Earthbound's Wilderness Medicine Class
       Any natural disaster or civil disturbance has the potential of 
turning the area in which you live into a medical wilderness. Be ready 
for your next wilderness experience.


I am trying to get the survival course because it is more in depth than 
the wilderness course, but I can only get people together for the 
wilderness course, so be it...

Here is a review of the wilderness course, I think it statements all this 
the best:

I took the Earthbound class last year.  For those interested, here is a
review I wrote back then:


----------------------------------------------------------
The screaming stops and the silence is not welcome...  tremors are
beginning  in the climber's legs... Oh hell, here we go again... 

His body begins to convulse uncontrollably. Three rescuers dive 
across him in an effort to prevent further injury in the rocky terrain. 

Two people have sacrificed their rain gear and jackets to help keep 
the injured climber warm.  They now stand shivering and soaked in 
the pouring rain.

The convulsions cease for a moment and the team goes into action.  
Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABC).  The climber is beginning to 
mumble incoherently.  Airway is clear, Breathing is present.  
Capillary refill at the extremities indicates that circulation is not 
impaired.  A serious head injury is the major concern and probably 
responsible for the convulsions.  Level of Consciousness times 0 to 
times 1 - a bad sign.

The rain is really coming down now.  It's very dark out, the sun set 
long ago. Flashlights fitfully illuminate the area where small groups 
surround the three injured men.  One climber is actually laying in the 
creek.  He is slowly turning blue as the icy water flows around him.  

Fist sized rocks are washing off the cliff face next to us.  30 more 
minutes until the Medevac helicopter is expected.  It can only carry 
two victims and all three need immediate evacuation; which ones to 
choose?

A figure in a poncho looms out of the dark.  She looks down at our 
victim and says "I'm afraid his head injuries were just too severe... 
he's dead". "Let's get out of the rain".

As the other "injured" begin to arise, our "climber" gets up as well 
and we all begin to scramble out of the creek bottom and back to 
camp.


It's been the final "scenario" for our Earthbound Medical Rescue 
training class, a two day intensive course on backcountry medicine.  
The injuries were simulated, the "victim" in the creek was wearing a 
wetsuit, but everything else was real.

This superb class teaches the essentials required to deal with major 
injuries sustained beyond the reach of professional aid.  While 
targeted at backcountry explorers and wilderness trip leaders, the 
skills would be equally useful after an earthquake or hurricane when 
local resources are overwhelmed.


Earthbound Medical Rescue is the current Wilderness Medicine 
contractor to the US Geological Survey. They have recently made 
their classes available to the general public.  The instructors bring 
with them a wealth of practical experience as EMTs with wilderness 
certification.

No prerequisites are required, although a general knowledge of basic 
first aid procedures is quite useful.  The class I took was about half 
medical professionals and half interested outdoorspeople like myself.

The class was taught outdoors and was evenly divided between 
lecture and exercises, culminating in the "emergency" described 
above.  I viewed the "hands on" portion as being, perhaps, the most 
valuable portion of the course.  Practicing skills as they taught 
reinforced the lessons and builds the confidence necessary to handle 
an actual situation.  Class size was small which allowed us to work 
with the instructors on an individual basis.

Briefly, the course contained sections on Lyme disease, Cervical Spine 
immobilizations, Level of Consciousness evaluation, Wilderness vs. 
the Urban environment, Patient assessment, Chest injuries, Shock, 
Spinal Injury, Environmental (Hypo/Hyperthermia/AMS...), 
Orthopedics, Wound Care, Bites & Stings, Medical Emergencies, Long 
term care, Rescue Considerations, and Ethics. This is not a 
comprehensive list, but provides some idea of the breadth of training 
provided.  A brief introduction to alternative medicine, specifically 
homeopathy, was also given by a guest lecturer.

All in all, I was well satisfied with the course and would not hesitate 
to sign up for any further classes that Earthbound might offer.  If 
you ever expect to be in a situation beyond the reach of 911, I highly 
recommend this training. The cost for the weekend was $100.


I have no affiliation with Earthbound Medical Rescue other than 
being a satisfied customer.


anyway, that's it

dave

Subject: Politics in Raving
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ever notice how, when you first started raving, it was all good?  It was 
new, (almost) no party was a bad party, and everybody was cool to party 
with?  Then by the time you've been in it for six months, you avoid certain 
parties because of the promoters?  And it's because:

1. There are nasty narc/jerk/weirdo rumors going around about them.
2. They had a falling out with some other promoter you consider cool.
3. The general consensus is that their parties attract the "wrong element".
4. Your friends dislike them and they want you to go with them somewhere else.

And suddenly you find yourself going to fewer parties or picking some 
parties over others because of politics?  Sucks, doesn't it?  Leslie and I 
were chatting about this and we came to the conclusion that raving is 
easier, purer, when you first start and you DON'T KNOW ANYTHING about the 
promoter politics.  You're ignorant, and it is in fact a blissful state.

Just an observation.

S

Ah, Jello... what words of wisdom.

I know you all know this, so spare the flames, but since there seems to be a
number  of you that watch it..
The Real World is anything but.  Each character (and I do mean character) is 
followed all day by a camera.  Multiply the number of hours by the number
of characters in the show, and then by 7 (days).  Then hand the footage to the
MTV editors (those shapers of youth personality), and get back a half-hour of
footage.  Real??
	Not to mention that some of the kids on the show are using it to try
to further careers (at least that's what they said).  And how real can your life
be when there are cameras following you?  And will an employer turn you down for
a job, losing the free advertising?
	Sorry to vent, I got too much sleep yesterday/last night.  I'm sure you
people that watch the show just to laugh at it (I can't even do that).  But I
know a number of people who think that it IS real-life, spontaneous reality!!!!
More candidates for forced sterilization, I guess.

And because it's a useless topic, feel free to flame or reply to me privately.
I don't want to clutter up the list with it.

-mike

> Ever notice how, when you first started raving, it was all good?  It was
> new, (almost) no party was a bad party, and everybody was cool to party
> with?  Then by the time you've been in it for six months, you avoid certain
> parties because of the promoters?  And it's because:

I know what you're talking about, but when the politics come into play
it's usually time to make quality of events a factor in your decisions
than quantity. Expecting the scene to be utopic is a bit too much,  but 
no matter what, there's still always going to be pure music and pure
people!

-- 
^      ^
@   @
   U
   O ....digdatbeat!
      Gregor Hoffman

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 17 19:36:39 1996

Received: from mail-gw.fsr.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA07894; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 19:36:35 -0700
Received: from Maxine.lewiston.com (ppp144.lewiston.com [204.227.174.144]) by mail-gw.fsr.net (8.7.5/8.6.9) with SMTP id TAA10516 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 19:54:55 -0700
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 1996 19:54:55 -0700
Message-Id: <199607180254.TAA10516@mail-gw.fsr.net>
X-Sender: tuskluv@mail.lewiston.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com>
Subject: Re: Videotaping
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(More views and opinions on videotaping rave gatherings)
>
>It's not really a matter of how we feel about what we do but what other
>think and their actions.... 

I could not disagree with this statement more.  While I'm not intending to
start any flaming sessions, IT IS REALLY A MATTER OF HOW WE THINK AND FEEL.
We cannot allow others to dictate our actions or our beleifs, because they
rarely have our best interests in mind.  The world has spun off in very
negative directions because individuals could not and would not take
personal responsibility for their actions or their beleifs.  Hiding who and
what you are, and who and what you beleive, is more than simply self-
destructive...it causes the breakdown of independent thought and rational
actions towards the insanity of the world.  In other words, we must stand.  

>I feel that if we really want to change something in this world, people
>like us should come to positions of power. I have no problem with them
>lying about inhaling or whatever, as long as they use there position
>for the good of all...(reference to Clinton)

While liars claim to have intentions for the 'good of all', this is not the
case and we should ALWAYS have problems with them.  Liars are selfish and
chaotic individuals seeking nothing more than their own self-fulfillment.
As far as striving to reach positions of "power"(I strongly encourage
everybody to re-read 'The Promise'), I think we need to think about real
"power" and worldly "power".  These are completely different things. 

>Being ashamed and breaking the law are two different things.  I know many 
>people that aren't ashamed of smoking pot and are very open about but 
>that doesn't mean they want to be filmed partaking of illegal activites 
>which could get them arrested?!  I do illegal things sometimes (I'd say 
>everyone does but I'd get flamed ;) and I'm not ashamed of them, but I'd 
>rather not have those moments/times be publicly accessible.

While there is an abundance of drugs at rave parties, most people usually go
to the bathroom stalls or outside to do their drugs.  Others might quickly
swallow something like 'e', but rarely have I seen many people do anything
else but smoke pot in front of others.  I don't think Hard Copy would take a
video tape of people smoking pot to the police, and if they did, how could
they arrest us or prove beyond doubt as to exactly what we were smoking?  

I think the essence of raving is the vibe.  This might be difficult to catch
on film, but don't some of you desire to share with the rest of the world
the "powerful", spiritually moving gatherings we sometimes attend?  And the
powerful, wonderous, innovative and special music we sometimes hear? I know
there is a lot that happens at some raves which the rest of society might
not understand. But I definitely think that honesty and Truth about what we
experience at times, especially those things which are 'esoteric', should be
shared with the general population for educational purposes.  

The "kingdom" is within, why not share it?  It's the only way to maintain a
presence there anyways.  As a very wise man once said...Stand!  Shine!

Love,

Troy

PS.  If I beleive in you, and you beleive in me, there ain't nothin we can't
do.  Of course, first, we must believe in ourselves.  Love don't help those
who don't try to help themselves first!!  Take care 'fam'!  


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 17 21:08:03 1996

Received: by si.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id VAA01634; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 21:06:46 -0700
Date: Wed, 17 Jul 1996 21:06:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: RE: Videotaping 
To: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
cc: Renaud Waldura <rw@softway.com>, sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <9607170752.AA05566@mail.ico.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9607172049.A926-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Wed, 17 Jul 1996, Roy Feague wrote:

> 
> Some interesting points have been made on VideoTaping.  I think it was   
> Heisenberg who first recognized this important scientific principle: to   
> observe is to disturb.  In scientific circles, it means that any system   
> you wish to observe is changed by virtue of the fact that you observe it.   
> 

Yet all situations are observed in some way I think.



> In raves, it means that by trying to record the vibe, you can disturb   
> it, even destroy it in the extreme case.  People can't let go when they   
> know they are being observed, and a camera is the coldest of observers.
>

Let's look at the assumptions being made here.

   "There is a vibe of some sorts." While I essientially go along with 
    this belief it is by no means a certainty except in certain belief 
    structures (flame away). Also; is there just one type of vibe? if 
    more than one, what are they? Would all vibes be "destroyed" by video 
    taping or other documentation? Why can't a vibe exist alongside 
    documentation? If the vibe is a human construction can we not learn 
    to have it coexist with documentation? Is a camera any colder than a 
    audio tape deck? How many of you enjoy audio tapes from parties 
    you've been to? Is "disturb" choosen for it's negative conntations?





 
> It's something to think about.  Videotaping a public event may be within   
> the bounds of one's rights, but if many find it disturbing, then perhaps   
> it's not within the bounds of courtesy.
>  -Roy
> 


Define many. One? Three? Twenty? A thousand? If there were to be more 
video taping maybe folks would not find it disturbing.

 I would at this time like to restate my position: At any free public 
gathering on public land, I and my camera are no more intrusive than the 
often times destructive elements of a rave party. If you are doing drugs 
(or other illegal activities) in public, at a rave, you are doing far 
more to damage the vibe and the rave communitty than I or anyone else 
with a camera could ever do. In my not so humble opinion.

 If the party is public but a paid admission event I feel it is up to the 
promoter to regulate the door and well being of the public within (within 
reason) and this should include weather cameras of any type should be 
allowed in (which at big commercial concerts they are not). Again, folks 
doing illegal things openly are hurting the scene far worse than any 
camera and I have very little sympathy for them.

 If folks really want to have parties where there are no cameras, by all 
means throw them!! If a promoter asks me not to document an event I, for 
one, will respect that request.

I really am enjoying all the exchange of ideas on this subject!! By no 
means is my mind shut on this issue and hope to hear from more folks (yes 
that's an invite to you lurkers out there!!).



Peace 

Ran


                           -=*=-
                             ~

I brought a friend, who had never been to a rave much less heard good
underground music, to Freedom and while we were sitting on top of the
hill watching the sun rise he said that he had no idea that the feeling
of intense love from everyone there was even possible and the music 
according to his words, "it's just...just PERFECT!!!".

Last weekend I brought 4 friends to Beautiful People but in their case
they all had been to several commercial massives, I met them at the
last Funky Tekno Tribe, but they had always felt that something was
missing...yeah there was the incredible music, the mind bogling lasers
and special effects, and E but was that it? I told them about the first 
Beautiful People that I went to back in May and how it has changed my
life, so they came to BP this past Saturday to find out what they had
been missing. Later that night all they could say was that words would
not even begin to describe the intense LOVE that they felt for and from
EVERYBODY!!!! Again it changed all of their lives saying that not only
would they take that love and bring it to all the parties they attended,
including the massives, but also into their daily lives...they're
re-learning how to base their decisions on their HEART and NOT their
fears! Fear and hatred are learned emotions but we've NEVER had to learn
how to love! We were born in a state of pure LOVE!

The thing that all of my friends had in common was that they all
had a deep desire to know why they are here? What is their purpose 
in life? They all knew already that becoming filthy rich wasn't
the answer....so it seems one set of criteria could be:

1. The person is in search of the answers to their life's questions...
a spiritual mission to find more than just material wealth. Not 
everyone is ready for this since they may have yet to experience 
enough to realize that there MUST be more.

2. Bring the person to a party where you know the promoters intentions
are to spread the vibe of LOVE and NOT just to make a quick profit.

With Love and Light,
John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 17 23:32:38 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA25642; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 23:32:38 -0700
Received: from mail.ico.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id XAA25635; Wed, 17 Jul 1996 23:32:34 -0700
Received: from starbase.starfishsoftware.com by mail.ico.net with SMTP (5.65/950621.1)
	id AA05633; Wed, 17 Jul 96 23:32:37 -0700
Message-Id: <9607180632.AA05633@mail.ico.net>
Priority: non-urgent
Date: Thu, 18 Jul 1996 00:26:00 -0700
From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: RE: Videotaping
To: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Back at ya, Randy!  ;)
You write:
>Let's look at the assumptions being made here.
>  "There is a vibe of some sorts." While I essientially go along with
>  this belief it is by no means a certainty except in certain belief
>    structures (flame away). Also; is there just one type of vibe? if
>    more than one, what are they?
I think there is a common understanding of what a good vibe is, some   
elements of which might be people having a good time in a friendly,   
comfortable, non-threatening atmosphere.  Are you suggesting that vibe   
doesn't exist?  That would imply that the atmosphere at every rave and   
every gathering is identical, which is a difficult point to defend, I   
think.

>Would all vibes be "destroyed" by video
>    taping or other documentation? Why can't a vibe exist alongside
>    documentation?
I'm suggesting that for many people (we'll come back to that "many"   
concept) being on video makes them feel observed, recorded, and therefore   
(important point here) they are inevitably going to be more aware of how   
they appear.  Do I look like an idiot dancing?  Sure other ravers see me,   
but they're dancing.  They aren't there to watch me.  A camera is there   
solely to watch and record, and it's somewhat threatening in that   
respect.  This has a negative effect on one's ability to let go of   
thinking about how one appears... it's natural to be nervous about being   
observed.  Stage fright is a great example.

>If the vibe is a human construction can we not learn
>    to have it coexist with documentation?
Maybe we could learn, but I'm more interested in talking about how things   
are than how they could be if we could videotape every rave and persuade   
people to feel differently than they do.

>Is a camera any colder than a
>    audio tape deck? How many of you enjoy audio tapes from parties
>    you've been to?
Sure it is.  Audio tapes are typically made of the DJ's mixing, not of   
the conversations of individuals.  BIG difference.

>Is "disturb" choosen for it's negative conntations?
Yes, it is, because I'm suggesting a negative effect.
   

>Define many. One? Three? Twenty? A thousand?
Many?  Hmm.  Many is enough that I sense it in myself and have heard it   
from other people and have come to feel intuitively that "many" people   
feel the same way.  This is of course arguable, but really, do you   
honestly believe that there are NOT many people who find a camera   
disturbing?  Surely you've seen people shy away from your camera.  So you   
respect those folks; that's cool.  How about the people who are   
disturbed, but not disturbed enough to make a fuss?  They're still   
disturbed.

>If there were to be more
>video taping maybe folks would not find it disturbing.
Well, again, maybe things could be different, but I'd only talking about   
how things ARE.

>If you are doing drugs
>(or other illegal activities) in public, at a rave, you are doing far
>more to damage the vibe and the rave communitty than I or anyone else
>with a camera could ever do. In my not so humble opinion.
>...
>Again, folks
>doing illegal things openly are hurting the scene far worse than any
>camera and I have very little sympathy for them.
You keep coming back to illegal things.  I think cameras can be   
disturbing to people who aren't doing anything illegal, but instead just   
don't wish to feel like their actions are going to be recorded for later   
scrutiny by someone (or many people) they may not even know.

>I really am enjoying all the exchange of ideas on this subject!! By no
>means is my mind shut on this issue and hope to hear from more folks   
(yes
>that's an invite to you lurkers out there!!).
Hear hear!
While we're clarifying, I don't think cameras are evil.  I don't think   
Videotaping at a massive rave is a bad thing because it's so public to   
begin with, and there's tremendous anonymity.  I'm thinking more of   
smaller, more intimate settings.  And even then, I'm not saying   
absolutely don't do it.  I'm just saying, realize that if one tapes   
people, some will not like it.  If one goes ahead and tapes anyway...   
well, maybe those folks will just have to deal.  But at least then the   
videographer isn't living under any illusions.
>Peace
Peace!
 -Roy

Hi all,

sorry this is late but I've been sick and it's been a very depressing week.
I am getting better though.

I went last thursday to funkitron which also ws spun's birthday.  I't was
alot of fun.  It's going to be a new weekly at the maritime on 1st &
harrison starting july 25.  The dj's last thursday were Tracy, Jeno, and
Spun.  I only got to hear jeno and spun and both were great.  I got hung up
during jeno's set when he sped up a tune (accidently??) and tryed to
recover buy playing with the speeds.  It cam out all right but up till that
point i was in a dancing trance from his beats.  The music continued and i
met many great people.  About 30-40 in all but the place has great
potential.  We all sang happy birthday to spun at the conclusion and went
off to the beach to mellow out.  Great party.  I didn't go out at all this
weekend because i was sick (except for a outdoor psycadelic excursion on
friday).

Well next thursday on the 25th Josh and John Howard will be there, and i
might go if I have the energy or money.

Peace

Subject: shadows, techno and goo
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

And the shadow fell away...

Big assed HELLO!!!! to my new found family I have never spoken to.  In fact,
I have never even sent a message to anyone (yes, I was scared for some
inexplicable reason...)on the net, and I'm glad I waited for the proper time
and place to loose my virginity....

So, as a newbie to both the web and rave culture, I was wondering a few
things:

--   1: What is a reasonably close estimate of the % of  lurkers vs. ...% of
what.......posters?

--   2: I get the basic picture, but please define more thuroughly  the
concept of flaming (feel free to test by fire... a little...) and is there
such a thing as a reverse flame?

--    3: I found the rave slang posts (am I using the term "post" in correct
context?) I read cool, informative and caring , and I would like to open a
 discussion topic along those lines:

                                SO MANY TYPES OF TECHNO!!!!!

Can everyone here please help this big excited guy get all these definitions
a little more in order?  I mean, some are self explanatory like ambient or
trance, but even those get broken down in to sub-categories.  And, like,
which DJ's spin what, and do we consider Hip-Hop a type of techno, or just
related cuz they both use Techniques(sp?)  I'm sure all have their own
opinions, and I'm not trying to start wars here {some people are like wine
snobs about it:  Firm urine overtones subtled by  roasted iguana nuts and
motor oil undertones with a piquant tannic finnish reminiscent of dog pubic
hair...{|8^]) }, but discussion and multiple opinions would smell nice...

To ooze a bit on a general note:

Education about the inherent truths of positivity and community given to
those who don't necessarily want to hear it MUST cotinue, and I know I dont
need to say this but it makes me feel good, so: Everyone, please, DO NOT BE
AFRAID to let the good, sincere feelings that are inside us seep out of the
cracks of our very existance and flow on to the freaking floor!!!  Those who
do not feel them inside must see that WE DO feel, it's OK, and would like
them to come along on our fantastic voyage beyond any party ever thrown!!!  I
know we all (mostly, when we arn't down for personal reasons) smile at that
scowling old woman at the grocery store, so keep it up.  And cops.  Some of
them are people too (no, really...) and it might help (besides, we need them
on our side for the revolution!).  So tell everyone to be cool to eachother
and self, and make HONESTY with everyone and self the cornerstone upon which
trust, love and a great time can be built.

Thank you all for being so real! (Hallucinations please disregard this
statement)

!!tuO ecaeP

---Justin W....

P.S.: call me J-Dub if you like, I'v noticed others named Justin

                          ,.-~'~-.,_,.-think globaly, act individually--~'
      _,.-~'~-.,_,.-~'

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: scaplier@ousd.k12.ca.us (Moander)
Subject: Re: A Guide to Breaking In Rave Newbies
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>
>
>I always bring newbies to Sunset! It's in the day, it's in a beautiful place
>with lots of nice people and people often bring their kids and dogs and stuff
>so it feels like a real family.
>
>
>Who doesn't like sunset? :)

        I for one am not too fond of sunset. It had its moments at times
but now I'm just more into the darker type rave scenes... For instance, now
on sunday nights I try to always go to mantra because I personally love
trance, especially goa, and the ambiance is just dark lit only with
blacklights and psychedilic images and shit... Also, those f-8 parties are
always pretty cool, again because of the cybertrance, but also just because
of its ambiance.

        I mean, I don't know, but it just seems to me that some, not all,
music is better suited to different scenery. I mean sure, some funky
breakbeats and thumping bass is always a joy on a hot weekend afternoon, or
progressive, deep house in a club if you're more into that clubby,
meat-market, alcohol scene, but at least since I matured musically, nothing
beats lung-shaking cybertrance in a abandoned parisian sewer, for instance,
with movies of anime and sci-fi computer generated animations speeding like
crazy.... or mind-rushing goa eating your brain in a room only lit with
flashing strobes, lasers, and my own acid.

        Going back to sunset, it's really nice and all, and not meaning any
disrepect, but sometimes that happy shit just gets to me.

        But please people, this is only an opinion, everyone has their own
tastes...

        Moander

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 18 08:24:28 1996

have enough variety of yummies to eat.

no noxious farting going on the day of the picnic. :P

a white tee shirt and a maroon floral skirt. I'll have my laminate on 
too!  This is my first event in a long time where I feel like being 
social, so watch out - I wanna meet lotsa new folks! :) 

love,

then we'll all avoid your sucky parties.  :^)

In case anyone missed it, Dave Bayer, [dlb@typhoon-ether.Berkeley.EDU]
forwarded the message below.  He's interested in taking a class regarding
emergency situations.  Ahnon has suggested this too,and I think it's an
excellent idea.  Let's get some input on this, does anyone know of any other
of such classes.  It would be great to attend one that covered other areas
such as epileptic seisures (e.g. last years sunset incident), and maybe
negative drug reactions and overdoses.  
Keep in mind the key factor of cost, perhaps if we find something good, but
not very affordable we can arrange some sort of fund raising thing.  Goddess
knows we all need one more reason to throw a rave! 
-StEvEo

Forwarded message:
>I am looking for people interested in taking a wilderness first aid  course
taught by Earthbound medical which teaches how to deal with really  bad
situations in the wilderness, a good course for a few of you who like
 camping parties. I don't have a price on this yet because 1) it is highly 
dependent on the number of people who attend and 2) Earthbound hasn't let me
know when they will have time to set  a class up (they are 3 day  courses)
but they will arrange one for a group of 10 or so.... So any takers?

dave

Message-Id: <9607181030.ZM14376@horatio.ucsf.edu>
Date: Thu, 18 Jul 1996 10:30:50 -0700
In-Reply-To: Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com>
        "Re: Videotaping" (Jul 17,  7:54pm)
References: <199607180254.TAA10516@mail-gw.fsr.net>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Videotaping
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Jul 17,  7:54pm, Wowser wrote:
> Subject: Re: Videotaping
> (More views and opinions on videotaping rave gatherings)
> >
> >It's not really a matter of how we feel about what we do but what other
> >think and their actions....
>
> I could not disagree with this statement more.  While I'm not intending to
> start any flaming sessions, IT IS REALLY A MATTER OF HOW WE THINK AND FEEL.
> We cannot allow others to dictate our actions or our beleifs, because they
> rarely have our best interests in mind.  The world has spun off in very
> negative directions because individuals could not and would not take
> personal responsibility for their actions or their beleifs.  Hiding who and
> what you are, and who and what you beleive, is more than simply self-
> destructive...it causes the breakdown of independent thought and rational
> actions towards the insanity of the world.  In other words, we must stand.

Although I agree with you in general, there are several cases where it is
not wise to be open about your identity, simply because it will be directly
harmful to you. For instance, it would not be wise to visit KKK meetings
if you're black, to tell a police officer you are carrying herion and feel
you should have the right to do so or to tell your employer that you like to
smoke pot. Such actions are unlikely to improve the world we live in but
likely to ruin your chances of living happily ever after. Saying that, I
would like to add that this doesn't mean that you don't have to fight for
your rights and live as you want to, you just have to do it smarter. My
motto is, if you can't beat them, fool them. The fact is, a large part of
society, law enforcement and politics are against us, you can stand as
much as you like, being a minority you are likely to loose. I still intend
to change "the insanity of the world" but I feel our chances of success
are greater when it's done from within. Otherwise I might end up as a
unabomber-kind of person.

>
> >I feel that if we really want to change something in this world, people
> >like us should come to positions of power. I have no problem with them
> >lying about inhaling or whatever, as long as they use there position
> >for the good of all...(reference to Clinton)
>
> While liars claim to have intentions for the 'good of all', this is not the
> case and we should ALWAYS have problems with them.  Liars are selfish and
> chaotic individuals seeking nothing more than their own self-fulfillment.

If you claim that you have never lied to anybody in your life, I would
say you are a liar. It's very human.

> As far as striving to reach positions of "power"(I strongly encourage
> everybody to re-read 'The Promise'), I think we need to think about real
> "power" and worldly "power".  These are completely different things.

Please explain that to me a bit more.

>
> >Being ashamed and breaking the law are two different things.  I know many
> >people that aren't ashamed of smoking pot and are very open about but
> >that doesn't mean they want to be filmed partaking of illegal activites
> >which could get them arrested?!  I do illegal things sometimes (I'd say
> >everyone does but I'd get flamed ;) and I'm not ashamed of them, but I'd
> >rather not have those moments/times be publicly accessible.
>
> While there is an abundance of drugs at rave parties, most people usually go
> to the bathroom stalls or outside to do their drugs.  Others might quickly
> swallow something like 'e', but rarely have I seen many people do anything
> else but smoke pot in front of others.  I don't think Hard Copy would take a
> video tape of people smoking pot to the police, and if they did, how could
> they arrest us or prove beyond doubt as to exactly what we were smoking?

You would be surprised of what people are arrested for these days. And if
are lifestyle is going to portrayed in the media as drug-infested too
many times, you can bet some politian will see it as an opportunity to
"get tough on raves". Look at the situation in England were small gatherings
have been outlawed and promotors are being sent to jail just for throwing
a party. Keep it underground, I say, they don't understand.

> I think the essence of raving is the vibe.  This might be difficult to catch
> on film, but don't some of you desire to share with the rest of the world
> the "powerful", spiritually moving gatherings we sometimes attend?  And the
> powerful, wonderous, innovative and special music we sometimes hear? I know
> there is a lot that happens at some raves which the rest of society might
> not understand. But I definitely think that honesty and Truth about what we
> experience at times, especially those things which are 'esoteric', should be
> shared with the general population for educational purposes.

Look at what happened to the Flower Power generation, on average they seemed
to be more idealistic than the average hedonistic raver. They haven't achieved
too much in terms of increasing love and understanding in this world. This
is a slow process and I feel that confronting the masses with our "thing"
might backfire. For the past few thousand years people have already told
everybody that they should love each other and their planet and progress
in that direction is still slow. Raving, I think, in itself will not change
that too much. Making sure people with the right mindset enter the mass media,
politics, big business etc. might be more effective.

> The "kingdom" is within, why not share it?  It's the only way to maintain a
> presence there anyways.  As a very wise man once said...Stand!  Shine!

I think we only disagree on the way of sharing it.

>
> Love,
> Troy

> PS.  If I beleive in you, and you beleive in me, there ain't nothin we can't
> do.

You are an idealist.

> Of course, first, we must believe in ourselves.  Love don't help those
> who don't try to help themselves first!!  Take care 'fam'!



The Frying Dutchman

--

At 10:07 AM 7/18/96 -0800, you wrote:
>At 6:50 PM -0300 7/17/96, Gregor Hoffman wrote:
>>SDream wrote:
>>>
>>> Ever notice how, when you first started raving, it was all good?  It was
>>> new, (almost) no party was a bad party, and everybody was cool to party
>>> with?  Then by the time you've been in it for six months, you avoid certain
>>> parties because of the promoters?  And it's because:
>>
>>I know what you're talking about, but when the politics come into play
>>it's usually time to make quality of events a factor in your decisions
>>than quantity. Expecting the scene to be utopic is a bit too much,  but
>>no matter what, there's still always going to be pure music and pure
>>people!

I think it comes down to diversity and decisions.  We are lucky that this
scene is so diverse that we can all be satisfied by different types of
parties.  I mean, on one weekend there will be people going to a jungle
party in a wharehouse, a cybertrance journey in the woods, deep house in the
city, and ambient grooves in someone's loft.  Once you get involved in the
scene and know more about it, you start making decisions about where, when,
and who..  You start having music preferences, location preferences, and
friends in the scene. 

For me, any promoter/crew/system who believes in a positive VIBE, and the
ideals of PLUR will get my support and full props.  To me, big parties !=
(not equal) BAD.  I like going to big parties as well as small parties,
because of the immense diversity available in the people.  Big parties also
draw lots of newbies which is cool esp. when you take someone 'round and
introduce them to lots of people.

Anyways.. discuss <-

PLUR,
Aaron.

>
>Ever notice how, when you first started raving, it was all good?  It was 
>new, (almost) no party was a bad party, and everybody was cool to party 
>with?  Then by the time you've been in it for six months, you avoid certain

I just started raving about a year ago, and when I first got into it I
noticed the politics.  ing
On the DJ side of it, I'm a rookie (less than 1 year) DJ and I've had talks
with other DJ's who can't believe how political the whole thravi is.  I was
advised not to even try and send a demo to Wicked!  I just wish that more of
the promoters would give new DJ's a chance, because I can honestly say that
some of the DJ's that are so played out are SHIT compared to some of the
fresh, new DJ's that I've had the pleasure of hearing.  I have even called a
couple of the promoters to try and get in touch with them about hearravi my
demo, and very few have called back!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 18 11:41:33 1996

> On the DJ side of it, I'm a rookie (less than 1 year) DJ and I've had talks
> with other DJ's who can't believe how political the whole thravi is.  I was
> advised not to even try and send a demo to Wicked!  I just wish that more of
> the promoters would give new DJ's a chance, because I can honestly say that
> some of the DJ's that are so played out are SHIT compared to some of the
> fresh, new DJ's that I've had the pleasure of hearing.  I have even called a
> couple of the promoters to try and get in touch with them about hearravi my
> demo, and very few have called back!  

The best way to become known as a DJ is to promote your own parties.  Most
promoters have thier own circle of DJs that not only spin but also get the
party together.  Look at Galen or Ethan... they became successful DJs
just by working hard on their own parties, not relying on other promoters.
Even the Wicked crew owes much of their success to putting a huge amounts
of effort into the free Full Moon raves.  

If you put effort into the scene, you will become popular.

I agree, though, that there is lots of DJ talant that is being overlooked
in the scene, and many established DJs are sounding stale.

-troy

"Rave World"

Same concept as Real Word, 'cept its centered around a bunch of 20-ish people living in a wharehouse.  

A money greedy promoter that throws $20 parties that get broken up by 12

A DJ from New York named Super Star DJ Groove.

A slimey "X" dealer

A guy that wears nothing buy those Cereal Box T-shirts

a country guitar player from Memphis

"The media hack"

The guy who seems like a pretty normal, charismatic fellow who would
entertain people nicely in-between commercials for Zit cream and Hair
Gel.  But midway through the season, he decides to make it his personal
goal in life to use his noteriety on the Rave World to spead the message
of the evils of television and the joys of responible, community-building
dance cultures who use psychedelics to break through the mental shackles
imposed on the youth of this country, much to the chagrin of the show's
producers, MTV executives and Ted Turner.

As you can see, I have often daydreamed about being on that show.

-troy

>The best way to become known as a DJ is to promote your own parties.  Most
>promoters have their own circle of DJs that not only spin but also get the
>party together.

I agree, though it somewhat dissapoints me. DJ's are like musicians, and
shouldn't have to promote their own 'concerts' to get recognized. Talent is
talent. Often times (but not always) the music does get stale, because the
same DJ's are always hanging out and playing together in the same context.

In San Diego we had Sundays in the Park, a venue which encouraged new dj's
to come out and make themselves known. Often times an unknown jock would
get the crowd pumping more than a vet would. Sometimes a new dj would
trainwreck, but people would note the quality of the music he/she was
playing. This exemplified the overall community. We were looking out for
our own, encouraging fresh faces to become involved, giving them
inspiration by giving them a chance....
-peace-
alex

Alex Ward
bwret@best.com                         May the Funk be with you...Always.

On Jul 18, 12:36pm, Renzo Saunders wrote:
> Subject: GHB?
>      Hello all,
>         Anybody ever heard of something called GHB? It looks like water and
>      supposedly has the effects of being on nitrous and E. A bunch of
>      people I know have been taking this stuff lately and it seems to have
>      no effect on some people while others' simply pass out shortly after
>      drinking this stuff. It looks like water and supposedly has a really
>      bad taste. Apparently it doesn't take much to get to you. Anybody know
>      what it is? I've never seen this shit, but someone said that it is
>      some sort of herbs or aminos or some shit. Later......
>
>      -REN
>-- End of excerpt from Renzo Saunders

GHB is gamma hydroxy butyrate, a small naturally occuring chemical that
as far as I know (it's legal in Holland) comes as a white powder. It's
effects are feelings of well-being to mild euphoria. There are two
major problems with it, in combination with alcohol you can very easily
pass out and it is relatively easy to overdose with the same result
(passing out). It is apparently dissolved in water for easier intake.
I think a bunch of people have ended up in the ER after someone passed
them a spiked waterbottle (there was an article in the SF Weekly on
GHB some time ago). Pretty harmless for the rest. It's not allowed
by the FDA but the DEA has no problems with it, making it illegal to
sell but legal to have on you I think. It's not derived from herbs,
it's just a chemical.

The Frying Dutchman

--

a country guitar player from Memphis

know of anyone, just add em to the list......

In-Reply-To: <960718042604_240289204@emout16.mail.aol.com>

> So, as a newbie to both the web and rave culture, I was wondering a few
> things:
 
> Can everyone here please help this big excited guy get all these definitions
> a little more in order?  I mean, some are self explanatory like ambient or
> trance, but even those get broken down in to sub-categories.

Uh ho...  This question tends to come up every once in a while and no
one ever seems to answer it to a reasonable level of satisfaction...
Its really hard to describe music with words, yknow!  :-)  Lesse if I
can spell out some of the more basic terms w/o losing my audience/mind.

Ambient - (I know you said you get it already but lemme have my fun :-)
Ambient is the Little Fluffy Cloud in the sky during sundown.  Y'see,
we lived in Arizona and the skies all had Little Fluffy Clouds in them
and uh...  You don't see that...  You might still see it in the desert.

Jungle - Jungle is the shootout at the OK coral...  Sometimes its
the Romeo and Juliet but more often its litter on the sidewalk and
you knew who threw it there.  It has a habit of running around alot
but it always ends up back in the same place.

Hardcore (Happy) - Happy Hardcore is elusive.  Sometimes it can be
found hiding in a brush but lately it likes to try to stay in motion.
My advice : Just Close Your Eyes.  Get the No More Tears formula.
After all, its the Music For The 90's, kid!

House - Very popular around this time.  Be careful : sometimes there
are Six-Million Ways To Die.

- David

In case you havent noticed, I have a tendency to be of no use to anyone
:-)  You try running simulations all day and see how much sense YOU make :-P

Hi all,

Renzo Saunders wrote:
>      Hello all,
>         Anybody ever heard of something called GHB? It looks like water and
>      supposedly has the effects of being on nitrous and E. A bunch of
>      people I know have been taking this stuff lately and it seems to have
>      no effect on some people while others' simply pass out shortly after
>      drinking this stuff. It looks like water and supposedly has a really
>      bad taste. Apparently it doesn't take much to get to you. Anybody know
>      what it is? I've never seen this shit, but someone said that it is
>      some sort of herbs or aminos or some shit. Later......

yes, I've heard of it, come across it, but have seen almost NO discussion on 
it anywhere.  I've heard it is a steriod that was used by bodybuilders.  Some 
people say it is VERY dangerous <like most drugs aren't, right>.  It is 
supposedly very popular in the gay community.

I know a few people that have taken it a lot, and they tell me that it tastes 
like bad, salty water, and it's perfectly clear.  Two or three capfuls (evian 
bottle cap) are a decent dose.  

After about twenty minutes you'll get flushed and start to lose your balance.  
DON'T ride your bike, drive a car, or try to go hiking in the woods at night.  
Don't do anything that requres serious motor coordination.  

You will like touching and feeling others.  Sex will be good, very good (and 
it doesn't require good motor skills!).  It lasts for a little under two 
hours.  No hangover.  You could take it in the morning and be fine the rest of 
the day.

If you take too much you'll vomit badly for a few hours, although I think 
you've got to take a lot to get to that point.  I know a smallish girl that 
took three to four caps over the course of a few hours and was fine.  I'm not 
sure if you can die from it, although another friend of mine said he heard a 
report about a fellow that dropped dead drinking it <sigh>

My friends tell me it's probably not even illegal.

That's all I know.  Hope it helps.
pauly

On Jul 18,  1:16pm, w. p. risenhoover wrote:
> Subject: Re: GHB?
> Hi all,
>
> Renzo Saunders wrote:
> >      Hello all,
> >         Anybody ever heard of something called GHB? It looks like water and
> >      supposedly has the effects of being on nitrous and E. A bunch of
> >      people I know have been taking this stuff lately and it seems to have
> >      no effect on some people while others' simply pass out shortly after
> >      drinking this stuff. It looks like water and supposedly has a really
> >      bad taste. Apparently it doesn't take much to get to you. Anybody know
> >      what it is? I've never seen this shit, but someone said that it is
> >      some sort of herbs or aminos or some shit. Later......
>
> yes, I've heard of it, come across it, but have seen almost NO discussion on
> it anywhere.  I've heard it is a steriod that was used by bodybuilders.  Some
> people say it is VERY dangerous <like most drugs aren't, right>.  It is
> supposedly very popular in the gay community.

It's not a steroid and it's not very dangerous. It's:

HO-CH2-CH2-CH2-CHOOH (gamma hydroxy butyric acid)

and it acts through the GABA (GammaAminoButericAcid) neurotransmitter system,
similarly as alcohol (!). It's usually sold as the sodium salt and then
dissolved in water.
>
> I know a few people that have taken it a lot, and they tell me that it tastes
> like bad, salty water, and it's perfectly clear.  Two or three capfuls (evian
> bottle cap) are a decent dose.
>
> After about twenty minutes you'll get flushed and start to lose your balance.
> DON'T ride your bike, drive a car, or try to go hiking in the woods at night.
> Don't do anything that requres serious motor coordination.
>
> You will like touching and feeling others.  Sex will be good, very good (and
> it doesn't require good motor skills!).  It lasts for a little under two
> hours.  No hangover.  You could take it in the morning and be fine the rest
of
> the day.

Yep, no hangover or burn out as with E.

>
> If you take too much you'll vomit badly for a few hours, although I think
> you've got to take a lot to get to that point.

The problem is that that point is essentially unknown until you pass it :-(

> I know a smallish girl that
> took three to four caps over the course of a few hours and was fine.  I'm not
> sure if you can die from it, although another friend of mine said he heard a
> report about a fellow that dropped dead drinking it <sigh>

Seems unlikely.

>
> My friends tell me it's probably not even illegal.

Not allowed by the FDA (so you can't sell it in a store) but allowed by the
DEA (possesion is OK).

>
> That's all I know.  Hope it helps.
> pauly
>-- End of excerpt from w. p. risenhoover

Part 1 of 2

=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*==*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=
*  L I F E   E N H A N C E M E N T   N E W S  *  Issue #001 - November 5, 1994
=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*==*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=
 < Smart@andronix.org > John Morgenthaler, Ward Dean, MD, & Steven Wm. Fowkes
  To subscribe, email Smart@andronix.org with "subscribe your@email.address".
=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*==*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=*=

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
     GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyrate)*   ---   by John Morgenthaler and Dan Joy
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

        GHB, or gamma-hydroxybutyrate, is a normal component of mammalian
metabolism. It is found naturally in every cell in the human body and is most
properly considered a nutrient. In the brain, the highest amounts are found in
the hypothalamus and basal ganglia [Gallimberti, 1989]. GHB is found in
greater concentrations in kidney, heart, skeletal muscles, and brown fat
tissues [Chin and Kreutzer, 1992]. It is believed to be a neurotransmitter,
although the jury is still out as to whether it exhibits all of the properties
required for fulfillment of this function [Chin and Kreutzer, 1992]. It is
both a metabolite and precursor of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA
(gamma-aminobutyric acid, or gamma-aminobutyrate), another nutrient to which
it bears a close structural relationship. GHB, however, does not act directly
on GABA receptor sites [Chin and Kreutzer, 1992].
        GHB was first synthesized about thirty years ago by Dr. H. Laborit, a
French researcher interested in exploring the effects of GABA in the brain.
Because little or no GABA crosses the blood-brain barrier, Laborit synthesized
GHB, which substitutes a hydroxy group for an amino group. This difference
allows GHB to cross the blood brain barrier where some of it is metabolized
into GABA [Vickers, 1969].
        As it turned out, Laborit found that GHB exhibited a range of effects
beyond those expected from GABA. Over the intervening years, numerous
researchers have extensively studied GHB's effects. It is has come to be used
in Europe as a general anesthetic, a treatment for insomnia and narcolepsy (a
daytime sleeping disorder), an aid to childbirth (increasing strength of
contractions, decreasing pain, and increasing dilation of the cervix), a
treatment for alcoholism and alcohol withdrawal syndrome, and for many other
uses.
        During the 1980s, GHB was widely available over-the-counter in
health-food stores, purchased largely by body-builders for its ability to
stimulate growth hormone release which aids in fat reduction and muscle
building. In the last few years it has been gaining popularity as a
"recreational" drug offering a pleasant, alcohol-like, hangover-free "high"
with potent prosexual effects.

        --- Scientific Reports on GHB ---

        For the thirty years prior to 1990, the scientific papers on GHB were
unanimous in reporting numerous beneficial physiological effects and the
absence of long-term negative effects. In 1964, Laborit listed "very low
toxicity" as one of the "principle elements" of the compound's pharmacology.
In a 1969 report on GHB's anesthetic uses, Vickers referred to GHB as "a
truly nontoxic hypnotic" and repeatedly emphasized its "lack of toxicity."
Vickers cited evidence that GHB demonstrates "no toxic effects on the liver
and kidney." In 1972, Laborit described the body's metabolism of GHB and
stressed "the absence of any need of detoxification by the organism."
        As recently as 1989, this scientific consensus on GHB's benign nature
remained unchanged. Gallimberti's study from that year on its uses in
treating alcohol withdrawal in humans notes that "GHB's action ...seems to be
without serious side effects." His almost off-hand reference to the "safety
of GHB" shows how well-established this property of the nutrient had become.
        Then, on November 8th, 1990, the FDA banned the over-the-counter sale
of GHB in the United States. In 1991, two scientists from the California
Department of Health Services wrote a report on ten "poisonings" associated
with GHB. The authors, Chin and Kreutzer, warned of GHB's "tremendous
potential for abuse." They observed that "all interviewed patients reported a
pleasurable sensation or a `high.' Several of them...continued taking [GHB]
because it made them `feel good'." Apparently, the authors construed feeling
good in and of itself as a potential threat to public health. Despite such
dire language, the report acknowledged that "there are no documented reports
of long-term [detrimental] effects. Nor is there any evidence for physiologic
addiction."
        Of the ten "poisonings" reported, four involved "unknown doses," four
featured the "coingestion" of other drugs, (usually alcohol), one involved
unmedicated epilepsy, and another a history of grand mal seizures. Since
alcohol and other central nervous system (CNS) depressants are not
recommended with GHB, and because GHB is contraindicated for epileptics, such
cases are not unexpected. Chin and Kreutzer acknowledge that the "more severe
reactions...generally occurred when patients took an unmeasured dose, a
particularly large dose, or several doses within a short period of time."
Such problems are easily avoided by following the directions for GHB's use.
        Although the specific clinical details of these ten cases are too
lengthy to go into here, one point needs addressing--the use of the terms
"coma" and "seizures" in descriptions of these cases. At a sufficiently high
dose, GHB can cause CLONUS, a rapid, rhythmic contraction and relaxation of
muscles which would be better described as muscle spasm or uncontrollable
twitching than a seizure. GHB can also cause intense drowsiness, abrupt
sedation, and deep sleep which is probably better described as unarrousability
or deep sedation than coma. Vickers [1969] described it as a "nontoxic coma,"
which blunts some of the inflammatory connotations of the term coma.
        Regardless of their alarmist tone, the authors confirm that "there
have not been any reported deaths" and that "if product use is discontinued,
full recovery with no long-term side effects is universal." They concluded
that "the prognosis for people who experience GHB poisoning is quite good."
        The degree to which the pleasant state of GHB euphoria may be
psychologically addicting may not be fully appreciated. Anybody with known
attraction or addiction to tranquilizers or alcohol should pay special heed
to this possibility. In the few cases of GHB abuse that we have investigated,
there were pre-existing use/abuse patterns with alcohol and/or tranquilizers.
Ironically, it was GHB's lack of toxicity that led to increased frequency of
use (numerous times per day) that characterized what can only be called
classic cases of psychological addiction. Without the dehydration and CNS
irritation of alcohol, or the side effects of tranquilizers, there was no
incentive to moderate or curtail GHB use. Fortunately, few people seem to
have such overwhelming attraction to the GHB state. Even Chin and Kreutzer
minimize GHB's abuse potential by stating, "No investigator [has] reported
any long-term adverse effects, addictive or dependent qualities associated
with discontinued usage of the drug."

        --- Why Was GHB Banned? ---

        It seems likely, then, that at least some of the motives behind the
1990 FDA ban of GHB were other than those of public safety. Such a ban
constitutes the only means of Federal control of a substance neither scheduled
by the DEA nor approved by the FDA as a drug. In the absence of a genuine
public-health concern, such control might have been motivated by a desire to
protect the pharmaceutical industry (with which the FDA is closely
intertwined) from competition from a safer, more effective and less expensive
alternative to sleeping pills. Is it a coincidence that the FDA has also
banned L-tryptophan, another nutrient that functions as a safe and effective
sleep aid?

        --- What Are the Real Concerns? ---

        As with most substances, unpleasant and possibly dangerous side
effects can be associated with excessive doses of GHB. A dose usually only
about twice the amount required for relaxation or a prosexual effect can, as
one user put it, "knock you out but fast." In this respect, GHB is probably
comparable to alcohol: if you drink twice as much as you normally would, you
probably wouldn't function very well. Despite its general safety and lack of
toxicity, the safe use of GHB requires information, preparation, caution, and
good judgment. In other words, follow the usage guidelines!

        --- How Does It Feel? ---

        Most users find that GHB induces a pleasant state of relaxation and
tranquility. Frequent effects are placidity, sensuality, mild euphoria, and a
tendency to verbalize. Anxieties and inhibitions tend to dissolve into a
feeling of emotional warmth, wellbeing, and pleasant drowsiness.
        The "morning after" effects of GHB lack the unpleasant or debilitating
characteristics associated with alcohol and other relaxation-oriented drugs.
In fact, many users report feeling particularly refreshed, even energized, the
next day.
        The effects of GHB can generally be felt within five to twenty minutes
after ingestion. They usually last no more than one and a half to three hours,
although they can be indefinitely prolonged through repeated dosing. The
effects of GHB are very dose-dependent. SMALL INCREASES IN THE AMOUNT INGESTED
LEAD TO SIGNIFICANT INTENSIFICATION OF THE EFFECT. Higher levels feature
greater giddiness, silliness, and interference with mobility and verbal
coherence, and maybe even dizziness. Even higher doses usually induce sleep.

        --- The Actions of GHB in the Body ---

        GHB temporarily inhibits the release of dopamine in the brain. This
may cause increased dopamine storage, and later increased dopamine release
when the GHB influence wears off [Chin and Kreutzer, 1992]. This effect could
account for the middle-of-the-night wakings common with use of higher GHB
doses, and the general feelings of increased well-being, alertness and arousal
the next day.
        GHB also stimulates pituitary growth hormone (GH) release. One
methodologically rigorous Japanese study reported nine-fold and sixteen-fold
increases in growth hormone 30 and 60 minutes respectively after intravenous
administration of 2.5 grams of GHB in six healthy men between the ages of
twenty-five and forty [Takahara, 1977]. GH levels were still seven-fold
higher at 120 minutes.
        The mechanism by which GHB stimulates growth-hormone release is not
known. Dopamine activity in the hypothalamus is known to stimulate pituitary
release of growth hormone, but GHB inhibits dopamine release at the same time
that it stimulates GH release. This suggests that GHB's GH-releasing effect
takes place through an entirely different mechanism [Takahara, 1977].
        At the same time GH is being released, prolactin levels also rise.
Serum prolactin levels increase in a similar time-dependent manner as GH,
peaking at five-fold above baseline at 60 minutes [Takahara, 1977]. This
effect, unlike the release of GH, is entirely consistent with GHB's inhibition
of dopamine. Other compounds which lessen dopamine activity in the brain (such
as the neuroleptic Thorazine) have been shown to result in prolactin release.
Although prolactin tends to counteract many of the beneficial effects of GH,
the sixteen-fold increases in GH probably overwhelm the five-fold increases in
prolactin.
        GHB induces "remarkable hypotonia" (muscle relaxation) [Vickers,
1969]. It is now gaining popularity in France and Italy as an aid to
childbirth. GHB causes "spectacular action on the dilation of the cervix,"
decreased anxiety, greater intensity and frequency of uterine contractions,
increased sensitivity to oxytocic drugs (used to induce contractions),
preservation of reflexes, a lack of respiratory depression in the fetus, and
protection against fetal cardiac anoxia (especially in cases where the
umbilical cord wraps around the fetus' neck) [Vickers, 1969; Laborit, 1964].
        GHB is completely metabolized into carbon dioxide and water, leaving
absolutely no residue of toxic metabolites [Vickers, 1969; Laborit, 1972].
Metabolism is so efficient that GHB can no longer be detected in urine four
to five hours after it is taken by injection [Laborit, 1964].
        GHB activates a metabolic process known as the "pentose pathway" which
plays an important role in the synthesis of protein within the body [Laborit,
1972]. It also causes a "protein sparing" effect [Laborit, 1964] which reduces
the rate at which the body breaks down its own proteins. These properties,
along with GHB's effect on growth hormone, underlie its common use as an aid
to muscle-building and fat loss.
        Anesthetic (large) doses of GHB are accompanied by a small increase in
blood sugar levels, and a significant decrease in cholesterol. Respiration
becomes slower and deeper. Blood pressure may rise or fall slightly, or remain
stable, but a moderate bradycardia (slowing of the heart) is consistent
[Vickers, 1969; Laborit, 1964]. A slight drop in body temperature also occurs
[Laborit, 1964].
        GHB also stimulates the release of acetylcholine in the brain
[Gallimberti, 1989].

        --- GHB and Sleep ---

        GHB has been called "almost an ideal sleep inducing substance" [SMART
DRUGS II, p245]. Small doses produce relaxation, tranquility and drowsiness
which make it extremely easy to fall asleep naturally. Higher doses increase
the drowsiness effect and decrease the time it takes to fall asleep. A
sufficiently large dose of GHB will induce sudden sleep within five to ten
minutes [Laborit, 1964].
        Many other hypnotics interfere with various stages of the sleep cycle
thus preventing the body from achieving a complete and balanced session of
rest and recuperation. The most remarkable facet of GHB-induced sleep is its
physiological resemblance to normal sleep. For instance, GHB sleep is
characterized by increased levels of carbon dioxide in the arteries, as in
normal sleep [Vickers, 1969]. During normal and GHB sleep, the CNS continues
to be responsive to "noxious stimuli" (pain and other irritations), a factor
which sets limits on GHB's uses in anesthesia [Vickers, 1969]. GHB facilitates
both REM (rapid eye movement) sleep, and "slow-wave" (non-REM) sleep, the
stage of sleep featuring increased release of growth hormone [Laborit, 1972].
And unlike the unconsciousness induced by other anesthetics, that triggered by
GHB does not feature a systemic decrease in oxygen consumption [Laborit,
1964].
        The primary disadvantage to GHB's use as a sleep aid is it's
short-term influence--about three hours. During GHB's influence, sleep is
deeper and more restful, but after the GHB has worn off, people have a
tendency to wake up. The higher the dose, the greater is this tendency. Some
have called this pattern the "dawn effect" and have speculated that it is
related to the release of stored-up dopamine. Some people minimize this effect
by taking minimal doses of GHB. Others take advantage of this effect by
getting a couple of hours of work done in the middle of the night. Still
others choose to take a second dose of GHB to sleep for another three hours.
        It should be noted that not everyone can be put to sleep by GHB. We
have spoken to three men who have never achieved sleep even with the doses
normally used for such purposes. In addition, Takahara [1977] reported that
one of the six men in the growth hormone study cited above remained conscious
even though he had received two and a half grams of GHB intravenously, a
dosage which rendered the rest of the participants unconscious.

        --- GHB, Alcohol and Alcoholism ---

        GHB shows great promise in the treatment of alcoholism. In Europe,
one of its primary uses is to relieve withdrawal symptoms, cravings, and
anxiety among alcoholics.
        In laboratory rats addicted to alcohol, withdrawal symptoms closely
resemble those exhibited by humans, including tremors, convulsions, and
hypersensitivity to sound. All of these symptoms were blocked by sufficiently
high doses of GHB [Fadda, 1989]. Administration of GHB has also been found to
prevent alcohol consumption among rats that voluntarily ingest alcohol
[Fadda, 1989; Gallimberti, 1989].
        In a rigorous, double-blind, placebo-controlled study conducted of
human alcoholics, "nearly all withdrawal symptoms disappeared within two to
seven hours" after administration of GHB. On a severe-moderate-mild-or-none
scale, withdrawal symptoms remained below moderate during the entire period.
The only side effect observed was slight, occasional, and transient dizziness.
The researchers concluded, "the results clearly indicated that GHB is
effective for the suppression of withdrawal symptoms in alcoholics"
[Gallimberti, 1989].
