Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Sorry about the massive bandwidth consumption but this is important...

There's been a HUGE amount of response and questions from all over the
world on how to assemble these booklets.  Below is a basic description on
how to set up the text layout and assembly.  Enclosed is a revised version
of the text based on some of those comments.


If you follow the proceedure below, you can make a handy little booklet
that fits perfectly into your back pocket and doesn't end up on the floor.
We're making ours with flourescent paper to further entice people to keep
them and take 'em home to read.


HOW TO CONFIGURE THE TEXT BY PAGE NUMBER:
(3 sheets per booklet- front and back)

     Front         Back
I-----i------II------i------I
Iback i      II pg 1 ipg 18*I
Icoveri coverII blanki----- I
Iblanki      II      i------I
I-----i------II------i------I
I pg  i      II      i      I
I 17  i  2   II  3   i 16** I
I     i      II      i      I
I_____i______II______i______I

     Front         Back
I-----i------II------i------I
I     i      II      i      I
I  5  i  14  II  15  i   4  I
I     i      II      i      I
I-----i------II------i------I
I     i      II      i      I
I  7  i  12  II  13  i   6  I
I     i      II      i      I
I_____i______II______i______I

     Front         Back
I-----i------II------i------I
I     i      II      i      I
Iblankiblank IIblank iblank I
I     i      II      i      I
I-----i------II------i------I
I     i      II      i      I
I 11  i   8  II  9   i  10  I
I     i      II      i      I
I_____i______II______i______I

*Page 18 is just a bunch of lines to write phone numbers of new raver friends!
**Page 16 is specific to the Southern California area only!!!



HOW TO ASSEMBLE THE BOOKLETS:

1)Layout the text with the corresponding page #s as above

2)After placing the text into quadrants on each page, photocopy them double
sided as indicated above (top to top)

3)If you've done everything correctly and accounted for some margin space,
you should be able to cut each page EXACTLY across the middle of the page
so that you end up with 5 horizontal half sheets of paper with printing on
front and back.

4)Arrange the half sheets in numerical order.

5)Fold the half sheet EXACTLY through the center so that it makes a booklet

6)Staple through the binding (you may need a long stapler!)

7)Pass them out to all the ravers you meet!



Feel free to costumize them as needed for your community...

Like the first paragraph says "This is booklet is not intended to be
definative in its' approach... it is a starting point for communication
about very important issues that directly affect each of us."


RESPECT+
ACCOUNTABILITY+
COMMUNICATION & EDUCATION=
RAVE ELATION FOREVER !




For more information or to find out how you can help in our
fight to generate greater responsibility in the rave community
please write to:

Responsibility in Raving
Kc-of-DUNE
2014 N. Sycamore  1st floor
Los Angeles, CA   90068

or e-mail to
sarahtonen@earthlink.net




--========================_16300076==_
Content-Type: text/plain; name="Handbook_Text"; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="Handbook_Text"

<cover>

how much do you love raving?


a handbook for responsible raving


<P A G E  1 BLANK>


<P A G E  2>
The Goodvibe Starts from Within

Stop complaining
about everyone else.  What about yourself?
Are you treating others
the way you want to be treated?
That is the only route toward the
positivity that will unite us all.
Don't be afraid!
Fear is the source of all our conflicts and
aggressions.
The next time someone gives you a hard look,
understand that they are still captive
to their fears like you once were.
Don't resort to a negative response because that
will only create more  negativity.
Smile! Let the goodwill within you flow!
Maybe your strength and love will give them
the courage to open themselves,
and they will follow the new direction.
It is all up to you...
						-tito



<P A G E  3>
This booklet is not intended to be definitive in its' approach...
it is a starting point for communication about very important
issues that directly affect each of us.

Our hope is that it will encourage you to step away
from the music with some friends for a moment so
that you can discuss the importance of individual
efforts in responsible raving.




Yeah?  So what's the problem?

It is becoming more and more difficult to continue our cultural
phenomenon known as the "Rave Movement." The reason
that raving is more difficult is because raves and even smaller
parties are being shut down by the police and other authorities
at an alarming rate.  Apart from DJs, sound and lights, in
order to throw a successful event you need secure locations,
permits/permission and insurance.  With any of these
ingredients missing there is a strong chance that the event will
not get off the ground.

In order to get these ingredients we must go to people outside
of the rave community... the public.


<P A G E  4>
It is the public that formulates opinions about us as ravers.
Most times it is public opinion that keeps a landowner from
granting us on his property... that keeps an insurance
company from providing a necessary policy... that keeps civil
agencies from issuing a permit that makes an event legal and
"unbustable."

The police are not shutting us down because of a giant
conspiracy against ravers, raving and living life to its'
fullest...

They are shutting us down because of our own...

selfishness
carelessness
&
ignorance

If we rid ourselves of these anchors, our public image will
greatly improve and our fragile movement will surely
flourish.

How?  What can you do?  A lot!

YOU can make or break our movement!

<P A G E  5>
It is incredibly easy to combat selfishness,
carelessness and ignorance and still have the time
of your life... maybe even have a better time than you've
ever experienced.  Imagine having the best time you've ever
had at a rave... now couple that with the feeling of
satisfaction and accomplishment that you would get from
helping build up and progress our scene... knowing that you
did your part.


*SELFISHNESS IS OVERCOME
BY RESPECT*

Each rave event is not yours alone... it is a communal
experience made for everyone.  It is the togetherness of
everyone that makes raves fun and fulfilling.  To completely
kill a group experience it only takes a few individuals who
don't understand the concept of community.  Here are some
examples of selfish acts.  Each is  followed by a way to
overcome the selfishness.

-RESPECTING  THE PUBLICS'' OPINION OF RAVERS-
Visibility of drugs and alcohol-
Drugs are taboo to most of the public that forms an opinion about us... the
same public that gives us permission to gather and rave.  If you feel that
you need to have your mood
elevated, please be discrete.  Don't let anyone see the presence of drugs.
Don't give them a reason to accuse us.  Nitrous balloons are the biggest
problem in this area.  Balloons can easily be seen from a great distance
and the hiss of the valves makes it very easy to find the tanks.  PLEASE
DON'T BRING BALLOONS OR NITROUS TANKS INTO RAVES!   Similarly marijuana can
easily be smelled.  It is more difficult to findbut don't make it obvious.

<P A G E  6>
Being rude or obnoxious to non-ravers-
Rude and obnoxious behavior does nothing but upset people,
sometimes to the point of having them call the police.  Please
be polite to any "outsider" that you encounter while on the
way to or away from a rave.  Be polite to everyone for that
matter!

Noise-
Noise is a very big problem in most residential areas and is
often the reason for shut-downs.  Please be as quiet as
possible going to site.  Playing car radios loud, horn
honking, screeching tires and yelling can be louder than the
sound system enclosed in the venue.  Loitering around in the
parking area is illegal and only draws unwanted attention to
the party.  As you're walking to the door remember that you
are only moments away from being able to make as much
noise as you want!!

Fireworks-
Although cool to see, fireworks are a reason for instant shut-
downs. We all know about the danger of fires.  Enough said.
Additionally, the loud explosions can be misconstrued as
gun-shots which will get the police to the location faster than
anything.

Guns and Violence-
Neither of these belong at a rave.  It is our non-violent nature
that sets us apart from the rock and rap scenes.  Hopefully, a positive
rave experience will change the life of a violent natured person.


<P A G E  7>
-RESPECTING EVENT FACILITIES AND THE DESERT-

Parking-
Park only where it is permitted and, once again, don't hang
out in the parking lot or on the streets.  Don't throw trash and
flyers on the ground.  Keep as low a profile as possible.

Tagging-
We lose locations because of tagging more than anything else.
Tagging simply tells the landlord that we don't have any
respect for him or his property even though it is the landlord
that has been so kind to share his property with us.  Tagging
makes insurance rates climb. If you see someone tagging,
explain to them that they are keeping you from being able to
rave in L.A.  Ask them if they want to continue to rave...
then ask them to please stop.  Make sure everyone in the
area hears you so that they also become involved in making
the tagger stop.

Trash-
Many times the property owner is shocked by the trash left in
the facility, especially bathrooms.  It only takes a few seconds
to find a trash can... a very worthwhile investment of your
time.  Trash and especially flyers should NEVER be dropped
outdoors.  The wind can blow them away and where they will
never be found... except perhaps by a park ranger or other
authority figure.  It is very difficult to say  "that trash
was already there when we got here" when the trash is a
bunch of rave flyers.  Gum, candy and cig butts can be just as
incriminating.

<P A G E  8>
-RESECT FOR OTHER RAVERS-

Aggression/Violence-
Part of the attraction of a rave is that it can be a place to escape the
craziness of the rest of the world.  Leave your personal problems at the
door...    don't bring them into the celebration. Alcohol often brings
about aggressive behavior as well.

The rave scene prides itself on its' peaceful nature so there is absolutely
no tolerance for violence or aggression.  This even includes any
frustration that you may have with security, entry lines, etc.

A peaceful but enthusiastic attitude can quickly spread to others creating
a pocket of "vibe" that everyone will want to be a part of.  Acceptance of
others, even those different from
you, catches on quickly and creates a bond among all of us.  When outsiders
look in at our scene and see this bond, they cannot discredit it... they
can only see something positive...
perhaps it will be something that they will discuss with others. This is
the easieast way that we can create a more positive public image!

Blatant Selfishness-
This not only kills "the vibe" but it breaks us apart, making it difficult
to band together to help our movement as a whole.  A prime example of this
is blatant nitrous usage.  People sucking on balloons must know that  they
are jeopardizing EVERYONE'S right to rave and yet they continue to do it.  T
heir short-term high becomes more important than the future of raving
itself.  This kind of selfishness will certainly kill our future.  PLEASE
DON'T BRING NITROUS TO RAVES... leave it at home where it won't be a
selfish act that discredits all of us.


<P A G E  9>
*CARELESSNESS IS OVERCOME
THROUGH ACCOUNTABILITY*

Carelessness, which sometimes is accidental, can easily be
overcome through a system of accountability.  It only takes
two friends to commit to be accountable to each other in
reminding the other if they are being careless.  The more
people you have in your accountability group (also called
"true friends"), the less likely you are to do something
careless. Create an acountability group with the friends you rave with the
most.   Ask someone to be accountable for you RIGHT NOW!!!!

All you have to do is give a simple reminder.... speak up and
say, "I don't think it's such a good idea for you to do that."
Here are some places where carelessness becomes a problem
for each of us in the rave movement:

Forgetting about any of the above selfishness issues-
Go ahead... re-read them!

Driving safely-
There is nothing wrong with being too messed up or too tired
to drive home... unless of course you try to drive anyway.
Ask a more sober friend from your accountability group to
drive or wait until someone is able to drive.  Coffee and other
stimulants won''t do the trick..  Take your time so you
and your friends can rave again another day!
	
<P A G E  10>
Dealing with the wrong people-
Who are the wrong people? Unscrupulous drug dealers are just as problematic
as undercover drug enforcement agents. If you think getting something
"bunk" is a problem.... think about how bad it would be if you bought
something poisonous or lethal! This is becoming a bigger and bigger problem
as drug manufacturers are finding cheaper ways to make money. Most of them
aren't chemists and don't bother testing their new batch... you may become
a "test subject" for an unknown substance.   The media and law enforcement
agencies are infiltrating our masses to collect information to use against
us at a later time. You can never know who is who... so be careful.  Know
who you're dealing with.

Loitering outside of the venue-
This only draws attention to the  event and makes police curious enough to
"investigate."  Loitering also makes it more difficult to patrol a parking
area to look for people breaking into cars or doing other selfish
activities that hurt individual ravers and hurt the scene overall.  When
you're walking through a parking lot and you see people standing around ask
them to please go inside... but explain to them why it is important for
them to help in this regard.

Acting safely/Acting responsibly-
This is a broad area that has too many specific "infractions." Every once
in a while just ask yourself (and the people you''re accountable for) these
questions...

What am I doing?
Am I directly/indirectly harming myself or other ravers?
Am I keeping someone else from having a great time?
Am I helping build a positive public image about the rave scene?

<P A G E  11>
*IGNORANCE IS OVERCOME THROUGH
COMMUNICATION AND EDUCATION*


Ignorance is the easiest problem to overcome but it also depends on
individual efforts..  All we need to do is educate ourselves.  But two
things must happen before we can educate each other.

First, we must be willing to be educated... we must recognized that we are
being stupid and want to change.

And secondly, we must communicate with each other.

Since we have no organized arena for ravers to come together and
communicate we are held in the dark.  We must find a centralized forum
where together we can learn from our past mistakes and innovate our future.
Until we find that forum, it is up to you to discuss these problems and
re-shape our future.

The existence of rave culture depends entirely on you to simply talk with
one another... to share all of these important issues with others... with
people you meet for the first time.

<P A G E  12>
Know what you're talking about-
Rumors and misinformation are splitting us apart.  Know the facts about the
realreasons for "busts"... or the dangers of certain substances.  Don't let
yourself be used as a tool for a promoters personal gain... or mouthpiece
for fabricated drug hysteria.

Know what you're taking-
We've already discussed unscrupulous drug dealers.  Don't combine lots of
different drugs!  There are combinations of substances that can quickly
become lethal.  In fact, more drug related casualties are due to lethal
combinations of drugs and alcohol than overdosing!

Let the DJ do the mixing!

Know your limit-
Your accountability group can help you with this.  Be careful trying to
"bump" your dosage.  Always let someone know exactly how much of what your
taking BEFORE you take it.

Know the law-
Get to know the specific legalities of possessing controlled substances.
Know the consequences if you're busted and ask yourself if it is worth the
risk.

Know how to handle yourself with the police-
Be cooperative but also know your rights regarding search and seizure laws
(especially in searching a vehicle).  Avoid dragging down the rave scene
with you.  Don't even mention
raves if you have a run in with officers.  Be afraid of the seriousness of
the consequences but don't let yourself be intimidated to the point that
you incriminate yourself.


<P A G E  13>
Know what to do in case of an emergency-
This is a very important area if we wish to police ourselves at raves.

In case of an overdose or other drug related medical trauma
follow these steps before calling an ambulance.

1)Move the victim to a safe, private and discrete area away
from the noise and everyone else.

2)Find out EVERYTHING that they took... including
dosage, combinations and alcohol.

3)Find the victims friends.

4)Don't panic.  Some drug related trauma can be relieved
simply through sleeping it off.

5)Find someone trustworthy and knowledgeable about those
substances and get their advice. (Like Medi-Rave!)

6)Do NOT administer CPR, induce vomiting, or other
first aid proceedures unless fully capable and qualified.

7)In the desert or in a hot venue, dehydration
could be the problem, so try drinking some water.

8)If necessary ask security to call for help or ambulance.


<P A G E  14>
Know your promoters-
It's time that ravers determine how much an event is worth.
If you think you're getting ripped off or if a promoter is
constantly being busted... STOP SUPPORTING THOSE EVENTS!!!  Try to remember
that promoter's  other events.  Think about what the promoter promised for
those raves...

Bust-free? (which might not really possible anymore)
Carnival rides/visuals/multiple areas?
Free water/gifts/etc.?
Big name Djs/bands?

So what do you and your accountability group do if you're
not getting your money's worth?  All of you should:

-find and tell the promoter that you're not satisfied
-leave a message(s) on the voice mail
-don't go to that promoter''s events again
-write letters to local music magazines
-post to the internet rave related mail groups
-throw your own event... large or small!!!

Remember that many promoters throw raves for a living and
that they must make money.  We're not asking promoters to
lose money!  We're thankful that they go through all the
hassle to even HAVE an event to go to.  However, we ARE
asking promoters to re-invest into the scene.... after all... if
the scene doesn't survive, the promoters don't survive either.

Support promoters that are helping our movement flourish...
that are innovating with creative ideas...that deliver what they
promise... that re-invest in the scene... that respect ravers,
DJs, venues, officers, public opinion and Mother Earth!

<P A G E  15>
The best way to combat ignorance is to get and stay informed.
All that is required of this is communication!  Call unbiased
info lines to get the "scoop" on upcoming events.  Read the
local magazines that report on rave culture.

Perhaps the BEST way to get informed is... if you know
someone with an internet connection... get online!  Subscribe
to So-Cal Raves or visit web sites like Dr. Freeclouds and
Hyperreal (see next page).

 The information  and feedback offered by online
communication can really benefit you as an individual raver
and will help the rave movement flourish overall.  Here's
what you can get from being informed through the net:

-A calendar of upcoming raves, clubs, after-hours and rave-related radio/TV
shows
-Help determine which promoters and events are worthwhile
-Find out about events that you may have missed
-Read other ravers'' opinions of events, DJs, music, and mix tapes
-Find out more about DJs or bands you like
-Voice your frustrations about specific rave related issues
-Get advanced info on location, line-up, changes, and mergers
-Get info on specific drug-related warnings or scams
-Learn more about rave/DJ culture
-Find out about unpromoted events and micro-raves
-MOST IMPORTANTLY...
Find new raver friends that share similar tastes and views with you.


<P A G E  16>
Getting Online-

To learn more about So-Cal Raves visit the So-Cal Raves
WWW homepage.  You''ll find info about the list, the people
on it, the calendar of events and how to subscribe.

Just point your browser to:

http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/socal/

For more info on responsible recreational drug use, raving,
music and more go to:

http://www.hyperreal.com/

To get rave info on specific LA events and issues go to
Dr. Freeclouds at:

http://www.drfreeclouds.com

Thanks for your time!  Hope to see you online and
at many fabulous future raves!		
         -Kc-of-DUNE

Thanks to those who care enough to help:
My So-Cal Raves Family, Hyperreal, Mason Lyte,
Medi-Rave,Tito, tom-of-stimuli, John 'n' Veronica,  Dallas,
Garrett, Moontribe, Moonchild, DUNE...
...and YOU !


<P A G E  17>
Recreational drug use is an evolving issue of individual
freedom. This manual does not promote the use of illegal
drugs or encourage illegal activity.  The practical
references listed here are in no way to be construed as
favoring the use of controlled substances or  illegal
activity but, is  solely intended to promote
greater awareness of the issues of safety and
responsibilty in raving.



RESPECT+
ACCOUNTABILITY+
COMMUNICATION & EDUCATION=
RAVE ELATION FOREVER !




For more information or to find out how you can help in our
fight to generate greater responsibility in the rave community
please write to:

Responsibility in Raving
2014 N. Sycamore  1st floor
Los Angeles, CA   90068

or e-mail to
sarahtonen@earthlink.net

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: bwret@best.com (Alex Ward)
Subject: 60's movie
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night I saw a flick aptly titled "the Hippie Revolution". First off:
it was incredibly cheesy! Imagery of naked girls frolicking through the
forest...a girl selling a newspaper for twenty cents which is dipped in
acid and can be rolled up and smoked (?!?)- scenes like this are all too
stereotyoical and campy. At the same time, the entire film/documentary is
set in SF...which still looks the same!! The way the kids were talking
about the communal love they felt was reallt remeniscent of my first summer
in the scene. But somehow the innocence was lost...after the disenchanted
70's...the money-grubbing 80's, we're trying our best, but who can blame us
for being at least a bit cautious.
       It was also amazing that so many people migrated here from around
the world in 1967. I always wish that we could have a bigger community
which was highly mobile (like the rave cummunity in the UK), but we are so
large and diverse- nestled in alcoves across the country. Imagine what SF
would be like if a 100,000 kids came here (crowded, sure!) for the scene.
That's what 1967 was like...anyhows, despite the cheesiness of the movie,
the images of the past blew my mind.
-peace, love, dove and BBQ's-
alex

Alex Ward
bwret@best.com                         May the Funk be with you...Always.

Subject: Need Your Help Reviewing Raves!!!
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey Everybody -

I am in the currently in the process of making a website devoted to 
personal rave reviews in the S.F. bay area. Originally I was going to 
write all the reviews myself, but it would take forever for me to 
review the 75+ raves I've been to in the last few years.

So I've decided to open it up to you guys. If you've been to a rave in 
the last few years that you absolutely loved (or hated). Write a review 
of approx. 250 words or less with this format:

Title
By (your name)
Date: (date)
Location: (location)

Body

Then e-mail it to me with "Rave Reviews" in the subject.

Please feel free to make them as personal as possible. Write whatever
you want. But depending on the response (and server space) I may not be 
able to publish every single review, but I'll try my best. The site 
should be up in a week or two. 

Big special thanks the Troy Sheets and Mike Migurski for helping me get
this thing going! =)

PLUR,

CT

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lmnt@immersivearts.org (ed colmar)
Subject: Help us buy a tent for the rave camp at burning man!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


We are raising funds to purchase a huge tent to cover rave camp at burning
man, and to provide shelter for underground outdoor raves in the bay area.
Which would extend outdoor party season through the winter.

Those of you that have attended burning man before know how important shade
and shelter are, and this will provide them both, protecting us and (uh,
one of the) soundsystems.

The tent we want to get is 20 feet by 60 feet, canvas with removable side
walls (that help keep heat and sound in and wind and dust out), and High
ceilings (for killer light shows and scaffolding towers).  Ever seen a
circus tent?

-------------------

The price of the tent is : $9930.00

$7770.00 - Top and frame
$2160.00 - 16 - 10 foot sections of side walls

-------------------

Damn pretty expensive...  Well, it's worth a shot...  Many people will
benefit from it.  I believe this may be worth substantial money to some...


So If you want to rave in the shade/rain/hail/sandstorms, send me what it's
worth to you...  I'll hold all donations until we have all the money, if we
don't get enough, I'll send it back to you.

If you want to check my scene friendly credentials, contact Ethan Miller,
Tom Leichardt, Derek, or anyone in Gateway systems.

-------------------

Send checks (payable to me) to:
ed colmar
6114 LaSalle ave #120
Oakland Ca 94611

Be sure to include a return address, a phone number and email.

If you have an ecash account, you can donate on the Web.

http://www.immersivearts.org/trust/

Do it fast too, there are outdoor events happening now that could be
benefiting from this hardware, and burning man isn't too far away.

-------------------

Some math for reference...

9930/20 = 496.5 (I personally don't think that many people will donate)
9930/50 = 198.6 (more reasonable cost)
9930/75 = 132.4 (getting pricey, but more realistic people wise)
9930/100 = 99.3 (I dunno....)

-------------------

Feel free to spread this information to those that may be interested.

::hugs::

e

        We live in American right, I just woke up...... Oh, yeah we live in
American where almost anything can be purchased, and also RENTED or better
yet LEASED.  I think this would be much more a prudet idea than investing
10k in a tent. Just my 2 cents worth.

Peace
Brian

Allergic  to Reality, It Gives Me A Rash


At 01:58 PM 7/20/96 -0800, you wrote:
>
>We are raising funds to purchase a huge tent to cover rave camp at burning
>man, and to provide shelter for underground outdoor raves in the bay area.
>Which would extend outdoor party season through the winter.
>
>Those of you that have attended burning man before know how important shade
>and shelter are, and this will provide them both, protecting us and (uh,
>one of the) soundsystems.
>
>The tent we want to get is 20 feet by 60 feet, canvas with removable side
>walls (that help keep heat and sound in and wind and dust out), and High
>ceilings (for killer light shows and scaffolding towers).  Ever seen a
>circus tent?
>
>-------------------
>
>The price of the tent is : $9930.00
>
>$7770.00 - Top and frame
>$2160.00 - 16 - 10 foot sections of side walls
>
>-------------------
>
>Damn pretty expensive...  Well, it's worth a shot...  Many people will
>benefit from it.  I believe this may be worth substantial money to some...
>
>
>So If you want to rave in the shade/rain/hail/sandstorms, send me what it's
>worth to you...  I'll hold all donations until we have all the money, if we
>don't get enough, I'll send it back to you.
>
>If you want to check my scene friendly credentials, contact Ethan Miller,
>Tom Leichardt, Derek, or anyone in Gateway systems.
>
>-------------------
>
>Send checks (payable to me) to:
>ed colmar
>6114 LaSalle ave #120
>Oakland Ca 94611
>
>Be sure to include a return address, a phone number and email.
>
>If you have an ecash account, you can donate on the Web.
>
>http://www.immersivearts.org/trust/
>
>Do it fast too, there are outdoor events happening now that could be
>benefiting from this hardware, and burning man isn't too far away.
>
>-------------------
>
>Some math for reference...
>
>9930/20 = 496.5 (I personally don't think that many people will donate)
>9930/50 = 198.6 (more reasonable cost)
>9930/75 = 132.4 (getting pricey, but more realistic people wise)
>9930/100 = 99.3 (I dunno....)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jul 20 21:23:25 1996

Date: Sun, 14 Apr 1996 21:34:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Josh Kneubuhl <joshk@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
X-Sender: nancy@bamboozle.HIP.Berkeley.EDU
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: BBQ and all of U 
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960720204044.23630A-100000@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Just back from the BBQ, sunburned, grinning, and STUFFED.  What a lovely 
day!  What lovely people!  What a nice party!  

Pt. Molate is beautiful of course, a little cove at the foot of Richmond 
Bridge that is just far enough away from civilization to let us seriously 
CHILL.  So great to see all you netheads out in PERSON (yes, there ARE 
real people behind the posts!).  Finally got my requisite necklace 
laminates (had felt like a naked raver without them :).  And macked on 
the F-n-F tix.  A sell-out before the last veggie dog had even been 
cooked!  It's a trip that 600 tickets would go just from the greater F-F 
collective and the internet picnic'ers - I guess our extended family is 
HUGE!  And many more are going to be bummed out to miss it.

Music was _really_ good, our own Jon dropped the bomb on us, Jeff got 
biological on our asses, but the sun was too hot for many of us to show 
our appreciation.  I bobbed my head in the shade.

And the FOOD!  You SFRavers are too generous - every single person (it 
seemed) came loaded down with bags of food, way more than we could consume (though I tried my 
best!).  Props due to Paul's brownies, Eric's massive fruit salad, and of 
course Tim for standing over a steaming barbeque all fuckin day (and for 
organizing this, you're the best!).

Keep an eye out for Chris the cameraman.  He's got stacks of amazing 
pictures from many parties, and he is truly an artist.  Especially good 
is his trick of layering several images, so ravers appear to be dancing 
amid fields of daisies or one person is shown in several moments.  The 
images really captured (for me) the true feelings and range of 
raving.  I wished I could have them in a book to show outsiders when 
I try to tell them what I feel.

Good-night!  Have loads of fun wherever you are headed tonight - 
Eon, New Moon, or (like me) something NRR.  'Cause I like to keep it 
something special. 

Love, Nancy

> I'll probably write more on this another time but::
> 
>      Do not take someone who gets drunk for fun.
>      Do not bring someone who has anything against: gays, men in womens
> clothing, people who are diffirent, or people who do drugs.
>      Do not bring someone that has to bitch about everything (you'll thank
> me for this).
>      Do not bring someone looking to get laid.
>      Do not bring someone who usually doesn't do anything ever and always
> just sits at home wondering what to do when there's tons of things that they
> wouldn't do anyway.
>      Do not bring a violent person.
>      Do not bring a person with any respiratory problems.
>      Don't bring a clean freak.
>      
>      Do bring the opposite of the above.
>      Do bring loveable, kind, sharing people.
>      Do bring someone who could have a good time dancing, or watching people
> dance, or meeting people.

From: David Lowe <dlowe@best.com>

  Whoopee!

  Well, I had a great time at the BBQ too.  It was my first outdoor rave,
and it was great!  There is definitely something to be said for dancing &
music in an outdoor setting.  Quite a different experience, and, I'm happy
to say, a very good one.

  The space was gorgeous.  The sunset was not very dramatic, but still
gorgeous.  The food was excellent!  I brought lots, but there was so much
food that I got most of mine back at the end of the night.  I don't know
what I'll do with all the veggie dogs :)

  The music was good, up until the last DJ came on (sorry, I don't know
any names)... then, it was GREAT!  I danced a fair bit, and it took me a
few hours to figure out that barefoot was the way to go.  It only took a
few minutes to figure out that it wouldn't be wise to dance in the full
sun though!  It was hot!  Beautiful weather we've been having.

  Best of all was the people.  I had wanted to meet lots of SFRavers...
but in the end, shyness got the best of me, and I only met a few new
people (matt/lanima00, crunch, and a couple others) - hi!  It was also a
great chance for me to hang out with a couple of the sfravers I already
had met (john k, robert, mattloaf - howdy!) in a more laid back
environment than a full blown, overnight rave.  To the curious: I was the
guy with the outgrown buzz-cut (damn, I need a haircut!), wearing a dark
red t-shirt and black corduroy cut-offs - and a big grin most of the time.
If I met you and didn't remember your name, please don't take offence!  I
have a crappy memory for names!
  
  Special thanks to the people who organized and executed this little
get-together.  It was really wonderful, and I hope there will be more!

  The rest of you will probably be at F&F next weekend, but I will be out
of town.  I'm pretty bummed about missing it.  But I will live.  AIDS walk
tomorrow.  Should be great.  Sleep well (or rave well to some of you!)
everyone!

: : J. David Lowe ::: dlowe@best.com ::: ai334@freenet.carleton.ca : :
:: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ ::::: ftp://ftp.best.com/web1/dlowe/ ::
 : : : : : : : : : finger for pgp key and geek code : : : : : : : : :

On Wed, 17 Jul 1996, Ethan Miller wrote:
> I also wanted to mention that this party will be a benefit for
> hyperreal.com, the system this list runs on and indeed a bastion of
> electronic music, rave and alternative culture not only locally but
> worldwide. Unfortunately our budget for this party, with a a donation of
> $5, is right at the break-even point. We will, therefore, have a donation
> box at the party and I personally would encourage everyone to support this
> amazing and ongoing project. Many, many thanks to Brian and to everyone
> else that has made hyperreal what it is. Nice one.

I just want to say, to Ethan and to everyone else at FnF: 
thank you! thank you! thank you!  There's actually a good amount of
upgrading that I've been meaning to do on hyperreal (more disk space, more
memory, and a new motherboard - with the latter, perhaps a new OS) which
something like this will definitely help with.  Woohoo!  

With this as a spark, I will be starting a page on hyperreal which will
outline exactly what the "status" of the machine is - what hardware's
being used, what new hardware was bought, what's on the wish list, and
what the donation level is at, etc.  I think that's only fair, so you know
where the money is going, etc.  I'll post details about that when it's up.

See you all next Saturday night!

	Brian

Jonathan, BioJeff and Tom did great also.

ended up wanting to stay for the whole thing, that was great. I also want

water, it looked really beautiful.

peoples...thanks everyone...what a great community we have together...so

Subject: Parties I went to with no names
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi again!

Despite my troubled heart, I still managed to pack in a full weekend of rad
parties Friday, Sat and in to Sun...  
Friday I went to this dinker party in Concord.  Not much, just a bunch of
friends doing the small intimate type, I had a good time and met some nice
folks...Till the po po's came at 1:00ish and made us all leave! Lame!  

But ever quest full, we ventured forth to Berkeley, where we went to the
"symbol" (no name...like Prince) party.  We were too late for the map point,
frustrated, about to go home, when some coolies struttin pointed the way!!!
 Was fate, cuz it was so much fun!  Two floors, rad outside area with cool
visuals (low tech, but  on 2  20X20' screens, all 60's style) plus a
synchronized strobe and low frequency sound generator experiment at like 4:30
upstairs...really mind boggling except for the lameos yelling (why? cuz they
turned off the beats? GO DOWN STAIRS!!!!) It's going to be a weekly, so you
should all check it out $10.00  510-869-4114  415-263-3926

And then,  on SAT I went to the coolest, deepest party I've been to in a
while, the GOA trance party in the woods!!! Well worth the giant hill we had
to climb to get there.  Beautiful setting.  Stars so bright you didn't need a
flashlight even after the moon went down.  Plus AMAZING music.  Admittedly, I
am not the most qualified judge, but it seemed the beats pouring from the
system there were the best music ever created since the beginning of time
(which is infinite).  But I did get agreement from some well knowledged
friends.  Strange system.  Two DAT tape decks that they used all night to mix
the most amazing shit, with some sort of little book with song names and
numbers in a list, all hand written.  SO MANY LAYERS OF SCI-FI FX!!!  Like
aliens on acid in a belching contest (oh no, that was just me).  Plus the fat
fast trancey beats holding it all together. Weirdness.  When I asked the DJ,
he said it was "stuff we made 'back home' that was still not on vinyl".  He
had an accent... from Germany? They had tables, but they didn't even use them
till like 8:00am (well, we got there at 11:00pm ish, and it had been going
since noon, so they might have earlier).  But, they didn't need them in my
opinion.  Who are these guys/gals?  Smiles, food to share at 7:00am, good
feelings, they all knew each other it seemed (by morning, or already?).
Really good folks, fun to dance with especially when there were only like 15
of us left! This is what the scene is really about (I believe). Even if the
dance floor was a dirt hill (I can see the headline:  Erosion Caused by
"Rave" Party Starts Rock Slide Covering the Town of Cazadero!!!!)!!

Shout out to the SFR people I met there: WATZUP TRIPPERZ!  

Ann:  Sorry, I forgot to give you my address...didn't remember until I was 
way down the hill...acadosi@aol.com

Brian: Thanks for the stoke, helped the synapses return to normal! 

Moander (aw, man! I forgot your real name!):  Dude!  Thank you SO MUCH for
pointing the way to this local [for me] party.  I even met some friends there
I didn't expect to see who I've been missing...

If they ever do it again, GO GO GOA!!!!!

Hope all your weekends were fun, and don't forget to follow your heart, even
if it hurts!

!!!TuO EcaeP

-J-dub, or Fust(long story) or Faust or just justin W.  you choose...

PS: I still need FnF tix as bad as an alcoholic needs a liver
transplant!!!pleasepleasepleaseplease....

Subject: Once Again, Killing The Mith About E & H
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

From: Nicholas Saunders <nicholas@neals.cityscape.co.uk>
Date: Sun, 27 Nov 1994 10:43:13 GMT

Newsgroups: alt.drugs
Subject: Ecstasy spiked with heroin and other rumours

This is an edited version of an article in December issue of
Eternity/magazine/Rumours

You've probably heard stories of E being spiked with addictive and
poisonous substances. True, when you buy "Ecstasy" there's no quality
control and you may well get cocktails of other drugs, particularly when
the dealer has run out of MDMA. You may also get a dud. But not heroin or
poison.

Every day the police confiscate suspect drugs which are sent to a
forensic laboratory at Aldermaston specially equipped to detect drugs,
and they have never come across drugs sold as Ecstasy containing heroin.
People taken to hospital with possible drug problems have samples of
their blood sent to the National Poisons Unit which has special equipment
to detect drugs: heroin has not been found in the blood of patients
reported to have taken only Ecstasy. So how did the rumours start?
A year ago Time Out magazine ran a double page feature entitled "Bitter
Pills", subtitled "Ecstasy has turned to agony for thousands of E users"
as dealers spike tablets and capsules with heroin, LSD, rat poison and
crushed glass. The story was repeated all over the place, even in a
Danish newspaper.

I questioned the source quoted: Stephen Beard of the Newham Drugs Advice
Project. He was elusive, and when I finally I got him on the phone would
only say that the story came from a dealer who said he made fake Ecstasy
by crushing light bulbs. There was no supporting evidence such as lab
tests or reports from doctors who had treated users. The National Poisons
Unit told me there had been no recent cases of poisoning due to ground
glass or rat poison. Yet, in spite of my protests, Newham and Time Out
did nothing to correct the story. Likewise, Mixmag's recent feature on
Ecstasy omitted to mention the Glasgow tests showing that Ecstasy was not
contaminated, even though they had the results. Mixmag also said: "300mg
MDMA can kill a small girl" (the lowest lethal dose recorded in animal
trials was 20mg/kilo, or 300mg for someone weighing 15kg: a very small
girl); and "MDA is like strong LSD mixed with speed" (MDA has no LSD-like
effects, it is similar to MDMA but longer lasting and with less warmth).
Its as though no-one wants to undermine the established myths.
One of these came from a satirical song in the fifties called The Old
Dope Peddler: "He gives the kids free samples because he knows full well,
that today's young innocent faces will become tomorrow's clientele". Its
no more likely than your local wine merchant going to the trouble and
expense of injecting bottles with heroin, hoping that you will become an
addict to boost his sales. True, some dealers cheat by selling any old
white powder as Ecstasy, but cheats are unlikely to sell heroin at a loss
or go to the trouble of crushing light bulbs.
Most of the substitutes found in Ecstasy are not harmful, but can produce
unexpected effects. However, before you blame the pill, you should
realise just how important is the situation and you own expectations. In
fact, very few people realise and accept how much the effect of drugs
like Ecstasy depends on their own situation, and state of mind at the
time. My best E experience was caused by an identical tablet as one that
made a friend sick and another that had no effect (at a party in an
enclosed tunnel).
Remember that E is not simply a happy pill, but lowers your defences and
allows you to open up. However, it may be more comfortable to remain
defensive and reserved unless you are in a situation where you feel good.
E can bring up suppressed feelings which you may not be prepared to face.
More on situations to avoid and emotional dangers next month.
Deaths in Scotland
I have been trying to discover what caused the deaths at Hanger 13 - so
as to inform people and prevent more tragedies. I have even spoken to say
they know but can't tell because, mad though it seems, Scottish law
prohibits them from revealing cause of death. However, the Home Office
licensed Glasgow University to collect and analyse 15 samples of
"Ecstasy" after the deaths. 14 were pure MDMA and one was a capsule that
contained speed with just a trace of MDMA. So it seems unlikely that
these deaths were due to poisons sold as Ecstasy. Incidentally, doctors
who had talked to users of "Rhubarb and Custard" said they believed it
contained "MDMA plus a strong hypnotic" (e.g. heroin). In fact it was
pure MDMA.
A possibility, believed by the National Poisons Unit, is that these
people died from overheating which has been the cause of nearly all rave
deaths, particularly in clubs with nonstop hard core techno, no chill-out
area and no free water. The tragedy is that those people didn't know the
importance of avoiding overheating. The media love to say that people who
take Ecstasy risk dropping dead without warning, but the warning is clear
to those who look out for it: getting too hot. The risk can be avoided by
taking breaks, cooling off and drinking plenty of water. Overheating also
kills people who do not take drugs, but without drugs the discomfort is
more obvious.
Another theory is that the Scottish victims took Temazapam or Valium with
Ecstasy. Reports say the two taken together can "hit you like a hammer".
The lesson is: "Don't mix E with other drugs and don't take too much too
often".

My book E for Ecstasy is completely sold out, but a revised edition is
freely available on Internet in two locations. You can download the book
in two files located at: ftp://ftp.hmc.edu/pub/drugs/mdma/e.for.ecstasy.Z
and e.for.ecstasy.append.Z. You can also browse through the book
on-screen and find references using hypertext: use World Wide Web and do
a Lycos search for Ecstasy. The next printed edition is due by the end of
February 1995.



Peace
Brian

PS If you get some E with H in it, please give it to me.

Another praise report for the BBQ & Beats II: I had a wonderful time the
whole time.  It was very special to prepare food together, to find others
who understand how nearly-sacred garlic is, to have been blessed with
grapes and nectarines to complete my fruit salad by two beautiful angels,
and to witness ground beef being Matt-handled ;)  All the food was
outstanding!  *BURP*  :)
The weather, the water, and the space were gorgeous, the music just right
and very danceable, even though the heat discouraged many of us from
getting out there till there was more shade.  Sound system was excellent!
The altar was a sight to behold, and looked especially enchanting right as
the sun was setting.
We learned a valuable lesson from Renaud: don't sit on a Styrofoam cooler!
Graceful Gazelle Award goes to our brother from France ;)
Thanks to everyone for being so supportive at a time when I really needed
it.  If I didn't seem as friendly as I usually am or maybe should have been
or whatever, it was due to my weird state of mind because of this Sara
situation.  I appreciate all of you, and all you did for me, more than you
know :)
It was cool meeting so many friends and seeing so many friends I've already
met.  Another one of those perfect parties where both happen throughout the
event.
OK, maybe I should do some work now...hope to see y'all at FnF!

Love and more love (with bbq sauce!),

Eric

Dear friends,

        Many of us had such a good weekend, and (hopefully) all of us want
to treat each other decently, so please let's not be nasty to each other.
Get past the wording in a message to find the sentiments behind those
words, if you read something that rubs you the wrong way.  Brother Matt's
intentions were beautiful, and it hurts when kindness is returned with
unkindness.
(Hey, Matt, can I have my $2 now?  J/k  ;)).

Love to all,

Eric

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello all,

        When I say I love you, please don't take it the wrong way.  I don't
do it expecting anything in return; I just mean that I appreciate you,
respect you, and value you, and wish you all the best.  I don't mean to
turn anyone off with mushiness or make anyone feel uncomfortable.  I'd say
"I love you, but don't let it go to your head," but that's kinda silly
(even for me ;)).  That's been on my mind for a long time, and I wanted
everyone to know it.
        Second note: In Saturday's mail, I received a card.  It's one of
those computer-printed cards that you print on a sheet of paper and fold in
quarters.  The art is in Egyptian style.  On the front it says "Beware the
thorns of the Black Rose of Love" and inside it says "Lest your Soul they
prick."  There's nothing written on the card.  The envelope has no return
address, has a San Jose postmark, and has the letter E on the back.  The
front has my first name, and the address was applied by cutting out my
return address from a piece of mail I sent someone.  This has me puzzled.
If anyone on this list sent this, please let me know who you are.  I
suspect it might have been Sara, but I'm not sure, and I'm very curious.

That's all for now.  Thanks!
Love, light, and peace to everyone,

Eric

Dear All;

        Every time I go to a Trance Party it's like visiting the United
Nations. The SF Trance scene is soooo much more multi-national and diverse,
than the other Techno styles. I routinely meet people from Germany, France,
England, Ireland, South Africa, Australia, & Japan. It's so empowering, like
I have the world before me and I'm it's embassador, right here, right now, I
can help change how we think & feel about one another through MY actions.
That it's MY responsibility to spread some love & goodwill that will travel
the world, and also get some of that global love for myself.

        Fuckin AYE!!!!!! It gives me sooooo much hope that yes, I can help
change the world for the better, That TODAY I helped the planet get a little
bit more positive, that TODAY I helped take back this grid we call planet
Earth from all the negativity that dominates our globe.

Peace
Brian

Dear All;

        I feel that often the road to hell is paved with good intentions. I
feel that it's the writers responsibility when composing their retoric to
make sure their ideas, feelings, and intentions are brought out in a clear
and concise manner allowing the reader to digest only the writers true
meaning. As difficult as it sounds, I certainly believe that it is possible
to do. I myself need a lot of help in doing the above mentioned, and would
be happy to hear some suggestions from our literary experts out there on how
this can be achieved.

Sincerely
Brian

ok...get this...I am writing a ten page paper on how media manipulates 
language to change their audience's perception on raves...say...lilke 
Hard Copy?!?!?
Anyhow...it would really help if y'all chipped in your opinion to help my 
evidence.  If you don't have much time, you can just type in y/n 
answers...thanks.

Do you think that media has a major handle on individual's perception of 
things (raves)?

Do you think that media from sources like Hard Copy,etc. purposefully 
misrepresent raves?

If you have seen-read the Hard Copy bit, do you think that they 
represented raves as they are?  Please comment.

Do you think that raves are a safe place to be?

What do you think is the negative side to raves?  and the positive?

Why do you attend raves/support them?

Please give additional examples of media misuse or media that represented 
the scene well (if you know of anymore).


Thanks for everyone who has helped me with this assignment so far!!
Rah-nay

From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: BBQ memoirs etc..
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960722105818.24490K-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a really great time at the BBQ.  It was so nice to sincerely talk 
with people and get to know them.  It's funny how my "raving" life goes 
in jumps and spurts.  My relationships with you guys goes from one 
weekend to the next, and this BBQ allowed me to bridge that gap somewhat.

The collective effort of the party was amazing and the music was good too!!


I got my FnF tix, and I have one word: EXCITEMENT!  I already told this 
to a bunch of you, but I was dreaming about what color the laminates 
would be the night before the BBQ (I dreamt the wrong color, though!).  
Maybe I'm just a spazz, but I derive so much fun from anticipation alone!!

I'm bringing two dear friends to FnF who have never ever been to a rave.  
I told them that if they never go to another one, they just can't miss 
this one!  My excitement comes off as very bizarre to them, but maybe 
they will understand after next weekend!  They have begun to ask me the 
list of "silly" questions, my favorite being "Is this going to be in one 
of those, you know, warehouses?"  Too cute!

I saw Roger's and Justin's pictures of Beautiful People.  I have to admit 
that I *never* thought there would be a picture of myself on the web.  It 
is so strange!! I kind of laugh about it because a year ago, I didn't 
even know how to use the web.  It's so funny:)  And, their pictures are 
amazing.  That camera made some really flattering pictures.

I remember everyone who I met, I just don't have time to list all the 
names.  I am very good at remembering names and also the first time I met 
you.  I also remember all of your posts (when I have time to read them) 
and all of the spellings of your names.  I think I have a slight 
photographic memory which I didn't realize until I realized that no one 
else seemed to remember some of the stuff I do!!  So, I have a challenge.  
If you see me, quiz me as to your name and where I met you.  If I get it 
wrong, I owe you a sticker!! :P

Have a great week, I'll be seeing you SOON!!

-KaySEE

okay.. run down of the weekend if peeps want to hear it.

Fri-  "Untitled" party.  Berkeley housing.  lo-tek 60's style visuals.  Nice
patio w/ torches.  Glass blowing person NICE touch.  Some good jungle work
by Polywog & Abstract.  Mind test experiment... woowoowoo.  Who the hell was
shouting '96??  Dutch (now Starbuck?) played high energy music in the early
morn.  People I saw (hi!).. girl promoting "Nation", Chris, branka, Jeff,
John and others.

Sat- BBQ and Beasts.. or was it BBQ and Beets.. Beef? (Nope.. no beef there)
=) Solid music. Lots of happy faces.  Real family style atmosphere..  Props
to all involved in putting it together (Tony, Tim).  Hi and hugs to Amy,
Paul, Kirsten, Nancy, Chris, Tony, John, Adam, CT, everybody else I met.  
If I didn't meet you, I was the guy with long hair running around in the
"Alien with Dr. Seuss hat" t-shirt, and shiny blue shorts.

Hung out with Jeff from Nexus.  Everyone should go to his party on the 23rd
of August called "Open".. If you liked "Second Chakra" you'll love this one.
I've got flyers if anyone needs them.  *SPECIAL*  There is going to be a
*live butterfly dome*  where you can sit among butterflies!

Sun- Hit Haight street.  Spun some reckids.  Drooled over new gear.  Saw
Mars + Myster-E at F-8.  Also saw Paul and John there. 
Watched the anime "Ghost in the Shell".  Definately pick this one up if you
like Japanimation.  Real dark futur kinda stuff.
Wanted to go to Mantra, but had to drive the hr and 1/2 home.. :(
 
Have a good week!
Aaron.

Hey all!

I am glad there are so many good reviews from last few days.  It just 
makes me happy to see how many people had fun :).

Friday night I ended up checking a small party in Concord, which was in 
an apartment complex, by the pool.  I didn't know many people, the 
party was too small, and I felt a little old (hmmm...  I usually don't, 
but that time i did).  My friends and I ended up leaving soon and going to 
Untitled.  The place was pretty cool (a dorm - I am impressed how people 
who live there didn't mind the loud music).  The upstairs area was OK, 
although it seemed there wasn't enough air at some points.  I ended up 
spending a lot of time in the nice outdoor area watching the LSD show 
:).  It was fun.  Met one SFR person - Aaron at the party - hey :))).

Saturday I couldn't stop thinking about the BBQ, because although Untitled 
was fun, I felt like I didn't know enough people and I wanted some of my 
friends to be there...  I guess I really depend on people :P.  
Everybody already said so much about the BBQ, that I am not sure what to 
say.  I LOVED it.  Thank you all for making it so much fun.  Big thanks 
to Tim (who stood by the BBQ all afternoon while the heat was kicking in) and 
Tony.  It was great seeing all the people I know.  The only thing I regret 
about the BBQ - I haven't met many new people.  I was reading some posts 
and I was looking forward meeting some of you guys, but somehow it just 
didn't happen (I guess I was too busy eating great food and dancing).  
For those that I met, but can't remember (except Nancy and Greg), I was 
wearing green bathing suite top and green baggy shorts, long brown hair..
 
I will be looking for you guys at FnF.  I also want to go to Theta, but I 
am not sure if 2 parties in 1 night will be possible.  Also, I heard so 
much about FnF and haven't had a chance to go to any, so that might be my 
first choice.  And many of you will be there :).

OK, time to get back to work....

Love you guys,
Branka

On Mon, 22 Jul 1996, Branka Cehic wrote:

> but that time i did).  My friends and I ended up leaving soon and going to 
> Untitled.  The place was pretty cool (a dorm - I am impressed how people 
> who live there didn't mind the loud music).  The upstairs area was OK, 


It's a student cooperative aka co-op.  Berkeley has the oldest, largest 
co-op system in the world.  It has lots of history, including FBI files 
during the 60's, and even a racketeering suit brought on one house during 
the late 80's.  The house where the party was has a lot of ravers, and it 
is notorious for obnoxious parties.  Green Day got their start there as 
well as many other bands!

just an old co-oper,

KaySEE

> the late 80's.  The house where the party was has a lot of ravers, and it 
> is notorious for obnoxious parties.  Green Day got their start there as 
> well as many other bands!
> 
> just an old co-oper,
> 
> KaySEE
> 
>               ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****
> 
> 
Thanks Kirsten,
I was aondering if I would have to set this record straight... dorm?...not
quite!

just another old co-oper
Tony Rose

Date: Mon, 22 Jul 1996 12:55:03 -0700
Message-Id: <199607221955.MAA20861@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (Beating my feet on the Mississippi mud....)
Subject: Review: BBQ & Beats
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It was Sunday morning, a GORGEOUS day.  I threw some pies in the front seat, 
the hamstas climbed in the back seat, and we sped off towards Pt. Molate and 
the BBQ...

Todds, Tims, Toms, Tony, et al, we all went to pick up the sound equipment 
and some more food.  Ethan provided the sound -- a very respectable system.  
We regrouped at the Point, joined by Shawna, Matt, Eric, Jeff, a couple of 
Jasons, and more.  We set things up, Matt and Eric prepared food, and we sat 
back and waited.

And the ravers came.

The sound started up with Todd Manley who threw down a short but fantastic 
set.  I got a chance to talk with Todd about a couple of his ideas for 
future sets.  I think we'll be seeing some really good stuff from this guy!  
The people gathered, ate good food, danced in the grass, and had a WONDERFUL 
time.  I tried to get the hamstas groovin, but they found a bushy spot next 
to the water and settled in for a nap.  Every time I'd try to get them 
dancing, they'd throw bits of grass at me and tell me to ... well, I won't 
tell you what they said, but I let them alone...

Tim has a grill that would get any guy's testosterone pumping.  He loaded 
the grill with goodies, loaded the goodies with his World Famous BBQ Sauce, 
loaded his forehead with lotion, and got BUSY churning out some serious 
grub.  By the end of the day the poor guy was burned out big time.  A truly 
heroic effort!

The New Moon folx set up an altar on some rocks next to the water.  A very 
nice touch.  I got my FnF tix (sorry, I only got 2), stuffed myself fool of 
food, and talked to SO MANY PEOPLE!  I was the regular social butterfly.  My 
apologies to anyone I just said a few words to before running off again.  
Y'know how little kids get when there's a lot of company over?  At first, 
they're a little shy.  Then they're running here and there playing with 
everyone.  Pretty soon they're overloaded, totally unable to sit still.  
That was me...  8)  About the only time I really sat still was to chat with 
the lovely Miss Starkey (FINALLY!).  And I also got a chance to meet Larry 
Ching and Brian Behlendorf (sp?).  Met the SFR Amazon, Marisa, and I got to 
flip through Chris' pix.  I think we'll be seeing a lot more of Chris' work 
in the future.

Leslie showed up with popsickles (WE'RE NOT WORTHY, WE'RE NOT WORTHY!)  Num, 
num!

Tom threw down excellent choons, backed up by BioJeff, Jon, and Monty.  Yow! 
 Great music!  Some of these "ravers" just sat and watched (woosies!!! ;) ), 
but I bopped around in my bare feet.  I even popped a little when the music 
got funky...  but don't tell no one...

But the star of the show: Ethan's daughter.  What a CUTEY!

Y'know, I really like the outdoor events because you can get away from the 
music and actually converse with someone if you want.  I got a chance to 
have intelligent, non-shouted, conversation with so many good people.

The sunset was soft and beautiful, and everyone cheered Nature's 
performance, but Kirsten and I both voice the opinion that it was over too 
soon.  I just wasn't ready for the sun to go down yet.  I wanted to keep 
playing.  Even Ethan's daughter (whose name escapes me) was upset -- she was 
bawling in his truck as we tried to load the gear up.

About this time I noticed some of the hamstas sitting on one of the rocks, 
wiggling their toes and watching the sun go down.  Some of them were bopping 
to the music.  Then they started pulling on their baggy jeans, bootie 
britches, and Adida jackets, packing their gear and sneaking off through the 
tall grass.  I heard them whispering about trying to find the New Moon party...

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

PLEASE READ:

BTW you guys, Tony and Tim put a lot of money into this venture out of 
pocket.  I *know* there weren't enough donations made to cover the whole 
thing.  We need to work something out so these guys don't take such a heavy 
hit just to help us get together.  Perhaps there should be an additional 
donation box sitting among the food.  Perhaps the food should be in a tent 
with tickets required to chow.  I don't know, but these guys shouldn't have 
to take it so hard in the wallet doing such great work, y'know?  Just my $.02.

S

Over the course of the last couple hours my cover has been blown.  I have
been successfully guiling you all.  Yes, I have been in disguise.  I am not
Tony Rotundo, stout contribtor to The Scene, sort of balanced, some what
adult like character that servers fruit and smiles indiscriminantly.  I do
not put positive energy into some of the fun parties that happen in this
area.  I do not like you at all.  In fact I hate you.  And one more thing!
I shall now reveal my true identity!

I am Ted Bennett, giant among men!  Yes, it's true, Alex Bennett is my
illegitimate father.  And that's why i hate him so.  He was so mean and
cruel to me...Once he made me watch Benny Hill for 48 hours straight.  By
the end I was in love with the old bald guy.  He was soooo cute!  Boy I
hated when Benny used to slap him around...

Anyway, with that said, that explains why I'm such a loud, farting,
dripping asshole to you all.  That's why deep down my master plan is to
throw a giant gala party called A Scam for Cash And Money (ASCAM) and take
all the proceeds and move to a deserted beach in Reno.  If anyone would
like to join me, feel free, but large breasted woman need only apply.
Damn, see there I go, just like dad again.  :^(

Oh one other horrible trait: I'm sarcastic on Monday mornings, and I know
that's what hurts most.

Please, if you see me out, you can now refer to me as Ted.

:^p
TB

P.S.  Thanks to *everyone* who made it out to the BBQ Saturday.  I think I
saw some old faces I'd just *love* to see again!  ;^)



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 22 14:18:01 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA11416; Mon, 22 Jul 1996 14:18:01 -0700
Received: from xanadu.cyborganic.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA11395; Mon, 22 Jul 1996 14:17:58 -0700
Received: (from tsheets@localhost) by xanadu.cyborganic.net (8.7.5/8.7.1) id OAA20364 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 22 Jul 1996 14:18:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199607222118.OAA20364@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: Cloud Factory disaster.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 22 Jul 1996 14:18:05 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


We really wanted to go to the New Moon party, becuase the weather in SF this
last weekend is as good as it gets.  New moon was cancelled, so....

After having so much fun at the Chi party, and hearing such great reviews
of the Cloud Factory party last year in Monterey, we made the trek down
for this year's Monterey party.

We went to Monterey, found that the map point was in the direction we came,
so we back tracked a bit.  The party was on an old military base that has been
shut down.  We arrived and the police were in the process of busting the party.
We hung around for awhile, talking with some people, and at around 1am we
got the directions to the 2nd location, the one that was used last year.
We got there and they told us to park off the main road to keep us from
attrracting attention.  We did, and waited for about 20 mins until we
got the word that it was okay.  We caravanned, with our headlights off,
to the location and payed 5 dollars/person to get in.  We walked down to
the cool, sandy site where they had the system setup and playing music.
We were inthe process of setting up our tent when the music stopped.  The
2nd location was busted.  Our money was refunded.

We hung out for awhile, talking with the police who were pretty friendly
and happy to see that we did not have any alcohol.  The sympathized with
us and told us how hard it was even for them to get permits for their 
police get-togethers.  They suggested minature golf.

We decided just to make the 2 hour drive back to SF.  As it turns out, CF
decided not to try another location.

All in all, a good effort by Cloud Factory, but luck was not on our side.

-troy

ode to the green monday mornin funk

woke up this mornin
as I looked about my room
I saw dis green funk a growin in my head
ah shit I said I,  gottsa git outa bed
and go to work this mornin with green funk all in my head
sit down in da kitchen, the newspaper is all read
look down...at da green funk sittin on my toasted bread.
(chorus)
green funk green funk
get outa my head
green funk green funk
wish i was still in bed
(repeat 3 x's and fade out)

Happy monday everyone!

OK, I feel like I have to say few word because I personally know Tony and 
Tim and some things that are said here are just plain wrong.

I met Tony when I started raving - 5 months ago and I think he is one of 
the most wonderful people I know.  He accepted my roomates and myself far 
better than some other people in the rave community did.  He has been 
there for me at some moments that maybe he is not even aware of when I 
had arguments (misunderstandings) with our mutual friend.
  And I would never consider myself popular, so why did he do that?

I don't knwo what Tony has done to you Brian, but although I didn't want 
to get involved with this, I feel that you are getting a little bit out 
of line.  Considering Tony so dear to me I am asking you to please stop 
this flames, because I fond them not only silly, but also rude.  If you 
have a problem with him why don't you take it privatly?  His comment 
about A. Bennet show did not sound rude (IMHO) and I think you 
over-reacted.  Relax :))).  He apologized to you and selling your tickets 
to FnF seems to be very childish act (if it's for the reason of 
popularity).  Even if you don't want to hang out with Tony I am sure 
there are many more people that you might meet and like (I am sure I am 
not on your list after standing on Tony's side, but I just wanted to say 
my opinion on this).


OK - enough said.
Hugz,
Branka

P.S.  I was considering going with you to AB show, but I hate mornings 
and getting up that early just makes me bitchy...  I do listen to him in 
the morning on the way to work, but I must admit sometimes he is too rude...

hyperreal is not pronouced hyper-real but instead rhymes with imperial.

Joe and Ethan are not that cool.  I am.  But that's not the point.
Mr. Rice sheds in the shower every morning and never cleans out the 
clogged drain.  Worse, when he's fucking his girlfriend, he makes too
much noise.

But his fans did.  They were *pissed*.  The rule?  Don't screw famous
people.  The lesson?  Stupid ideas are a dime a dozen.

Raver encounter:  I bought a bagel from a raver.  I said "you look 
really familiar - are you a raver?"  She said saturday's wicked party 
was great and held the mayo.  

I said no sprouts, please.   She said mad props.

I say mad props to anyone who sells bagels with glitter
for eye shadow.

Dave

Hi Everyone

Since i've just made my first post to SF Raves, it's probably about
time to introduce myself. :)

I'm Jeremy, i'm 26 and am originally from New Zealand. I've been
living in and around Sydney from 91 until two weeks ago, and raving
there and in other bits of Australia since 92. (Also this year:
Mayday X in Germany, a great little Goa party near Dunedin, New Zealand,
and a really cool night at a trance club in London. :) I've
also been a regular on the Ausrave list since it got started in 93.

Some of you know my good friend and ex-roommate, Grant (the one with
the fangs), and i've met at least one SFRaver in Sydney (heya
Crunchman!)

I'm working in San Jose. Not exactly rave central, but SF isn't that
far away. :) Does anyone know anyone looking for a rave-friendly
roommate around here?

Jeremy

You know what kids? I won't let this pass cause I've been wronged too long
by him. I can't believe that THX1138 (Brian) can flame me and others like he
has done in the past, and still does, and then expects us to feel sorry for
him or respect him because somebody didn't like Alex Bennett and flamed him
a bit.  Everytime he has responded to ANYTHING I have ever written here, he
fills it with lies, twists it and is just downright nasty.  NASTY!

Everytime I post something about Love or the positive/negative conflicts, he
puts "religous" labels on me, claims that I am a *&^#$^% Christian, claims
that God is evil, and insults me in front everybody!  If I mailed him
privately in the past, he would send his nasty responses to the group and
twist what I had written.  I've tried to be his friend on this site, but he
is filled with only hate towards me.  His insults have passed over the line.  
Today, I sent him a note PRIVATELY saying how I wish he would not leave the
group. I was trying to be honest with him.  Since he is convinced that I
sent it to the group, I will now.  But I do this ONLY because you all should
know EXACTLY what was said between he and I...and for no other reason.  
Here was what I wrote to him today:

****************************
Hi Brian!  I'm sorry to hear your leaving.  A few weeks ago I posted some of
my thoughts on a controversial subject.  It was about "comeunity".  I shared
my feelings and concern about what is happening with regards to positive and
negative energy.  As I recall, you were the first one to attack me...did you
ever!  You were rude, mean and downright viscious.  You told the other
posters, "this one's mine!".  You ridiculed not only my views, but my faith,
my perceptions and even my God.  You hurt me really bad with your words.
But you know what...I took it all in stride.  Even though you were obviously
upset by what I wrote from my heart, and even though you attacked every word
I wrote and flamed me brutally, I told myself that you were just pissed off
about something else and that I was getting the blunt end of it.

After that, I watched what you wrote.  You lightened up a bit after the
comeunity thing blew over and I even liked some of your latter posts
(unrelated) about finding strength in yourself.  I agreed with you.  

I honestly have no hard feelings for you, cause I know that you must be
going through some tough times or something and needed to vent.  But I ask
you now...after what you did to me, how can you justify leaving the group
because someone treated you like you treated me?  Just does not make sense.
I know you might think it dumb, but what comes around goes around.  That's
why we treat others the way we want to be treated.  It's gold.  It works!

Brian, I know you've been sick with the flu, and I know those people bummed
you out today about that silly Alex Bennett thing.  I just hope that you
will keep lookin' ahead and not let it get to you.  Your feelings were hurt,
as was your pride.  But hey bro', don't go!  I care about what you think,
and why, and when and how and all that stuff.  I know you like posting and I
know you'll miss it.  And strangely, if you go...I'll miss ya.  (Even though
we don't see eye to eye).

Think about it?

Love,

Troy
(Wowser)  

**********************************

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


GEEZ!!!! So much negativity!  How about a joke to lighten things up a bit?  
One of my coworkers just told me this.

First, let me say this is JUST A JOKE!  No offense is intended to anyone of 
the Christian faith or to any lawyers or lawyers-to-be.  It struck me as 
funny so I'm passing it on...

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Three lawyers are chasing a ambulance one day when their car loses control 
and slams into a telephone poll.  As other lawyers descend on the accident 
with dollar signs in their eyes, the souls of the three dead lawyers get 
misrouted and end up at the Pearly Gates.  Saint Peter immediately sees that 
there's a problem and tells the lawyers they can't enter.  Each of the 
lawyers insists that in fact they've been good little Christians and should 
be allowed to enter.

Peter says, "Ok, so you're all Christian, eh?  Ok, I'm going to ask you some 
questions, and if you can't answer, you can't enter."  The lawyers looked at 
each other, and each having received the best education litigated money can 
buy, they agreed.

Peter asked the first lawyer, "What's Christmas?"

The lawyer thought about this for a moment and replied, "That's when the... 
uh... pilgrims and the indians .... um ... they dress up in turkey suits 
and, ...eh ..."  >POOF!<  The lawyer was gone.

Peter asked the second lawyer, "What's Thanksgiving?"

The lawyer gave this some serious thought, then replied, "That's when little 
kids look for eggs, and they have football games on TV, and..."  >POOF!<  
Another lawyer gone.

Peter turned to the last lawyer, a smug look on his face, and asked, "What's 
Easter?"

The lawyer, who would be sweating if snakes had pores, did his best, 
"Easter... uh... ok, I know.... see, Christ was nailed to a cross and uh, 
then he was taken off the cross and put in a cave... and ....let's see...  
and he was in the cave for three days and... wait, I know this one...  and 
then he arose from the dead and came out of the cave... and ... uh... he saw 
his shadow and went back in the cave and there was 3 more months of 
winter..."  >POOF!<

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>

     Well allow me to retort...
     
     Eon:
     I got to Eon at about 11:30 and the line was fairly organized.  An hour 
     and a half later, after security had inadvertently let in everybody 
     behind me, I got near the front of the line.  Right then, they carry a 
     guy out who's suffering the classic good living side effects of yacking 
     all over himself and convulsing mildly.  The security were total morons 
     (chaos, yelling and threatening is NOT an effective means of crowd 
     control), and had no fu@!ing idea about Drugs, People, Ethics, Safety, 
     Security or Organization and probably spent their high school years 
     trash-canning people who would later drive nicer cars than them.  It's 
     a good thing the cops intervened, and got the guy on his side, checked 
     vitals, looked for funky chunks in his airway, etc.  Thank you for 
     being competent.
     
     Once inside, I found a reasonably pleasant rave environ, and met up 
     with several of the brethren and sistren.  It was a pleasure to go to 
     a rave totally sober, and get some good vibe and some good music.  I 
     think the problem with most twenty-plus dollar raves is people walk in 
     with a 'SHOW ME' attitude, which is not an ingredient to a whoppin 
     fiesta de noir.  The sound was pretty, the lasers were lasing, and the 
     video screens were tasty.  I really liked the fact that the video crew 
     were actually asking if it would be cool to 'put people up' on the 
     video screens (a recent topic of controversy around these here parts).
     
     So I met a lot of your corporeal chassisssiss at BBQ&Beats despite 
     getting there really late.  I'm always pleasantly surprised by the 
     openness and acceptance by all whenever I have met SF-Ravers.  
     Everybody I met was megacool, and a SuperStrength Bomb Hug o' Mighty 
     Love to JOHN!!!  Not only has John been one of the greatest people to 
     talk to, and a proponent of goodness unadulterated, but he kicked down 
     the grand palooka of all gifts in my time of weakness... I will bring 
     vibe John, I will spread it like boysenberry preserves over toasted 
     seven grain bread.  And finally, yes it's a SF-Raves laminate, yes 
     it's my design (unofficial as it may be), no I don't dislike the ones 
     that they were selling, I'm just a social salmon sometimes and have to 
     engage in self indulgent grafikal arts and crafts from time to time 
     (shouldn't do it for a living, too colorblind they say).  Great music, 
     great company, I wish we could have stayed right there and locked that 
     vibe in all night long, or tunneled off to some epic outdoor 
     location... bummer how those permits and complaints and legal issues 
     of all flavors interrupt life's finer moments.  
     
     It was nice meeting you everybody,
     Andy W
     
     
     ---------------
     Safety and Sanity Tip:
     Never drive home from an Oakland rave at 5:45am if you:
     a. drive a convertible suzuki summersault and left the top at home
     b. sweat when you dance
     c. live in south san jose
     d. notice it's a little chilly walking to the car
     e. don't have a jacket

...lots of friendly faces
   ...I was very happy :) to meet all my fellow SFRavers (Adam, Michal, 
      Terry, John ("beautiful", "love"), John (DJ), Andy, Leslie (Mother of 
      all us ravers), Ethan.....everybody, too many for me to count, 
      remember correct names (that's a good thing)

         ...beautiful location
     ...great beats
        ...and I got my SFRaves LAMINATE and my ticket to Fn&F :)

...great location, just 10 min. from home :)
   ...big line :(
      ...surprise $25 :(
  ...hot inside, but they opened it up after a bit  :|
     ...pretty phat house & BB (though it wasn't DAN :(   )
        ...no free water :(
     ...lots of room to dance :)
  ...friendly people :)
      ...my fellow SFRavers spreading the GOOD VIBE :)
