...good security == feel safe (car still there, unharmed)  :)

As everyone has already said, the BBQ&B2 was a great time, great people,
great strawberry and black cherry sodas etc.

Went to Hedquarters on Saturday night, a new downtempo club at the Voodoo
Lounge hosted by Tomas and Markus, who did Techsture at Cafe Abir earlier
this year. The beats are in effect here and it was fresh -  a well dressed
slightly clubby crowd, but in a good way. =) The place for headz to check
on Saturdays before the big rave, perhaps.

bsp I'll be playing there 8/3.

Joe

well, hell, at least it hasn't gotten this bad yet! :-)

LOSER IN BIBLE CONTEST SOUGHT IN WINNER'S DEATH
Associated Press

DADEVILLE, ALA.-A man who lost a Bible-quoting contest is suspected of 
killing the man who beat him, police said.

Gabel Taylor, 38, was shot once in the face outside his apartment 
Thursday.  Police are searching for the suspect, whose name was not 
released.  Taylor, a minister's brother, and the suspect apparently were 
comparing their Bible knowledge outside an apartment complex, each 
quoting different versions of the same passage.  The suspect retrieved 
his Bible and realized he was wrong, witnesses said.

"He said Taylor did know more and that made him mad," police chief Terry 
Wright quoted witnesses as saying.  The man then threatened Taylor, 
saying, "I'll kill you before the night is out," Wright said.

Did you ever wake up in the morning and log onto SFR and find it had been
invaded by the Nasties?  That happened to me today, and I'm still trying to
wake up from this little short nightmare.  Quick, somebody pinch me!

Oh, you say your mommie used the Nasties spray and sprayed it under the bed
and in the closet, so now the Nasties are gone and they won't come back?
Well, I don't mind if they come back, because sometimes Nasties  keep our
little world interesting, but it sure would be nice if that spray just kept
'em in line a little... you know, kept them from calling people dirty
names, and it would be really cool if they could get a little sense of
humor back in the process .... You know, nice Nasties who see the world in
a different way, but don't forget their manners ...

Oh well, I guess maybe I'm still dreaming!  But let's keep those Nasties
away, ok kids?

Leslie  ; )

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: A Great Weekend and the Hunab Ku
X-URL: http://mas.atext.com/PoorDb/PoorDb.cgi?recordFile=7%2E22%2E96%2E1567%2E185&cat=ewssupport&mode=record
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Had a great time at the "no-name" party at the Casa Zimbabwe co-op
in Berkeley...superb buffet of different kinds of music from house to
trance and a cool trippy experimental visual "mind test" to boot!

I wasn't gonna go to the BBQ because I was feeling kinda tired after
staying out partying all night but, DANG, I'm sure glad I did go! It
was great meeting a bunch of new sfravers and seeing everyone again...
thank you Tim and the BBQ crew for organizing the perfect picnic!
Cool to hear some new fresh sfraves DJs spinning...WOW, I didn't even
know y'all were DJs, can't wait to hear ya spin again?! I've been
hearing a lot about the Hunab Ku "the Mayan calendar" lately so I
asked Dave Abel, with Gateway, what it's all about. He piqued my 
interest enough to do some research and I found a really cool
web site that gives an introduction to it. Check it out at the URL:

http://www.resonate.com/

Also, be sure to check out an article at the web site called
"Psychedelic Shamanism" by Jim DeKorne. At the URL:

http://www.resonate.com/places/articles/m_blend/dekorne.htm

On Sunday went and did the Aids walk with Robert Brown and David
Lowe from the list and had an extremely trippy but FUN day. I read
the Little Prince for the first time in my life Sunday morning before
doing the walk and for the rest of the day weird coincidences 
"synchronicities" just kept happening about every hour seemingly to
reaffirm my belief that it's necessary to try and return to that
mental state of pure innocence and love that everyone is in as a 
newborn baby. One of the more trippy coincidences included an 
unplanned stop at F8 after the walk on Haight and having Mars 
recommend to me a beautiful trance track on a label called, "Le
Petit Prince" the Little Prince!!!! Of course I had to buy it!

Peace and Love Always,
John

I'm sorry for the delay in writing a total THANK YOU!!! to Tim and Tony and
everyone whose efforts made the Saturday BBQ such a success!!

Unfortunately I couldn't get there until 6:30 (hey, at least the Giants
beat the Dodgers!), and I was so psyched to see how many happy faces were
there having a great time!  I apologize for so greatly underestimating how
many popsicles you guys could suck down on a scorching day!  Next time,
I'll bring LOTS more!!

Now, I hope people don't mind, but since Tim was our total
slave-labor-of-love all day, getting up at the crack of dawn, schlepping
his HUGE barbecue, then cooking all day long, then staying until the very
end to clean up ... I promised him that we would repay him with MAJOR
massages ...

So how about at Friends and Family that each and every SFRaver who had fun
due to his efforts, would give him a 10 minute massage (more if you;re
loving it as much as he will!) -- just picture, poor tired Tim, laying in
the chill space, a smirk on his face as someone has his left arm, someone
his right, one on each leg, and someone putting him into bliss with a
face/head/neck massage ...  he'd be a happy man, and he'd know how much we
appreciate his work on our behalf!

So let's show him our thanks .... of course not to leave out Tony's great
work, and all the djs and equipment people who made our music possible, and
the great banner, and the awesome food ... I can hardly wait until next
time!

(p.s.  In case you missed my obnoxious nagging for donations, any
additional supplemental cash would be helpful to replenish the
out-of-pocket expense that Tim and Tony personally took on -- just a couple
bucks apiece would be well worth it, more if you can -- any overages would
be applied to our next picnic!)

Anyway, Saturday was a reminder to me of how many wonderful friends I've
made through SFR, and how thankful I am to be part of this group!!!!!
YESSSS!!!

Love, Leslie

Dear All;

        A very close friend who is far away told me I should do this.

        Regarding why I'm acting like such a shit. I've been sick, sick with
the flu for over a week, combined with a sinus inflection which either
forces my left eye closed or blurs it's vision with mucus, in the process of
self with-drawing from a 6 month Heroin addiction, and today I just found
out I have an inflected root canal that screams at me. 

        My head is splitting in half, I feel so bad I want to die, I spend
the day sitting on the toilet with a bucket in my hand, I'm running a 100
degree temperature, and have all the pain associated with the flu. I can't
remember when or what I ate last, but it doesn't matter my sinuses just
drain all day long and this seems to take care of my hunger. I have nightly
nightmares about people physically torturing me; that's when I can sleep.

        I don't get any visitors except the postal person. E-Mail was my
only form of contact until everyone started jumping on my shit for an
innocent post. I had people who I opened my home to, given free massages to
and taken all around the city tell me there glad I'm un subbed from the list
rather than ask what's wrong. People posting private messages publicly that
I sent to them behind my back; twisting them so they can appear cool. People
getting involved in personal battles that have nothing to do with them, and
having others support them. A lot of these so called friends I've personally
helped out with either rides, money and/or assistance on more than one
occasion. Others taking advantage of my depleted state and trying to steal
money/property from me. Oh, and others to  busy checking my spelling; hey
you forgot my grammar.

        Yet, where are you now huh; busy kicking me when I'm down & in one
of my darkest hours that's where they are; and you wonder why I'm so bitter,
and angry. So when you say we didn't know, I'l say you never asked, just
jumped on my shit; I fight pretty good for the vegetable that I'm right now.
Just goes to show you can't keep a good man down.

Sincerely & Back To Un subscribed Land
Brian

ps Just thought I owed you all a reason

Thursday, July 25th for Galactic New Years Eve, Green Day 1996. I'm very 
serious in saying that this will be an extra-dimensional affair!!!  =)

yet expansive party that will help you dance and see the cosmos in a 
unique way.

equipment. We will pay your gas and you get to experience the party 
without paying the door admission.

lighting gear. Then it is off to SF to set up for the party. I will be 
spending the night in SF. Driver must commit to hauling me and equipment 
back on Friday (say  8-9 am or so). We can accomadate driver if they wish 
to stay overnight on Wendsday. Vehicle must be a van or pickup with 
camper shell (or like hauling vehicle). Decision will be made on Tuesday 
evening as to driver. I don't need someone to do any lifting.

From: Ann Elizabeth Loraine <anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199607230918.CAA25714@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: dj art carried to new heights at...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 1996 02:18:21 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	Saturday night I went to Big Heart City with my bro' P.
to hear Felix and Thomas spin together on four turntables,
with two mixers.  It was unbelievable.  Toward the end of the set they had
developed a powerful rapour.  In the beginning of the set, they kept
interrupting the beats in a painful, almost aggressive way.  I felt like a
victim, listening and trying to dance to that. Toward the middle of the
set the flow took over. 

I moved closer to the dj's, so that I could see what they were doing. I
went into some kind of trance in which I
was completely focused on the music, and what it was telling my body.  I
felt like I was swimming in air.  I wasn't paying any attention at all to
the people around me.  

I tried to shake myself out of the trance to look at how the other people
were responding.  There were many different rhythms in the music, and it
seemed that people were grooving to different beats.  People were doing
different dance styles.  Many people were dancing with their eyes closed,
with looks of deep concentration on their faces.  

Felix and Thomas were
jumping from record box to turntable looking totally psyched about the
musical pastiche they were creating.  They were mixing like fiends,
playing bits of records over other bits, switching from record to record
so fast that that nothing sounded like it "normally" does when you hear
the whole unadulterated track.  

Recently I started trying to play and mix ambient music, and just a couple
of hours on the decks have given me a new appreciation for how complex the
dj art can be.  And it made the transition that dj's often make from
playing records to making records seem so much more natural and obvious.

Last year around this time I heard Felix play before dawn at a New Moon
party.  I could tell then that he has an unusual gift with music.  I heard
him a few times at Roots after that, but the setting wasn't perfect- the
club had a
system downstairs that bled through to the lounge where Felix was playing.
He told me once he wasn't happy with that.

At Big Heart City there was no such problem.  He and Thomas were playing
on a long, wooden coffin suspended from the ceiling.  It was a trip
watching it sway gently every time they dropped a new record onto a
turntable.

Getting to dance to this set was worth every penny of the $14 I paid to
get into the club!  Can't wait for another chance to hear these guys do it
again.  Makes me want to buy a fuckn' DAT recorder.

-Ann

From: rinc@gnn.com (Lawrence Rincon)
To: ggiladi@aol.com, caliban@aug.com, Kenkrps@gnn.com, wing@icanect.net,
        kerina@pacific.net.sg, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: View from Top of Berkeley Hills-1:17am
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 my Florida eyes, consulted each other..are you seeing what im seeing. I 
have biked up Panoramic to the top of Strawberry Canyon, again. Waiting up 
there is usually what is down here- the East Bay/Bay/City/Headlands and 
anything possible obliged to sight, not imagination.  Usually.

 Tonight I am lost above the lingering fog. I have walked in on a 
sleep-over. Where Alameda/Oakland once burned in the night, two children 
hide under cotton-candy covers, flashlights selling secrets to the night. 
Not far across the bed, Berkeley has fallen to Pirates whose treasure glow  

stolen from the black Pacific City and its Gate. The room is oblivious to 
me 
and the stars above.

  I will close the door and come in through the window. Both hands tied 
behind my back,reason and rational kneel before passion. I have turned my 
head upside down....stars become starfish and above me ....above me 
mother-of-pearl has fed milk to the grateful skye..and me   I am drowning.

 
  are you here?

Precedence: bulk

Eric:
>What a mess.  At the risk of sounding cliche, to err is human; to forgive,
>divine.  How 'bout we manifest our divine nature here?

>Just a thought :)

I agree.  Here's another.

Sometimes, sfraves can seem like a virtual community, but this
list is mainly a forum for communication.  Which is still a very
wonderful thing.  But as a "community", there are limitations as
to what we can expect from it.  Sure, we can comfort, entertain,
inform, and even insult each other.  BUt I think it is unfair to
expect sfraves to be a place where deep serious problems of a
personal nature can be resolved, or even helped to a significant
degree.  Likewise, it is unfair for someone to expect this list
to be a place where such problems can be catered to.  Like others
have pointed out in the past (JS Lee) we really can't even expect
to get to know each other very well through this forum.

There are other places in our society where serious cries for
attention/help are served.  And if these are inadequate, there
is little this list can do about it.  Well perhaps there is.  If
anyone here is truly moved to help someone who expresses a need,
they do have the option of getting personally involved, though I
would hope that they truly understand what it is they are getting
into.  Serious problems require serious action.  Writing that
you care/love/forgive someone, welcoming their rants and tolerating
selfdestructive behavior... that's kinda like throwing a bum a quarter
so they can buy another bottle of wine.

But then there are a lot of people who really thing they are helping
when they do that too.  Anyway, sorry for preaching; looking forward
to sharing lot's of positive energy at F&F and beyond.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Don't be fooled.  Although the Official DPT vehicles look like overgrown
tricycles, they are actually state-of-the-art Urban Assult Units designed
by Lockheed.  I mean, where do you think all the money for those 2.2 million
traffic tickets are going?  DPT is quietly building an covert army to
take over this city.  You see them all lines up, poised for battle down
on Harrison street.  Under that flimsly-looking sheet-metal skin are
dual, side-mounted 50mm rotary cannons, 2 surface-to-air missles that
can take out an F-14, 4 anti-tank/Hummer projectiles... they are tied
to an advance radar system that can track several targets at once.  All
of this packaged in a tiny, highly manueverable vehicle that can run
circles around M-1 tanks that are stuck in traffic.  Yes, when the DPT
fist comes down on this city, nothing will stop them.  We will be forced
to hail the New World DPT Order, lest be destroyed by the best technology
parking ticket money can buy.

-troy

     A few jokes to lighten up all the tension in the group today. 
     Everybody play nice please.
     
     -Renzo
     
     ---------------------------------------------------------------------
     
     Bar humor......
     
     
     A very shy guy goes into a bar and sees a beautiful woman sitting at 
     the bar.  After an hour of gathering up his courage he finally goes 
     over to her and asks, tentatively, "Um, would you mind if I chatted 
     with you for a while?" To which she responds by yelling, at the top of 
     her lungs, "No, I won't sleep with you tonight!" Everyone in the bar 
     is now staring at them.  Naturally, the guy is hopelessly and 
     completely embarrassed and
     he slinks back to his table.
     
     After a few minutes, the woman walks over to him and apologizes.
     She smiles at him and says, "I'm sorry if I embarrassed you.  You see, 
     I'm a graduate student in psychology and I'm studying how people 
     respond
     to embarrassing situations."
     
     To which he responds, at the top of his lungs, "What do you mean 
     $200?"
     
     
     ----------------------------------------------------------------------
     
For decades, two heroic statues, one male and one female, faced each other in a 
city park, until one day an angel came down from heaven.

"You've been such exemplary statues," he announced to them, "That
I'm going to give you a special gift.  I'm going to bring you both to life for 
thirty minutes, in which you can do anything you want."
And with a clap of his hands, the angel brought the statues to life.

The two approached each other a bit shyly, but soon dashed for the bushes, from 
which shortly emerged a good deal of giggling, laughter, and shaking of 
branches.  Fifteen minutes later, the two statues emerged from the bushes, wide 
grins on their faces.

"You still have fifteen more minutes," said the angel, winking at them.

Grinning even more widely the female statue turned to the male statue and said, 
"Great!  Only this time you hold the pigeon down and I'll crap on its head."


------------- Begin Forwarded Message -------------
     
     
Text item: 
     
>     Two whales, a male and female, are swimming off the coast of Japan 
>     when the male looks up and sees the whaling ship  that killed   his
>     father  five  years  ago.   Excited   at   the opportunity  to avenge 
>     his father's death, the  male  whale says  to  the female "Let's go
>     underneath the ship and blow air  through our blow holes.  That ought 
>     to knock their boat over, and  make  them think twice about  killing 
>     innocent whales."   The  female whale agrees,  and  the  plan  works 
>     perfectly.
>
>     Once the whaling ship has completely sunk, the male whale notices
>     that most of the sailors are making their way  back to  the  shore  by 
>     either swimming or in  lifeboats.   Not willing  to  let  them get
>     away so easily,  the  male  whale yells  "They're going to shore - 
>     Let's go gobble  them  up!"
>
>     Just then, the female whale becomes less cooperative: "Sure", she
>     says, "I didn't mind the blow job, but there is NO WAY I'm swallowing 
>     seamen!"
>
>
>
     
T
------------- End Forwarded Message -------------

Ann Elizabeth Loraine <anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu> writes:
> 	Saturday night I went to Big Heart City with my bro' P.
> to hear Felix and Thomas spin together on four turntables,
> with two mixers.  It was unbelievable.  Toward the end of the set they had
> developed a powerful rapour.  In the beginning of the set, they kept
> interrupting the beats in a painful, almost aggressive way.  I felt like a
> victim, listening and trying to dance to that. Toward the middle of the
> set the flow took over. 
> [...]
> Felix and Thomas were
> jumping from record box to turntable looking totally psyched about the
> musical pastiche they were creating.  They were mixing like fiends,
> playing bits of records over other bits, switching from record to record
> so fast that that nothing sounded like it "normally" does when you hear
> the whole unadulterated track.  

Hee hee. I'm sorry I missed it. Anyone who knows me knows
how I feel about DJs cutting it up and working the mix. I
know it's not for everyone, but I just love it when a DJ
shreds two songs apart and puts them together in new and
unusual ways. People like Jeff Mills and Claude Young, or 
even Carl Craig are good examples of what I'm talking about.

-Sho

On Tue, 23 Jul 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Eric:
> >What a mess.  At the risk of sounding cliche, to err is human; to forgive,
> >divine.  How 'bout we manifest our divine nature here?
> 
> >Just a thought :)
> 
> I agree.  Here's another.
> 
> Sometimes, sfraves can seem like a virtual community, but this
> list is mainly a forum for communication.  Which is still a very
> wonderful thing.  But as a "community", there are limitations as
> to what we can expect from it.  Sure, we can comfort, entertain,
> inform, and even insult each other.  BUt I think it is unfair to
> expect sfraves to be a place where deep serious problems of a
> personal nature can be resolved, or even helped to a significant
> degree.  Likewise, it is unfair for someone to expect this list
> to be a place where such problems can be catered to.  Like others
> have pointed out in the past (JS Lee) we really can't even expect
> to get to know each other very well through this forum.

The problem with this medium is that you can not see a persons body 
language, the expression on their face, or the look in their eyes. 
However I respectfully disagree that we can't get to know one another 
through the list or with this form of communication in general. Even with 
it's limitations, this manner of expressing ourselves allows for one 
important advantage; that is to organize ones thoughts and feelings 
before expressing them. I would wholeheartedly agree however, that 
sometimes people don't bother to take the time to do so.

                                        
                                          Black Adder

Sunny, if you need any help rolling a few of those pups into the Bay,   
gimme a call.  Also, hot tip I learned dealing with parking folks in Ann   
Arbor:  for just a few dollars, you can buy a handy little tool at a bike   
store that will let you unscrew the valve from a tire, like, say, a meter   
reader's tire (hypothetically), in just a couple of seconds.  And you   
know how busy they are when they are going down a row writing tickets...   
it's pretty easy to duck down next to their vehicle (which is probably   
parked illegally as they go down the row), and have that valve out in no   
time.  Seems to slow them down a bit.

Not that I would _ever_ advocate such... such... good, therapeutic fun...
;)
 -Roy

Precedence: bulk


On Tue, 23 Jul 1996, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:

> 	Saturday night I went to Big Heart City with my bro' P.
> to hear Felix and Thomas spin together on four turntables,
> with two mixers.  It was unbelievable.  

Cami and I were there too, but it sounds like we left a little too
early... 

> Toward the end of the set they had
> developed a powerful rapour.  In the beginning of the set, they kept
> interrupting the beats in a painful, almost aggressive way.  I felt like a
> victim, listening and trying to dance to that. Toward the middle of the
> set the flow took over. 

Yeah, when they first got on things were a bit silly, we should have given
them a little more time to get going... 

We got there early in hopes of getting some of the promised freebies and
the cheaper cover ($12).  Caught part of Anna's (?) set, which was fine,
and Gavin's set, which was really good until he ruined it at the end with
two really lame vocal tracks that were bordering on rock, bummer.  DJ
Spooky (that subliminal kid) was on next, who started with some heavy
jungle (which went on a little too long for me), and then got into more of
a nice hip/tr*p-hop groove later on.  His set was interesting, but I got
the impression he didn't know the music that well, some of the mixes were
rediculously abrupt.  But overall, it was cool... 

> At Big Heart City there was no such problem.  He and Thomas were playing
> on a long, wooden coffin suspended from the ceiling.  It was a trip
> watching it sway gently every time they dropped a new record onto a
> turntable.

the turntable setup was nice (although the flyer/voicemail promised 6
turntables, but I can't really see anyone putting to use more than 4
really...), and the sound system was more than adequate, maybe just a
little too bass heavy though...

> Getting to dance to this set was worth every penny of the $14 I paid to
> get into the club!  Can't wait for another chance to hear these guys do it
> again.  Makes me want to buy a fuckn' DAT recorder.

definitely, hopefully we'll see more events that give dj's a chance to be
a bit more experimental... 


Andy

ps anyone go to the Wicked burning man benefit?

Greetings Friends!

Regarding FnF tix... the sad truth is that they sold out almost instantly.
We had hoped to be able to put some in ameba or primal but after the bbq
there were simply none left, and the prospect of telling the people that
came out in force to get them at the bbq, "Sorry, wait till tuseday, then
go to ameba" seemed ludicrous...

We did offer (and deliver!) mail order for people that would have a hard
time getting here from wherever. I got 3 orders... kind of surprised me.

In any event, there *are* tickets out there in the community, so ask
around, and good luck =)

take it easy
ethan

Every so often the subject of SFR t-shirts comes up. People seem to be
interested but the topic always eventually dies out. SoCal Raves has 'em...
NW Raves is considering 'em...

Well, I'm going to be making a bunch as a favor to all y'all (and because I
enjoy silkscreening)... I finished preparing the screens yesterday, and
I'll have a bagful of printed T's ready by FnF this weekend. If you want
one at FnF, e-mail me by early Friday afternoon and tell me what size,
color, etc. The place where I'm buying them has pretty much any color you'd
want, and they're cheap too. I'm buying them for about $3.99 per shirt, so
if you could give me 3 or 4 bucks for 'em that would help (I don't like
charging, but I'd like to come close to breaking even).

The design is posted on my website, at www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~lachim. Look
in the gallery section under "illustrator work." The final size is about 5
or 6 inches square, right on the center of the chest, like all those shirts
the hip daddy-O skater boys and skater girls are wearing these days.

I think they'll look really good in green.

-m.

Thanks for a thoughtful response about the moolah issue, Tim.  I'd like to
suggest that we begin discussing the overall issue among ourselves and
think about where we want to go with it ....   and in the meantime ... Tim
and Tony, please think about how much out-of-pocket you are from Saturday
(beyond what you might have spent anyway on your share of "potluck"
donations to the feast, of course) and maybe accept some reimbursement of
that now from the offerers.   Then we can talk about our fiduciary setup
for later.

Leslie

>I have had a few people mention that they wanted to send donations, I'm bad
>about asking for money to begin with. Hell if I had to ask for my paycheck,
>I'd probally get paid a week later. Anyway back to the point.
>
>If this  is going to be an on going thing, maybe we need to think about
>having someone be in charge of funds. For say further events, helping out
>the other Collectives when they need it. Getting a small but descent sound
>system for the SF Raves Collective in the future.
>
>We also have to think about our goals. Tony's credo is good, but let's
>expand that. We can be a Collective that supports Causes and our community.
>We can have an event to help the hungry, Aids, etc..as well as our own
>"rave" community. There are a few collectives here that just
>cover-cost..(ie..FnF and a few others) when the have a party. We can hold
>events to help out our big brother & sister collectives. It's hard to throw
>a great event to please everyone and to just cover cost.
>
>If we all put a dollar here and there away for this, we will not have to
>have out of pocket expenses. They will be a collective expense with funds
>already available and whatever is donated, part of it can go back into the
>fund pool and the rest can goto helping out another collective.  We can ask
>people to bring can food to help the hungry once we start getting into the
>indoor all night thing.
>
>These are just my opinions and thoughts. As flakey as it may sound, I have
>had THE BEST time of my life since I've been involve in the "Rave" scene. I
>have some really great friends here and love them alot. It has opened my
>eyes a great deal. I want to give to the scene to make it that much better.
>Now I can see why Ethan is so involved with FnF, Greg with Harmony,BP. as
>well as the Sunset and Gateway crew are. They love what they are doing, and
>who can blame them. I nearly cried with joy when I stepped back and saw the
>people having such a great time at the BBQ.
>
>So, in closing maybe we should have some kind of fund setup to keep all the
>donations in one spot. and we can throw money into it when we can. Let me
>know what you all think of this whether it be good or bad.
>
>Tim (knucklehead)

hello all-

this thursday night, matt is sponsoring (i.e. arranging but not
financing) a sushi night at ebisu sushi on 9'th avenue and lincoln.

we'll meet around 8 pm (i'll be there around 6:30 getting a table) and
eat wonderful sushi and have a good old time.

we've done this twice before, and it's been fun both times.  anyone
interested, please let me know as soon as possible so i can make
reservations.

bring friends, random people (one person brought randall schwartz, for
all you perl hackers!)

love-

matt l

Subject: Rave train to BurningMan ie  BurningTrain 
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 96 15:56:01 -0000
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
From: Kevin Mathieu <kevin@infoflow.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0

If you are going to BurningMan  then  blow off the driving,  take the =
Burning Train there,  extend  your vacation by partying on the train =
instead of  driving, and make  your  BurningMan experience hassle =
free. 

 InfoFlow,  in collaboration  with many others,  has reserved an =
entire train  for a private party with  rave DJ's ,  The Mermen, and =
more, entertaining us to the  Burning Man festival on Friday Aug 30th =
and returning  on Monday Sept 2nd.  The train route is from  Oakland, =
CA  to  Gerlach, N.V.  and hopefully right to  Trego Springs at the =
lakebed edge of the Black Rock playa. Then transport from the train =
to the camp. 

 This private train trip includes:
 food  & drink on the  train,
 music
 other entertainment,  
breakfast on the weekend
a  ticket to BurningMan. 
Truck for oversize items and bicycles and anything not fitting on the =
train 
Transport from the train to the  BurningMan camp  

The Music   lineup:
The Mermen.
 DJ=B9s : 
Jon Williams
DJ Spun the Gathering
Polywog the baby frog
 Claire 
 jasdavdi  Countrymon  Reggae and Dub
Felix the dog  downcore 
 Alex 
Tracy 
 Darkhorse  natural music
Shakti Bonny
 dj monty justice league

Other  entertainment:
Movies
fellow travelers
The  Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence  Inc: Sister Kitty and  Sister  =
Dana  Van Iquity
Tarot Card readings  by C Scott Young
The Sierra scenery

Cost is $ 225
Anyone that brings in 15 paid travellers gets to go for free.  1 per =
group. Tickets must be bought by August 5th. They are already going  =
fast. Please make checks  payable to InfoFlow  include your name , =
address,  and phone #
Your BurningTrain packet with your tickets will be sent out in the =
second week of August
Contact Info
Web page : http://www.infoflow.com/bman/
InfoLine: 415 905 8047  415 357 0520      Email:  train@infoflow.com  =
 
InfoFlow 472 Third St San Francisco CA 94107

 What you are not convinced yet? 
Imagine how relaxed you could be  by  traveling  by  train instead of =
by car. No car no hassles, no playa damage, no dust  to wreck your =
car.   Would you rather be   cramped in a car for 8 hours?  Plus all =
that  great talent to listen to. 

It's really the only way to go. 

Information about the train: 
The trains is a specially chartered  Western special with 3  Amtrak =
passenger cars, 2 deluxe private viewing  bubble cars (the Indian =
Chiefs), and our  own engine. The  train is exclusively for =
BurningMan and only contains those going to the festival. 
Smoking of all types is allowed. We will have a non smoking car as =
well. 
Each car is equipped  with a bathroom, and the private cars have a =
shower for our use (perfect  for showering off the playa dust on the =
way back). The private cars also  have a kitchen.  Each car is =
equipped  with 110 power  for  your digital  toys, camcorders, =
laptops, and  whatnot. 
The  5  spacious  cars  we have reserved  will each  have  a theme. =
The themes are still being decided  upon.  The working themes are: 
The Rave Car  with Dj=B9s spinning techno, house, and acid, for the  =
way up and  down
The Chill Car with ambient  music escorting you and  your friends  =
with beanbags through the sierras
Technical Car for all those wishing to  do the computer thing and =
plenty of power, 
Dining Room car ( Indian Chief) The Mermen playing!
Viewing car (Indian Chief #2) for   relaxed couch  side enjoyment and =
conversation. 
Movie Car So you can catch up on  alls those great movie you have =
missed in the last year. 

What is arranged for the weekend:
Once at the playa  we will have  cooking  stoves for  general use , =
coffee each morning, and continental breakfast  plus   a reserved =
area  for the Burning Train camp. 

What  you should   bring:
Camping gear,  tents, sleeping bags, warm  clothes, suntan lotion, 3 =
gallons of water, bicycle,  food for  late fri night,  Lunch and =
dinner food for Sat and Sunday, sunglasses, your indulgences, party =
gear, and common  sense. To see the official recommendations look at  =
the Burningman official site in the participate/ survival  section =
http://www.istorm.com/burningman/participate.html

The schedule of events: 
We all meet up in the morning of Friday 
August 30th at the Oakland Train station before noon . We  		pack the =
train, and   get on Then at Noon we take off for  the  festival.  =
Arrival time is  estimated to be before   dusk.  
 We have the entire train   for our enjoyment.
Then we hang out  and drink and party and read or use our laptops or =
polish our  binoculars or chat.   You do  whatever you are into. And =
you do not have to deal with driver=B9s definitions of speeding, or =
the  drivers  beliefs in  bathroom stops. There are  a bunch of =
bathrooms on the train. 
You can roam the train and meet new  folk , or swap stories of past  =
Burning Man experiences. 
Plus house,  ambient, trance and other styled DJ=B9s and  The Mermen. =
DJ=B9s : Jon Williams, Spun,  Polywog the baby frog, Claire,  =
jasdavdi, Felix the dog, Alex, Tracy, Darkhorse, Shakti Bonny, dj =
monty justice league.
There will be 2 viewing cars so  you can see the Sierras in style and =
comfort.  Best yet it=B9s the eco way to travel, leaving the car at =
home  helps the playa.
Munchies and  drink will be provided  on the way up and on the way  =
back. Remember, this is not just an adventure , it=B9s a vacation. 

Short schedule: 
Friday  pack  train and trucks at Oakland  train station  from 9  to =
noon 
Noon Friday  take off  for BurningMan and  get into the  vibe,  the =
music,   the food and drink
Friday night arrival then unload train and   transport to the =
BurningMan camp
Friday night at camp set up  then go wander
Sat  breakfast  then go wander   
Sunday breakfast   then go wander 
Sunday night  The BurningMan burns 
Monday 10 ish  pack and transport to the train 
Monday 2  pm  the train leaves  for  Oakland
Monday train  more entertainment, music,  food and drink, and  =
decompress or party 
Monday  night arrival in Oakland 

Contact Info
Web page : http://www.infoflow.com/bman/
InfoLine: 415 905 8047  415 357 0520      Email:  train@infoflow.com  =
 
InfoFlow 472 Third St San Francisco CA 94107



This train trip is not officially   associated  with the BurningMan =
Project.  But they are highly supportive  since this is   an awesome  =
fun trip and it keeps cars off the playa. We are basically , just =
covering the cost of the trip and thought  this would be a fun thing =
to do. Thanks for your interest.

Other related web pages:

The official Burningman pages 
http://www.istorm.com/burningman/

http://www.sirius.com/~shag/burn

http://www.creative.net/~mhmedia/home.html

X-Sender: sandoz@pluto
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Burning man distance??? and driving protocol
In-Reply-To: <199607221919.MAA17739@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960723215444.15504A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At a liberal estemate (i.e by the time you've gone shopping, smoked a few 
joints and then smoked another one just to be sure that's four hours 
gone right there) it is eight hours on the freeway and four hours once 
your off it.  And remember: not even insects live out there so under no 
circumstances go off-road onto the dessert floor at night.  Distances and 
angles are real deceptive out there and just because it appears to be just
over there it's nine-and-a-haf times out of ten not.  The best time to 
get there (that is where you have to go over the railroad just before you 
get onto the floor) is right at dawn.  Travel all night on the freeway 
becauuse, obviously, their be less traffic and Bob is your uncle.
  It's a clear run all the way to the State line and then rudeuce your speed
 for 
the last two  and then turn off and party time is just around the 
corner.  Please: do not speed in Navada, do not have no/out of date 
driver's license, do not have a warrent out for arrest and make sure that 
you stash your stash well; remember to talk about where it all is before 
you set out on your journey, what you are going to tell the cops as far 
as where you are going etc and have all your documents readily at hand.  
Providing all these are in order and the cop has told you why he has 
stopped you in the first place he has no right what so ever to search you 
or your vechile nor does he have the right to detain you while they send 
for a sniffer dog.  In Navada an eigth will get you a manditory six month 
sentence even if it's your first offence and your car will just be a 
memory.  But don't worry, I've been to Burning Man for the last four 
years and not heard of a single on-sight arrest. 
More helpful Burning Man tips to come from your friends at united way.
Trstan.

ones _I_ hadn't seen that i thought it would be worthwhile to share em.

__________________________________________________________________________


Air France Bulletin
December 1,1989.

Here are some signs and notices written in English that were discovered
throughout the world. Your have to give the writers an `E' for Effort.
We hope you enjoy them.

In a Tokyo Hotel:
	Is forbidden to steal hotel towels please. If you are not a person
	to do such a thing is please not to read notis.

In a Bucharest hotel lobby:
	The lift is being fixed for the next day. During that time we regret
	that you will be unbearable.

In a Leipzig elevator:
	Do not enter lift backwards, only when lit up.

In a Belgrade hotel elevator:
	To move the cabin, push button for wishing floor. If the cabin should
	enter more persons, each one should press a number of wishing floor.
	Driving is then going alphabetically by national order.

In a Paris hotel elevator:
	Please leave your values at the front desk.

In a hotel in Athens:
	Visitors are expected to complain at the office between the hours of
	9 and 11 am daily.

In a Yugoslavian hotel;
	The flattening of underwear with pleasure is the job of the
chambermaid.

In a Japanese hotel:
	Your are invited to take advantage of the chambermaid.

In the lobby of a Moscow hotel across from Russion Orthodox Monastary:
	You are welcome to visit the cemetary where famous Russian and Soviet
	composers, artists and writers are buried daily except Thursday.

In an Austrian hotel catering to skiers:
	Not to perambulate the corridors during hours of repose in the boots of
	ascension.

On the menu of a Swiss restaurant:
	Our wines leave you nothing to hope for.

On the menu of a Polish restaurant:
	Salad a firm's own make; limpid red beet soup with cheesy dumplings
	in the form of a finger: roasted duck let loose: beef rashers beaten
	up in the country people's fashion.

Outside a Hong Kong tailer shop:
	Ladies may have a fit upstairs.

In a Bangkok dry cleaner:
	Drop your trousers here for best results.

Outside a Paris dress shop:
	Dresses for street walking.

In a Rhodes tailor shop:
	Order your summer suit. Beause is big rush we will execute customers
	in strict rotation.

>From the Soviet Weekly:
	There will be a Moscow Exhibition of Arts by 150,000 Soviet Republic
	painters and sculpters. These were executed over the past two years.

A sign posted in Germany's Black Forest:
	In is strictly forbidden on our black forest camping site that people
	of different sex, for instance men and women, live together in one tent
	unless they are married with each other for that purpose.

In a Zurich hotel:
	Because of the impropriety of entertaining guests of the opposite sex
	in the bedroom, it is suggested that the lobby be used for this
purpose.

In an advertisement by a Hong Kong dentist:
	Teeth extracted by the latest Methodists.

In a Rome laundry:
	Ladies, leave your clothes here and the spend the afternoon having a
	good time.


In a Czechoslovakian tourist agency:
	Take one of our horse-driven city tours. We guarantee no miscarriages.

Advertisement for donkey rides in Thailand:
	Would you like to ride on your own ass?

In a Swiss mountain inn:
	Special today -- no ice cream.

In a Bangkok temple:
	Its is forbidden to enter a woman even a foreigner if dressed as a
	man.

In a Tokyo bar:
	Special cocktails for ladies with nuts.


In a Copenhagen airline ticket office:
	We take your bags and send them in all directions.


On the door of a Moscow hotel room:
	If this is your first visit to the USSR, you are welcome to it.

In a Norwegian coctail lounge:
	Ladies are requested not to have children in the bar.

In a Budapest zoo:
	Please do not feed the animals. If you have suitable food, please give
	it to the guard on duty.

In the office of a Roman doctor:
	Specialist in women and other diseases.

In an Acapulco hotel:
	The manager has personally passed all the water served here.

In a Tokyo shop:
	Our nylons cost more than common, but you'll find they are best in the
	long run.

>From a Japanese information booklet about using the hotel air conditioner:
	Cooles and Heates: If you want just condition of warm in your room,
	please control yourself.

>From a brochure of a car rental firm in Tokyo:
	When passenger of foot heave in sight, tootle the horn.  Trumpet him
	melodiously at first, but if he still obstacles your passage then
	tootle him with vigor.

Two signs from a Mojorcan shop entrance:
	-English well speaking.
	-Here speeching American.


--

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 1996 23:00:52 -0500
From: seul <jsong@MAILHOST.TCS.TULANE.EDU>
Reply-To: South East Rave List <SERAVES@AMERICAN.EDU>
To: Multiple recipients of list SERAVES <SERAVES@AMERICAN.EDU>

on behalf of some of the djs that r looking for bookings by placing a
posting on the internet, i'd like to pitch in 2 pennies and let everyone
know how i feel.

first of all, i respect those djs & commend them for using an effective
media, the internet in an effort to try and reach as many ppl as possible
on seraves & any other parts of the world.  it shows that they're trying
hard to let everyone know that they want to introduce their talents to your
areas.  if you're interested hearing their gig live, we as ppl with
internet access ought to put a few words into our promoters & let them know
that dj so & so is looking for bookings.  regardless of whether if it's dj
joe smith, or if it's someone with a well-developed reputation such as
orbital or photek, everyone has their highs' and lows in their lives, and
are trying hard to let everyone know that they're interested in doing a gig
in your town.  so i think everyone should have a fair chance in letting
everyone know that they're interested in doing a gig.

secondly, for those of u who r so frustrated with such postings, with a
click of a mouse, u can hit delete & trash the posting, and *NOT* send
prank mail to them by letting them know that u don't want them putting up
such postings.  yeah, it may get on your nerves in your perspective, but
not everyone is like that.  i'm always on the look, and i'd like 2 support
as many ppl as i can if they're lookin' for gigs in an effort to introduce
new talents into our scene & other outta town scenes if they may b
interested.

so please, all i ask is that u all give everyone a chance, and don't
bombard them with negative e-mail or bad-mouth them when they're trying
hard to get a gig to introduce new talents in your scene, okay?


cheers,


seul    :)

On Tue, 23 Jul 1996, Alex Ward wrote:

> hey everyone,
>         I'm really bummed that I didn't get a FnF ticket. It's ironic that
> I really wanted to experience the intimate 'family' vibe, but you sorta
> have to be in the family to get in. In the future it would be cool if
> tickets were spread out a bit more. Thanks and peace out.


Ethan made available the option of mail-ordering tickets if you couldn't 
get them.  However, people didn't capitalize on this fact.  Also, who was 
to know that the tickets were going to sell out at the BBQ.  Actually you 
had an advantage of knowing about the party over the internet, which many 
people don't.

FnF is a *very* popular party.  It sells out faster and faster each 
time.  Tickets were spread out the best they could have been.  You really 
can't control the "consumers."  I realized this last time when I almost 
didn't get a ticket.  So next time you can prepare for this.

However, don't give up hope.  Lots 
of tickets become available the night of the party because that is when 
people know for sure if they have extras.  Last time Purple Tiger 
(haven't seen him post in a very long time) arranged all of these extra 
tickets and set people up the night of the show.  All my friends got 
tickets this way.

I understand your angst, but, dare I say, I think it's a bit mis-directed.

-KaySEE

Subject: It's Gone, Thanks, Sorry, F&F Tickets, List Status
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

        I'm very happy to say that the H left my body 24 - 48 hours ago, and
it's a memory at this point. This is one of my greatest personal victories,
for I rank this up there with dropping out of high school in the 10th grade
and going on to collage to finally become an Electrical Engineer. 

        I have no psychological or physical craving for it, because I was
only physically addicted to it. I'm still very sick however with this very
nasty bug that appears to be going around. I'm not leaving my house even
though I've been stuck in here since the end of the weekend, because I just
refuse to past this awful, awful bug onto anyone else. 

        On the bright side, my siamese cats Ernesto Kitty, & Archimedes are
in 7th Heaven because they get to lie around on top of me all day. I hope to
be out by the weekend if not sooner.

        Thanks for all the wonderful e-mail everyone; there are many people
on this list like Eric, Roy, KCRoy, Leslie, Tim, Tom, JDub, Tristian, DJ
Tom, Matt, Tony Rose, Geoff White, Martin, Artoo 99, Joe Rice, Raven,
Maureen, and yes Niels P. Mayer who ****I***** think know and understand a
lot more about what PLUR is about than many of our lists so call
"contributors"; and that we including myself could learn a lot from them.

        I'm so shocked at the level of hatred, cruelty, & negativity from
some of the people on this list who talk about PLUR that it totally appalls
me. Despite my history or anyone elses for that matter; two wrongs don't
make a right. What ever happened to lead by example, or does that just apply
to negativity? I've gotten some awful responses from people who I've never
even met me, and I'm sorry I just don't & can't understand your cruelty,
because that all it is. Like sharks smelling blood, it really makes me sick.
Does it make you feel good to be cruel to another human being that you don't
even know? I felt bad with regard to Wowser, but then again I didn't attack
anyone, state any beliefs, PUBLICLY accuse anyone or any organization, in
fact I just asked for people to get together for what I thought would be a
good time; with the added benefit of bringing more Techno awareness to a
section of the public which have no idea what they are missing.

        Whether or not Tony's post was humor, or an insult is not the
question. It was a PUBLIC post devoid of positivity, with no indication of
it's tone or intention ...eg smiley faces. I'll take responsibility and
limit my apology to list for not checking it out with him further, but
that's all. However, me mother(intentionally written that way) always told
me that if I didn't have anything nice to say, not to say anything at all. I
wished at this point I would have listened to her, as I wish Tony would have
listened to his mother. As for the rest of the people who chose to get
involved PUBLICLY you were wrong, & rude for doing so, and you know it.
Tony's response should have been private, not public. Yet I was made to feel
like the bad guy for posting it at all, I didn't know Tony & Andy ran this list.

        I noticed that anytime someone sent me a negative post, their
friends like Andy & Tony ...etc were copied, what's that about huh? I'm
actually glad that this happened for it clarified my relationship status
regarding certain list person/s who I have been nothing but kind(money,
shelter, time & energy) to, I'm glad you showed your true colors. Tell me
how does it feel to be cruel to someone who opened up their home, life, &
heart to you?

        Enough of that, it's my day today, and I'm VERY, VERY HAPPY to have
SUCCESSFULLY gotten through my ordeal, and am SO MUCH STRONGER as a result.
I got more excellent news this morning from the Burning Man staff; that they
definitely want me to be at Burning Man as a Black Rock Ranger. So look for
me setting up both the Rave & the Main Camps Electrical Systems; as well as
working in the Camp/s First Aid Areas hopefully giving away free massage as
opposed to having to save peoples lives. 

        As for the F&F tickets I understand that people really want to go to
this hyped up event to feel that so called Family vibe. I however am so
disheartened & disillusioned by the fact that a lot of you only seem to care
about the tickets(what can I get from you) rather than the human being(PLUR)
holding them that I've decided to most likely either give them away to two
people on the street who have never been to a Rave before, or end up going
myself. I actually have had a few people who have flamed me either recently
or in the past who are asking me for these tickets, my only response to
these sad individuals is do you really thing I'm that dumb.

        Thanks once again to all the beautiful people who practiced PLUR
instead of talking about it. If I forgot to mention your name, my heart has
not forgotten you and I'm sure fate will bring us together eventually. I
will not entertain anymore posts regarding this, if you sent me a negative
post your name was added to my trash can list as I hope my name was added to
yours. I just hope that when we finally meet in person, that you, as I, will
put aside our past virtual disagreements and try to be kind to one another.
This always feels much better than what has been happening as of late.

        It seems, and to my surprise more people than I thought really care
about what I have to say, enjoy my humor, as well as my and uncompromising
honesty, & sincerity so I will for the time being remain on this list.

        Hope to see you out at a Trance thang this weekend if I'm better.

Sincerely;
Brian

I was just browsing around hyperreal... when I came across this piece by

>                                           Positive
>
>Life gets so crazy and chaotic, so much so sometimes that we forget why we
are here on this planet together. We are here to
>celebrate life, to live together in harmony, or rhythmically, positively.
We we create negative energy, this energy carries on
>from one person to another until eventually these negative vibrations come
back to us. Who wants to deal with this bad
>energy? The more positive energy we radiate, the more positive our lives
will be. Having respect for our mother earth, her
>oceans and her land is where good vibrations begin. There are so many ways
to show her love and respect. If we stop and
>take some time to be with nature, to appreciate her sounds, her beauty, her
peaceful energy will be very cleansing. This world
>of ours has become so complicated that it's easy to forget just how simple
life is. Together we are stronger than anyone can
>be alone and when we work together it is truly amazing what we can
accomplish (we can arrive at positive results). The
>spirit of community and cooperation, love, trust, and sharing are the tools
of this positivity and they are not always achieved as
>easily as one might think. Obstacles such as money and the tireless forms
of greed that surround it can easily and frequently
>come between us and we are tempted to become factional and politicians in
order to preserve a kind of harmony that still
>enables us to take our fine helping of greed pudding while avoiding
conflict with our brothers and sisters (as if being caught
>were out of the question!). There is already so much downpression on this
beautiful planet, so much that it hurts us to even
>begin to examine it. From this point of view we feel so powerless, and yet
the solutions begin simply and humbly with you and
>me together, joining our forces to save our planet and thereby setting our
spirits free. Be thankful, whenever you remember,
>for the sun and the moon for they are the best example of balance and
harmony in the universe. Imagine, such a powerful
>reminder available to us each and every day and night! Take the time,
whenever you remember, to truly feel the beauty and
>tranquility of the sunrise and the sunset for they are the beginnings and
endings of of days full of endless opportunities for
>positive energy. It's amazing what a random smile can do for for the
universe. Life is full of rhythms and vibrations. If we have
>the faith in such manifestations and remain conscious of them as we move
through each day, we can all exist together on a
>positive plane. It doesn't matter where you're from or what we possess, it
is simply what we do, how we live our lives, and
>how we communicate that makes us who we truly are. Life is constantly
testing us, very much like a constantly intersecting set
>of roads to choose from. Our reactions to these tests determines which road
we will walk upon. If we react positively to life's
>challenges we will remain on a positive path, but as soon as we falter and
react in a negative fashion, we begin to spew out
>negativity and we soon find our lives heading downhill. Brothers and
sisters, we must walk this higher path, as individuals and
>as a people. We must remain positive if we can ever hope to do so. There is
only one race on this planet and that is the
>human race. It is so important that we all live together with one heart and
one love. We all have a spirit in us and one day our
>spirits will be set free, yet how we choose to live our lives on this
planet determines what will become of our spirits, live on
>earth again, or truly be set free. Please live your life positively. Set
yourself free! Peace, love, and respect to all of the beautiful
>brothers and sisters of our planet mother earth. Positive!
>
>ministry of love.san francisco.95
>


Aaron.

To anybody who bought in bulk and may end up having a ticket to spare, as 
tends to be the case, you can add my name to the growing list of have-nots. 
Here's what I'll gladly trade for one (1) laminate :

* $5. cash.
* DJ Dan :Chicago: 2/4/95: 80min audio from soundboard : A really good 
night for the guy, better than anything he's done recentlly. It's not 
harder tech - no, but it does have a beat that the kids can dance to.
* a black & white roxie cinema 'Naked Killer' poster. 
* Longshot #1 : Art Adams first work at Marvel Comics. Kinda odd on some 
panels, but still a great comic.
* that Deee-Lite booklet flyer from 2 years ago: The show never happened 
but the flyer stands out in my mind as being one of the more unique  
things put together.
* Beastie Boys 11/24/92 LA video. Second to the last show on the Check 
Your Head tour. Has real good interaction between the Beasties & the 
crowd. Good for doing your morning areobics to or just a good excuse to 
bounce around your living room.
* 2 orange ninjas

that's really all I could come up with at the moment. If this means 
anything to anybody out there I'd like to hear from you. thanks -

Mike Bolger.

Yesterday I posted that the design for the SFR shirts was on my web-page;

it is, but it turns out that the staff of the OCF (my server) is in the
middle of moving files to and fro, so web pages will be "up and down over
the next few days." Sorry for the inconvenience, it really is a nice
design!

page... Todd, what's the URL for that? Is it still up? The SFR shirt logo
is a slightly edited update of the "molecule" one. The main difference is
the lack of a slimy looking background and the lettering: the letters are
sort of "disintegrated." It looks pretty cool (IMHO). So, if my page is
still acting loopy but you're interested in checking out the design, check
with Todd's page. Maybe he'll post the URL or something.

Subject: Re: About donations & funds  (NOT LONG)
References: <v02130501ae1b70645b02@[205.231.222.75]>

Tim,

Wow!  It sounds like the BBQ & Beats II went OFF!  I really wish I 
could have been there; I had a good time at the meeting at Tony's 
house, just think of the fun that I would have had at the actual 
BBQ! (I just returned from a family reunion in Nebraska.)  

I did notice the thread about money and donations.  Boy, do I have a 
timely story to share with you!  My family reunion takes place every 
other year, and requires an expense to put on the "shindig" for about 
170 people.  Passing the hat was "uncomfortable" and never netted more 
than about $300.00. Because there are not many people who can afford to 
help with cash donations, the costs are always absorbed by the few 
people that plan/pay for the reuion. 
 
NOT ANYMORE!  This year we had an auction.  It was made up of donated 
crafts and food.  We brought in over $1900.00!  I couldn't believe it.  
Upon first glance, the offerings on the auction table looked pretty 
simple, nothing looked like it would sell for very much.

I bought a pie for $16.00, after beating one of my cousins in a bidding 
war.  Upon unwrapping it, I discovered that it was a "cow pie." I had a 
great time, and an aunt slipped me a real pie that was the best I've 
ever eaten.   

An auction is great in many ways:
-Providing auction goods is a way for people to contribute without 
involving money or time.

-An auction is fun to watch.

-People bidding on items know that the money is going for a good cause.

-Good deals can be found at auctions, (someone bought a hand-made afghan 
for less than $100.00 at my reunion.)

Ravers are an interesting bunch, imagine what kind of things we could 
donate for an auction.

Sincerely,
Diana Greer

Good day,

I think this post has something to do with the use of sfraves and other mailing lists for
the sole purpose of advertising their wares.  If I recall correctly, a previous post by DJ
Hardware, was an advertisement for about a half dozen or more cds put together by 
him.  My response was to delve into my own little archive to retrieve the post that is
sent to all new sfrave subscribers by the server and echo the part back pertaining to
using this base only to advertise a product etc.  I have no problem with an occasional 
plug for one's self, but this looked like junk mail to me.  I get enough of it here at the
house, that I am less tolerant of it here on the net.  If anyone really cares to see the 
origional post, I might be able to dig it up for you to peruse.

Take care,
                     Jason
  

>>first of all, i respect those djs & commend them for using an effective media, the internet in
>>an effort to try and reach as many ppl as possible on seraves & any other parts of the world
>>.it shows that they're trying hard to let everyone know that they want to introduce their talents
>>to your areas.  if you're interested hearing their gig live, we as ppl with internet access ough
>> to put a few words into our promoters & let them know that dj so & so is looking for bookings.
>>regardless of whether if it's dj joe smith, or if it's someone with a well-developed reputation
>>such as orbital or photek, everyone has their highs' and lows in their lives, and are trying
>>hard to let everyone know that they're interested in doing a gig in your town.  so i think
>>everyone should have a fair chance in letting everyone know that they're interested in
>>doing a gig. secondly, for those of u who r so frustrated with such postings, with a click
>>of a mouse, u can hit delete & trash the posting, and *NOT* send prank mail to them by
>>letting them know that u don't want them putting up such postings.  yeah, it may get on
>>your nerves in your perspective, but not everyone is like that.  i'm always on the look, and
>>i'd like 2 support as many ppl as i can if they're lookin' for gigs in an effort to introduce
>>new talents into our scene & other outta town scenes if they may b interested. so please
>>all i ask is that u all give everyone a chance, and don't bombard them with negative e-mail
>>or bad-mouth them when they're trying hard to get a gig to introduce new talents in your

RE:     Jokes....no offense intended ;)
>
>==========================================================
>
>The pope walked into this hotel in Las Vegas and walked up to the
>desk to check in.  The clerk said" I don't believe it, it's Elvis Presely!"
>
>The Pope replied," No, No it's me the pope.  See my white robes."
>
>The clerk said," Oh yes I see, sorry." and gave him his keys.
>
>The bellboy came over to get the Popes bags and said "Oh my God it's
>Elvis Presely, I don't believe it.  I knew you were alive!"
>
>The Pope chuckled and said, "No, no my son.  I'm the Pope Gods
>representative on earth.  See my pointed hat and white robes."
>
>"Oh yes, I see," said the bellboy and took his bags up to the Popes
>room.
>
>When the Pope got to his room and opened his door he saw a naked lady
>lying on his bed.  The naked lady looked at the Pope and shouted, "Elvis
>Presely, it's Elvis Presely!"
>
>The Pope said, "A one for the money, two for the show..."
>
>
>A bus stops and two Italian men get on. They seat themselves and engage in
>animated conversation. The lady sitting behind them ignores their conversation
>at first, but her attention is galvanized when she hears one of the men
>say the
>following:
>
>"Emma come first. Den I come. Two asses, dey come together. I come again. Two
>asses, dey come together again. I come again and pee twice. Den I come one-a
>more."
>
>"You foul-mouthed swine," retorted the lady indignantly. "In this country we
>don't talk about our sex lives in public!."
>
>"Hey, coola-downa lady", said the man. "Imma justa teachin' my fren' howa to
>spella Mississippi.
>
>
>One day Mrs. Jones went to have a talk with the minister at the local church.
>"Reverend," she said, "I have a problem--my husband keeps falling asleep
>during
>your sermons.  It's very embarrassing. What should I do?"
>"I have an idea," said the minister. "Take this hatpin with you. I will be
>able
>to tell when Mr. Jones is sleeping, and I will motion to you at specific
>times.
>When I motion, you give him a good poke in the leg."
>
>In church the following Sunday, Jones dozed off. Noticing this, the
>preacher put
>his plan to work. "And who lay made the ultimate sacrifice for you?" he said,
>nodding to Mrs. Jones.
>
>"Jesus!" Jones cried as his wife jabbed him in the leg with the hatpin. "Yes,
>you are right, Mr. Jones," said the minister. Soon, Jones nodded off again.
>Again, the minister noticed. "Who is your redeemer?" he asked the
>congregation,
>motioning towards Mrs. Jones.
>
>"God!" Jones cried out as he was stuck again with the hatpin. "Right again,"
>said the minister, smiling. Before long, Jones again winked off. However, this
>time the minister did not notice. As he picked up the tempo of his sermon, he
>made a few motions that Mrs. Jones mistook as signals to bayonet her husband
>with the hatpin again.
>
>The minister asked, "And what did Eve say to Adam after she bore him
>his 99th son?" Mrs. Jones poked her husband, who yelled, "You stick that
>goddamned thing in me one more time and I'll break it off and shove it up your
>ass!"

          Yeah... $25!  If you want that VIBE you gotta pay the
          piper.  You think VIBE is free...?  Next thing you know
          you'll start ranting about Love, or taking care of people...

          Jokes aside, if this thing is half as together as the events
          that lead me there (knock knock knock), I will probably die
          a happy freak walking back in a post-loving-event bliss
          cloud as I get punked broadside by one of those crappy SF
          drivers who's driving around town downloading smutty gif's
          to his Ricochet equipped notebook.  Weeehaaaa.

          Meanwhile, I brought my roommates to a weekly (weakly?) here
          in San Jose on Sunday night (stop laughing until I'm
          finished!), and it was really scary.  Just when you think
          they might get hung up over the music or the openness or
          something like that, you realize they're scammers and are
          talking to ravrrrrchicks from the get go.  Either way,
          fortunately their advances were rejected, and they decided
          that it did in fact suck (it's amazing how much the scene
          CAN protect itself from the forces of selfishness
          unbridled).  I think if someone can maintain at a weekly,
          and be cool with the music and the scene and not use it as
          an opportunity to use their crotch as a docking station,
          maybe then you should take them to a rave.  It's a bummer
          really.  Now I have to start looking for a new drummer (I've
          heard this guy -Roland- is pretty popular around these
          circles) because I was just kinda disgusted by the whole
          commodity aspect of the thing (the worst 'evil cult' vibe of
          all) that I had brought myself.

          So I tried explaining on the way home... I go to raves to go
          to raves.  When I'm there, I don't want to be doing anything
          else.  I'm full of emotion, be it tension, or awe, or love,
          or willingness to try new things, or just talking to new
          people.

          His reaction:  Whatever...

          Whatever is right.


          Andy W

          Work sucks.  It must be beautiful on Mt.Tam right now.

Black market markups are lame, but to be expected for any
high-demand/low-supply situation. However, it seems that allowing people to
buy large blocks of tickets  CREATED that "black market" in the first
place... as much as I hate fascist BASS/Ticketmaster, there's a reason that
they have a per-person ticket limit for some of the higher-profile events.

It sure seems like there are LOTS of people who want tickets (myself
included). Understandably not everyone can get in because of space limits,
but there are lots of people who wanted to go, but couldn't make the BBQ.
Perhaps if tickets hadn't been sold in giant blocks, there would still be
tickets for a few of us?

Just my .02


--
Brian

From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>

At 4:54 PM -0800 7/24/96, Brian Benitez wrote:

>Black market markups are lame, but to be expected for any
>high-demand/low-supply situation. However, it seems that allowing people to
>buy large blocks of tickets  CREATED that "black market" in the first
>place... as much as I hate fascist BASS/Ticketmaster, there's a reason that
>they have a per-person ticket limit for some of the higher-profile events.

Unfortunately you're a little mistaken here. In general *no one that was
not a member of the FnF production team"* was sold 'large' blocks of
tickets. At teh bbq one or two peopel bought 8 - 10 only after convincing
me, by naimg the people, that they were doing it for people that couldn't
be there. Most of the tickets taht were availabel for public consumption
went in groups of 2 - 4.

Of the ~45 people in our group each was allowed 10 - 15 to get to their
friends and associates, however,once again, many of these 45 people took
only 3 - 5. I see nothing wrong with the people that break their butts to
make these parties happen being able to invite 10 -15 friends of theirs,
especially given the massive overlap bewteen those friends and this list
for instance.

However, more to the point, here is the situation: We made a decsion a
*long* time ago to limit the size of our parties. We did this to a)
preserve an intimate experience, and b) try and insure a safe, manageable,
and fun party --  in that order. Since then, the amount of people that want
to attend FnFs has far outstripped the number any of us comfortable
hosting. This, by definition, means that people that want to go, won't be
able to.

Trying to be as fair as we can is important to us, and I feel very strongly
that we always make a *real* effort in this regard. How many other
'promoters' do you know that offer mail order? We can't help it if people
assume a, b, or c, wait till the last minute, and miss out.

If you review the post in which I said they would be available at the bbq I
think you'll notice that I also suggested that they would probably be gone
by monday, which they were.

sigh.

take it easy
ethan

-----------------------------( ethan miller )-----------------------------
-------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )-------------------
-------( you're only paranoid if they're not really watching you )--------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 24 19:28:36 1996

From: Josh Kneubuhl <joshk@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: FnF Frenzy/Our Creation of the Underground
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960724182937.5258A-100000@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(from Nancy)

The last couple of FnF's (way WAY back in our foggy collective memory) 
almost happened without me, but miraculously a gleaming, shiny ticket 
materialized for me the night of. :)  This time around I raced to the BBQ 
way too early to make sure I got my ticket. 

Yes, it sucks for those who didn't get a ticket on Saturday.  But first 
off I'd like to say that all the people I know who bought 5+ (myself 
included) were buying for a bunch of friends.  I don't think anyone snapped them up to scalp (and anyone profiting off of this goes against 
the spirit that makes FnF so special!).  

However, this DOES mean that probably Saturday night some tickets will 
become available. :) (You can try wandering around in cyperspace calling 
out, "I need a miracle!") I would like to ask of the list that if anyone 
has extra tickets, before giving them to some random acquaintance we should make them available on the list.

But what bothers me is my feeling that the FnF feeding frenzy obscures a 
fundamental ravetruth.  I have learned through "partying" that WE create the vibe, that each of us is 
responsible for our own happiness through the love and positivity that we 
center on and share with others.  This fixation on FnF suggests to me the 
belief that such experience is only possible at certain parties, i.e. the 
vibe stems from a party and not from one's own inner state.  Raving has 
been a very spiritual journey for me in the sense that I have come to see 
my power in the creation of my reality.  FnF is not the power, it lies 
within each of us.  

If FnF is so special because everyone comes there with open heart and 
mind, the people involved do it from love, and people's excitement and 
anticipation animate the whole atmosphere around the party, I 
think we are fully capable of creating MANY FnFs.  It sucks to think that we are dependent on an FnF 
happening in order to have that experience (and the last one was HALLOWEEN, 
everyone!).

There are other groups that are coming from much the same wavelength.  
Gateway is throwing Chrysalis the very next weekend after FnF.  Harmony is 
coming up.  But still, FnF is composed of a volunteer vibe army.  To have 
an even more vibrant underground just takes people who are willing to 
take more responsibility in creating it.  (I don't mean that facetiously 
- what I mean is that when we recognize that we really are the creators, 
we take more and more conscious action toward the creation of what we want).


Here lies the division between takers and givers.  Now as this applies to 
the underground I have been very ambivalent, because I am torn between 
loving to run all around a party slurping it all up, and realizing that 
maintaining that experience requires HELPING at some point.  There are 
too many people who love to slurp it all up for one FnF to accomodate.  
Instead of anger over the ticket roulette (which is bound to unfairly 
exclude many), I would love to see our community rededicate itself to the 
CREATION of a bigger, stronger underground. 

Just something for us all to think about as this weekend's Friends and 
Family fades into memory...

Love, Nancy

Clarification
(from Nancy)

I didn't mean to imply in my post that MANY people got lots of tickets for 
"bunches" of friends (though reading it over, that's what it sounds 
like!).  I actually just know one other who got 5+ like me, and in both 
our cases it was for people who wanted to go but couldn't get to the BBQ.  

I HAD assumed that a lot of people did the same (though I also assumed it 
was for people who couldn't go to the BBQ, probably almost all 
SFRavers).  Ethan's post helped clear that up for me.

>But what bothers me is my feeling that the FnF feeding frenzy obscures a 
>fundamental ravetruth.  I have learned through "partying" that WE create the
>vibe, that each of us is 
>responsible for our own happiness through the love and positivity that we 
>center on and share with others.  This fixation on FnF suggests to me the 
>belief that such experience is only possible at certain parties, i.e. the 
>vibe stems from a party and not from one's own inner state.  Raving has 
>been a very spiritual journey for me in the sense that I have come to see 
>my power in the creation of my reality.  FnF is not the power, it lies 
>within each of us.  
>


Right on! The Moontribe Collective in SoCal has run into similar problems
of becoming trendy, and being overrun by people congratulating themselves
on having found the coolest party around. This has forced them to go *deep*
underground, and, as an unexpected bonus, has forced the SoCal Raves
contingent to go out and start their own parties.

You're absolutely right, the spirit is within us. We are responsible for
influencing the vibe around us, whether it's at some 6-figure megarave or
on a secluded patch of sand somewhere with 5 other people.

Peace,

<Home is where the stereo is (and I still don't have one where I'm staying...)>

On Wed, 24 Jul 1996, Josh Kneubuhl wrote:

> 
> (from Nancy)
> 
> However, this DOES mean that probably Saturday night some tickets will 
> become available. :) (You can try wandering around in cyperspace calling 
> out, "I need a miracle!") I would like to ask of the list that if anyone 
> has extra tickets, before giving them to some random acquaintance we 
>should make them available on the list.

I would like to share some personal experience here and hilight what may 
be a potential problem for the scene in general and for FnF in 
particular. I used to participate in the somewhat underground scene of 
the deadheads from about 1978 to 1992 or so. During that time the scene 
went from a fairly intimate feel to a way too popular, overblown feel. 
One aspect that drew a lot of unwanted attention from the police and 
public were hordes of deadheads trying to bum/buy/trade tickets at the 
shows. This became a serious problem (IMHO) and really hardened me to the 
show as, clutching my ticket, I would procede through (sometimes) 
hundreds of desprate, sad, pathetic yet occasionally radiant people. I 
really was trying to be happy going into the show but all those people so 
desprately trying to get in saddened me. Hopefully FnF is ready for 
something like this. Perhaps a map point where tickets are checked will 
alleviate some of these potential difficulties.



> I would love to see our community rededicate itself to the 
> CREATION of a bigger, stronger underground. 

I would like to see more people involved in throwing parties. I think 
therin  lies the true growth and survival of our scene. The Dead had 
problems as they were pretty much (after a certain point) the only ones 
who did what they did.


> 
> Love, Nancy   
> 


Love back to you all,


Ran



                              -=*=-
                                ~

Subject: Re: TECHNO, JAZZ, & CLASSICAL MUSIC.....
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, arthurc@crl.com
