Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 11:19 PM 7/16/96 -0700, Arthur Chandler wrote:
> little by little, the "get up
>and dance" part of classical music disappeared. There are still folks who
>do classical waltz today; but it is professional ballet that carries on
>most of the dance part of classical music.  Dancing to classical music,
>however, isn't for the plain folks. If you got up during a classical
>concert and started to boogie, you'd be thrown out or locked up. 

Which is really too bad.  This is the real reason I don't generally
go to classical music concerts.  To REALLY listen to music my
body has to be involved.

>  Jazz had something like the same beginnings: the blue notes and rhythms
>of spirituals worked their way into the early jazz played at brothels in
>New Orleans. Then, with the advent of bebop in the 40s and 50s, folks
>stopped dancing to jazz (Charlie Mingus used to tell people who started to
>dance at his gigs to sit down, shut up, and listen). "You can't wiggle
>your butt and really listen at the same time," John Handy once said.

Perhaps HE couldn't.  I can't really listen and sit still.  I've done it both
ways, a lot, and there is no comparison.

>though there are still folks who dance to jazz, jazz dance is becoming
>more and more of a hobby form: something you learn because you're
>interested in the genre, noty because it has a life of its own with broad
>popular support. Jazz itself, like classical music, is in danger of
>becoming a museum form: a tiny corner of the music world that can't
>support itself without government and private grants to keep it alive. 
>I hope this doesn't come to pass. Jazz is America's greatest contribution 
>to the music of the human race, and deserves to survive on its own 

By not allowing people to dance at classical concerts and discouraging
it at jazz concerts, they are choking the life out of them.   A dancing
audience just adds so much power to any kind of music.

>  Techno seems to me to have been born without the sacred roots. Some 
>trance and ambient seem at times to be headed in the cosmic direction; 
>but the roots of the music are secular. Whether or not techno musicians 
>can make music that appeals to people in future generations remains to be 
>seen. If not.... then picture yourself as Gramps or Grandma in the year 
>2050, with the young whippersnappers snickering, "Oh wow! That old-time 
>techno is REALLY funny! Imagine people actually wanting to listen to 
>thump-music for hours!"

The techno people will have gotten together with the jazz people and the
African drummers and  people will have become accustomed to dancing to
stuff that's 140 bpm and 11 or more  beats to the measure and you never
know where it's headed next.  :^)  :^)  :^)


The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

X-Sender: andy-pythagoras@sanmateo01.pop.internex.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 2.1.1
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 24 Jul 1996 23:36:56 -0700
To: "SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey'" <silver@salinas.net>,
        SFRaves@Hyperreal.com
From: andy@pythagoras.org (Andrew Nourse)
Subject: Re: Computers,Anti-Technology Musings,(Long) sorta NRR....
Message-ID: <19960725063415.AAB23189@[205.158.215.178]>
Sender: owner-sfraves@Hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 07:47 PM 7/16/96 -0700, SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey' wrote:
>...The radio,the television, were thought to bring access to information,
>once only reserved for the elite. Television... has trivialized
>politics, and replaced high culture with entertainment only.

Television has centralized the control of information in a very small, very
conservative group of corporate executives.  You could fit all of them in
one room.  They have used this control to sell people an entire lifestyle,
all the acoutrements that go with it, and the beliefs that go with it.  Every
Presidential election year the number of television stations that could be
owned by a single entity was raised, which made the TV networks very
very happy (I don't think there is any limit anymore).

Cable TV was supposed to offer more diversity, but it has done nothing
of the kind.  Cable companies have been getting bought up right and left
until cable is just as centralized as over-the-air TV, and largely by the same
people.

>replaced reading the paper as a major source of information. Newspaper
>subscriptions are dropping, book sales are likewise falling.

But the newspapers have been their own second-worst enemy.  Most papers
are part of nationwide newspaper chains now, with some of the same effects
that the networks have on TV.  And a lot of papers just are not very good
(including all of the ones in the Bay Area that I've tried).

>the computer and the net threaten to replace the printed word and the
television
>altogether. What are the possible consequences of that?

This is a GOOD thing.   You seek out information on the net, and choose what
you want to explore further.   You READ it, like a newspaper.  You are not
spoon-fed it by the anchorman, like on TV.  You can get your news from
anywhere in the world, from anyone with network access.   You can POST.

>If you don't know, the US ranks last in literacy among industrialized
>nations, while we have the greatest access to
>libraries,newspapers,bookstores,television,
>computers,(all manner of electronic media)--every accessment indicator says
>that we are reading less

If you only count reading books and newspapers.  Why does reading a computer
screen not count as reading?

> and know less as a general populace.(The paradox principle)

Know less about what?  Your results will vary a lot depending on what you
test for.
(this usually resolves to "know less about what I had to learn when I was a
kid").

>We have the highest prison popluation, 80% of whom are illiterates. In the
>area of public debate, we might be better served to address some gang
>members,criminals, and drop-outs as illiterates to emphasize the problem,
>for without literacy, one cannot be a functioning member of society.
>                                1(Barry Sanders--A is for Ox)

This is rapidly becoming true for computer literacy as well.
In any case, computers can be a powerful tool for learning to read.

> However, it appears, like the world of economics,  the rich are getting
>richer, and the poor getting poorer, while the technological elite are
>getting more skilled and educated, while the middle and lower class, are
>less informed and unskilled.

There is little reason for this anymore.  Old computers are extremely cheap
now, and even they can provide access to the network.

>So, is the computer of the 90's really the television of the 50's???  Just
>another diabolical gadget?

Not at all.  All one can do with television is passively watch it, unless one
has access to a studio and a TV station -- something that very few people
have.   The network can be a channel for anyone to present the fruits
of his|her creativity.   Nothing quite like it has ever existed before.
The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jul 25 04:02:31 1996

Date: Thu, 25 Jul 1996 04:02:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG <sandoz@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: sandoz@pluto
To: Jeremy Lawrence <jlawrenc@stratacom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Politics in raving/Excellent Web Site
In-Reply-To: <9607230054.AA04809@polaris.strata.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960725033505.14812F-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Now that's waht I call a party.  The other day some one was on this list 
talking about politics in raving; but it was about people only and not 
issues that effect them (e.g. having your village ripped up for a new 
freeway). For me, this is why I got into raves in te first place: not to 
simply go out and have a good time (although obviously this is a very 
important factor) but, in the tradition of punk rock, to do my two cense 
in trying to smAsh the system.  And that's what needs to happen here: 
raves need to become more politicised.  Don't forget: every time you are 
at a rave and are tripping you are risking going to jail for ten years 
with no remission or porole; yet this is never talked about on this 
list.  And as for how we rape our natural evironment!  We need to have 
people at raves giving out info on drugs etc as well 
as free condoms to name but a few.  We need more people at raves doing 
healing and body work. In short, we are in danger of becoming victims of 
our own superficiality and we need to stop this from happening.  Because, 
otherwise, when we are older and we are hanging-out in the sterilization 
chamber with your kids and they ask us what we did to try and stop this 
from happening are you going to be able to live with yourself and look 
them in the face and say, " I dunno, I was to busy working and and having 
a good time to bother about it!"  That's not good enough and we all know 
it.
So what can we, as an American movement, do about this?  This is a 
difficult question as politics is much more elitist in it's nature then 
in England (where everyone has already be politicised from an early age) 
and there is a danger we might alienate the very people we need to 
educate.  BUt it is definatly some thing we need to think about.  Any 
suggestions?
Tristan.

At 7:07 PM -0700 7/24/96, Brian Benitez wrote:

>(have parties more often? :)   )


Well, the one thing that we can't/won't bend on is the right space.  The
main reason we don't have more parties is not due to lack of participation
or enthusiasm, but directly related to finding the right space(s), and not
compromising on that.

In order for our parties to have the unique characteristics that they have,
and that people seem to enjoy, we need to feel a little special something
about the space, a certain jene sais quoi if you will.

Tony

Je sais quoi, all right ;)  The spaces that appeal to me the most are
interesting in structure, have places you can go to cool off, and are
located in areas where vandalism/car theft isn't common.  The space has to
have something of a vibe of it's own, as if you can feel that it WANTS us
to gather and enjoy there.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Y'know, guys, I really feel for those that didn't get tix, but Ethan 
explained the break down to me when I bought mine and it made perfect sense. 
 FnF is being quite fair with the distribution of tix, IMHO, and very smart 
about limiting the number of tix sold.  There're a LOT of people on this 
list, and a LOT of people in the extended rave family.  Something like 900 
people on this list (?) and only a fraction of the rave community is online. 
 It's not surprising not everyone will be able to get in the door.

If I had any advice for Ethan, it would be to only take half with you to 
sell personally and, yeah, go ahead and put the rest at Ameba or something.  
Not everyone could get to the BBQ, and I think that's where part of the 
frustration is coming from.  Then when you sell out, just say, "Oops, only 
brought so many, they're gone, check with [whoever]..."  I know, it seemed 
like a lame excuse at the time, but in hindsight...

Ethan, don't sweat the controversy.  It's kind of a compliment, this 
scrambling for tix.

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Nancy,

        Excellent points and reminders for us all.  It's sometimes easier
for people to think "This will be a wonderful experience" rather than
"Let's MAKE this a wonderful experience."  Nevertheless, there are some
parties that are thought of as most likely to have what some of us seek the
most.  For me, Harmony events always come to mind first, then Gateway
(specifically, Chrysalis).
        I recall a FnF I attended quite a while ago, my first FnF, which
also had "it," and it was probably because of the combination of elements
present, not just who the promoters were, that created "it" at that
particular party.  That was the party where Baktash (sp?) stood up in the
chill area toward the end of the night and exclaimed something to the
effect of "Beautiful people!  Beautiful people!  The party's not over!
Carlos is spinning!  Get up!  Give each other a hug, and go dance!!!"  That
was the inspiration for Harmony's Beautiful People parties.  That was also
where and when I got my first tast of "vibe," though I wasn't superficially
aware of it.
        I recall reading reviews of parties that described the writers'
efforts to create a positive situation out of a less-than-positive party
environment.  This supports your comments that we create the vibe.  I
receive you loud and clear, and I agree with your point of view.  Let's do
what we can to make every party a wonderful, magical, and fulfilling
experience!

Love to all,

Eric

>Nancy,
>
>        Excellent points and reminders for us all.  It's sometimes easier
>for people to think "This will be a wonderful experience" rather than
>"Let's MAKE this a wonderful experience."  Nevertheless, there are some

does it matter?

I think that just the fact that everyone's going to FnF with high hopes is
going to make it a good party. If everyone walks in thinking "This party's
going to KICK ASS (it will!)" then it will just because everyone thinks
so... The promoter has very little effect on the vibe. It's mainly a
people-created thing, though not necessarily consciously created.

IMHO.

-m.

In-Reply-To: <v02130504ae1d85e1838b@[206.79.2.38]>

On Thu, 25 Jul 1996, michal migurski wrote:

> >Nancy,
> >
> >        Excellent points and reminders for us all.  It's sometimes easier
> >for people to think "This will be a wonderful experience" rather than
> >"Let's MAKE this a wonderful experience."  Nevertheless, there are some
> 
> does it matter?
> 
> I think that just the fact that everyone's going to FnF with high hopes is
> going to make it a good party. If everyone walks in thinking "This party's
> going to KICK ASS (it will!)" then it will just because everyone thinks
> so... The promoter has very little effect on the vibe. It's mainly a
> people-created thing, though not necessarily consciously created.

Yes and no. There are a lot of steps that promoters can take to help make a 
party. Things like free water, adequate bathroom facilities, well 
equalized and amplified sound, good lighting, adequate ventilation, decent 
chill spaces, competent DJ's, and the little intangibles. I can't count 
the number of times lack of one or more of the things mentioned above 
have been listed in peoples reviews as detracting from their overall 
experience. These are the things that the groups like Harmony, Cloud 
Factory, Gateway Systems, F&F, and all the other groups that get good 
reviews usually do. There is a real synergy between party-thrower and 
party-goer. Show people you care about them, their safety, and their 
well-being, and they will notice.

                                       Black Adder

Well, in light of the situation of FnF and no doubt Harmony, chrystialsys
(sp?)  that will be coming soon, I many are begining to realize what thier
concepts of ravers are...

I would of loved to fo to FnF, however a current obligation had kept me from
the BBQ, and thus not acquiring a ticket.  So instead, I contacted others and
alinged other venues to go to.  Some of us rave for the association of the
family we create.  I've seen SFRaves, on many ocasions, be referenced as a
"tribe" more than once, and within that collective are seperate more intamite
circles.  Other SFRavers (such as myself) try to create the Vibe where we go
and travel through more personal paths.  Ultimatley we grow, we care, to
whatever path you choose.

To the list, I know many...  Face to face I know few...

It's about choice...

If you feel that you need the SFR family @ events then, yes, FnF will be the
bomb...
If you dance like a mad man for 5hours straight, turn and see a crowd of
happy  dancing ravers, none of which you know but, on that higher level,
share the intimacy of the vibe, weither it be @ FnF, _LUST_, CCC, Resistance,
Fast step Productions...  That's the bomb too...

I've learned soo much from all of you, one's that I've talked to, yet never
seen... The very few to whom I talked to (Vince, Wayne, Brian, Rikki, Purple
T) I consider honored.   And the ones to whom I've yet to converse with, I
look foward to our meeting...  And there are the slecet few to which I just
have to see, and communicate at a level where words are meaningless (YOU have
seen me to and know who you are...).

So Have fun.  Live, learn, cry, smile...  Be with thoese you love or be with
none and love everyone.

"dance with me..."

-Adam

Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


On Thu, 25 Jul 1996, matthew d. p. k. lanier, the bucket wrote:

> i know the <hr> tag, which displays a horizontal line.  is there an
> analogous attribute that displays a vertical line (i've tried <vr> and it
> doesn't work).  i'd put in a graphic to do it, but it screws up when people
> resize the window.
>
> any suggestions, help?

  Other than javascript (already suggested) the only thing you might do
would be to create a wide, skinny background graphic with your line in it.
No control over the height of the line that way, and you have to be
careful to keep your text off it.  But it won't be affected by a window
resize, and it will be vertical.  On the other hand, if you already have a
bg graphic, this is a lot of work, unless your bg graphic is already
horizontally oriented.
  All I can think of.  Good luck.

: : J. David Lowe ::: dlowe@best.com ::: ai334@freenet.carleton.ca : :
:: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ ::::: ftp://ftp.best.com/web1/dlowe/ ::
 : : : : : : : : : finger for pgp key and geek code : : : : : : : : :

>i know the <hr> tag, which displays a horizontal line.  is there an
>analogous attribute that displays a vertical line 

Not that I'm aware of, but you can use a table to format the page and keep a 
graphic of a vertical line in place.  I forget the actual syntax, but 
there's an attribute you can use to make the table itself invisible so it 
only controls where text and images appear.

Not much help, but a clue nonetheless...

S

OK, all, thanks for your responses!  Feel free to e-mail me your birthdays
as well (I'll want them anyway, so I can remember y'all on your special
days!).  I want to set a deadline of 1:00pm on Friday (tomorrow) for anyone
who wants to send me their zodiac sign and hasn't yet.  As soon as I can,
probably sometime next week, I'll make a list, in order from greatest
number to fewest number per sign, and post it to the mailing list, so we
have something of a picture of how many people are of this or that sign.
Based on the responses, it still looks like we've got more Aquarians than
anything else.  If the traits associated with the various signs apply,
we'll also have something of an idea of what kinds of people are attracted
to this scene of ours.
For the statistically anal out there, I realize that this isn't
scientifically accurate, but hey, neither is astrology (MHO, no flames,
please).  I'm just doing this as a curiosity, and to take my mind off other
things (like work ;)).
Thanks again to all participants in this project :)

PLUR,

- E

 FnF in Richmond Civic Center???. although for a brief moment grandeur
such as that was considered - it was very quickly dropped....
Anyone who talks with Ethan understands quickly that FnF is about
small is beautiful (including cost) values... not about how big we
can get... although there are a few of us who wonder just how many
tickets could we sell if we really tried ... hummmm..

But really, bottom line this is a party for family put on by the rave
families... which is one reason no one profits from it... except by
the joy we get in sharing the experience.....

Greetings to all ye sfravers!

I'm just writing a quick note to everyone to say I'M LOOKING FORWARD TO 
FRIENDS AND FAMILY this Saturday.  I'm curious to know what some of you will 
be wearing?  Look for me in my silver pantsuit!!  I've got quite a weekend 
lined up for myself and my honey.  I'm in my cousin's wedding (I'm a 
bridesmade) on Sat. in Colfax (leaving tomorrow after work) and we're driving 
back that same night to be at the party!  Chris is sewing my dress, what a 
guy huh?  

Seriously, this F&F is very important to me!  It's where I got together with 
Chris (at a F&F last Haloween).  He left a very significant impression on me 
and I followed up with a phone call to him (thank you Amy S. for his #) the 
next week inviting myself over for a visit.  We spent the day together and 
ended up going out to Stinson Bch. where during sunset we kissed each other 
and fell in love:) Since then I've left Sacramento to move in with him and 
we're now engaged, thanks to F&F I've met my spiritual partner for life! It's 
been hard at times moving and getting reacclamated over here but I'm 
extremely happy and I've managed to get what is looking like a permanent gig 
as a computer graphic artist at Broderbund where I live in Novato.  Looking 
forward to seeing all my friends (I love you guys) and meet more of the 
sfravers on this list!!  Take care everyone and enjoy yourselves:) 

XX
OO
Carol

Friends and Family is already sold out but Unity is an alternative -
it'll be much larger, of course, but it's got a massive local lineup.

Thanks to everyone who's been sending in info.  The weeklies seem
kind of bloated - lemme know if any of them are over...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, July 26th - _Give It Back!_
   a party with a purpose
   Sean Murray, John Howard, Andre Lucero, Galen, Laron, Jason, Matt
   Brown.
   Visuals by Hyperdelic.
   All $$ donated to the SF Aids Foundation
   Sound donated by Renegade
   415.679.3113
   
   Saturday, July 27th - Theta presents _Lust for Life_
   Thomas Trouble, Biojeff, Jeremy (Portland), Mars, Mystr-E, Shaggy (the
   original), Andrew, Mike, Moshe.
   A benefit rave for the Burning Man Foundation
   415.437.5797
   
   Saturday, July 27th - Friends & Family - sold out
   
   Saturday, July 27th - _Unity_
   Garth, Simon, Carlos, Tony, DJ Dan, Mark Farina, Dubtribe, Freaky
   Chakra, Henrik, Tracy, Galen, Andre Lucero, Cesar, Solar, Darkhorse,
   Abstract, Nick Philip, Charlotte, Laron, Shoam, Pollywog, Andrew
   Rawnsley, Jason.
   proceeds will go toward Malachy's healing fund
   9pm-7am, $20. 415.263.6968 510.287.5887
   
   Wednesday, July 31st - Blasthaus presents Up n'Atom
   Seth, Rick Preston, Robbie Hardkiss, Astronaut (live), Freaky Chakra
   (live), Laron, Felix the Dogge, guests.
   a Terran Collective/Mercury Uno record release party
   7pm-. 111 Minna St, SF. 415.789.8044
   
   Friday, August 2nd - The Brotherhood of Indonesia presents _Planet E_
   Jim Hopkins, Donald Glaude, Tony, Jeno, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Simon,
   Rick Preston, Essence, Kwashi, Kevin Kind, Joshua.
   415.560.5324 408.235.9344 415.340.5607
   
   Friday, August 2nd - Tricycle Productions and Flomotion presents
   _Chemical Daze_
   An evolving dance party celebrating the release of the cult hit movie
   Trainspotting.
   Gavan (Rub-a-Dub), Chris Orr (XLR8R), Andre Lucero, Everett, John
   Howard.
   Visuals by Dimension Se7en.
   10pm-5am, . 600 Beach Street (at the Cannery), SF. 415.487.6613
   
   Saturday, August 3rd - Space Children, In Touch, Mantra & Bay Area
   Sound System presents Juggernaut Festival
   Kenny Larkin, Barada, Freaky Chakra, Mark E Quark, Cesar, Omar, Nav,
   Sleepy C., Terry Mullan, Hipp-E, Donald Glaude, Jim Hopkins, Barry
   Weaver, John Howard, DJ Crust, Kode IV/Ceiba (live), Dutch, Surge,
   Theta Blip, Radley, Anon, Velocette, Beyond Race, Professor Smith,
   Wunjo, Jonah Sharp, Darkhorse, Keyser Sose meets the Cyclops, Glimmer
   of Dope, U.F.O., Abstract, Noel, Thad, 3D.
   Visuals by Eyetribe, Hyperdelic, Mantra.
   5 zones of electronic dance and chill music.
   415.273.1622 408.327.9277 510.433.7216 916.554.7177
   
   Saturday, August 3rd - Gateway presents _Chrysalis_
   Minor Minor, Alex, James Dee, John Carel, Deaks, ambient DJ guests.
   10:30pm-6:30am, . 415.536.9453
   
   Sunday, August 4th - _Dub Mission_
   glorious roots to neo dub
   Sep, Jah Bill.
   first sunday of each month
   9pm-2am, 21+, $3. Elbo Room, 647 Valencia, SF.
   
   Friday, August 9th - GrooveKid and FunkyBeat Productions presents Fed
   Ex
   DJ Dan, Donald Glaude, Tony, Simon, Jim Hopkins, Josh.
   120,000 sq.ft. indoor/outdoor space
   415.605.1915 510.726.5947
   
   Friday, August 9th - 100 acre woods presents _Hunny_
   Gerlando Piro, Dutch, Greg, DJ Dan, Cloud, Jon Williams.
   10pm-6am, . SF. 415.263.4885
   
   Saturday, August 10th - Spundae presents _Nation _
   Sasha (UK), John Digweed (UK), Jimmy Van Malleghem (Florida), Taylor
   (LA), Kimball Collins, Donald Glaude, Simon, DJ Dan, Henrik, Jeno,
   Carlos, Tony, B.T. featuring Vincent Covello (live), Freaky Chakra
   (live), Professor Smith, Wunjo.
   presale tix at Housewares, Ameba, Record Rack, Primal, Solid Grooves,
   In-Tha-Mix
   9pm-8am, . 415.764.2922 415.267.0568 415.974.9389 503.514.2776
   
   Saturday, August 10th - Cloud 23 presents N.A.S.A. (Nice & Safe
   Attitude)
   Manuel, Jaz, JoNathan, Chris Jackson, erol, Jason.
   outdoors
   Free. 408.720.8646
   
   Sunday, August 11st - Funky Tekno Tribe and Urb Magazine presents _The
   Logical Progression Tour_
   LTJ Bukem, MC Conrad, Tayla, Raymond Roker, Darkhorse, Jonah Sharp,
   surprise guests.
   Free. 415.266.8215
   
   Friday, August 16th - Global Groove presents _Irian Jaya_
   a party about togetherness
   Taj, John Howard, Thomas, Norm the Truth, Moises (aka Mofo), Danz,
   Brainee.
   10pm-6am, . 415.273.5449
   
   Saturday, August 17th - Tribal Funk presents _Got Funk?_
   Spun, Josh, Jeno, Tony, Daniel (moontribe), O'Keef (Philly).
   more info to come...
   
   
   Saturday, August 23rd - Nexus presents _Open_
   Hipp-E, Eric Davenport, Trance, Terence Toy, Tony, Jeno, Moshe, Shome,
   Boomerang, Fidget.
   Nexus Holistic Sanctuary, Live Butterfly Palace
   Free acupuncture, aroma therapy, herbal clinics, massage, water, fruit.
   $10 before 11pm if you bring a flower
   dress like an angel or fairy and receive 2$ off
   9pm-7am, . 415.273.5350 510.473.4767
   
   Wednesday, August 28th - Burning Man 1996
   includes Wicked, Dimension Se7en, Gateway Systems, CCC, Drop Bass
   Network, SPAZ and Generation of Noise Sound Systems.
   save $10 by registering by June 1st.
   runs entire weekend, through September 2nd.
   All ages, $35. Black Rock Desert, Nevada. 415.985.7471
   
   Saturday, August 31st - Feel Good Entertainment presents _Mega-Buzz
   One_
   Sean Murray, Galen, Solar, John Howard, John Mac, Laron, NYC Sense,
   Harry Who?, Mattski, Erik Spire, Liquid, Mei-Lwun, Jay Hartley, Chris
   #23, Carlos, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Essence, Henrik, Simon, Tony, Ernie
   Munson.
   6 arenas in virgin SF location
   415.569.6226 408.535.0402 510.433.9434 916.491.5950 209.569.7973
   707.523.9369
   
   Friday, September 6th - Cloud Factory presents _Planetarium_
   DJs, food, frolinking, camping and such in Mendocino County
   drenalin, tim mcknew, deaks, cloud, brian flipp, mc^2, guests.
   runs all weekend thru the 8th
   mendocino.
   
   Saturday, September 14th - _Harmony_
   Three Year Anniversary
   the final Harmony - presale tix only!
   408.486.9591 408.450.3044

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Hey Kidds--

LA Dave here.  

Hey I just picked up the July/August issue of "Psychology Today" and
they had a great article on the Second Coming of Psychadelics.

I don't have it with me--but here's some interesting tidbits--

**1987--39% of college student had tried MDMA at least once
**1993--3 billion doses of MDMA are being manufactured in homemade labs
**"the most shining example of this are parties called 'raves'"
   In SF, on almost any given weekend, you can find 10-20,000 teenagers
at these all night parties--80% of which are on drugs.

It's actually a very balanced and good article!!

I'm glad my favortie mag has caught up with me!! :)

See ya kidds--

Hope you're all doing well!!

             Hello all,

             This weekend sees THETA's first party, Lust for Life
             a benefit for the Burning Man foundation. All profit
             from the event will be donated to the foundation. In
             particular, most of the money will be going to help
             with the cost for facilities at the Techno Ghetto - this
             years incarnation of the Rave Camp.

             We'd like to give back to the Burning Man for the time
             we spent on the playa. Also, there's been some animosity
             in the past between the Main & Rave camps, by working
             together we improve the relationship.

             We're really looking forward to the night. Putting the
             event together has been very rewarding, especially due
             to the many people donating time, equipment and services.

             All we need now is a cast of participants for the nights
             celebration - hopefully we'll see some of you there.


             The DJ line up for the night is...

             In the main room:

             Jeremy (Portland), Alex, BioJeff, Thomas Trouble, Mars,
             Myster-E

             And in the other:

             Mosha, Mike, Shaggy

             Call 415.437.5797 on the night for final information, we'll
             be kicking things off at 10:00.

             THETA

> 
> Hey Dave!
> 
> Why does Burning Man need to have a benefit if the tickets are $25 a 
> pop, and there is a projected attendance of 8000-10,000 people?
> 
> Is wood really that expensive?  

Porta-potties, trash cleanup crews, permits, medical facilities, security,
paying for the BLM presence, paying off... er, supporting the local
population, insurance, ect.

Doing this large of an event 100% by the books and 100% legally requires
more expenses than you can imagine.

-troy

Date: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 10:38:06 -0700
Message-Id: <v01530506ae1e4e89a368@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Thoughts on Vibe and Anticipation
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Allow me to preface this with the request that I no longer be referred to
as RaveMom by anyone over the age of 18, ok?  I'm not that old for
Chrissakes!  And unless you were born of my loins, I'm not your mom
(besides my daughter would be really jealous).  Nevertheless, I have some
thoughts from the perspective of age that I'd like to share.

I'm noticing over the last days (as often happens) the tendency we all have
to take our hopes and anticipation, and put them into some upcoming event
that we're really looking foward to.  I do it too, but I had a realization
about it a few months ago that I wanted to share.

OK, it's Tuesday, we're really excited about something that's going to
happen Saturday, and we say to ourselves .... "I can't wait.... I wish
Saturday would get here soon!"   Stop!  What are you doing?  YOU ARE
WISHING YOUR LIFE AWAY!!!  You are wishing that PRECIOUS DAYS of your life
would speed by, so that you can get to an experience that you HOPE will
make you happy!

This is so seductive, and it's SOOOO DANGEROUS!  Because, you have to face
it, Saturday (or next month, or Christmas, or your vacation) MAY NEVER
COME!  Really, something could happen that keeps you from being in that
much-anticipated place (an accident, family emergency, whatever) and you
now have lost those days with no way to get them back.  Or, as often
happens, the upcoming event doesn't live up to your expecations at all.

So, not to sound trite, it's so important to LIVE FOR TODAY!  Yes, plan for
tomorrow, and yes, make plans that you really are excited about ... but
whenever you find yourself wishing today away so that tomorrow might come,
stop and put yourself into the 'now' and find what you can do to make TODAY
the place that you're happy to be ... when it all comes down to it, that's
all we have.

Pep talk over.

Love, Leslie

       XXXXXXXXXX
   XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

     [8    ._.     8]

Your words make all the sense in the world, Leslie.  Last week at the BBQ 
I was thinking that this week would go by at an incredibly slow, 
torturous pace.  Was I ever wrong!  Maybe if I sat at home all day long 
with nothing to do, then the week would crawl by.  Thankfully, most of us 
are quite busy during our weekdays to make them go by faster.  The bad 
thing is that when you are having a really good time, the time also flys 
by.  Sheeze, no wonder the years seem to whiz by - all the more reason to 
follow Leslie's advice and cherish each and every day.  And if you live 
in the moment, anticipation will loosen its grip on your gut a little. :)
Nonetheless, I am excited about tomarrow cause Mel and I will be leaving 
for SF sometime in the afternoon. But I shall appreciate Friday at the 
same time!  

love,
Amy

Subject: <NRR> Webcompass
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

        I just checked Webcompass from QuaterDeck. Webcompass is FREE
Internet  Search Engine software. What it does is, say you want to search
for Raves or rave related material on the net. It will send the search
request to every search engine publicly available on the net and compile all
the results for ya. Pretty neat; so instead of you having to go to every
search engine on the net, you have but one place to go. This however is bad
news for Internet Bandwidth Activists, because it eats up a lot of bandwidth.

to download the FREE software go to:

http://arachnid.qdeck.com/qdeck/demosoft/

Peace
Brian

From: Anarch <anarch@scruznet.com>

Brandon William Brown, bbrown@cats.ucsc.edu wrote:
>
>Fri, 26 Jul 1996, Stephen Woltosz wrote:
>> Does anyone have any suggestions for really kool Acid Jazz collections out
>> there?
>
>there was this single I heard "Sugar Free Jazz"  had a nice little jungle 
>beat goin' on in the distance....can't remember the artist though...damn

"Sugar Free Jazz" is by Soul Coughing, who are bit outside the main line 
of "acid jazz" (whatever that means), but a great band nonetheless, well 
worth checking out.  "Sugar Free Jazz" is on the album Ruby Vroom.

There are two compilation series, "The Acid Jazz Test" and "This is Acid 
Jazz," that have some pretty good stuff.  I haven't heard all the issues 
(there are 5 so far in "This is Acid Jazz," not sure about the other) but 
my favorite so far is Acid Jazz Test 2.  Abstrakt Workshop is great 
compilation with bit more of a trip-hop feel.  I think Abstrakt Workshop 
2 was recently released, but I haven't seen it.

anarch@scruznet.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul 26 11:54:16 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA20546; Fri, 26 Jul 1996 11:54:16 -0700
Received: from pluto.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA20541; Fri, 26 Jul 1996 11:54:09 -0700

Date: Fri, 26 Jul 1996 11:53:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG <sandoz@sfsu.edu>

To: Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com>

Subject: Re: Malachy's healing fund
In-Reply-To: <199607260431.VAA22244@mail-gw.fsr.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960726114457.10977A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Malachy was an Irish man who came over here about five years ago and 
started doing parties.  He was one of the first pople involved in both 
Whicked and the full-moon raves as well as doing the first gathering 
parties.  Then, about two years ago he waS driving back from a full-moon 
rave when the vechile that he was driving in had a very bad accident 
which left him parrallized from the neck down.  He then went back to 
Ireland to get better and I saw him here at the last come-unity party 
and, while he was still in a wheelchair, he did look to be getting a lot 
better.  In short, Malachy was one of the founding-father's of the SF 
rave scene and the scene would most probably not be as big as it today if 
it was not for this man.  And, since reconstructive surgey is so 
expensive (even in a country that has free health-care!?) people have 
been having parties from time-to-time to raise money for him.  In fact, I 
do not believe that this is the first F&F party in which the proceeds of 
it have gone to Malachy's health-care fund.
Tristan.

> Could someone send me some more info on this?  Thanks!!

This may have possibly happened, but most of the benefits have been and
continue to be thrown by reputable people who have been close to  
and are still in touch with him.  The fact that Malachy still returns to
SF and shows up at many/most of these events I think testifies to this.

Looks like a raver's weekend of worthy causes.  Obviously I'm
going to be at the one for hyperreal (F&F) but if the Malachy benefit
(Unity) is not too far away I'm going to try and hit that one too.
I hope the Aids (Give It Back!) and BM (Lust for Life) benefits are also
successful.  All worthwhile causes; Freedom of expression and Caring
for folks in need.  These themes transcend politics (i.e. us vs. them)
which is how I prefer raving to be.

Imaginary Scenario:
Scene: Friends and Family, 2AM. A police car is parked nearby, and
       a Police Officer (PO) is looking at the id of one Larry Ching (Elsie).
PO: It says here that you're 41 years old. Don't you know you're too
    old to be at a rave ? Go home!
ELSIE: Oh gee Officer! That's my dad's id! Here's mine!
PO: Hey - the lamination's still warm on this! And you don't look 18!
ELSIE: Uh ... I had a long day skateboarding and doing my homework!!!
PO: Yeah,yeah .. we're arresting you for using a fake id! Get in the back
    of the cruiser!

I'd subscribe back into SFRaves for the weekend to get the latest news
about FnF and this weekend. I'm glad I did - I didn't know that the
proceeds for FnF was going to be going to the Malachy fund instead of
Hyperreal ( will there be a benefit for Hyperreal in the future? ).
That keeps me from feeling guilty about not going to Unity - although
I was strongly tempted to go to both of 'em!

a benefit for the BM foundation itself, or something similar-sounding?

the phrase "...benefit for the Burning Man .." is illegible to me.
Otherwise, sounds interesting too - it's up against some big competition,
tho' .

On Fri, 26 Jul 1996, 
Anarch wrote:

> Brandon William Brown, bbrown@cats.ucsc.edu wrote:
> >
> >Fri, 26 Jul 1996, Stephen Woltosz wrote:
> >> Does anyone have any suggestions for really kool Acid Jazz collections out
> >> there?
> >
> >there was this single I heard "Sugar Free Jazz"  had a nice little jungle 
> >beat goin' on in the distance....can't remember the artist though...damn
> 
> "Sugar Free Jazz" is by Soul Coughing, who are bit outside the main line 
> of "acid jazz" (whatever that means), but a great band nonetheless, well 
> worth checking out.  "Sugar Free Jazz" is on the album Ruby Vroom.
> 
> There are two compilation series, "The Acid Jazz Test" and "This is Acid 
> Jazz," that have some pretty good stuff.  I haven't heard all the issues 
> (there are 5 so far in "This is Acid Jazz," not sure about the other) but 
> my favorite so far is Acid Jazz Test 2.  Abstrakt Workshop is great 
> compilation with bit more of a trip-hop feel.  I think Abstrakt Workshop 
> 2 was recently released, but I haven't seen it.
> 
> anarch@scruznet.com
>

> at the troc on august 1st... but it says no presale tix available, listen

Wow! I saw these guys live in a crowd of 10000 at the Big Day Out
(a one-day festival like Lollapollooza (sp?) plus a few dance acts)
in Sydney in February. They were amazing: really energetic and
pushing musical boundaries. They're not really a dance act anymore,
but thrive in uncharted territory between jungle, hip-hop and heavy
metal.

Jeremy

Subject: More on Trainspotting
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.960726125115.20908A@crl4.crl.com>

Precedence: bulk

There is an interview with "Trainspotting" author Irvine Welsh in Spin.  
He gives much credit to the Scottish rave scene for inspiration.  He said 
he wanted to tell a story in his writing "just like a DJ."  
I have started reading his book from last year, with a strange title I 
can't recall now.   He gives thanks to his favorite clubs in the forward.
His new book is called "Ecstacy."  It is three stories about the drug and 
other means of reaching ecstacy.  A man on E sees a thalidomide victim and 
swears revenge on the corporation responsible.  A woman with a drug 
addict boyfriend takes E, changing her life.  For more info, do a  
Altavista search on "irvine welsh" +Ecstacy, it'll be under e-tour.
I'm going to the 9:45 showing at the Kabuki.  Hope to see some of you there!

David

Subject: german techno/FnF descript.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

It's time for another mike-wants-to-flesh-out-his-music-collection post!

This time, I'm looking for *mainstrean* german happy
trance/gabber/hardcore. Stuff along the lines of Members of Mayday,
Westbam, Marusha, Chill'n'Force, Dr. Robotniko, Scooter, and others. I've
got Happy Rave '95, I've got RaveBasePhase3 and RaveMachineVol.2 (the
polish bootleg double tape sets! =) and I need more... To my knowledge
there aren't any local DJs who spin this, but It's so big in Europe that
VIVA (Germnay's MTV) rolls out Gabber videos during primetime! (they're
surprisingly calm, considering the nature of the music-- very slick
computer 3D animations from Mark'Oh and Dune...)

so... can anyone help? I want dj mixtapes, CDs, non-mixed stuff, whatever.
I'm going to Poland this winter (maybe) and I'll be passing through Berlin
so if anyone knows of German DJs to look for, or CDs to buy (despite the
ridiculously high price of CDs in Germany =P ) drop me a line.


Oh yeah, there's a stack of y'all who need to find me at FnF to pick up
your t-shirts. Here's what I look like: 6'0", green SFR shirt, blue jeans
(shorts or pants, I'm not sure yet. gotta figure out what the weather's
like on saturday), butt-parted short-ish brown hair with bleached bangs,
and brown airwalks. Or you can just ask people who already have shirts
where I am... I know enough SFRavers to make it easy for someone to point
me out.

see everyone there! I can't wait...

-m.

Leslie, our beautiful rave big sista ;) you are so right about living life
in the moment . . .

For me, up until an hour ago when the project I've been working on was
finally done and I crawled home to crash, this week has been about 15 hour
workdays, where there was so much stuff to do that even as you wish it was
over you can't help living in the moment.  This sort of work pace doesn't
happen often, or I'd be dead, but it does happen to me two or three times a
year.  I don't always love my work, but it is my choice.

And because there was so much work to do before the deadline, time was
flying, and now my four-day weekend has started a few hours early (I'm
taking Monday & Tuesday off for the Further festival shows in Sacramento
and Shoreline).

Knowing that my first big fnf was this weekend, and then two days off,
sustained me really well during this hellish week.  All the postitive fun
energy i've been storing and haven't been able to express (until this
morning, when sleep deprivation & then the end of the work has made me
fairly giddy) will be pouring out of me tomorrow :)

I have a comment on this thought:

>so that you can get to an experience that you HOPE will make you happy!

The experience doesn't make you happy -- YOU make yourself happy by what
you bring to the experience and how you feel it.  Of course, some events
have the vibe more than others, and other people can feel the presence or
absence of it and it affects their experience. But it's up to us all to
bring the vibe with us wherever and whenever we can.

see you all tomorrow night!  Until then it's time to rest, get prepared,
rest, and take some vitamins!  And maybe watch a little Olympics.

peace,

leftjab

Dear All;

        Simon's in G-Ville, Florida is an awesome SE Coast dedicated Techno
venue, I've personally spent many a nights at. The vibe down there is
awesome because it's a small town, everyone literally knows everyone else.
But people travel from city to city down there like a little dead thang. I
traveled around Orlando, Gainesville, Jacksonville, ..etc. But routinely met
people from Georgia, and the pan handle The E is very, VERY, VERY strong,
not for the weak of heart, and people are just plain party crazy, nitrous &
special K everywhere. 
        Gainesville is hot north central florida and home to the beautiful &
totally natural Florida parie, lots o alligators, University of Florida, An
Army Base, & 14 Prisons; including serial killer Danny Rolins. 

        Lot more Latino/Brass influence especially the closer you get to
Miami. Florida is rad, it's where this soul, bonded to the soul of Techno
Vibe. I when back there to Simon's & Florida recently to see Sasha spin,
twice, I had serious  tears of  joy when I walked into Simon's at midnight,
because it hadn't changed(no sarcasms present).

        Check out Simon's the only Nationally rated club that I know that I
can say has vibe. The South East Coast scene is all clubs.

Peace
Brian
Peace
Brian

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9606268384.AA838416266@smtplink.acer.com>
To: "THX1138" <THX1138@planet-jubip.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Do You Tweak Your EQ?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


          Well,

          I've spent some time on sound... for Trance and the really
          synthy stuff, I'd keep the mids flat, a little (4db) bump
          around 8k (hi hats), and a gradual bass rise starting at 200
          hz to about 40 hz (where it should be about +0-+8 depending
          on room, speaks and mix).  For house I would boost the
          bass some more, but my favorite thing about house tends
          to be the bass (not a big piano sample and divas fan).
          For jungle, I turn the bass down a bit, and turn up upper
          mids (so you can hear the trademark 'busy toms' sound).
          One thing I've noticed is people try to boost the bass at
          the EQ... this sucks because of the severe distortion
          present in most EQ's.  I tend to just put more power amps
          and speaks after the crossover for the subs to get that
          happy jolly house/techno/acid bass.

          For home use (i.e. no active crossovers..) remember that
          EQ's usually are not ideal, and boost signals in excess of
          the range the claim to.  When boosting bass near the volume
          threshold of your speakers/amp, remember set it up flat and
          crank it.

          Turn up the super lows until the test muzik sound yummy.

          Turn down the higer bass freq's (around 100hz) till the
          muddiness goes away.  This is the most valueable tip I have,
          and I used it a LOT... it doesn't seem to make sense (more
          bass by cutting bass) but it really does work.

          Turn the highs up a little (most home systems aren't capable
          of causticly loud highs).

          Should be good.

          Take Care,
          See you Saturday...
          Andy W

HELLo!


Anyone heard of a program run by Microsoft at their web site that allows them
to search your hard drive when you access them, looking for
unregistered/cracked programs?  'Twas a rumor I heard from a friend of mine
and I just wanted to cross reference it with all you
smarter-than-I-about-computers folks.  Is it possible for anyone look at what
is on your drive when you access a site?

J,

This was a rumor that started when Win95 came out.  It was a hidden 
little goodie that was supposed to check serial numbers of all MS 
Software on your drive whenever it found you on the net.

This would suck.

The last we heard of (November 94) Win95 was planning to put this in.  I 
haven't heard anything since - but MS is probably doing it and a whole 
lot more.

Then again, I work at Apple so I don't deal with this crap.

I believe that there was some controversy about this a while back. It only
happens if you are using the Microsoft Network software, and as I recall,
there was such an outrage about it, MS killed the "feature" in their later
releases of the software.
So, the answer is NO, your hard drive CANNOT be accessed merely by
accessing a site or anything else on the Net for that matter.
Tim

Hello!  Yes, with much delight I will be at F&F (and for the record I
only bought one ticket for me :) .   As for what I'll be wearing  I
won't know until tomorrow night so who knows other than it will be
one of my rave T-shirts.  I should wear my "anti-Felix" shirt if
Brandon B. will wear his Felix shirt.  :-)  I'm 6'1", just past shoulder
length very light brown hair which may or may not be in a pony tail,
depending on how hot it is inside.

So, if you see me, please say hi - and hugz n' smiles are always available. :)

Lost @ the BBQ on Saturday:  one yellow sport bottle that had the name
of some Dr. Mark V (something) from Cupertino.  Not a monetarily valuable
item, but it was one of my only bottles that actually sealed! Useful for
raves and biking.  If anyone happened to have picked it up, lemme know.

 Comment on the availability of F&F tickets.
 As with any event that has more people wanting to go than there are
 tickets available, those not acquiring a ticket will be disappointed.
 So, it's not the end of life if that happens, right?
 I think F&F did a very fair and even-handed job of distributing the
 tickets.   I noticed some people suggesting leaving them at certain
 record stores in SF or Berkeley, but to me that's not much of a solution.
 Being in the South Bay that renders them almost as unavailable to me
 as it would to those who couldn't make it to the BBQ, for example.

For those of you going to FnF - see you there
Have a great weekend!

Peace
  - R

ACadosi@aol.com wrote:
> 
> HELLo!
> 
> Anyone heard of a program run by Microsoft at their web site that allows them
> to search your hard drive when you access them, looking for
> unregistered/cracked programs?  'Twas a rumor I heard from a friend of mine
> and I just wanted to cross reference it with all you
> smarter-than-I-about-computers folks.  Is it possible for anyone look at what
> is on your drive when you access a site?
> 
> Scared,
> 
> -JDub

Ok, the facts. 

1. Microsoft Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator (possibly others)
make use of a data type called a 'cookie'. This data is normally simple
basic stuff used by the browser. That data can be read by the server.
Bot Netscape and MS allow you to turn off the cookie reporting function
of the browser. 

2. Any Java enabled browser is a possible security breach. There was a
loophole in the java classes that allowed an applet to affect the
computer beyond the Java virtual machine. This has been fixed, however,
java is so new that there are probably lots of undiscovered  security
holes left.

3. Win95 and WinNT make extensive use of a file called the Registry.
This is a flat file database of the machine and user settings (kind of
like a giant *.ini file). All 32-bit apps (and most 16 bit) will be
defined in the registry. There are tools that make use of the registry
for software metering and client inventory. All of them require a client
side agent to be installed to function. 

I don't much like microsoft either but this is a false rumor.

Patrick Hancox - random WinNT guru on the street.

drawbacks:  They feel pretty heavy on your feet after hours of dancing, 
and:         Not very high arch support.

are still as good as new.

your questions.

all know I'm going to be at F&F, so any of you were undecided about going

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jul 26 19:47:43 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA03888; Fri, 26 Jul 1996 19:47:43 -0700
Received: from stratacom.strata.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id TAA03870; Fri, 26 Jul 1996 19:47:39 -0700

	id AA06519; Fri, 26 Jul 96 19:46:26 PDT
Received: from polaris.strata.com by Strata.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1/StrataCom-GCA-Kiwi-931007-1)
	id AA07466; Fri, 26 Jul 96 19:46:26 PDT

	id AA07047; Fri, 26 Jul 96 19:46:30 PDT

From: jlawrenc@stratacom.com (Jeremy Lawrence)
Message-Id: <9607270246.AA07047@polaris.strata.com>
To: sandoz@sfsu.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Politics in raving (long)
Cc: ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wrote:
> > Have a look at:
> >   http://www.oneworld.org/news/reports/rts/index.html

Tristan wrote on SFRaves:
> Now that's waht I call a party.  The other day some one was on this list 
> talking about politics in raving; but it was about people only and not 
> issues that effect them (e.g. having your village ripped up for a new 
> freeway). 

You touch on an important point there. I'll get back to it.

> For me, this is why I got into raves in te first place: not to 
> simply go out and have a good time (although obviously this is a very 
> important factor) but, in the tradition of punk rock, to do my two cense 
> in trying to smAsh the system.  

Methinks that's not quite how the whole rave thing works. Here's a
comment by Paul Hartnoll of Orbital:
   "Whereas punk was 'Come on, let's smash the system, lets knock 'em
   down', the whole dance music thing is more like people saying 'We
   don't like this life that we've been given so we're just going to
   do our own thing anyway'. And it's actually so much more effective
   because it is actually living by example, it's like I'm not just
   going to try and smash the Tories [conservatives] down, I'm just
   going to live contrary to them." -Dream Creation 10, p11
   
While i agree with Paul that rave/dance culture is preferrable to punk
as a counter-cultural movement, i don't agree that it was actually
more effective. Until very recently, that is.

Lets have a look at history of counter-cultural movements. Kath
Williamson (i think) pointed out on Ausrave that recent
counter-cultural/musical movements have happened in roughly
ten-year cycles.

1956: Rock and Roll
Philosophy: Fuck your staid attitudes, we're having a good time,
   stay out of our way or there'll be trouble.
Limitation: "Rebel Without a Cause" syndrome. Staid attitudes
   don't make much of a potent symbol for rebellion.
   
1966: Pschedelia & Hippies
Philosophy: Your attitudes are uncool, we'll show you an alternative.
Limitation: 'Turn the other cheek' doesn't stand up to pressure
   that well. Once the authorities convinced himselves that it was
   ok to beat up hippies on mass (e.g. Reagan calling in the
   National Guard to Berkeley), they became marginalised in the
   public eye.
   
1976: Punk
Philosophy: Fuck your attitudes, fuck the system, fuck you. Punk was
   Rock and Roll with more attitude and a powerful symbol: the whole
   system.
Limitation: The whole system was too powerful. Punk was 
   ultimately futile fury.

1986: House/Rave/Dance Culture
Philosophy: Your attitude sucks, we'll do things our own way, stay
    out of our way or there might be trouble. This was an attempt
    to find the middle path between Pschedelia's weakness and
    Punk's ineffective fury. The first post-modern counter-cultural 
    movement. :)
Limitation: Without an explicit political philosphy, Rave didn't
    achieve much except it's own survival. (Though it was remarkably
    successful at this: Rave is healthier after ten years than Punk
    or the hippy thing was.)

1996: ???

I think we can see what is happening now. The music is evolving
as always, and becoming more mainstream-palatable without
losing it's integrity. A music reviewer for the Sydney Morning
Herald said that Trip-Hop and Fusion were "letting todays kids
listen to the music that their parents were listening to," which
is partially true. The Prodigy makes Jungle palatable to
Metal-Heads. (Remember that Metal's turned 21. Even Homer Simpson
was into it. :) Hop/Fusion unites Reggae and Rave. Result:
thousands of people of all types turn up to a protest party in
London.

Popular appeal lets rave develop politics (both "popular" and
"politics" comes from the Latin for "of the people"). Not the
futile "smash the system" politics of punk, but single-issue 
politics with simplicity and immediate interest. 

So we get small daylight/evening protest parties in Sydney about
police brutality (April 1995), French nuclear testing at Muroroa
Atoll (late 1995/early 1996), and logging of old-growth native
forests (eraly 1996). And unauthorised street parties in
London protesting about road building and car culture (mid 95,
mid 96) culminating in 7000 people partying on a freeway
earlier this month.

Tristan wrote about the US rave scene:
> And that's what needs to happen here: raves need to become more
> politicised.  Don't forget: every time you are 
> at a rave and are tripping you are risking going to jail for ten years 
> with no remission or porole; yet this is never talked about on this 
> list.  And as for how we rape our natural evironment!  We need to have 
> people at raves giving out info on drugs etc as well 
> as free condoms to name but a few.  We need more people at raves doing 
> healing and body work. 

Whoah! All they're all valid points, but don't try handling them
all at once.

> So what can we, as an American movement, do about this?  This is a 
> difficult question as politics is much more elitist in it's nature then 
> in England (where everyone has already be politicised from an early age) 
> and there is a danger we might alienate the very people we need to 
> educate.  BUt it is definatly some thing we need to think about.  Any 
> suggestions?

Remove the elitism by taking the politics to the people.
Pick single issues that effect People Like Us. And use raves
as a protest. It seems to work elsewhere.

Jeremy

Did you know-

Bob Marley wrote many songs on the back porch of 56 Hope Road.  Many
mornings/days, as spliffs were rolled, the seeds from the herb would be
thrown onto the ground where birds would pick them up in their beaks.  This
inspired the song "Three Little Birds" (one of my favorites) from the trio
of ground doves picking up seeds.

From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Green Day review
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9607262233.A5437-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>

Hi all!

 Wow. I'm so tired!! Green day had many problems. The location was 
changed at the last moment and then the dance studio wouldn't let us set 
up from 6-9pm due to already booked dance classes. My ride (provided by 
the promoters in exchange for my work) got me to the studio at about 
4:30 pm on thursday so we did not have a lot of time. :(

 We started late of course but the two rooms; main dance floor with GOA 
and trance/acid flowing and INCREDIBLE black lite paintings and the 
ambient room with a phatty sound system (thanks Dutch!) which looked very 
spectral, were pretty happening. The mayan calendar glph readings went 
off well and there were a lot of incredible chance meetings. 
Unfortunately the police did swing by and shut down the party at about 
2-3 am (?). We let people who were not in any condition to drive stay and 
then started music up again about an hour later (subdued of course).

 Biggest problems were people flakking on helping which caused those of 
us dedicated to work much harder (I came up from Santa Cruz with a LOT of 
equipment and was sound engineer for the Stephan and Martin Kent drum/dig 
ritual, worked my ass off for free AND ended up sweeping, mopping and doing
other assorted lovely chores). Also the system interface between me and 
the DJ mixer wasn't optimum (Pro level audio driving consumer level 
electronics) and with the time and energy crunch it was not very feasible 
to trouble shoot the system to perfection. It worked but I was not pleased.

 The drum/dig ritual was very nice with an impromptu opening invocation by 
a visiting high priestess (very strange but evocative). One guy who 
showed up playing the D'Jhimbe (sp?) was incredible as well as the guest 
kit drummer. After that stuff (lasted about 80 minutes or so with some 
really wild dancing) I was on for the rest of the night. But due to the 
audio problems I just DJ'ed in a Very rElaxed way rather much actually 
performing (although I was playing my analog synth with the ritual folks) 

 My favorite part of the whole evening was meeting some really incredible 
people; Raven, Dagny. Beverly ( I'm sorry honey :( ), Robert and Amy 
(thanks for the shower!!), Allen, Surge, Stephen and Martin Kent (you 
guys were beautiful!!). My sympathies to Dutch for his health problems. 
The couple times I did get to dance I really loved all the swirling acid 
soundz being pumped out.


Peace ya alls



Ran

                                  -=*=-
                                    ~




PS: Be on the look out for Hallucination, Augest 24th.

It's 2:30 and I just got home from a small house party.  Turn on the TV to
catch something that will put me to sleep after a good evening.  I catch
the news.  A bomb has gone off at the Central Plaza in Atlanta.  Many hurt,
many more scard.  This such bullshit.  A BOMB has gone off at a place where
the world has gathered to come together for many more reasons than
competition.  I'm watching CNN and seeing alot of pain, suffering,
confusion.  I am now sad.  This really puts a damper on not only my evening
but a lot of other peoples and the whole concept of an Olympic games event.
This days after one of our airplains has tragically been destroyed by a
possible bomb as well.  Why as people so selfish for thier personal goals;
trying to make an impression, get a message across, or get attention by
dangerous means.

My heart goes out to all the people in Atlanta and around the world touched
by this disasterous event.

PEACE!

Austin

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jul 27 02:48:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA08172; Sat, 27 Jul 1996 02:48:33 -0700
Received: from tempest.organic.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA08165; Sat, 27 Jul 1996 02:48:31 -0700
Received: from localhost (caliban@localhost) by tempest.organic.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id JAA03036; Sat, 27 Jul 1996 09:49:02 GMT
X-Authentication-Warning: tempest.organic.com: caliban owned process doing -bs
Date: Sat, 27 Jul 1996 02:49:02 -0700 (PDT)
From: Rocky Mullin <caliban@organic.com>
To: cc@cyborganic.net
cc: bb@bigbook.com, pork@wired.com, bman@bud.com, mullinj@aol.com,
        terry@impactsf.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: report from atlanta
Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.93.960727013718.2738A-100000@tempest.organic.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	for those of you who don't know, i'm in atlanta and
	was about two blocks from the park when the explosion
	happened.  we're here working on www.nike.com.

	my good larry springer works there in the park...

	ok, larry paged me from his hotel, he's fine fine fine.
	i had been very worried about him; as coverage learned
	more about the incident, every minute the location of
	the blast was pinpointed closer to his location.

	the story is that he called me today and invited me 
	down to tour his workplace.

	he's a lighting designer, and did the lights at the att
	pavillion at centennial park (which has now been renamed
	by the media "olympic park" which is absurd).  you have
	all by now seen the tape of the bomb going off, that 
	white tower there is exactly where he works (worked),
	second level.  anyway, he called and asked me to come
	down tonight, and check out his gig.  special plug to 
	emily and the writers here at nike for giving me what i
	thought was a whole too many audio quotes.  thanx :)
	this basically made me miss the incident.

	anyway, this richard fellow, who found the bomb, was
	the guy i was supposed to find to get access to the 
	mix tower, actually.  he is the security guard for the
	tower.

	larry told me that richard found the package, and they 
	were evacuated from the mix tower.  their attitude was
	"ok, bomb scare, fine whatever".  this was their second 
	bomb scare, one was a few weeks ago.  so a couple minutes
	later, the thing went off.

	larry is experienced in stage work, including pyro, and
	did not think this was that big or loud.  of course, stage
	pyro is controlled and directed.  anyway, afterwards he 
	approached and saw a number of people on the ground, most
	"writhing" and one of them "still".  he sort of diddn't
	know why there was so much commotion. he was then shooed out	
	by security, even though some of the cops were asking for 
	the lights to be turned on.
	
	outside it's kind of nuts.  i tried to get to nike park to 
	deliver fresh camera batteries and other gear but they 
	stopped us within a block.  those damn betacams are heavy 
	as hell, i lugged it four miles all around the entire 
	georgiadome/omni/cnn plaza to try to get in, but the
	cop was rather sure we could not go in.  he did tell us
	that they have a word for "us" (i was with a film crew)
	but that he'd rather not say what it was.  i told him 
	that that does go both ways.  we caught a cab back to 
	nike hq on marietta, and here i am now.  

	as far as security goes, it's tight and it's not.  for 
	instance, there are metal detectors and bag searches at
	all events.  however, had i converted the bowerbook i 
	was carrying into a bomb, i could have blown up the men's
	gymnastics final because the security volunteers did
	not make me turn it on like they do in airports.  the
	security at centennial park does not do any searching
	or metal-screening, though they were certainly careful
	about not letting me in with my rollerblades on.  as
	usual, priorities.

	also, i came out of my apartment building this morning
	to immediately be hustled around by secret service agents.
	apparently al gore was nearby, and i even got to see him.
	<http://www.organic.com/Staff/caliban/jwz/Imagez/gore1.jpg>
	at what point can security be tight enough?  i was close
	enough to cause him harm, had i that intention as well 
	as the intention to die myself.  i kind of like the old 
	elvis guy, despite what his wife tried to do to rock 'n
	roll.

	this terrorism sucks.  i hope it's not indicative of a
	police state to come.

	anyway, i think i am going to go find some breakfast.
	this will be a night where sleep is impossible, one of thos
	two day periods that pass percieved as one, long, thick day.

-- 
\  c   /\  a   /\  l   /\  i   /\  b   /\  a   /\  n   /\     rocky mullin

hmm, ok. im sure some people out there arent going to like what i have to 
say about the bomb thing, but hey, this is probably more realistic then 
saying the CIA did it. 

basicly, we had it coming. the reasons are that a certain presendent 
decided to put the United States in everyother countrys bussiness. The 
Serbs hate us, all of the Middle East hates us (for those of you who dont 
know, we're (USA) now running Saudi Arabia), about a half-dozen 
African groups hate us, and oh, not to forget about the South American 
groups that hate us, Along with Communists in Russia.

another reason, when you put 30,000+ security guards in one spot, its 
asking for someone to test out the security and see how good it really 
is. 

now then, we can basicly assume a police state is coming. why? well 
because of Bubba from Arkansas saying things like "a cop on every corner 
in America" and other insane ideas about having more cops. are more cops 
gonna solve the problem? of course not, look at Ireland. they've got a 
bomb going off everyweek over there, and there is no constitution. the 
cops can do what they like to you. stop you. search you. detain you for
ever, etc. but still the IRA gets the bombs off.  a police state doesnt 
work. 

why would some group do this? to get total media attention. 6 months from 
now the media will still be talking about it. hell, if you can make it 
look like someone else did it, and not your group, then thats even better!

oh and btw, if the CIA did this, everyone at that concert would have been 
in little bitty pieces. ;)

To quote Richard. H.Kirk:
"The penial body is a small conical body arising from the third eye 
ventricle in the human brain.  In hte middle ages, scientists claimed 
it to be the seat of the soul: a little later they said it was the 
vestigal third eye.  Before long they'll conclude that it is all 
three.
Seeing used to an active sence.  The pineal body used to emmit it's own 
internal ray which, together with the suns light, made all of creation 
shimmer like a tapestry illuminated by light from the seat of the soul.  
Then they invented telivision and the preponderence of artificial light 
caused the penial body to atrophy, and we lost our ability to see nature 
by the light of our own internal ray.  That's why only so-called 
primative people can see the spirit world, because they still have active 
penial bodies.
Go out to the bush late at night.  If you don't have a soul you will not 
be able to see.  The moon won't help you.  You can only see by the light 
of your own internal ray.  It's the one way to find out if your pineal 
body still exists.

Remember: the mind is like a sieve, used to strain from memory the grit and 
splinters of a violent age.  The structure of the Human brain makes us 
record each and every image thAt we see, yet our recollection is the mesh 
on which those millions-upon-millions of pictures of the past are sifted 
through, for the benefit of conscious present."

As already stated, seeing used to be an active sense.

Tristan.

[ to eric & sfraves ]

 If you know that you're going to be in a place where your toes won't be
stepped on, a pair of padded sole Etonics are good ( unless you want 
something more stylish in appearance ).

 If running/walking style shoes are what you want, try doing some research
at the public library - that's how I decided to buy my Etonics. Mostly
looking through back issues of running magazines. 

 I just bought a pair of Red Wing safety leather athletic shoes with
steel toes and ankle support - I use them for outdoor events, and for
times when I feel my toes need the protection ( crowded raves and
concerts with mosh pits ) They feel good - a lot heavier than your
regular "running" style shoe, of course. 

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Good morning everybody,
If I may, I'd like to ask if anyone out there possibly, just maybe, 
hypothetically, theoretically, conceivably, hopefully, or perhaps even
definitely could help me in my day-long quest for (gulp) *3 F&F TIX*
(Yes, I know that request sounds phenomenally unrealistic, and perhaps
even a bit presumptuous or brazen, but let me explain).
In the true spirit of summer raving that we all know so well, two now
very-good friends of mine who had never been to a rave just a few months
ago, have fallen in love with the San Francisco scene--I've taken them to 
raves all summer, and we've bonded and had a fantastic, magical time, and
I've told them over and over how good Friends and Family is. Due to a
complicated ticket mix-up which I will not bore you with, however, they
are suddenly ticket-less, and Darin's girlfriend, who is flying in from
Washington tonight, is also empty-handed.
   I know that I am probably caught in an insurmountable obstacle--one
ticket would be Wonka-esque; three seems like an excessively ambitious
goal, but if any kind soul who has an extra or extras could email me or
ring me up, at 510.845.8481, I would be eternally grateful and would owe
you a proverbial 'one' big-time.  Also, you'll get the added kick of
seeing my mates and I in full drag tonight--I made my friends promise that
if we somehow got tix, they had to go in dramatic fashion! 
  So if you're low on karma and/or high on ticket quantity, and could
contact poor little me *sniff* *whimper* :) I would be undyingly thankful.
rubbing my rabbit's foot,
Timothy

Why does hyperreal try to send me a cookie when I access it?

> 
> ACadosi@aol.com wrote:
> > 
> > HELLo!
> > 
> > Anyone heard of a program run by Microsoft at their web site that allows them
> > to search your hard drive when you access them, looking for
> > unregistered/cracked programs?  'Twas a rumor I heard from a friend of mine
> > and I just wanted to cross reference it with all you
> > smarter-than-I-about-computers folks.  Is it possible for anyone look at what
> > is on your drive when you access a site?
> > 
> > Scared,
> > 
> > -JDub
> 
> Ok, the facts. 
> 
> 1. Microsoft Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator (possibly others)
> make use of a data type called a 'cookie'. This data is normally simple
> basic stuff used by the browser. That data can be read by the server.
> Bot Netscape and MS allow you to turn off the cookie reporting function
> of the browser. 
> 
>
