On Sat, 27 Jul 1996, Rocky Mullin wrote:
> 
> 	for those of you who don't know, i'm in atlanta and
> 	was about two blocks from the park when the explosion
> 	happened.  we're here working on www.nike.com.
> 
> 	my good larry springer works there in the park...
> 
> 	ok, larry paged me from his hotel, he's fine fine fine.
> 	i had been very worried about him; as coverage learned
> 	more about the incident, every minute the location of
> 	the blast was pinpointed closer to his location.
> 
> 	the story is that he called me today and invited me 
> 	down to tour his workplace.
> 
> 	he's a lighting designer, and did the lights at the att
> 	pavillion at centennial park (which has now been renamed
> 	by the media "olympic park" which is absurd).  you have
> 	all by now seen the tape of the bomb going off, that 
> 	white tower there is exactly where he works (worked),
> 	second level.  anyway, he called and asked me to come
> 	down tonight, and check out his gig.  special plug to 
> 	emily and the writers here at nike for giving me what i
> 	thought was a whole too many audio quotes.  thanx :)
> 	this basically made me miss the incident.
> 
> 	anyway, this richard fellow, who found the bomb, was
> 	the guy i was supposed to find to get access to the 
> 	mix tower, actually.  he is the security guard for the
> 	tower.
> 
> 	larry told me that richard found the package, and they 
> 	were evacuated from the mix tower.  their attitude was
> 	"ok, bomb scare, fine whatever".  this was their second 
> 	bomb scare, one was a few weeks ago.  so a couple minutes
> 	later, the thing went off.
> 
> 	larry is experienced in stage work, including pyro, and
> 	did not think this was that big or loud.  of course, stage
> 	pyro is controlled and directed.  anyway, afterwards he 
> 	approached and saw a number of people on the ground, most
> 	"writhing" and one of them "still".  he sort of diddn't
> 	know why there was so much commotion. he was then shooed out	
> 	by security, even though some of the cops were asking for 
> 	the lights to be turned on.
> 	
> 	outside it's kind of nuts.  i tried to get to nike park to 
> 	deliver fresh camera batteries and other gear but they 
> 	stopped us within a block.  those damn betacams are heavy 
> 	as hell, i lugged it four miles all around the entire 
> 	georgiadome/omni/cnn plaza to try to get in, but the
> 	cop was rather sure we could not go in.  he did tell us
> 	that they have a word for "us" (i was with a film crew)
> 	but that he'd rather not say what it was.  i told him 
> 	that that does go both ways.  we caught a cab back to 
> 	nike hq on marietta, and here i am now.  
> 
> 	as far as security goes, it's tight and it's not.  for 
> 	instance, there are metal detectors and bag searches at
> 	all events.  however, had i converted the bowerbook i 
> 	was carrying into a bomb, i could have blown up the men's
> 	gymnastics final because the security volunteers did
> 	not make me turn it on like they do in airports.  the
> 	security at centennial park does not do any searching
> 	or metal-screening, though they were certainly careful
> 	about not letting me in with my rollerblades on.  as
> 	usual, priorities.
> 
> 	also, i came out of my apartment building this morning
> 	to immediately be hustled around by secret service agents.
> 	apparently al gore was nearby, and i even got to see him.
> 	<http://www.organic.com/Staff/caliban/jwz/Imagez/gore1.jpg>
> 	at what point can security be tight enough?  i was close
> 	enough to cause him harm, had i that intention as well 
> 	as the intention to die myself.  i kind of like the old 
> 	elvis guy, despite what his wife tried to do to rock 'n
> 	roll.
> 
> 	this terrorism sucks.  i hope it's not indicative of a
> 	police state to come.

I just wanted to wish many of you an evening filled with love, growth and
sharing tonight at Friends and Family.  Seeking for Love to attend this
event with full-on vibe is not an easy task, for there are some out there
who seek nothing but to ridicule and challenge the positivity of Love.

Focus, courage, and dedication are required full-on for the vibe to come as
so many hope.  Hope, in itself, is also quite powerful.  Of course, I am not
telling many of you anything new...just wanted to express myself!  :)

I know this event always makes me re-think about what the words "friends"
and "family" really and truly mean to us.  For us.  There are some out there
who call themselves "friends" but are nothing more than wolves in sheeps
clothing, as they say.  And there are some out there who claim to do what is
best for the "family" when in essence, they are seeking to destroy it
because they are terribly misguided.  But there are a growing number of us
who seek to shine our light, stand and encourage others towards finding
Truth so they too may grow and share a special and almost hidden joy.  

I just hope and pray for each of you tonight that Love will indeed shine
from your beautiful souls and from beyond...the source.  And I also wish
each of you the best on the path of courage to not accept imitations and to
stand up for that which we hold so dear.  Love.

All my best to you tonight!

Troy J

stone to censorship or to weed out "subversives".  Watch your back, friend

If any of you guys check this in time for tonight's party, look for me....

I'm 5'3", short chin-length brown hair.  I'll be wearing black Ben Davis
pants, with a black and white checkered shirt, with flowers on each of the
black/white squares.  I'll probably be up in front most of the night, since
that's where I always get most of my energy from.  I'll be with a group of
friends, and we would love to open up our circle and welcome anyone!! :-)

Hope you all have a great and wonderful time tonight, and please only bring
good vibes, positive attitudes, and of course your gorgeous smiles!!!!

Peace, :-), and happiness!

Karen

unjust centuries in history, desperately trying to come up with a

prosperity categories.  We've been lead down the garden path, believing
we can cheat a zero-sum game. Our doghma does not have dharma nature.

	our apartments in the william oliver building are exactly
	one one of the five points.

	we could not leave our apartments today because they found
	another device, this one a c4 explosive, at the underground
	atlanta mall.  (underground atlanta is a lot like a version
	of fisherman's wharf except it is underground and it sucks
	more).  anyway they detonated it in some sort of bomb tank
	thing, i heard the boom from the bathtub.

	i was searched leaving our building, as well as entering 41
	marietta.  for perspective:

	41 marietta is two blocks from centennial park, which is 
	also on marietta.  these are our offices, we were in the
	basement working last night when the initial attack occured.

	the william oliver is at five points.  five points is the
	historic intersection of peachtree and marietta (there 
	must be some sort of georgian law that all streets must be
	called peachtree).  this intersection is one block from
	nike hq at 41 marietta.  one block further from centennial
	park. 

	underground atlanta is one-half blocks from the william 
	oliver building, on peachtree.	

	but, as they said, the games are going on.

Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> Remember -- "They" still need to claim about 499,700 more lives before
> they get even, and "they" probably will. 
> 
> War begets war begets war begets war. When will we learn?

While i agree with the sentiment, the implication that the Atlanta bomb
was planted by non-US terrorists looks to be incorrect:  the bomb was
apparently very amateurish, and very similar to those trialled earlier
by local militia groups.

How's this for a proposition:

The rise of the militia is an example of old Cold War pigeons coming
home to roost: if you label half the world "commie", some people will
start to believe that half the world is against them. If you encourage
people to become insular, then their country or state becomes their
world. In the inevitable logic of paranoia, half their country seems to
be against them. And sometimes they fight back.

Good day,

Just when you thought the sense of community couldn't get much better...

I was on the phone to my friend Ron discussing his lack of an F&F ticket, about to go out
onto the list and beg for one, when HE got a call from Paul.  He had given him his # , last
weekend after the BBQ, in hopes that he might come across a ticket.  This is the same
random kindness that has drawn me to all of YOU, and had impressed Ron the afternoon
of the BBQ.  We can make a difference.  I did not feel this way about people or their actions
before I met YOU.  Thank you.

Take care,

	crowded place yet only two people died.  definately
	c+ terrorist work. (ok, *maybe* b-)

	rumor is it might be a disgruntled vendor, which seems
	pretty likely to me.  it's really fun and exciting to 
	think it's the cia or the dole campaign, but whatever.

	i been wrong about things all weekend, but my theory
	is that this is an isolated asshole as opposed to a
	sweeping plan of terror.

	ok, off to see some handball matches.

	because hyperreal rocks:)

	cookies are not inherently bad.  some implimentations
	of cookies are really really lame, but not hyperreal's.

	they basically make your browsing experience better
	and more efficient, they way they are designed.  if 
	someone sends you cookies that only return to themselves
	and expire immediately (that day) no worries, imo.  
	if they are set to expire in 1999 or some shit, refuse it.
	that's what i do.

	heh, would you take a cookie from the alt.drug archives
	machine?  *i* would :)

On Sat, 27 Jul 1996, Chris Beaumont wrote:

> Why does hyperreal try to send me a cookie when I access it?
> 
> > 
> > ACadosi@aol.com wrote:
> > > 
> > > HELLo!
> > > 
> > > Anyone heard of a program run by Microsoft at their web site that allows them
> > > to search your hard drive when you access them, looking for
> > > unregistered/cracked programs?  'Twas a rumor I heard from a friend of mine
> > > and I just wanted to cross reference it with all you
> > > smarter-than-I-about-computers folks.  Is it possible for anyone look at what
> > > is on your drive when you access a site?
> > > 
> > > Scared,
> > > 
> > > -JDub
> > 
> > Ok, the facts. 
> > 
> > 1. Microsoft Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator (possibly others)
> > make use of a data type called a 'cookie'. This data is normally simple
> > basic stuff used by the browser. That data can be read by the server.
> > Bot Netscape and MS allow you to turn off the cookie reporting function
> > of the browser. 
> > 
> >

Hi all!!

 uhhhh FUCKIN' WOW!!! Holy shit was that a good party!!!

Of course I'm refering to FnF. The range of experiences and people I met 
simply can not be compared to any moment of my life. Rather than 
expose in detail my memories I would like to relate a personal experience 
that, I feel, sums up for me what that party was all about:

 At about 4am or so I noticed a slender man about 5' 8" (or so) dancing. 
He had a dark tint to his skin and he sported a pair of short red horns 
from his brow. I thought to myself, "cool, there goes satan dancing with 
the ravers. It's a really happy time here dancing with satan, the only 
thing to make it better would to be to have god dancing with us 
(including satan of course)." 
 About 2 hours later I was pulled out of my comfy position in a bean bag 
chair to look at the 2nd of two rainbows that appeared in the sky, 
visable from the parking lot behind our party (where a lot of people 
were hanging out dancing to the sound spill from indoors). And I thought 
to myself, "well, now god is dancing with us."


FnF ROCKS!!!!


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams



                                  -=*=-
                                    ~


PS: Thanks to the miracles who helped me make it to this event. You know 
who you are.  =)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 607       
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> What is a cookie?

A cookie is a string generated by the webserver that is sent
back to a browser as part of the response to an HTTP request.
The browser stores this string locally and sends it back when
it returns to the same host.  This is how they do things like
letting you create a customized version of their homepage or
just about anything else that requires maintaining persistent
client side state.

But other than the host that you come from to see web pages
or information you may have given them to generate the cookie,
this is *not* a way to see what is on your hard drive, etc, etc.

	Sami

On Sun, 28 Jul 1996 ACadosi@aol.com wrote:

> Not to personally attack you, but Nike has just been the subject of a probe
> that showes them terribly abusing "free trade zones" in many parts of the
> world by exploiting child labor. 

OK.

Ya touched a nerve here.  I work for a large company similar to Organic 
Online, and we also have clients that leave me disgusted, due to karmic 
implications of giving my energies to helping these corporations succeed 
in this new medium.  And I agree it is always important to ask "why".

This is a catch-22, the bete-noire of many of my friends and colleagues.
In order for this new medium to succeed, to build an environment that is 
rich fertilizer for memetic engineering (ie, populated by more than geeks 
like us), you have to do the Faustian Bargain thing.  Unless you are 
REALLY lucky and have a fat inheritance.  Yeah right.

How to get the portfolio and captial to begin a start-up web shop with 
the "hippy" consciousness you speak of?  Go to where the money is.  Learn 
from the mistakes of Ben and Jerry's.  Follow the lead of Real Goods.  
But idealism ain't nothin' but hot air without viability.  Show me a 
REAL "hippy shop" where I can be in a position to work with the Nikes, 
McDonalds, Philip Morrises of the world (and thus affect memetic change 
where it's really needed from the inside), and I'll send my resume.

This is one reason I can empathize with Bill Clinton.  I started out in 
92 working for Sen. Harkin, a "real liberal", but realized you have to "go 
moderate" to get into a position to affect change.  So the trick then 
becomes to keep your soul and to keep your priorities even as you get 
sucked into the Spectacle of the Beast called Compromise.

I don't have the answers, hell I'm still lookin' for the right questions, 
but I will defend brother Rocky because I sense he faces the same 
situation I do.   Poor and without portfolio won't get you far in this biz.

my $.02

john

I NEED ASSISTANCE!!

Last night at FnF I was pseudo-dancing with this girl and I feel I might 
have blown it because I didn't ask her name or introduce myself (very 
un-FnF)!  :P

For the record:
I was wearing blue jeans and almost an all white Solle XL T-Shirt...I 
have longish blond/Brown hair and a goatee (sp?).  I know - pretty damn 
average.

Her:
Brown Hair (I'm guessing somewhere between 5'6" and 5'8" ->but I really 
suck at guessing height).  Tight short sleeved dark blue top with what 
looked like foil designs on the front.  Phat blue jeans.  And one of 
those twisty metal things on her right arm.  I think glittery eyes as well.

We were dancing between the fan and the rear cabinets - to the left as 
you looked at Ethan's fre$h maneuvers (btw - nice set ETHAN!!!).

I'm hoping someone on the list knows her - or - she's here herself.

hoping for a little miracle..

_Brandon->

Points well taken.  Be aware that I am of late a bit scattered  as well as
frantic because I am noticing that people are turning away from the truth
_too_much_ these days.  Try these websites as examples of how the political
climate is becoming more hostile to the people and their rights ,more
friendly toward giant corp's, and how evil those corps are:

http://www.usatoday.com/news/court/nscot000.htmsupreme
http://http.tamu.edu:8000/~rst8074/nikenews.htmlnike
http://www.usatoday.com/news/washdc/ncs2.htmterror

  Indeed, I am short on solutions, but IMHO an  "if you can't beat 'em, join
'em"  attitude feeds the fire, creates statistics that can be quoted (see, no
one feels badly about Nike, everyone still does buisness with them...), and
helps the Nikes of the world succeede--at We The People's expense.  And in
regards to viability, we are _all_ living in an un-viable society.  And that
ain't no idealism.  I believe the corps see that too much info is getting out
there, so thier system of exploitation is in jepardy.  It's just a question
of who will get more desperate first, us or them?

In a message dated 96-07-28 18:30:37 EDT, you write:

<< 
 > Not to personally attack you, but Nike has just been the subject of a
probe
 > that showes them terribly abusing "free trade zones" in many parts of the
 > world by exploiting child labor. 
 
 OK.
 
 Ya touched a nerve here.  I work for a large company similar to Organic 
 Online, and we also have clients that leave me disgusted, due to karmic 
 implications of giving my energies to helping these corporations succeed 
 in this new medium.  And I agree it is always important to ask "why".
 
 This is a catch-22, the bete-noire of many of my friends and colleagues.
 In order for this new medium to succeed, to build an environment that is 
 rich fertilizer for memetic engineering (ie, populated by more than geeks 
 like us), you have to do the Faustian Bargain thing.  Unless you are 
 REALLY lucky and have a fat inheritance.  Yeah right.
 
 How to get the portfolio and captial to begin a start-up web shop with 
 the "hippy" consciousness you speak of?  Go to where the money is.  Learn 
 from the mistakes of Ben and Jerry's.  Follow the lead of Real Goods.  
 But idealism ain't nothin' but hot air without viability.  Show me a 
 REAL "hippy shop" where I can be in a position to work with the Nikes, 
 McDonalds, Philip Morrises of the world (and thus affect memetic change 
 where it's really needed from the inside), and I'll send my resume.
 
 This is one reason I can empathize with Bill Clinton.  I started out in 
 92 working for Sen. Harkin, a "real liberal", but realized you have to "go 
 moderate" to get into a position to affect change.  So the trick then 
 becomes to keep your soul and to keep your priorities even as you get 
 sucked into the Spectacle of the Beast called Compromise.
 
 I don't have the answers, hell I'm still lookin' for the right questions, 
 but I will defend brother Rocky because I sense he faces the same 
 situation I do.   Poor and without portfolio won't get you far in this biz.
 
 my $.02
 
 john
  >>

Though many may speak highly of F&F, there was still another great party.
Granted this was lust for life's first rave, but I think it went
tremendously well.
    Great Vibe
        Incredible Energy from crowd
    Wicked spinning by all dj's 
        Acme location which always has a cool groove to it
    Lot's of water from a faucet
        Excellent chillout room with air beds to lie on
    Good temperature control 
    
I can't say enough about the energy and the crowd. I think everyone that
couldn't go to F&F focused all thier energies toward Lust for Life.  Thank
you, Thank you for such a wonderful evening.  Hope to see everyone at
Chrysalis Next weekend!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Mike

Subject: UNITY review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello all,

still bummed I couldn't get to fnf, especially when all the positve reviews
come flowin' through my mail box

Unity was at Homebase.  It was the biggest party I've ever seen there (I
never made it to the last Gathering there so i can't compare) It was set up
with 3 systems -the dj in the middle of the floor of the main room, the
ambiant/jungle rm and an outdoors funk system thet didn't really get goin
till about 4.

My night started off bad and gradually built into a good time.  I first got
there and I found out there was a fight - more like a jumping 12 on 1 over
drugs and/or money.  I new the guy too: I never say what happened but heard
he went to the hospital in very bad shape.  Another friend of a friend OD
on what he thought was E and went to the hospital. And my friends Ann and
Keri were complaining that the guys would not stop jockin' them all night:
I got a very anti socal feeling from most girls there last night because of
this.

Positives:  DAN rocked the house.  MUSIC QUESTION: Anyone know where I can
pick up the funky track( or any tapes/cds/rekids/ i could find it on) with
the Redman sample on it: " I'm a Funk phenominon, a funk phenominon"  Phat
track!

Tony was next and then at 3.30 they did a cerimon for Malachy: Thanking him
for his support and explaining to the crowd about the cause.  They
performed a Kundalini healing dance where the crowd claped the rhythm.
This young and restles crowd was not into the cerimony much.  From were I
was people were yelling " turn the music back on." and "No more" Very
disapponted in the crowd at that point. It's all for a good cause so why
not show your support for a little exercise in self healing.

Galen got me back into the music and THEN came Dubtribe.  Yeah!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Ohhh man they were sick! I loved every sweaty, hot, bumpin' and funking
groovin' minute of it.  If you haven't seen Dubtribe you are missing out.
BP Natural August 1 DUBTRIBE, GALEN, JEN=D8 at Mision Rock Resort 817 China
Basin SF 415. 541.5678.  I am there. U?

My night had lifted and everything was all good.  Garth closed it out.  I
love him in the morning.  He played Michael Jackson  "dancin'.....
Yeah it was a good night but I am done with these big parties.

See you all at Full Moon maybe or chrystalis.

p
l
u
r

Austin

Hey everybody,

FnF was great, as usual.  The vibe was totally there.  I got to see people
there I hadn't seen in ages, and the new folks I met were so cool.

I love this party because it's totally open to anybody who wants to
participate.  Lots of us got there Saturday afternoon to help set up.  

I came with some stuff to build an altar, and that was hella fun.  As
always, the altar grew during the night. 

Michelle brought more stuff later on and set up the altar that was on the
floor against one wall in the ambient space.  She wrote "New Moon" in
chalk on the concrete, which I thought was really neat.

Minx, Cindy, Anna and friends also put up an altar next to the main room.
It was beautiful.  I liked how walking past it on my way to the main dance
area gave me a moment to chill and get into the right head space for
dancing.  Thank you!!

Thank you to everyone for a fabulous night.

Love,

Ann

After experiencing Friends & Family, I'll probably be glowing for dayz!

All of you just made the party R-O-C-K!! It was wonderful to see all 
those familiar smiling faces, and finally get to chat with everyone 
that I've been meaning to meet. (Tom, Amy, Johnathan, mHg, liquid, 
Brandon, and the rest)

If there is a such thing as a perfect party, This was it! Beautiful 
space, excellent music, *insane* chill room, Vibe jus' oozin' out of 
everybody in all directions, and for those of looked up as you were 
leaving...we were greeted by a beautiful rainbow that shone above the 
party in the morning! =)

Yes I'm guilty, I rave-hopped to UNITY at about 5:00am. (I wasn't the 
only one) Got in for free, just wanted to check it out. The set-up was 
sick! Got to hear the close of Dubtribe's set. Ran into a couple 
friends only to receive reports of two fights, bunk EntErtainmEnt, and 
a couple overdoses. Austin - You shoulda came back with me!!! Well, I 
didn't see very many smiling faces, so I aboutfaced after 20 minutes of 
that party and ran back to F&F.

Props to everybody who put so much time and effort into this party. 
Your *labor of love* was felt by everyone last night!

Hmmm.......Chrysalis anyone?????

Hugs, 

CT

On Sun, 28 Jul 1996 ACadosi@aol.com wrote:

> Hello! 
> Not to personally attack you, but Nike has just been the subject of a probe
> that showes them terribly abusing "free trade zones" in many parts of the
> world by exploiting child labor.  I thought that shit was supposed have been
> abolished 100 years ago!  Can you quit gracefully and work for a hippy
> company instead?   

	i work for organic.  nike is one of our clients.

	i have heard about this stuff.  whatever.  i don't
	buy nike shit, and am not married to it.  i also 
	maintain that as americans, each and every one of
	us has more than just some nike shit around the 
	house that comes from exploitive sources.

> I understand if you can't, I just wanted to be sure you
> were aware of this fact.  I realize that Nike _must_ have alot to offer you,
> but if you stop and think of _why_ they can offer it, you may feel
> differently about how you view them, being a  person just like those kids
> they exploit.   Unfortunately, I don't have the references to back up this
> alegation, but I got the info from someone I trust.  My mom.  I'll search the
> net and see what I can come up with.

	you might not like this, but it is perfectly normal in some
	parts of the world for children to work.  i dunno if nike
	has any child labor or not, i cannot remember what the press
	release said.  they did say that they pay more than the usual
	wage for their communities, and it is hard to enforce their
	labor requirements because they are dealing with contractors.
	i'll try to forward the release.  it comes down to who you 
	believe.  one thing i can say is that the people here
	where i am now are kind people and good people.  i dunno 
	if a single one of them has anything to do with contracting
	work overseas though.

	in the end, it's not up to us to tell another society what 
	they can or cannot do.  if you want to do that, then don't
	buy their products, of course.

On Sun, 28 Jul 1996, John Bagby wrote:

> 
> On Sun, 28 Jul 1996 ACadosi@aol.com wrote:
> 
> > Not to personally attack you, but Nike has just been the subject of a probe
> > that showes them terribly abusing "free trade zones" in many parts of the
> > world by exploiting child labor. 
> 
> OK.
> 
> Ya touched a nerve here.  I work for a large company similar to Organic 
> Online, and we also have clients that leave me disgusted, due to karmic 
> implications of giving my energies to helping these corporations succeed 
> in this new medium.  And I agree it is always important to ask "why".

	it is, and i do.  in fact, where i work i am given the choice
	to not work on a project if i have ethical problems with the
	client.  i exercised this choice with microsoft and mcdonald's.
 
> This is a catch-22, the bete-noire of many of my friends and colleagues.
> In order for this new medium to succeed, to build an environment that is 
> rich fertilizer for memetic engineering (ie, populated by more than geeks 
> like us), you have to do the Faustian Bargain thing.  Unless you are 
> REALLY lucky and have a fat inheritance.  Yeah right.

	and if you do, people bag on you for getting free money.
	can't win.

> How to get the portfolio and captial to begin a start-up web shop with 
> the "hippy" consciousness you speak of?  Go to where the money is.  Learn 
> from the mistakes of Ben and Jerry's.  Follow the lead of Real Goods.  
> But idealism ain't nothin' but hot air without viability.  Show me a 
> REAL "hippy shop" where I can be in a position to work with the Nikes, 
> McDonalds, Philip Morrises of the world (and thus affect memetic change 
> where it's really needed from the inside), and I'll send my resume.

	we would not be in business now if we refused all but the
	hippy stuff, i'm sure.  i dunno, i do not speak for organic.
	however, we do our best to give back the best we can.  for
	instance, do a traceroute to organic.com.  do a traceroute
	to hyperreal.com.  what do you see?  robin hood?  maybe...

	at one point we had a policy not to do tobacco or alcohol
	adds.  anyone who worked for a web shop a couple of web-years
	ago can probably tell you how many times zima called, and
	had to be told no, until that mtv dude took them in.  i 
	think this policy still stands, but again, i do not speak
	for the company i work for!

> This is one reason I can empathize with Bill Clinton.  I started out in 
> 92 working for Sen. Harkin, a "real liberal", but realized you have to "go 
> moderate" to get into a position to affect change.  So the trick then 
> becomes to keep your soul and to keep your priorities even as you get 
> sucked into the Spectacle of the Beast called Compromise.

	right.  cannot vote for achtenberg if she loses the primary, 
	but i can cast a vote for an inferior candidate that i feel
	is the least inferior of the ones that are left.

> I don't have the answers, hell I'm still lookin' for the right questions, 
> but I will defend brother Rocky because I sense he faces the same 
> situation I do.   Poor and without portfolio won't get you far in this biz.

	thank you, very very much.  i have recieved a number of
	different responses to this, about the labor issue, and
	in the end i am where i am.  some were nice, some were
	downright nasty and rude.  whatever.  i sleep at night.

Friends & Family was the bomb!  From the ultra homey chill room to the
mind-melding tunes that spun me all night to my friends new and old and all
the other smiling faces...this was one to remember and inspire me on those
days when I think life sucks...which won't be for a long time now!  Kudos
to Ethan and friends for pulling off another great party - this was my
second and I'm fully hooked!  Special thanks to SDream for giving me a
ticket and making it possible for me to go.  Nice meeting some
frequentposters to sfraves in person (Nancy, Crunchman).  Thank you all for
your spirit, your smiles, your open hearts and open minds.  The gods shone
upon us with that rainbow at dawn!!!  This was a magical event...can't wait
'til next time!
--David

Subject: F&F, Sunset, the Beautiful Skies, oh what a weekend!! :-)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey friends,

I can't even begin to express what a weekend this was.  This has been the
first weeked since I've been back to the Bay Area (June) that I've really
partied, and I couldn't have picked a better one.

Friends and Family was absolutely the best big party that I've been to.  And
this was my first F&F, too!!  I love you guys, you were ALL smiles and there
was nothing but that family feeling there!  I couldn't believe how much the
crowd was so together.  It's been too long since I've felt such energy and
love!!!

I'm really glad that I got to meet some of you SFRAVERs out there (Mike,
etc...you know who you are!!)  I was surprised that you came up to me and
recognized me in the crowd!  That was such a cool feeling!!

And I also couldn't believe that I made it throughout the night completely
SOBER!!  It's amazing how I was able to feel the energy bounce off from
person to person all around me.  I danced my ass off, so much since I was so
naturally high.  There's nothing like it.  I just realized that we don't need
drugs to have a great time (even though it's always fun to reach that next
higher level...)

And how many of you witnessed the beautiful sunrise?  I swear, this weekend
was made for all of us.  It was great when we were driving home to have the
sun rise on the left, while a HUGE perfectly horseshoe-shaped rainbow colored
the sky to the west.

And after hours of rest and recooperation, we went to the Sunset Party to
hear some groovin' house music while watching the sun go down.  The music was
great and really good vibes were present.  The sunset was spetacular, along
with the rising moon.

All in all, I was just completely overwhelmed about how this weekend turned
out.  I've been waiting to go dancing for a while, and this was well worth
it.

Thanks,  you guys for making this weekend really special for me.  This is
what makes San Francisco the heart of it all, for me.  I'm going to miss this
so much when I move back down to LA....   :-( 

Until next time........

Karen :-)

*** Reply to note of 07/26/96 17:37
FROM: Robert Brown

SUBJECT: Dancin' shoes

 I recently bought some Airwalks (the tongue of the shoe says "19oz"
 but I don't know if that's the model) that are super comfortable.
 The worked very well for Syntonic, BP, and F&F!  Arch support isn't
 too bad, and they are incredibly light.   Best of all - they were
 CHEAP!  Thanks to Mark Camp for the Ross recommendation (they were out
 of Converse one stars that I came in to buy).

 Nike.  I don't think Nike actually manufactures their own shoes they
 design and distribute them.  It would be the maunfacturing companies
 in Asia (primarily) that would be guilty of this alleged child labor
 abuse.  And, true, they are often expensive (retail), but they are
 good quality shoes.  I hit the outlet stores and clearance sales if in
 need of these shoes.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 10:47:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA18530; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:47:12 -0700
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA18490; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:47:04 -0700
Received: (from scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) id KAA16040; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:47:03 -0700
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:47:02 -0700 (PDT)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: Kristi Holland <kristih@sfsu.edu>
Subject: FnF
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960729100114.8919K-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Whoever said I wasn't a morning person hasn't seen me dance to gabber at 
7 a.m.  I was an instant convert!!  Dave Bayer had an amazingly wonderful 
set early in the morning.  I know some people were a bit weary of 
hard-core in the chill room, but there were some of us who adored it!!  
It was better than an early morning jog!  I think I live by the Jess 
Fogel rule of all or nothing.  The longer I rave, the more I'm attracted 
to faster music.  Slow music doesn't get my adrenalin pumping.  Slow 
music is such a let-down for my body.  So, that gabber set was just the 
injection I needed.  The handful of us dancing knew what it was all 
about!!  That was the first time I've heard gabber, and I hope I hear it 
again!!  It reminded me of early ska and the original skin-heads dancing the 
pogo.  

The gabber set was actually the first time the whole night that I went 
off.  I spent the rest of the time chilling out and soaking in the party.  
I had hopes of arriving around 10:30, but due to some last minute glitter 
preparations of my newbie friends, we didn't arrive until around 11:30!

When we arrived one of my friends said, "Wow, is it always this great?"  
It is so gratifying when you are finally able to share this feeling with 
close friends who have never felt it before!

I came with a huge group of extended friends and for the first hour there 
was all of this psuedo-coordination to do, which left me a bit 
frazzeled.  But, finally everyone discovered the exact place they wanted 
to be, and everything was fine.  I chatted with so many people and saw so 
many of your beautiful faces again.  Got a wonderful t-shirt from Michal, 
gave SDream a silly picture of the two of us, met Ran and Phelps (very 
charming people).  Got a back-breaking hug from Mattloaf (wow!:).  Hung 
out with Matt L., A-Ron, Roger (hope you got some pictures), erase, 
Branka, Eric, Erik, Reno.  Talked to Amy, Shawna, Black Adder, Reagan, Paul, 
Leslie, and the rest who I haven't forgotten.  Crowned Jon-Burger King with 
a special present.  Challenged Tony Rose while dancing to gabber to 
see who could hold out the longest!!  I think we tied!!  Helped Nancy find 
her infamous blue feather boa.  That was a BIG hit!!  Finally took 
pictures of everything.  I hope 
they come out well.  My flash seemed to be working great!  I was dressed 
entirely in pink with pink satin pants and a pink tank-top.  A friend of 
mine came up to me during the night in the dark and gave me a sticker 
that said "pink."  In the morning she realized just how appropriate that 
was!!

>From maybe 1:30-4 I disappeared into the world of anonymity and watched 
the party through the eyes of my newbie friends, gleefully remembering how 
I felt at my first rave.  The curiosity, the attraction, the beautiful 
chillroom (L-shaped and magnificently decorated), the strange music that 
seeps into your bones.  It was a special moment with special people.  I 
think I spoiled them, though, by bringing them to FnF!! :)  

I didn't actually dance very much until around 5 a.m. and then the gabber 
set came on and I was in heaven.

The morning was beautiful and warm, as was the entire night.  The rainbow 
was too perfect!!  The organic breakfast was a great end to a great 
night.  The group hug with people piling on was so special.  Seeing 
Kristi get in her full of dancing and wanting more as everyone was 
leaving!!  I don't know how she does that!!  She puts me to shame!!

Thank you to everyone involved, it was simply amazing.  Every FnF that I 
have been to has been special and unique.  I was trying not to compare 
this one to the others, worried that I'd be let down.  But, that just 
wasn't the case.  It was truly unique.

--KaySEE

              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 10:55:01 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA19367; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:55:01 -0700
Received: from gw3.pacbell.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id KAA19351; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:54:56 -0700
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by gw3.pacbell.com (5.x/PacBell-10/18/95)
	id AA03482; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 10:54:11 -0700
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/Mother-7/26/95)
	id AA18219; Mon, 29 Jul 96 10:54:10 PDT
Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA22300; Mon, 29 Jul 96 10:54:09 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9607291754.AA22300@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: F&F/Unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 96 10:54:08 PDT
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I started things off early at F&F.  This was probably the best
organized noncommercial event I've ever been to.  Great space, plenty
of room, beautiful decorations, all comforts taken care of.  I really
appreciated those big $1 cups of juice, candy, soft places to sit,
excellent visuals, street parking security and the big outdoor area.

The vibe was great, of course.  The main sound system was excellent
and everyone was going nuts there.  Not being a huge fan of trance, I
stayed mostly in the "ambient".  There was a lot of sound bleed
through from next door, but after a while I decided that I liked hearing 
some of that energy in the mix.  The ambient DJs were spinning 
pretty danceable stuff and I enjoyed adrenalin's and Tom's sets 
as the party got underway.  Monty came on and even spun us
some house, which got a happy little group of us on our feet.  I'm
looking forward to Monty's upcoming stint on the Sunset boat party.

Michael Mantra followed with stuff that was too mellow for dancing and
the main room was still pounding hard, so after 5 hours of fun it was
time to head up the street to Unity.  Tony was in full gear on a massive
4 corner system, and what he was spinning was not much softer than F&F, j
a little slower perhaps and as usual I fell under his spell.  The lazers
were great, and the space was put to good use, plenty of free water,
portopotties, etc.  There were even some colorful vending booths in the
"ambient" room and lot's of people hanging out outdoors.  I
thought the vibe was pretty good, different than F&F, with a higher
percentage of people just standing around on the dance floor (a sin
in my book).  Even though I only recognized about 2% of the poeple,
I felt welcome there.

Austin:
>Tony was next and then at 3.30 they did a cerimon for Malachy: Thanking him
>for his support and explaining to the crowd about the cause.  They
>performed a Kundalini healing dance where the crowd claped the rhythm.
>This young and restles crowd was not into the cerimony much.  From were I
>was people were yelling " turn the music back on." and "No more" Very
>disapponted in the crowd at that point. It's all for a good cause so why
>not show your support for a little exercise in self healing.

My take on this is a bit different.  At first, I felt that the crowd
very much into the speeches being made, and those who weren't were at
least were polite about it.  But after the 5th "just one more thing before
we turn the music back on" people started getting  restless.  Then
Ms. Celestine Prophecy (Susan of Progress) gets up and says "I want
to try something that works really well with the kindergarden class that
I teach..."  insisting to us how "very important" it is for us to join
this energy-channeling visualization exercise....  I found her to be
extremely condescending.  There's only so much follow-the-leader
cajoling a group of ravers can be expected to embrace, and in my mind
the promoters overdid it.  How well-recieved would it have been to have
stopped the music at the *peak* of F&F and so Brian could give a 1/2 hour 
lecture on how because the Internet might someday save the world each
of us should spend more time learning about computers?

After that the dance vibe was pretty dead so I wandered and discovered
that the ambient room had some killer Jungle going on.  Yeah!
Then outside the third sound system was going off with Darkhorse doing
his funky do.   I even enjoyed the circle dancers there who were
laughing and competing in a real positive playful kind of way.
Then back to the main room where Dubtribe was kicking major ass, totally
resurrecting the vibe.  But after Dubtribe, I felt it start to dissolve
again, so it was time to return to the warm glow of F&F.  

Dave Bayer was spinning in the "ambient" room something that
I think is called gabber, or happy hardcore (help me out Crunch).  Very
fast and kind of goofy, but a lot of fun, whee!  Maybe the real problem I
have with a lot of trance is that it's so damn serious.  Near the end he
Dave switched to some nice atmospheric stuff.  In the main room, Joe Rice
was delivering a nice morning set.  I always like Joe's DJ aura of calm
intelligence, like a laid back college professor.   Because DJ's can act
as shamans who channel different kinds of energy, it's good when you
can receive it not just from the music they spin, but from their very
own souls.  When Ethan spins, I often imagine that he's on fire with
smoke and flames shooting out of his nostrils.  Tony is like a scientist
delicately poking at his instraments (though when you talk to him he's
really more like a jolly brew-enhanced Rugby player). 

Anyway, I had a great time at both parties; each offered something 
positive but different.  F&F brings together people who are already on 
the same wavelength.  Always great to shmooze with friends.  Vibewise a 
sure bet even if a bit homogeneous.  Compared to Friends and Family, 
Unity could have been called "Strangers and Acquaintances".  Hard to 
achieve lot of cohesiveness, but whatever togetherness that does happen 
at this kind of party feels very good, like a special accomplishement in 
the face adversity.

So, kudos to everyone, everywhere (no point in leaving anyone out) for
yet another fine joyous, diverse adventure in raveland.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

On Jul 29, 10:47am, KaySEE wrote:
> Subject: FnF
> Whoever said I wasn't a morning person hasn't seen me dance to gabber at
> 7 a.m.  I was an instant convert!!  Dave Bayer had an amazingly wonderful
> set early in the morning.  I know some people were a bit weary of
> hard-core in the chill room, but there were some of us who adored it!!
> It was better than an early morning jog!  I think I live by the Jess
> Fogel rule of all or nothing.  The longer I rave, the more I'm attracted
> to faster music.  Slow music doesn't get my adrenalin pumping.  Slow
> music is such a let-down for my body.  So, that gabber set was just the
> injection I needed.  The handful of us dancing knew what it was all
> about!!  That was the first time I've heard gabber, and I hope I hear it
> again!!  It reminded me of early ska and the original skin-heads dancing the
> pogo.

Well, count your blessings that you can still enjoy hard fast music with a
bunch of nice and friendly people. Having seen the gabber scene in Holland
explode to 50.000 people parties, attracting bunches of speed snorting
16-year olds, neo-nazis etc. it seems to me it is very difficult to throw
gabber parties and attract a crowd that is intelligent, relaxed and friendly.
And if one hears records from a few years ago it seems that the overall
tempo of rave music is increasing over the years, which in my opinion
is due to the larger availability of stimulants in the scene. It's pretty
tough to keep up with 180 bpm for eight hours unenhanced (although it's
been done) and the gabber scene as I know it has the biggest drug intake
of all (and the most deadly overdoses). And actually I'm surprised that
gabber is played here in SF, I've always seen the scene here more directed
to trance/psychedelic/acid kind of stuff. Maybe it's a matter of definition,
the gabber I know from Holland is usually pretty aggressive, fast, very dark
and loud, with samples like: "six million ways to die, choose one", "I take
you all to fucking hell", "motherfuck" etc. The happy hardcore spin off
was sort of introduced to counter this dark element (and probably attract
more women and less speed-freaks) but is hardly taken seriously. Gabbers
go for the ultimate extreme experience.

And my weekend, ended up around 3 am at lust for life and really enjoyed the
hard trance & acid that was played there. Met a large number of Scots, Irish
and English folks. Left around 8 o'clock in the morning, being...

The Frying Dutchman

--

	Wah, FnF was the Bomb, okay it has been said many times now... 
	But really the BOMB, you get it? 

	Vibe 9+, People 9, Space 9, Gear 9, Music... ah, music... Well, most 
	of the night was really good (Ethan's set rocked), BUT I nearly died 
	in the morning when Joe Rice (I guess) went down to some slower beats. 
	Still full of energy and without the music to spend it on, I went
	roaring around for faster beats during an hour, very frustrating!
	Thankfully a genius put some GABBER in the AMBIENT room (wow, this
	guy is courageous!) and saved the end of my night.

KaySEE wrote:
>
> The longer I rave, the more I'm attracted to faster music.  Slow music 
> doesn't get my adrenalin pumping.  Slow music is such a let-down for my 
> body.  So, that gabber set was just the injection I needed.  The handful 
> of us dancing knew what it was all about!!  

        And sounds like I'm not alone in this! Let's preserve the Real Spirit
	of Raving(tm) together! :)
<provocation>
	Hey DJs, make us move our butts! Keep the mellow stuff in da clubs!
	That's what they're made for, aren't they?
	And blast our heads with real Techno during Raves! 
	You guys are _mellow_ ...
</provocation>
	;)
	Understand me: I went to 100% hardcore parties before, it's 
	downright boring. My opinion is that the key is in a good mix of
	styles and music, but it looks like my favorite level of beats is a 
	little bit faster than the SF average. What? Do I have to move to LA?

	Apart from that, I've been impressed by the number of people; woah,
	sure I knew it was 600, but that makes quite a bunch! What a big
	family we have! 
	And thus the organisation required, which didn't make any mistake, 
	everything correctly planned and thought of, space well divided, etc.
	Overall, 9+ and thumbs up to FnF!!!

Renaud

PS: I was the guy in orange pants with a glowstick between my teeth.
PS2: Where the f*ck were you, Tony and John K?!?! Looked for you guys :(

To: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 11:55:14 -0700 (PDT)

In-Reply-To: <v02130500ae1f13db93fe@[146.225.54.19]> from "Eric P. Peterson" at Jul 26, 96 05:37:03 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Here's another poll question for y'all: who's got a recommendation for
> shoes that are comfortable for both dancing and everyday wear?  I'm looking
> for brand name and style; I bought a pair of Reeboks that seemed
> comfortable, but the more I wear 'em, the more they hurt the top of my left
> foot on the right side, where the laces are pushing the tongue against the
> foot.  Also interested in shoes with good arch support, as I have inverted
> arches (you should see my footprints!).  Thanks!  - E

I swear by Doc Martens Air Weir shoes. I particularly like the
soft-sole greasy leather style. They come in a variety of heights -- I
have one pair of mid-top boots, and one pair of loafers. They are the
most comfortable shoes that I have worn that don't look like
sneakers. Dal Jeets and Villians (both on Upper Haight) have a wide
selection of Doc's in stock. You may want to get some arch support
inserts, if you need extra support.

For a more casual look, try Nike Air Horizon hiking boots. They have
very good arch support as well, and they are very lightweight.

Finally, if you are interested, I can refer you to a Massage Therapist
friend who specializes in footbone work. She is very good in restoring
fallen arches. 

Happy Feet,
E. Nygma

anyone who got an iron-on from me at FnF got the "limited edition
manufacturing defect" issue, where i was tired the night i made them and
printed them all up _backwards_! (doh!)  [what do you mean backwards? it's
on your back! it's supposed to be backwards! ;)  ]

anyway, i'll be printing up more (the correct way this time) and bringing
them out to raves with me. so, if you want one just find me some time.

ok. directions re-post.
     -----
-ironing surface: smooth, hard, non-porous surface that can withstand heat.-
-fold a pillowcase in half and put it on the surface.
-put the tshirt on top of the pillowcase.
*note: the tshirt should be rinkle-free and the surface shouldn't have chips
or grooves in it for best results (obviously)
-crank the iron up as hot as it can go and let it sit for a few minutes to
heat up to maximim temperature.
-flip an edge of the transfer up (so you can get a handhold to peel it up
after you apply it.
-make 2 10 second passes with the iron over the transfer
-make 10 or so circle motions with the iron
-don't burn your shirt
-peel the transfer off while it is still hot. if it doesn't come off, heat
it up again and peel it off. don't force it!
-wash in cold water
-remove immediately after wash is done (i don't know why, it just says this
in the directions.
-dry in dryer, etc.

*note: there is a very small possiblity that the ink from my printer does
not set properly (although my initial tests have shown it does). if you are
of the extra-cautious type, first wash the shirt, by itself, in cold water
with no detergent and a cupfull of vinigar thrown in. however, the ink does
seem to work properly. i'll know more by FnF, doubtless.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 12:40:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA00496; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 12:40:41 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA00487; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 12:40:38 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu
	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA199199233; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 12:40:33 -0700
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 12:40:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Okay, my F&F experience...
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9607291217.A16456-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


It was, of course, an incredible rave!!  I spent most of the night 
sitting and chatting with friends because this time I didn't have the 
energy or coordination to dance hard, as sometimes happens. But I still 
wouldn't change a thing... 

The night went perfectly:  It was actually almost *warm* outside - a 
pleasant surprise for the Bay Area.  We were even blessed with a few 
sprinkles (I thought I was getting spittled on by the person I was 
talking to til I realized it was raindrops!;)

The highlight came in the morning.  This is what happned for those of you 
who couldn't make it or who left early.  I was sitting outside and they 
opened up the big door from the main dance floor.  Most everyone who was 
dancing inside came outside and it must have been timed perfectly, 
because Mother Nature smiled down us with a perfect bright rainbow.  It 
seriously felt like a message from Mother, and we all cheered at Her gift.

Then Joe put on "Belfast" and I looked through the door into the main 
room and noticed everyone forming the circle.  I rushed in and joined in, 
my closest friends by my side as the circle grew and grew.  Then we all 
rushed into the center and clapped and cheered and danced like crazy.  It 
was so beautiful - everyone was hugging everyone, laughing and grinning 
like mad.  One man was so moved he was crying with a huge grin on his 
face.  I immediately gave him a big hug. We were all so in tune with each 
other, on the same plane.  I am still amazed at the power of the human 
spirit. 

Then at toward the end of the song, everyone closed in on the biggest 
group hug I have ever experienced.  I swear every person was there, 
giving his and her energy - it was so powerful.  Nothing embodied the 
words "Friends and Family" more.  The song ended and we were so stunned 
and elated....cheers and cries of joy erupted and filled the room. 

My thanks to each and every person who gave to this party.  Not only to 
those putting it on, but also those who simply contributed to the good 
vibe.  Which, dang it, would mean *everybody!* Raves like this DEFINATELY 
make my Mondays easier. ;)

love,
Amy

It sounds like some people are interested, so here's the
comments I posted to Ausrave last month. (Plus some
extra comments in [brackets]).

Jeremy

----- Begin Included Message -----

From jeremyl Wed Jun 12 17:18:52 1996
To: ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
Subject: Mayday

Hi All

I'm back very temporarily before a few weeks in NZ before another
few days in Sydney (I _might_ be here for the weekend of 6-7 July)
before finally heading off to California.

A few days after Mayday (Dortmund, Germany 30/4/96) [i.e. 4/30/96 :]
i seem to have scribbled this in my notebook :)

================================================================
Scattered Thoughts on Mayday

* Big

The main hall was like the Sydney Entertainment Centre only
bigger. The main dance floor was a the size of a mostly-dismantled
velodrome. There were maybe 15000  people dancing and hanging
around in the upper tiers of seats. [Also thousands were in two
other large rooms and outside. 26000 tickets were sold.]

* Small

The organisers looked after the little things, like having
the loos cleaned occasionally duruing the night.

* Fun

Going off in a crowd of 15000 mad rave heads.

* Not So Fun

Losing your rave buddy in a crowd of 15000 mad rave heads. :)

* Loud

My ears were sore. I was wearing earplugs. Erk.

* Quiet

Eh?

* Expensive

Ticket sales would have been well over 2M Deutschmarks, but it
was all out there in the production. Awesome!

Drinks started at 3.50. Uk.

* Cheap

Camel cigarettes handing out free samples early in the night.

* Capitalism

Camel cigarettes handing out free samples early in the night,
and selling them later on. They sponsored the jungley room, 
decorated complete with a few Camel pyramids. Get them
kiddies hooked.

The third room (house/dub/trip-hop) was sponsored by a company
pushing guarana ice-cream. Mmmmmm, rave food. :)

* Socialism

Hahaha! ROFL. Are you kidding. :)

* Hot

The whole thing.

* Cold

Huge walls of clear blocks of ice with ice creams frozen in the
middle. Kept the trippers amused all night. :)

* Friendly

Lots of smiling people.

Chatted with a guy at the ice-cream company's video games stand
for ages. The ice-cream co is sponsoring a DJ and techno act
booking service in Germany. (Whether this is a good thing is
open to debate.)

* Unfriendly

There was a sign at the entrance explaining the curfew laws
for under 18s. It looks like the cops were allowed to arrest
anyone under 18 who was there past midnight (8pm for under-14s).
They didn't seem to try it though.

* Musical

Lots of variety in main room from the start (6pm) until very late.
Some hard trance, hard acid, hard house, interesting Goa and not
very vocal mainstream techno. All really cool, with some interesting
leading-edge stuff being played to 15000 people. There was lots of
nice funky trip-hop in the third room.

* Unmusical

After about 4am, all three rooms degenerated into mindless-thudding-
to-keep-the-speeders-going.

* Energetic

The main room. It was impossible not to get caught up in the vibe.

* Tired

Me after dancing for 9 hours straight. :)

* Hi Tech

The main room had absolutely the best lights & lasers i have ever seen:
new things were happening all night. Rigs that were fixed for hours on end
suddenly started moving. There was great coordination between the lights
and lasers: the colours on the multi-coloured lasers and intelligent lights
were matched perfectly. There was excellent video as well.

* Low Tech

Zip. This rave was the antithesis of do-it-yourself. Was this a Bad
Thing? Dunno: i've had as good a time on a fraction of the cost,
but i'd go to another Mayday if i got the chance.
================================================================

Other than that, i had a really fun weekend clubbing and chilling
in London later in June.

Seeya

Jeremy


----- End Included Message -----

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 13:03:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA02785; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 13:03:08 -0700
Received: from ucscb.UCSC.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA02778; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 13:03:04 -0700
Received: by ucscb.UCSC.EDU (5.65/1.34)
	id AA14114; Mon, 29 Jul 96 12:58:01 -0700
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9607291958.AA14114@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: F&F/Unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 12:57:59 -0700 (MDT)
In-Reply-To: <9607291754.AA22300@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at Jul 29, 96 10:54:08 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3576      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My adventure at Unity had a lot of different componants, but I guess
that makes sense because with all the different people, promotors, and
ideology involved, the party was bound to a bit schizophrenic.
but with a general theme of unifying all those different energies, it turned
out to be an extremely enlightening and healthy night for me.

The setup was incredible.  an awesome laser/light show, a huge sound
system, that was often too loud for its own good, but still a lot of fun.
There was also a mellower room and an outside sound system, which were
also both very nice getaways from the main room.
The beginning and whole first half of the party was really satisfying
and had me sailing a very strong force as all these people were working
together and trying to make peace with each other.  In fact, I would say
that there were moments in there stronger than any other rave I've 
ever experienced.  But these moments, as strong as they were, soon began to 
go out of balance and then the energy clashed with itself as much
as it had resonated momentarily before.  It was right about this time that
the music stopped and they made some speeches.

> My take on this is a bit different.  At first, I felt that the crowd
> very much into the speeches being made, and those who weren't were at
> least were polite about it.  But after the 5th "just one more thing before
> we turn the music back on" people started getting  restless.  Then
> Ms. Celestine Prophecy (Susan of Progress) gets up and says "I want
> to try something that works really well with the kindergarden class that
> I teach..."  insisting to us how "very important" it is for us to join
> this energy-channeling visualization exercise....  I found her to be
> extremely condescending.  There's only so much follow-the-leader
> cajoling a group of ravers can be expected to embrace, and in my mind
> the promoters overdid it.  How well-recieved would it have been to have
> stopped the music at the *peak* of F&F and so Brian could give a 1/2 hour 
> lecture on how because the Internet might someday save the world each
> of us should spend more time learning about computers?
> 
I agree with Lee... I had a problem with Susan.  The urgency of her request
and the implication that some of us might be living life wrong seems to
contradict another idea which is that we're all in this together,
each playing our own part in a unified world that fits together perfectly.
If some pieces are wrong, and others right, well then energies clash
and stop flowing.  And this is what I feel started happening to the party.
As soon as a leader emerged, or a right/wrong relationship, it was a
large circle dance.  So a lot of people stopped dancing... a lot of people
started leaving.  I think that if the different promotors had individual
messages they wanted to share, they should have waited until the end.
Not forcing their individual ego into the group until the group had established
its own ego.

But, as this was a first try at unifying a very diverse group of promotor/party
egos and people, we can't expect achieving the balance to be easy.
After this Dubtribe did a very nice job at bringing things back into focus,
although nowhere close to the strength earlier on in the evening.

All in all, it was really good for me.  The strength and inspiration I
got from those early moments was unlike anything I've felt in a long time.
Now I just need to work on my balance, to sustain that level of energy.

anyway... my best wishes to all of you in having a spectacular day.

-john.
http://he.net/~swoosh

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 13:12:38 1996

Subject: FnF finally--wow!!!
ReSent-Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 13:12:27 -0700 (PDT)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

OK, finally good reason to cease lurking and speak up...

I've been hearing about the FnF parties since I met Wayne in March, and
_now_ I finally see what all the fuss is about!!  That was the best party
I've EVER been to, made even more meaningful for me because I was lucky
enough to help!!!

I've never ever had the experience of walking around a party and looking at
decorations my friends and I painted. Participating in the party from setup
to teardown made an amazing party even sweeter--I am sooooo proud to be
part of such an incredible group of people!! (And you'll surely find me
helping out elsewhere, now that I know how it makes everything more
special.)

It was particularly exciting when the police came, and Wayne and I got to
pose as a newly married couple at our wedding reception (good practice for
next April!). As the two very nice policeman walked into the party, Vince
arrived on stilts, and when they asked him what he was doing here, he said
he was the best man at the wedding. I think the officer was really
surprised when Ethan led him over to talk to Wayne and I, and we told him
how happy we were to be married (absolutely the truth--we might as well be
already!), and asked him if he'd seen our best man arriving on stilts!!
The two officers walked through the party, and on their way out, said to
Ehtan "Let's get one thing straight--this isn't a wedding reception, this
is a full-on rave. We weren't born yesterday..." But they left us to party
in peace...

It was really magical in the morning when EVERYONE came in to dance
together at the end of Joe Rice's set. Joe came out from behind the
turntables to dance with the crowd, everyone spontaneously joined hands in
a circle and danced together, and then rushed to the center of the room to
surround Ethan and Greg and everyone with a giant thank-you hug.

At very the end of the party, we found Phelps Feely outside, our new friend
from Freedom who managed to find Wayne in a crowd of 4000, and just had to
spend another 1/2 hour piled up on the sofa with her and Brian Darkness
before starting to sweep up rave drek and coil extension cords.

The last wonderful surprise of the day was waking up after a _long_ nap to
find Timmy (Knucklehead) and Tom Leichardt in our kitchen, freshly returned
from Sunset. We sent them home with a quesadilla and a hug...

We are soooooooooooo lucky to live in a city with such incredible things
happening. As Tony Rotundo would say... "Appreciate this!!!"

I'm still glowing...  See y'all at Chrysalis!!

Love,
   Marcy

 Marcy Swenson                                                415.695.9471

On Mon, 29 Jul 1996, michal migurski wrote:
> Are there going to be FnF pix posted on the FnF homepage? I got some choice
> (??? =P) photos of myself snapped and I'm interested to see pictures of
> everyone at the party when I'm sober and un-spun.
> 

All of the pics so far have been taken with my digital camera, but I only 
got 20-30 pics this time, cause I kept forgetting to take them, and was 
busy running around.  I'll put those up, if anyone has pictures they can 
scan and then let me ftp (or ftp them to me) I'll prepare them so Ethan 
can put them up.  I may also have time to scan some if you can't access a 
scanner, so if you need that tell me, we'll find someone to do it.

So if you got pictures and you want to share, email me and I'll help to 
get them together, this goes for past events too!

love scott

Marcy wrote:
 
> I've been hearing about the FnF parties since I met Wayne in March, and
> _now_ I finally see what all the fuss is about!!  That was the best party
> I've EVER been to, made even more meaningful for me because I was lucky
> enough to help!!!
> I've never ever had the experience of walking around a party and looking at
> decorations my friends and I painted. Participating in the party from setup
> to teardown made an amazing party even sweeter--I am sooooo proud to be
> part of such an incredible group of people!! (And you'll surely find me
> helping out elsewhere, now that I know how it makes everything more
> special.)

Right on!  I was in a similar situation; thanks to the kindness of one
individual =) I was lucky enough to help set up and stay for my first F&F...
it was really amazing...and I have to say that one of my favorite parts
really was helping set up in the afternoon...I'm really shy about meeting
people and it was so great to talk to such kind, warm folks (like you Marcy
:^) )...it really started the day/night off right.  What was also sooo cool
was being in this HUGE empty space bare as a newborn baby (the space not me
;) ) and being told, "this is the AMBIENT room..." Whooohoooo! :) :) :)
Later seeing the bare room dressed alladayglow with smileys, rockets, shroom
tapestries, rudolph the naughty bear books, etc...and seeing everyone glide
in with big grins, checking out the space and each other...


> It was particularly exciting when the police came, and Wayne and I got to
> pose as a newly married couple at our wedding reception (good practice for
> next April!). As the two very nice policeman walked into the party, Vince
> arrived on stilts, and when they asked him what he was doing here, he said
> he was the best man at the wedding. I think the officer was really
> surprised when Ethan led him over to talk to Wayne and I, and we told him
> how happy we were to be married (absolutely the truth--we might as well be
> already!), and asked him if he'd seen our best man arriving on stilts!!
> The two officers walked through the party, and on their way out, said to
> Ehtan "Let's get one thing straight--this isn't a wedding reception, this
> is a full-on rave. We weren't born yesterday..." But they left us to party
> in peace...

So that's what happened!  I thought they were looking to be paid off :o)
I heard them insisting, "It's more than 500 people...that makes it a RAVE,
not a party..."  I was kinda worried there for a while.  So glad they were
"nice cops"!
My thanks again, to everyone who made this party possible (which would
be... everyone! %^) )
And it was really cool to meet you, Marcy, and Wayne.  Hope to see all of 
y'all again sometime soon!

hugs,
shamini

Subject: The Journey -> (Feel the Vibe) F&F
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


As I was enveloped into the glowing, pulsating organism.. I thought,
"tonight is the night dreams are realized."  To quote _Eat Static_, this
organism had "Psychokinetic energy..... waves of energy that excite the
mind."  The music-makers were our shamans... leading us through sound...
leading us through to the beyond.  Throughout the night, this organism
churned, writhed, loved, laughed, cried, explored, voyaged, and finally
returned to this beautiful earth.  The mother welcomed us with her most
beautiful display of color, the rainbow.

Amazingly, karma came through, and beautiful people Stephanie and Jordan who
we saw in Berkeley on Sat, provided us with tickets (big HUGE thanks!).  As
we arrived, I was completely amazed at the time and energy our Family put
into the space to make it our communal home for the night.  I simply LOVED
the altars!  The communal living room like chill area was the BEST!  It was
a great place to meet new people and was suuuuuper comfy ;)   I wish more
parties would have areas like this.

The music in the main area went off nicely.  Visuals, lasers and lighting
were well done.  I didn't dance too much in the main room (too busy
spreading VIBE), but had a few good rushes.  The music in the ambient area
was well suited to the flow of energy in the crowd..  Morning Gabber??
hehe... I saw people rushing to it, but is this necessary? =)  It sure woke
people up!

The people there were sooo filled with PLUR and VIBE!  Everybody I saw had a
huge smile... everybody I met had hugs and warmth to share.  BIG HUGE HUGS
to Stephanie, Jordan, Adam, Terry, Randy, Branka, Tony, Matt, Rebecca,
Kirsten, Amy, Rachel... EVERYBODY!!  I wish I could have met each and every
person there!  If you saw a person with a *XTC* t-shirt, and a red bike
light running around giving hugs, that was me. =)

Alright.. this post is long enough, so I'll end with this:

"How many of you people know you're alive.... how many of you people REALLY
know you're alive?!"

I fell SO DAMN good! =) =)

Floating on da VIBE,
Aaron.

I headed out on Sunday for Sunset, and had a great time...  I just love
Sunset parties.. I have been going to them for quite a while, but missed
them when I went to Boulder.  It's just a great way to spend a tired Sunday
with friends.

But, there was someone there who thought it might be funny or amusing to set
off a *large* firecraker over the beach.  Now, to me this is unacceptable
(especially in light of recent events). It scared quite a few people and if
there had been cops anywhere near, they would have shut down the party super
fast.   I seriously doubt it would have been anybody on SFRaves though.
People should save that stuff up for Burning Man, where it will be more
appreciated.

Aaron.

Rocky wrote:
> 	from what i heard, slick willie is having this closed
> 	forever and torn town.  apparently, it just doesn't
> 	appeal to his aesthetic senses.  what a s.o.b.

According to CalTrans, the ramp was damaged in the '89 quake, and will
collapse when the next big one strikes. The reason Willie is speeding
up the tear-down is to force CalTrans to come up with a permanent
solution, rather than the band-aid fix they were originally
proposing. [This was reported in the Chronicle months ago.] I don't
like Willie's tactics, given that the result is going to be a major
traffic mess, but I don't blame his attitude, either, given how long
it took them to fix the I-280 and 101 interchange. 

The media also reported that Willie wants a tunnel to replace the
viaduct. Good luck trying to tunnel underneath the Muni Metro on
Market St. The Fell St. offramp will be reopened after they finish
tearing down the Oak St. onramp, at least.

Just imagine 90,000 cars detouring over alternate routes that can
handle two-thirds that much traffic, at most.

> On Sat, 27 Jul 1996, TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG wrote:
> > Also, don't forget that, after August 1st, the Fell Street exit of 101 
> > will be closed for three month's (a total bummer as I live on Fell) for 
> > reconstruction work.  I think that other exits are going to be closed as 
> > well.  Check it out by ringing up SF City Hall and ask for the road and 
> > traffic department for more details.

The Chronicle reported two Sundays ago that the work wasn't starting
until the end of August. Where did you hear the 8/1 date?

Fortunately, I just moved out of my apartment on Fell St. to my
fiancee's place in the Oakland Hills -- really good timing, on my
part. :) I'll miss SF, and all the funkiness of Haight, though.

E. N.

Saturday night was really special, as it was my first indoor FnF event...
and now I see what such personal dedication on the part of our wonderful
community can do.

Thanks to Sunny (who not only gave us 2 more tix, but included a care
package with a Solle Sanfrandisco t-shirt, a DJ Dan tape and life savers
too!) and Paul A (who always comes through for me!), I was able to bring
along four favorite friends.

The location was great, spacious, well laid out, supercomfortable with lots
of couches and carpet in the chill space, plenty of space in the dance
room, and a wonderful outdoor area for hangin' out under the  beautiful
night skies.  Altars everywhere, great hand-made-with-love banners and
posters, free water and fruit, couldn't ask for more.

The only part for me that was missing was that some of my favorite people
were putting on Theta across the bay, and my good intentions of making that
trip in the wee hours were nixed by my better judgment and fear of flashing
blue lights ... so I stayed at FnF in body and sent my spirit to the Acme
for a while (where I heard it was rocking!)

Then the rainbow in the morning ... and my night was complete .. Thanks
everyone for each little piece of vibe you brought to the party, it was so
cool to see so many SFRavers in one place at one time -- I mean, we even
had Vince on his stilts! --  and thanks Mike M for making such a rad
t-shirt!

Love,

Leslie

>Rocky wrote:
> 	from what i heard, slick willie is having this closed
> 	forever and torn town.  apparently, it just doesn't
> 	appeal to his aesthetic senses.  what a s.o.b.
>
For the facts, check out:

http://www.sfgate.com/wais/search/chron-pro.html

and search on central freeway

You might have to register first.

Here is what I found:

The Central Freeway was damaged by the Loma Prieta earthquake of
October 1989. The section extending up Franklin and Gough streets was
closed after the quake and torn down in 1991.

The remaining double-deck section was reinforced and kept open, while
slated for eventual demolition.

The city and the state could not agree on action until Mayor Willie
Brown took office and struck a deal with Caltrans to finally start
work. Originally, Brown wanted both decks taken down at once, but
changed his mind in negotiations with the state. The state wants the
upper deck taken down and the lower level temporarily reopened while
agreement is reached on a permanent replacement.

Some neighbors are concerned about what deal Brown and Caltrans will
make for an eventual replacement. Some favor no freeway at all, others
want it put fully or partially underground and others like a
single-deck surface roadway.

Caltrans is studying a few options sent to it by the city.

(copyright San Francisco Chronicle)

Jim Ausman
-------------
"Be reverant towards life." -Albert Schweitzer

Matthew Gedigian wrote:

>Also, by buying Nike shoes you are supporting the practice of spending
>megamillions on advertising and passing the cost along the consumer.  

Yes! I bet they could charge people half of what they do, pay their
sweat-shop-indentured servants double, spend  of what they do on
advertising, and still cut themselves a huge cheque every quarter.  But that
would probably require cutting those exorbitant executive salaries, a key
point that will never happen. They won't just shift more of the profits down
the ladder, they wuldn't be swindleing so much money, then!  
They also charge so much that only the upper middle-upper classes (and I
generalize heavily here, there's always an exception to the rule out there),
which is comprised mostly of them and the other execs on outrageous salaries
WE pay, can afford them without paying more than their wages can _really_
support.  They keep the middle class on credit, so they are slaves to the
system, paranoid that it could all come crashing down at any moment (which it
could). They use advertising to make people want to buy all these things that
are too expensive, in the name of being an eliteist (I.e. with more material
goods or a cooler look than the next Jane), and _everyone_ (again
generalizing) sees and believes it.  This makes the lower classes, who can't
afford it _hate_ the upper classes, which causes crime. And hatred goes both
ways, because the upper and middle classes knows the have-nots are willing to
take their money/goods by force.  Of course, the upper class is hit less
often because they can afford all the insurance, alarm systems and security,
and they know it.  
So it really comes down to classism. It's the upper class using the rift
between the lower class and the middle class, which _they_ have
created/maintain, and can more readily protect themselves from, to make their
profits.  Does that seem correct?

>It's always best to avoid companies that advertise too much, isn't it?

All too true!  And most advertising is nothing short of brainwashing!  I'm
sure you all know this!  Many ads, especially on TV, have a quality that
makes you feel inferior if you don't buy their product.  They offer
unrealistic images of how cool folx that wear nikes are, and imply that you
_aren't_ if you don't wear nikes.  I think all these images on TV and in
magazines (Cosmo, Teenwhatever, etc.) add to people being divided.  It makes
those feelings of : "if you ain't the way  _we_  think you should be, then
you are wrong, and therefore inferior", jump off the TV and in to real
peoples psyches, who then apply it to everyday life.  I think this feeling is
older than TV, but that TV and commercialism since the 50's has been a
_major_ factor that has been keeping  it alive, mostly because it motivates
people to buy.  The societal impact is almost a side effect, though a major
one.  Just my $2.00 :) worth! 

Peacefully though angstfully,

-Justin Wilson

P.S. : Thank you everyone for checkin' out this discussion, if anyone is ;) !
 I find myself using it to define some stuff for myself.
