I hate to drag this thread up again, but I was away all weekend.  I have
just a few things to say...

1 - Yes, Win95 reportedly scans your local drive for other MS software,
	and tries to determine whether it is legally registered.
2 - Cookie files can be used as a subliminal channel for getting this
	information back to MS.  This would be the elegant way of doing
	it.  More likely, the MS Explorer software would just connect with
	the MS site and send the info directly.
3 - Regarding Java: I wouldn't trust foreign code on my machine.  There
	are still big security holes, and more being discovered all the
	time.
4 - Having just come from DefCon, I have to say: nothing is 100% secure.

  My solution, by the way: don't run microsoft software.  Letter writing
campaings against a software company this size will get you nowhere so
long as you're paying for their products.  I personally don't use software
unless I can read the source code.  This is the only way to know for sure
whether or not rumours like the one above are true.

: : J. David Lowe ::: dlowe@best.com ::: ai334@freenet.carleton.ca : :
:: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ ::::: ftp://ftp.best.com/web1/dlowe/ ::
 : : : : : : : : : finger for pgp key and geek code : : : : : : : : :

Precedence: bulk

The space was breathtaking, otherworldly: colorful decorations throughout,
beautiful altars, a big, vibrant butterfly near the doorway to the dance
floor (I LOVE butterflies!).  Comfortable cushions, couches, etc.
Concertlike lighting in the dance area, and convenient cubby holes :)
The music, from first beat to last, was brilliant!  I heard only one moment
of unmatched beats, but it didn't faze us dancers.  I found myself making
several trips to the dance floor, and even danced to what Matt Lanier
called the "sharp, pointy" music!  This was the first time I found the
dancing trance; maybe the combination of the right music and the right vibe
encouraged it.  I was, well, somewhere I've never been to before, and it
was exciting yet relaxing, a feeling of being remotely attached to, and
remotely aware of, my dancing body.
The dance area was hot, but not oppressive, and the free water was a
godsend (or whatever ;)).  I enjoyed pouring water for a few thirsty ravers
:)
I think I spent most of my time outside, and shared some deep and
meaningful moments with beautiful souls there.  I also shared quite a lot
with a few people on the dance floor (although I feel hesitant to bother
people while they're dancing), and in the chill area.  I think I sat with
Robert for a while, can't recall what we were watching, just remember
sitting together on the floor, feeling more like one big ball of love and
positive energy than two separate beings.  There was another guy on the
dance floor, who wore a black miniskirt (who was he?  We didn't even
exchange names), and for no known reason we locked our fingers together,
stared into each other's eyes, and I felt a powerful but soothing exchange
of warmth and energy.  I deeply cherish the metaphysical experiences I have
while at parties!
Observation: It appears to me, from all the parties I've been to (two years
this September), that males are more likely to engage in these deep,
meaningful, ultra-personal exchanges with me than females are, and I don't
think my approach to either is different.  In such an environment, I
consider myself a being of light and love, not a male, female, straight,
gay, bisexual, republican, democrat, American, Welshman, etc.  I told
someone I talked with that it's all about peace, love, unity, and respect,
and he agreed, even though he wasn't on this list :)
There was this gal, with short, curly red hair, who had dropped, and it
much harder than she expected, but was still loving it.  She was so happy,
and she'd be running around and playing like a care-free child.  It was
wonderful to watch!  I sat with her outside for a bit, making sure she was
OK, and we explored the party a little, then she reminded me that I was
free to roam as I pleased, so I did.
Mattloaf gives AMAZING hugs, people!  And he's got a beautiful heart.  Meet
this guy!
I kept saying "Everyone's here!"  That was almost true.  The picture would
have been closer to complete if we had Jess Fogler, Marty, and John
Kawamoto there, to name a few.  I was overjoyed that so many of the people
who interduced me to raving (the old "Jeremy's garage crew," now disbanded
but a strong presence in the scene; anyone ever hear of Greg Sandler?).  I
also said, to almost everyone I talked to, "Don't take this the wrong way,
but I love you."  As if there's a wrong way to take that!  I think people
appreciated it and were amused by it at the same time :)
Nancy barely spoke to me, and always seemed to be on a mission, without the
time to stop and chat.  Diana Greer spent a few moments with me, here and
there, but all too few and too brief, and she left without saying good-bye.
Those were the closest things to low points of the entire party.
Pouring out from the dance floor into the morning light with the music, and
seeing the rainbow, helped lessen that feeling of "Oh, no!  It's morning
already!"  The fruit and muffins were delicious, and so was everyone there.
The hand-holding circle at the end that became a huge mass of flesh as we
all pressed together was the first such experience for me in about a year;
I'm so glad it continues!  The last dance was uplifting, and the conclusion
was the perfect way to end a 9.9 on a 10-scale experience.  WE created and
shared something magical, something deeper than we sometimes realize, while
strengthening the ties that bind us together in heart, mind, body, and
soul.  It is so nice indeed to have the family together!
Huge thanks to everyone who worked on this party, and to everyone who
attended.  Extra special thanks to Jay Wiley for the ride, and for being
such a cool and nice person :)

Now, don't take this the wrong way... ;)

Eric

be of integrity, not just the cheapest, which is probably how they decide.

trade agreements with the countries where the contracts lie (central America)
involving free trade zones and such.  To be honest, that is another area I
must study up on.  But what I gather is that they are areas with different
laws on trade and manufacturing, basicly removing tarriffs and abolishing
labor and environmental laws which makes the areas able to produce _cheaper_
, which is always the goal of the greedy.  Besides, if they now have lower
manufacture costs (even for the wrong reasons), we should at _least_ see a
drop in prices to the consumer.  But usually all we see is a jump in _their_
profits and executive salaries.  I didn't think I would ever think this, but
it looks like a planned system to keep the status quo at best, or make the
exploitation worse, more likely.
Gee, anyone up to revolution yet?  We should do something... Any suggestions
short of living my life as correctly as I can (guilty of NOT, but I try...)?
 I believe the current political system here keeps people frome having a true
voice.  But I still vote!

such a cliche term!  But whatever...), or do they kill  "the little peoples"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jul 29 18:49:53 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA04185; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 18:49:53 -0700
Received: from dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA04177; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 18:49:49 -0700
Received: from  (shawna-@wck-ca8-13.ix.netcom.com [204.31.231.77]) by dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id SAA08642; Mon, 29 Jul 1996 18:49:05 -0700
Date: Mon, 29 Jul 1996 18:49:05 -0700
Message-Id: <199607300149.SAA08642@dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: FnF review (long) (was Re: FnF finally--wow!!!)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I've never ever had the experience of walking around a party and looking at
>decorations my friends and I painted. Participating in the party from setup
>to teardown made an amazing party even sweeter--I am sooooo proud to be
>part of such an incredible group of people!! (And you'll surely find me
>helping out elsewhere, now that I know how it makes everything more
>special.)


Amen to that sister! :):)  It really was an incredible experience, being able 
to help set up during the day, this too was my first time doing that.  I've 
always been used to just attending parties, showing up 11-12 pm with BOOM! 
rave in your face, going full blast, and just jumping right into it.  This 
has always been immense fun of course.  This time it was very different to 
see the warehouse during the day and observe the slow transformation from 
empty warehouse to beautiful rave-site, and actually almost made it more 
difficult to make my own transition from running around trying to get stuff 
set up to allowing myself to go into party-goer mode, but it makes it all the 
more meaningful.  And it really was something special, and makes me proud, 
that I was able to contribute (in whatever small way) to something that went 
off that great! :)  I hope to do that again sometime.  (and did anybody get a 
chance to try the plums from the juice bar, we had fresh picked them that same 
day from the orchards! :)

And as a party itself, FnF rocked!! :)  It really was an amazing group of 
people gathered there that night.  Everybody I talked to had a *great* time.  
And the ending really just blew me away.  I was just sitting outside with 
friends staring at the beautiful clouds above listening to the music, when I 
just spontaneously decided I had to dance, so I ran inside to join the others 
in the dance area where Joe was spinning an absolutely delicious morning set 
(perfect set Joe, thanks! :).  It felt so great in spite of how tired I was at 
that point, the music just flowed thru me as perfectly as it could have. And I 
realize that as I'm dancing, everybody else is trickling thru the big opened 
roll-up door to join in the dance, and pretty soon all of us who were still 
there were dancing, and before I knew it everybody had joined hands & formed a 
big circle together, and then the circle broke apart and still dancing, 
everybody rushed to the middle of the room for one of the most intense 
enormous group hugs I've experienced! :)  Then, laughing & cheering, Ethan & 
everybody spontaneously break into a big ol' happy birthday song for Joe Rice, 
which of course seemed the perfect way to end the party.  (happy 24th you old 
fart! did reagan give you that spanking she was talking about? ;)   The space 
was just about perfect, seems like hardly anybody has an ambient room anymore 
at their parties, I really miss them!  So yeah, it had the main room, the 
ultra-comfy ambient room, and a great outdoor area which was AWESOME with the 
absolutely beautiful night.  And I am somehow absolutely astounded at the fact 
that a rainbow came out to greet us in the early morning!  Driving home later 
that morning I just couldn't get over how perfectly everything came together, 
culminating with the rainbow overhead and the enormous circle & group hug 
below.  Two full circles, above & below, (look out, spiritual symbolism! ;) 
everytime I go to a really spectacular party it reminds me of how we all 
somehow go thru these amazing journeys together, and at the end come full 
circle back home again, both literally and figuratively, all together with 
huge smiles on our faces.  What fun! :)

Boy, reading back on my post, my words really don't do much justice to the 
experience.  But it really was spectacular.  And I think I should say here, to 
all of you who went, what you all experienced at that party is the very reason 
these people throw these parties, it's why the superstar dj's ;) are out there 
sweeping & cleaning up with everybody else afterwards, it's why they only 
charge $5 a person, it's why all the proceeds benefit other people.  It's true 
that people have called me a rave-snob before, and I've always objected to 
that, but now I will openly admit that's true actually.  When I compare 
parties like the one I attended Saturday night, and see the effort that was 
put in when no profit at all is being made simply to give something beautiful 
to the scene *and* benefit other groups that deserve it, and compare it to $25 
parties with no effort or caring put in at all to any sort of comfort or 
beauty, or respect for the party-goers, where they cram 1000 people into a 
space that comfortably holds a max of 600-700 people, where half the promised 
big-name dj's don't show up (and no, I am not pointing fingers at any 
particular parties, so dont get your panties in a bunch! ;), I can't help but 
get just a *leetle* more selective about what parties I go to & what groups I 
support.  Yeah, that makes me pick some parties & choose to not attend other 
parties (or yeah, bitch when I find myself stuck at a party I probably 
shouldn't have attended), but it really does come down to quality I guess.  Of 
course I won't buy a pair of shoes I think are overexpensive pieces of shit 
(imho of course, other people may favor them), and I will buy ones I think are 
of good value and great quality.  That, and (this may earn me a flame or two, 
eh?) for me raving really does cross over into the realms of morals and ways 
to live life, and parties like saturday's are thrown by people whose ideas & 
ideals seem to jive way more with my own than a lot of other parties.  So call 
me a rave-snob!  Dammit, I'm proud to stick to my ideals! ;)

Alright, enough blithering.  Y'alls get the point! :)

Love,
Shawna

<<1 - Yes, Win95 reportedly scans your local drive for other MS software,
	and tries to determine whether it is legally registered.>>

Others said they removed this feature in their latest release.  If so, how
would I tell if mine is old or new? System properties says:   

SYSTEM:  
Microsoft Windows 95  
4.00.950

<<2 - Cookie files can be used as a subliminal channel for getting this
	information back to MS.  This would be the elegant way of doing
	it.  More likely, the MS Explorer software would just connect with
	the MS site and send the info directly.>>

Ok.  This cookie thing... It is written to my hard drive by any web site I
access (presumably the cache of AOL) and when I re-connect to the site, what
happens?  Thankfully I know enough to not use MSNet!

<<3 - Regarding Java: I wouldn't trust foreign code on my machine.  There
	are still big security holes, and more being discovered all the
	time.>>

Java a foreign code?  Must be a MAC thing, right?  Code for what?  And what
do you mean by security holes?

<<4 - Having just come from DefCon, I have to say: nothing is 100% secure.>>

DefCon... please explain...again! {Boy, you should charge me for all
this...:) }

<<  My solution, by the way: don't run microsoft software.  Letter writing
campaings against a software company this size will get you nowhere so
long as you're paying for their products.  >>

Of course, they do the best/only(that I've used) op. systems...And it sux,
but no letter  will get you anywhere.

<< I personally don't use software
unless I can read the source code.  This is the only way to know for sure
whether or not rumours like the one above are true.>>

What code is that?  Thanx SO much!!!


-Justin Wilson

     And now for an extended sermon...
     
     What moral code anywhere states that beating somebody like that is 
     cool?  I had lotsa friends that rumbled occasionally back in LA, and I 
     personally once got thumped on three to one, but I can't make sense of 
     this crap (and my doctor never did get my ribcage just right again).
     
     We've spent a lot of time talking about what raves to bring people to 
     for their first time, and hearing something like this makes me think 
     it might not be the rave that's not working out.  If you know people 
     who you think are capable of crap like this, keep them the fuck away 
     from me, because frankly, they don't make sense.  I want to live a 
     life that is MORE open, LESS afraid and more involved in the lives of 
     those around me.
     
     I honestly don't care how good the music was if somebody got 
     hopitalized at Unity.  It's not the promoters fault, I'm sure nobody 
     wanted it to happen but it SUCKS!!!  I hereby reserve the right to 
     speak my mind without being intimidated (20 of anything kicking my ass 
     would be pretty intimidating), to share my heart honestly, and to 
     enjoy life in an environment where openness is it's own reward.  I got 
     lucky and happened to be at a place where Peace, Love, Unity and 
     Respect found their proper place Saturday night...
     
     IN YOUR FACE SHAKIN YOUR ASS ON A DANCE FLOOR WHILE TRANCE IS PLAYING 
     AND EVERYBODY IS SMILING, GIFTS ARE EXCHANGING, AND LOVE ISN'T JUST A 
     WORD TO GET LAID WITH BUT A FORCE BEYOND COMPREHENSION!!!
     
     Love,
     Andy W
     
     So how do you get a crowd that appreciates a good mellow vibe and 
     won't start shit... hey, why don't they throw an invitation/referral 
     only rave... Now I understand, as fucked as it was for all the great 
     people that didn't make it.  Thank you.  If we all do our part in 
     making parties like this happen (promoting, spinning, helping out, 
     smiling, dancing, laughing, bringing altars, blessings, greeting, 
     sharing, cleaning up, storytelling, keeping it cool), eventually the 
     message/gift/vibe might get to everyone, at a time and place in their 
     lives when they're ready for it.  I guess I'm having trouble ending 
     this so sorry if I just stop here.

In a message dated 96-07-29 16:06:35 EDT, you write:
     
<< I agree with Lee... I had a problem with Susan.  The urgency of her 
request
 and the implication that some of us might be living life wrong seems to 
 contradict another idea which is that we're all in this together,
 each playing our own part in a unified world that fits together perfectly. 
 If some pieces are wrong, and others right, well then energies clash
 and stop flowing.  And this is what I feel started happening to the party. 
 As soon as a leader emerged, or a right/wrong relationship, it was a
 large circle dance.  So a lot of people stopped dancing... a lot of people 
 started leaving.  >>
     
I see your point on the subject, no one likes to be wrong, no one likes a 
preacher ( I sometimes falter there).  But do you deny that some people _do_ 
live life wrong?  The fights that broke out, which I understand were like 20 
on 1 affairs, prove that this is true (unless one thinks beating people up 
like that is OK...).  And to educate those who do live negatively may help.
 It shows them that there are people who really want to make this scociety
better, restoring some of the hope they have lost (IMHO why they live so neg). 
 People are too hung up on the "everyone is equal" thing to realize that 
whereas that is true, you can negate that fact with actions you choose, like 
jumping someone and sending them to the hospital.  No one, no matter how big 
an idiot, should be put in jepardy of life by others...which is what was going 
on if its 20 to 1 and the victim ends up needing serious medical attention.  
Just my $.02, Thanx!
     
>But, as this was a first try at unifying a very diverse group of 
promotor/party
>egos and people, we can't expect achieving the balance to be easy.
     
Excelent point.  We never can.
     
Peace,
     
-JDub

Hi all!

 Well now that I'm nearly recovered from FnF (whoosh!) I think that I 
should thank a few people who really made the night special for me;

Ethan;  Even though I feel I didn't work that hard you made the effort to 
        thank me personally for that work and you made me feel very 
        welcome. You brought a tear to my eye more than once. Thank you.

Kia;    You opened up your heart and shared your space and perspective 
        with me. You are one of the most intelligant people I have ever 
        met (IMHO) and I thank you for your warmth and honesty.

M.Clay; Thanks for your good cheer and your efforts to get me to the 
        party. You shared something of immense value that can not be 
        replicated ever.

Ela;    You will probably never read this but thank you. You choose to 
        spend time with me freely and at a time that I really needed 
        someone to be with. Your beauty and strength touched me in a way 
        I'll always cherish.

Brandon; Dude, you are such a gas to hang with (eh?)!! Thanks so much for 
         YOUR company and smiling face AND for introducing me around to 
         the SFravers!!

To all of the SFravers I met; Amy, Nancy (aha, finally we met!), Renault, 
and the others whose names I'm having difficulty recalling.

BIG THANKS TO THE FnF CREW!!!! I LOVE YOU GUYS!!!!!!!!!!

 (is okay to say that?) ;)

 I left my digital/multimeter at the party. It has my last name written 
 on the front (Cone) in large black letters. If anyone would like to 
 return it to me I would be very grateful. I use that device to make sure 
 things are working and safe for all party goers.


NEXT PARTY:

 someone who is driving that way. I'm also open to suggestions from those 
 of you out there on other partys.


Peace, hugs, =)s, and lots of love to any who read this!!!!

Subject: Friends and Family review - Yet another one
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friends and Family - A review
--------------------------------

Saturday finally arrives,   and as early evening approaches I head
out to the Haight to meet a friend then head out to San Mateo for
dinner with another friend,  where Jeremy is to meet up with us
later.

Jeremy finally arrives,  so we head out for E. Bay using San Mateo
bridge after learning that Bay Bridge is a NO NO.

We finally locate the venue,   and as we arrive in the parking area,
our car was efficiently shuffled into it's spot,   and we take a short
walk to the venue.

The Venue (A warehouse) was excellent.   It had a large outside area,
lots of old cars and trailers around,  and fairly large and spacious
inside.

>From the outside,  we could barely hear the music,  but once inside,
we were greeted with a well decorated chill space,  and off to the far
wall was the smoothie bar.

The main dance area was inside yet another area,  and was arranged
very well to prevent sound from escaping.

Not sure who the DJ was,  but he was spinning some good consistent
house.

The vibe was totally amazing,  and before long,  I found myself on
the dance floor,  totally into the music and the vibe.   There were
smiles everywhere..    Plenty of soft chill space to flop down on to
stretch after long dancing periods.    Fans to keep the air circulating,
and the temperature to a reasonable level, and a really large outside
area to romp around in.

Eventually Ethan went on and played his own stuff,   mixing it with
some of his fine vinyl.  Excellent set....

Towards the end,   as I was walking around outside,   I hear this fast
beats coming from the chill area,  so I discovered that Dave Bayer
was spinning some sick hardcore.    I wouldn't call it Gabber,
because Gabber is heaps faster than what Dave was spinning,  but it
was fast enough for most....  hovering round the 160- 170 BPM range.
Towards the end of Dave's set,  he veered off into more ambient as I
made my way to hear Joe Rice finish up his set.   Towards the end,
everyone formed a huge circle then rushed into the middle
to form this huge "Hug circle"....    At the end,  everyone cheered....

Excellent party....  my face still hurts from smiling so much...

Dean, Jeremy and myself finally pull out around 8 am and head back to
San Mateo...   Dean heads South and head north for some breakfast and
to 24 hour Nautilus for a workout and a well deserved shower and hottub
before heading out to a meadow to do some meditation before Sunset.

I arrive early at Pt Molate,  find a shady spot and chill until Sunset
started.

Sunset was Phat,  and Minor Minor ripped it up with some amazing and new
techno sounding stuff.   Good job...


The Crunchman

Oh Dr. Seuss, he's my hero he's so fine, he blows my mind!
Sorry to inconvenience any of yo're inboxes but rymes from Suess just 
make me feel funky, so i thought i'd make some o you feel FUNKY too!!~~~


 If Dr. Seuss were a Technical Writer

     Here's an easy game to play.
     Here's an easy thing to say.

     If a packet hits a pocket on a socket on a port,
     And the bus is interrupted as a very last resort.
     And the address of the memory makes your floppy disk abort,
     Then the socket packet pocket has an error to report!

     If your cursor finds a menu item followed by a dash,
     And the double-clicking icon puts your window in the trash,
     And your data is corrupted 'cause the index doesn't hash.
     Then your siutation's hopeless and your system's gonna crash!

     You can't say this?
     What a shame, sir!
     We'll find you
     another game, sir!

     If the label on the cable on the table at your house
     Says the network is connected to the button on the mouse,
     But your packets want to tunnel on another protocol,
     That's repeatedly rejected by the printer down the hall,
     And your screen is all distorted by the side affects of Gauss,
     So your icons in the windows are so wavy as a souse,
     Then you may as well reboot and go out with a bang,
     'Cause as sure as I'm a poet, the sucker's gonna hang!

     When the copy of your floppy's getting sloppy on the disk,
     And the microcode instructions cause unnecessary RISC.
     Then you have to flash your memory and you'll want to RAM your ROM.
     Quickly turn off the computer and be sure to tell your mom!

     Author Unknown

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Friends and Family, In Afterglow
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960729232039.19006B-100000@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(From Nancy)

Friends and Family...

...blew my mind.  Is it possible to still have your mind blown after two 
years of raving, of already having all the realizations about what it's 
all about?

Yes, because one revelation does not alter your reality forever.  We need 
to be reminded, we need to keep striving to return to our center, to the 
peace and love at the core, because the noise and chaos of everyday material reality pulls 
at us so tenaciously.  Maybe, back before religion was corrupted by 
institutionalization and power, that was the original intent behind a day 
set aside for worship each week - a continual recentering in love and light.

I was thinking Saturday of the experience as our church (I know that is 
not original! - many others have felt and articulated the same :).  There 
it is a house of worship where we abandon the cynicism and supposed 
apathy of our age.  We are given a haven in which we can connect to love 
without embarrassment or disbelief, but instead throw ourselves in with 
arms open wide and proclaim, "This is it!  This is what we believe!  This 
is what we're about - love and kindness and openness!"  And the 
sheltering protected space of the party is a unique space that 
immediately mirrors back to us the effect of acting wholeheartedly with 
that belief.  We are rewarded immeasurably by waves upon waves of 
positive energy returned to us.  The cosmic rule of what you give comes 
back to you, a thousand fold.

I have long felt the spirituality inherent in the best raves (to me, the 
true raves).  But often it is a personal experience, only hinted at by 
the party organizers themselves.  Friends and Family - as an 
"organization" - is explicit about the connection.  The many beautiful 
alters, the sage to mark our sacred space, the messages on the walls.  
These let us know that this is not just a party so we can have fun, 
partying and having fun is how we celebrate our beauty, our love, and the 
wonder of connection.  These are our religious ceremonies, the rituals 
that reunite us with the power of positivity and the possibilities of 
hope.

I was walking around the party overwhelmed with love for every single 
person there.  (Is it possible to fall in love with 500 people at 
once? :P)  Saturday night was the first time that I really 
felt "family."  Before I had felt great good will for all the people at 
parties like this, a definite collective connection through energy and 
music.  But at Friends and Family it finally REALLY hit me that everyone 
was there together.  And suddenly I was smiling at everyone, talking 
to people beyond those I already knew.  Because for the first time I 
realized that we were all brothers and sisters in this family of happy 
ravers, and it suddenly seemed almost rude NOT to say hi to whomever I 
was near! :)

Several newbies came, people I was pretty sure of.  I believe there 
are certain prerequisites for coming into the underground - they must 
be open and willing to give, or else it won't work for them.  It won't 
hurt the party, the people themselves just won't "get it."  They'll 
leave early and say that they don't like raving.   Because in our 
"church," there is no intermediary, no priest or rules telling you what 
your spirituality is.   There is only 
the individual's beliefs and attitude, and how that manifests their experience.    

It was more than gratifying to watch the expressions on the newbies' faces 
change from uncertainty upon entering (what is this rave thing all about?), to 
enjoyment, to awe.  I took one, an ex-Deadhead, showing him some things 
that I see.  He was quiet as he soaked it in, and then slowly turned to 
me and said with surprise, 'this is really cool!"  Aha!  Another one!

I wrote an earlier post about how we are not dependent on F&F for this 
experience (rad as their parties are).  Everyone that night oozed with 
friendliness and positivity, and (besides the incredible decoration 
and production and selflessness of the F& F crew - THANK YOU SO MUCH!!) 
THAT was what made the party so amazing.  Let's all remember to bring 
that same level of participation to all of our parties.  There's a 
Chrysalis next weekend - let's make it go OFF!!

P.S.  It would have been hard to miss me - I was quite elegantly 
turned-out in flowing thriftstore nightgown and feather boa ;).  But most of 
my conversations ended after hello, I was a little too out of my head to 
talk too much, and there's always so much to do at a party anyway!!  But 
love out to all of you and see you at the next one!

Love, Nancy

Dear friends,

        In my review of FnF, I made some remarks that have been
misunderstood.  I didn't mean a single word to be taken as a personal
attack or complaint.  I was merely pointing out something that I found odd
in the behavior of some of my friends, or, more accurately perhaps, my
perception of odd behavior.  I am reminded that not everyone experiences a
party in the same way.  I think it was a reaction from my hyper-sensitive
to have felt snubbed or neglected.  I bear no ill will toward anyone.  In
the future, I will try to express myself in a more appropriate manner, and
try to be more precise, so as to avoid any misunderstandings.  How else
will anyone believe me when I say that I love you all?  Sorry to bother
y'all with this.

Love,

Eric

From: Paul Anthony Rose <trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: (TUAAR)the life of a cup 
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960730094646.9193E-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

the life of a paper cup is not a good life most of the time.
the cup is thrown onto the ground into the middle of traffic.
feet sweeping by, barely noticing the poor cup sit there alone
but most dodge the cup as a subconscious gesture
if the cup is proud and strong, it stands upright for all to see
do not kick me over it seems to say
the unlucky cup, the sick cup lays on its side
but it doesnt matter in the end, sooner or later through some unfortunate
accident
through a forest of feet
and side stepping shoes
the little cup gets kicked, or crunched
after the first injury, the little cup gets even less respect.
while it is down and injured... crunch crunch until it is gone.
the life of a cup.
arent you glad people aren't cups?


ps. (TUAAR)=thought up at a rave
* * ** *** ***** ******** *************
Tony Rose
UC Berkeley CS
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~trose
************** ******* ***** *** ** * *

What can I say?  I was a little worried that I was expecting too much 
after hearing all the stuff from you guys, but it was beyond it...  My 
first FnF, but from now on I am sure I will never miss another one :).  

The chill room was incredible...  agghhh ...  I want one in my house just 
like that :)...

Great moments
- seeing Tony's picture mooning somebody displayed on the altar- GO 
TONY!!!!  - although you were not there I am sure many people thought of 
you :)

- seeing all my friends from the list (I am not naming everybody because 
I am sure I would forget somebody and then feel bad :( and meeting few 
new people (again, not as many as I wanted - I hate when that happens)

- morning rainbow, and trying to convince some guy that we have a project - 
gathering everybody from inside and telling them about rainbow (he wasn't 
ready to do that), and before I could shut up the door opened and 
everybody came outside anyway :)))

- fruit, water, muffins :)

- happy people who put up with my silly babling (I just could not shut 
up and stop smiling all night)

- trying to convince people that Ethan's tattoos were air-brushed because 
they just looked so good :P

- etc.....

Bad moments

- hearing only 5 min on John Carol's (SP???) set - my roommate recommended 
him highly, but I was too busy to notice when he came on - does he have 
a tape out? where?

- not dancing enough

- end of the party (I wished it would just keep going)


I can just keep thinking about it and tell people who didn't make it what 
they missed.  I am sorry about driving people crazy (if you were near me 
while I was sitting in the chair outside, or if I just ran into you and 
couldn't stop talking shit you know what I mean).  I didn't mean to be 
annoying (I am sure I was, but....  I had fun and I hope if I bugged you, 
you will forgive me).  OK....  enough...time to get back to work.

I love you all and see you soon.
Hugz,
Branka

P.S. Thanks FnF crew, thanks everybody for making my weekend so special

Subject: Re: Re[2]: F&F/Unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 30 Jul 1996 12:35:49 -0700 (MDT)
In-Reply-To: <9606298386.AA838696576@smtplink.acer.com> from "Andy Wyszkowski" at Jul 29, 96 08:08:28 pm

Precedence: bulk

Just a few thoughts to clarify:
>      
>      What moral code anywhere states that beating somebody like that is 
>      cool?  I had lotsa friends that rumbled occasionally back in LA, and I 
>      
of course nobody honestly believes that fighting is cool, or right...
(well, once you get deep enough into their soul, beyond their fears that
may feel a need to defend themselves)

But I think this scratches on an idea that is important to me.

>      it might not be the rave that's not working out.  If you know people 
>      who you think are capable of crap like this, keep them the fuck away 
>      from me, because frankly, they don't make sense.  I want to live a 
>      life that is MORE open, LESS afraid and more involved in the lives of 
>      those around me.
>      
It really isn't this simple.  You can't just hide or protect yourself from
'the evil people'.  The only way you will ever become free is when you are
strong enough to face that 'evil' head on and still be your ideal self.
When you can smile at the person who is grimacing at you and melt their fear
with your good intention.  When you can see yourself reflected in their
eyes and know that nothing can harm you, and then you proceed to dance and 
inspire them to dance with you.

I had the option of going to F&F or Unity and I chose Unity.  I knew that I
would've had a spectacular time at F&F because I have every time I've gone 
before.  But the reason I didn't go is because I already knew what I'd be 
getting at F&F.  as good as it is, if the struggle becomes too easy,
it can lose its beauty.  Understand that I'm not knocking anyone or F&F,
I plan on going to the next one, but sometimes in order to reach a new level
of strength you have to throw yourself into torrential waters, and find your
faith that you will survive stronger than before.  For me, the ideas
surrounding Unity encompassed such torrential energies that I couldn't
pass up the challenge.  and the fights that broke out, the whirlwind
of egos, and the sheer power of the coherent moments seem to vindicate
that these energies need balancing within me, and that when things become
aligned a powerful force will find itself.

I believe that everything you come across at a party or in normal life is 
a reflection of your own mind, and by finding your own internal peace with
the objects that confront you, you create peace in the material world.
 
>      I honestly don't care how good the music was if somebody got 
>      hopitalized at Unity.  It's not the promoters fault, I'm sure nobody 
>      wanted it to happen but it SUCKS!!!  I hereby reserve the right to 
>      speak my mind without being intimidated (20 of anything kicking my ass 
>      would be pretty intimidating), to share my heart honestly, and to 
>      enjoy life in an environment where openness is it's own reward.  I got 
>      lucky and happened to be at a place where Peace, Love, Unity and 
>      Respect found their proper place Saturday night...
>      
You're right... we are entitled to exactly those rights.  But we can't depend
on luck alone.  We need to feel able to bring peace, love, unity, and respect
to wherever we want, whenever we want... or we are just being intimidated
and succombing to fear in another form.

If you know what freedom is, you are not free.  

I know that F&F is a great model of freedom, but because I know it and
expect it, it becomes its own trap, keeping me from exploring the unknown.
sure there are scary things in the unknown, but they are all ultimately
reflections of myself, and I am the one who decides the meaning and makes
the rules... so in the end I will always recognize the evil as myself and
find my freedom.

It's not always easy, but it is always beautiful.

take care, my friends.

-john.
http://he.net/~swoosh

On Tue, 30 Jul 1996, michal migurski wrote:

> Over a year's worth of pushing and prodding from countless friends (esp. in
> UCB) has finally come to a head, so I think I'm going to try to go veg this
> semester.

you'll be glad you did... 

> I know many of you are vegetarians out there, so I thought I'd throw this
> out onto the list: Are there any kind of vitamins/protein supplements I
> should be taking? 

not really.  if you're going to try and go vegan (no dairy products), you
might think about taking a b12 supplement, but lots of grains are
"enriched" with b12 and other vitamins so most likely it's nothing to
worry about...

> Should I be a lot more careful about what I'm eating
> since I'm not getting that protein blast every time my dad makes steak?

ugh, you've been brainwashed to believe the "protein myth".  don't worry
about it, it's bullshit.  just eat good quality food (organic if
possible), and try and maintain a well-rounded diet (lots of veggies,
fruits, grains...).  grab some veggie cookbooks and make your own food,
it's cheaper and better (but can be a bit frustrating at first if you're
not used to it).  also, pick up John Robbins' "diet for a new america". 

> mmm... I'm really going to miss his steak =9

talk to me 6 months from now, you won't be missing it at all.  in fact
you'll be wondering how you could ever put that in your body before... 

Andy

michal wrote:
> Over a year's worth of pushing and prodding from countless friends (esp. in
> UCB) has finally come to a head, so I think I'm going to try to go veg this
> semester.

Yeah, good move!

> I know many of you are vegetarians out there, so I thought I'd throw this
> out onto the list: Are there any kind of vitamins/protein supplements I
> should be taking? Should I be a lot more careful about what I'm eating
> since I'm not getting that protein blast every time my dad makes steak?

Protein is easy. US diets are very high in protein and you can get by
on much less than most people eat. Just eat a reasonable amount of
beans, peas (or lentils or anything like that) or tofu. Tofu is a
bean-based product that's really high in protein, low in fat, and comes
in a myriad variety of forms, some of which can be cooked just like
meat. If you're eating dairy products, then you can get lots of protein
from cheese also.

The only real vitamin concern is that vegan diets can be deficient in
B12.  You can get B12 from diary products though. In any case, a cheap
multivitamin/mineral supplement won't hurt.
 
> mmm... I'm really going to miss his steak =9

Don't worry. It's amazing how much you lose appetite for meat if you
stop eating it for a while.

Jeremy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jul 30 13:56:15 1996

A friend of mine here at work is vegan (no animal products whatsoever)
and he says that you shouldn't have to worry about taking supplements
like B-12 if you're still gonna be eating dairy products. Protein 
shouldn't be a problem as long as you eat a variety of different kinds
of beans and other vegetarian/dairy sources of protein in order to get
the complete range of amino acids.

A good idea also would be to check with your doctor to see if you have
any other special requirements.

I'm also trying to convert to vegetarian...it's a better source of 
positive energy!!!!

Peace,
John

Precedence: bulk

I thought maybe some of you out there might like this..



      Abraham Lincoln was elected to Congress in 1846.  John F.
      Kennedy was elected to Congress in 1946.

      Abraham Lincoln was elected President in 1860.  John F.  Kennedy
      was elected President in 1960.

      The names Lincoln and Kennedy each contain seven letters.  Both
      were particularly concerned with civil rights.  Both their wives
      lost their children while living in the White House.

      Both Presidents were shot on a Friday.  Both were shot in the
      head.  Both were shot in the presence of their wives.  The
      Secretary of each President warned them not to go to the theater
      and to Dallas, respectively.

      Lincoln's Secretary was named Kennedy  Kennedy's Secretary was
      named Lincoln.

      Both were assassinated by Southerners.  Both were succeeded by
      Southerners.  Both successors were named Johnson.  Andrew
      Johnson, who succeeded Lincoln, was born in 1808.  Lyndon
      Johnson, who succeeded Kennedy, was born in 1908.

      John Wilkes Booth, who assassinated Lincoln, was born in 1839.

      Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated Kennedy, was born in 1939.

      Both assassins were known by their three names.  Both names
      comprise fifteen letters.  Booth ran from the theater and was
      captured in a warehouse.  Oswald ran from the warehouse and was
      captured in a theater.

      To cap it all off, Booth and Oswald were assassinated before
      their trials.

      What do you think: Mystery or a statistical co-incidence?


Pretty trippy if you ask me..

Tim (knucklehead)

Hey! Sorry to see you go!  I for one thank meat as the founder of human
intelligence and "succsess" as a species, as has been suggested by
anthropologists (refrences elude me).  Bipedality first, (ability to carry
kids AND other things simultaneously) and then protiens (building blocks for
your bod when it's growing) cuz we could grab 'em off the Savahna and run
back to the trees.  We have become humans because we were omnivorous.  Who am
I to second guess Nature?  Also, though I understand the evil practices of
beef, poultry and other meat producers, I try not to put limitations on
myself, because then I won't risk lying to me. And besides, I like steak!
 The two main reasons vegitarianism is a good idea: health and politics.  An
alternative plan I use to address these is to:   

A: limit the ammount of meat I eat. 

This is easy cuz it's so expensive!   The general public is driven by a false
campaign in the 70's-80's known as the four basic food groups...a documented
scam perpotrated by the dairy/beef industry... that helps us believe
underneath, even though we can now see the truth, that we need meat, and more
is better.It is strong because we heard it so long(or I did, anyway).  True,
meat is not needed, but protiens are, especially for kids, and meats chosen
wisely and moderately ensures they/you get enough.  

B: only eat meats produced localy by small-timers, organic if possible. No
McDonalds, No Foster Farms, etc. 

I happen to live on a cool farm up north in Sonoma County that has sheep(not
mine).  I see how they live, and I approve.  They just hang out together and
eat all day!  Plus, I have been through all phases of their "production",
from bucking (hick for stacking) hay to shearing the wool to reaching up in
there to help a chick sheep birth a lamb when the owner was unable to get
there in time to do it (yucky, yet beautifull!).  The only thing that bothers
me is that they play with hormones.

As far as the suppliment thing goes, I turn away from them.  We are
surrounded by foods containing all the proper nutrients, so if you eat right,
you shouldn't need pills.  As well, most suppliments do not contain key
enzymes and analogous compounds that are required to make the nutrients
available to your body.  I heard  that something  like 90% of calcium in
 non-chelated calcium pills (the typical type) is eliminated in body wastes,
while from milk, like 80% is usable!(These are approximations by me)  Big
diff, eh!

I've noticed that some people suggested Tofu.  RAD food!  I'll send you a
killer recipie.  But, I'm pretty sure it contains only simple protiens (soys
are like any bean), and must be eaten with rice or the like to get the
compound protiens your body needs.  This "simple protiens only" is a problem
I have heard of for veg's, so watch out.  You are wise to look carefully at
this issue of nutrients.  

Being a carnivore, I obviously have not all the answers.  I do know some
folks that have been veggies for like 25 years, dedicated to their health,
and educated in the ways of vegiterianism.  I can fax them for some
guidelines if you like!

Good luck on your new quest, i hope you have strong will power!  It can be
done if you really mean it ! :)!

-juhstyn

From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9606308387.AA838766898@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Mack 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
Subject: Re[2]: meat *It whats on this thread* (NRR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Confessions of a Carnivore
     
     Hate to be the voice of lameness, and this is going to cost me dearly, 
     but I had some personal experiences with vegetarian living...
     
     When I was 17, I decided I would quit eating meat.  I started losing 
     weight.  I maintained a well balanced diet, drank milk, took vitamin 
     and mineral supplements, and generally felt better once my system got 
     used to it.  My sister at the time was experiencing severe 
     anorexia/bulimia (she was down to 2/3 of her recommended body weight), 
     and her shrink and my parents got all over me because I was losing 
     weight too.  I had my arm twisted into it.  I still remember how gross 
     that first Chicken McNugget tasted (if you are going to eat crap, 
     avoid fried processed crap).
     
     When I was 19, I tried again.  Having been to the doctor some months 
     prior and bringing up some of my complications, I was told I was 
     mildly hypoglycemic, and that I would have to eat very responsibly to 
     maintain a vegetarian diet without losing weight.  I started keeping a 
     journal, and tried to stay within 2300-2800 calories (recommended for 
     my big dumb ass by my new doctor to maintain) and eat a well rounded 
     diet (best success I had was a home mod I did to Dr. Hass' eat to win 
     program with the words Tofu/BeanSalsaBurrito/Gluten substituting 
     Fish/Chicken).  I still lost weight.  At 155 pounds, I had to start 
     eating chicken or fish every couple dinners.
     
     I'm at 180, my target weight for healthy trancing now (5 yers later), 
     and I feel pretty swell.  I don't like red meat, and rarely eat it.  I 
     do eat white meat a couple times a week.  I still take vitamins and 
     maintain all other aspects of my lifestyle in a somewhat healthy 
     fashion.
     
     I feel empathy towards all living things, and sometimes have trouble 
     drawing the line between what is mine to consume, mine to share, and 
     mine to observe.  I have pet names for the cows (well, some of them 
     are cooler than others) I politely ask out of the way as I mountain 
     bike through Grant Ranch.  I respect vegetarians greatly, as I do 
     anyone who pursues a way of life that pursues ideals similar to mine 
     more vehemently than I do.
     
     Americans and most westerners in general eat too much meat, 
     particularly red meat.  I cut down my meat intake, and I'm healthier 
     for it.  I do not feel consistently healthy as a vegetarian, and my 
     doctor and I have attributed weight loss, headaches (blood sugar 
     related), and some stomach problems to the periods when I abstained 
     from meat altogether.  Maybe it's not for everybody.
     
     Fact:
     If I dug up a human, and looked at it's jaw, I would call it a 
     omnivore (based on the presence of choppers, rippers and mashers).
     
     Fact:
     You can be entirely healthy without eating meat.
     
     Fact:
     You can be entirely healthy and eat meat.
     
     Fact:
     I did experience a sense of being 'lighter' (less weighed down, 
     physically and morally) after about two weeks without meat.  It does 
     feel good.
     
     I feel like I can eat less 'regularly' when I eat omnivorously.  This 
     allows flexibilty like missing a meal without irritability or feeling 
     faint or headaches.
     
     As I alluded before, I'm not at odds with vegetarians, I'm just trying 
     to figure out a way for it to fit in my life.  I don't eat meat at 
     every meal, but I do eat it occasionally.  For anybody who is doing it 
     for diet reasons, phase it out of your diet gradually so you don't 
     'crave' it.
     
     Less meat is better than Joe average.  Michal, if you find it 
     difficult, don't take on the cold turkey approach of... well, I fucked 
     up so I might as well catch up on all those cheeseburgers I missed.  
     Take your time.  Listen to what your body wants.  Greens and rice and 
     beans ARE REALLY GOOD FOR YOU.  Spicy tofu kicked ass when I was veg 
     AND STILL DOES.
     
     Just trying to maintain a non commital wishy washy stance while 
     justifying my existence at the expense of other living things...
     Andy W
     
     P.S.       If anybody cares to dispute this, please do so personally.  
     I would be happy to try anything new that might help me with this with 
     an open heart and open mind.

Hey, all, please don't think my "suck" post was a pathetic attempt at
currying sympathy.  You all should know me better than that.  I just feel
like sh*t because part of my FnF review was grossly misinterpreted.  People
need to realize that there's usually no need to read anything into what I
say; I try to get my point across clearly.  My motives are honest and
beyond question.  And here I go again, apologizing for something that I
shouldn't have to.  I just love you all, and I care about you, and every
moment of personal exchange on any level is precious to me.
Thanks to everyone who was kind to me today, because I'm hurting, and I can
really use that positivity.
Sorry for misspelling "awful."  It's not like me to commit spelling errors ;)
I now return you to your regularly scheduled chaos.

Peace (please?),

Eric

OK I need to apologize firstly, for the gardening club room we tried to do
at Funky Techno Tribe a few months ago. Are position in the party was
merely as hired DJ's. We used "the gardening club" name because I got to
choose the line up in that room. We try & only work with people who are
reliable!(usually). Now I must admit it wasn't FTT's fault entirely that
the room never happened. Unfortunately the company doing the sound for that
room decided to show up at 11pm with only bass cabinets(no Highs). They
were from Sacramento which would have meant it would have taken them 3
hours to go and pick up the rest of the system and get back. Wicked offered
to do the system but things didn't pan out. I was as disappointed as anyone
about the situation. But I have been doing this long enough to realize
that, shit happens. I admit they should of dropped the price a bit when
this occurred but I had no say in that. Like I said earlier we have always
tried to bring you Quality music and DJ's for a reasonable price. We are
without a space at the moment so have to rely on doing the side rooms at
larger clubs to keep the gardening club around.

On Tue, 30 Jul 1996, Shawna McGourty wrote:

> >the life of a paper cup is not a good life most of the time.
> >the cup is thrown onto the ground into the middle of traffic.
> >feet sweeping by, barely noticing the poor cup sit there alone
> >but most dodge the cup as a subconscious gesture
> >if the cup is proud and strong, it stands upright for all to see
> >do not kick me over it seems to say
> >the unlucky cup, the sick cup lays on its side
> >but it doesnt matter in the end, sooner or later through some unfortunate
> >accident
> >through a forest of feet
> >and side stepping shoes
> >the little cup gets kicked, or crunched
> >after the first injury, the little cup gets even less respect.
> >while it is down and injured... crunch crunch until it is gone.
> >the life of a cup.
> >arent you glad people aren't cups?
> 
> 
> I think people are just exactly that, cups!  At least our physical bodies 
> anyway.  If you think of a cup, it's not the cup that's all that important, 
> it's the contents it holds.  Our bodies are temporary, transitory.  However, 
> they hold a very important content, our life energy/souls.  And one could even 
> get into a bit of reincarnation, which really sounds cup-like!  If you take a 
> paper cup and fill it with water, it will hold the water for a certain amount 
> of time, then eventually it will get old and start to fail and be less able to 
> contain the water.  At that point, the water gets poured from that old cup into 
> a new cup, and the process starts again.  The cups are discarded, are 
> "disposable", but the water/life/energy is carried consistently from one cup to 
> the next, thru a chain of cups, and is never lost.  Cups are pretty important, 
> they are the vessels of life/our energy.  Yet not too much importance should be 
> placed on them, cuz they are temporary, and should be let go of when the time 
> is right.  
> 
> So I think people are cups!
> 
> Just some thoughts I had a long time ago that you reminded me of with your 
> post. :) (pretty random, eh?)
> 
> Love,
> Shawna
> 
wow, I didnt think of it that way!...it is pretty random...i shoulda maybe
put a little background on my post...but sometimes I like to be
mysterious!... I was at fnf with 2 friends when we decided to put a cup on
the ground in traffic and see what happened...it was alot of fun! most
people side stepped it, but they didnt really notice the cup...even when
there was a huge crowd the cup would be missed 90% of the time, that is
until once it was knocked over once...no-one noticed it anymore... I feel
sorry for the guy that stepped on it the first time...CRUNCH... we all (a
few others had joined us living the life of a cup) we all went OHHHHHH!!!!
he looked so sad! he said he was sorry and apologised profusely! of course
it was ok...we were just a little heartbroken that our cup was squashed!

-Tony Rose

On Tue, 30 Jul 1996 Juhstyn@aol.com wrote:

*snip!*

> back to the trees.  We have become humans because we were omnivorous.  Who am

i just wanted to comment on this one sentence ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ actually
chimpanzees are omnivorous too .. and THEY haven't become human :) an
interesting thing to note about chimp society however is that usually
there is NO sharing of food - everyone grabs and eats what they can. 
EXCEPT when they kill a monkey to eat.  then the meat is shared among all
the members of the group ... which leads me (IMHO) to believe that
meat-eating began as a strictly ritual practice and then we got a taste
for it.

(From Nancy)

What's smaller than a breadbasket, more expensive than a Friends and 
Family ticket, and is an absolute necessity for any self-respecting raver??

Mixtapes.  And lots of them.

Unfortunately, though, at $15 a pop, most of us cannot afford them (we 
save that kind of money for illicit chemical compounds!).

So, I was thinking about community, and collectivism, and hit upon what 
(I hope) is a great idea...

The SFRaves DJ Mixtape Collective!!

The idea is this: many of us have a few mixtapes, and would like more.  
So, if you all think this will work, I thought we could post our 
collections, and make copies and trade with each other!

I will be the first!  (But first, a caveat - my collection is quite 
small, and doesn't totally reflect my favorite music or dj's).  Smiley 
faces denote the tapes I most highly recommend.


DJ Crust   Bootleg #2		crowd-pleasing happy trance	:)
	   Dreamline		deep, heavenly, energetic trance:):)
Dutch	   Funky Void		flowing trance			:)
	   Burning Chrome	harder-edge trance, Detroit-ish 
Jeno	   Soul Creation	progressive house for the softies out there
Myster-e   The Sirius Mystery	new, haven't really listened yet


I would adore anything by Ethan, Jon Carel, and the more breakbeat stuff 
by Dan.

** Also, if it exists, Ethan's set at midnight, New Year's Eve 96 at 
Begin Again, Dan's set from Spundae Memorial Day weekend (for those of 
you who were downstairs at 1015 that night, you remember this!!!).

Hope hope for tapes from the lastest FnF!!  Especially Alex, Jon and Ethan!!

P.S.  It is an absolute crime that Saturday night at the Light Campout 
wasn't taped.  That night rocked unbelievably.


Hope our Collective brings all of us much more music!!

On Tue, 30 Jul 1996, THX1138 wrote:

> Dear All;
> 
>         I had VEAL last night, in the Castro @ Sausage Factory; and it was
> good; but what does this thread have to do with raving?

I think that a healthy body and mind have a lot to do with raving.  In my 
opinion, being a vegetarian can only facilitate both of these things.  
Also, doing your own part to try to cut down on some of the cruelty and 
polution in the world doesn't completely go against the grain of what 
raving has come to mean to me, either.  I am by no means a militant veg, 
but it was great for me to see a post from someone talking about becoming 
a veg and all the people on the list supporting and helping him with his 
decision.  *IMHO* it has a lot more to do with raving than some things I 
see come across this screen.

At 01:19 PM 7/30/96 -0700, michal migurski wrote:
>Over a year's worth of pushing and prodding from countless friends (esp. in
>UCB) has finally come to a head, so I think I'm going to try to go veg this
>semester.


RIGHT ON!
Killing animals and then EATING them is really, really BAD KARMA!
I've been vegetarian for about 4 years now. It does get a little boring
around lunch time since the deli near my work's only vegitarian item is a
cheese sandwich. 

>I know many of you are vegetarians out there, so I thought I'd throw this
>out onto the list: Are there any kind of vitamins/protein supplements I
>should be taking? Should I be a lot more careful about what I'm eating
>since I'm not getting that protein blast every time my dad makes steak?


You might want to take an iron and vitamin B complex supplement.
There are plenty of other vegetarian things you can eat to get your protien. 



>mmm... I'm really going to miss his steak =9

magazine a few months back about what goes on in the slaughterhouse that you
might want to read.

To: Josh Kneubuhl <joshk@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>

In-Reply-To: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960730192129.26963B-100000@franklin.CS.Berkeley.EDU>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I for one would like to go on record as discouraging the formation of a
large collective of copying DJ mix tapes that are currently for sale...

My reason is that it costs to produce and distribute these tapes and
DJ's make very little money back on them as it is... it's been my
experience that a lot of them are given to friends & promoters anyway...
SO I'm saying scrounge a bit, dig deeper and support your local DJ
favorites with the extra cash....

 I feel it's fine to copy tapes that are out of production or were not
released for sale btw... like someone's dat made at a party....

 I would be more in support of the pass around and copy if some way was
implimented to make sure that some $$ support made it to the DJ's via
collections  etc. but I still suspect that the stores selling the tapes
also need every $ they can get...

 Someone can correct me if I'm off base here - but this is my immediate
impulse....


Mike (who has sold 4 tapes of his own and knows I needed the $$$)


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

>kids AND other things simultaneously) and then protiens (building blocks for
>your bod when it's growing) cuz we could grab 'em off the Savahna and run
hmm.. your body actually synthesizes protein from fats and carbohydrates if
it's in defecit. the protein thing is really just a myth. i got up to a nice
six foot never eating meat, my sister is about 5'10" after the same diet.
and muscle strength/effeciency aren't really related to protien consumption
in the extent that muscle bulk is. those guys in the olypics certainly
aren't superhuge bodybuilders, but they can lift a hell of a lot. 

>back to the trees.  We have become humans because we were omnivorous.  Who
sure, maybe eating meat helped humans discover clubs and weapons (and what a
wonderful contribution they are), but the invention of agriculture is what
fueled the development of towns, and with them the arts and sciences, and
everything else that our world is built on today. if anything, meat
consumption may have contributed to the aggressive nature of humanity,
herbavores being pretty docile in general, etc..

>No you wont. Just think where it comes from. There was an article in Details
>magazine a few months back about what goes on in the slaughterhouse that you
>might want to read.

heh. couple little anecdotes.
 i went into the meat freezer at the safeway i work at the other day, and
there was this huge garbage can full of chopped up, bloody meat bits. pretty
disgusting, i'm glad i don't eat that stuff.  (hmm, back to the hot dog
factory? <grin>)

another safeway one: i'm bagging someone's groceries, and this packaged meat
comes through that looks like the cow was just slaughtered, because the
package was _full_ of blood and leaking all over the place. the lady asks me
to please not loose any blood, by putting it in a bag all by itself. eeyuck.
ok, vampira.

my dad is doing a landscaping job at a chicken joint. walks into the back,
and is confronted with a huge pile of warm chickens lying on the counter.
flys buzzing all around, and some guy drops one onto the really dirty floor
and just throws it into the oven. mmmmm.. yummy.

my grade 12 biology class: we're disecting various animals. i, of course,
play with the animals like they were still living, and make numerous food
cracks. oddly enough, no one can eat their lunch after the class except me.
what? bad conscience?? ;)

To: Mack 99 <erase99@sirius.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "SpinSilver--'Robertj@Monterey'" <silver@salinas.net>
Subject: Re: DJ Mixtape Collective
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 08:51 PM 7/30/96 -0700, Mack 99 wrote:
>well, i was going to say pretty much the same thing as mike, but he beat me
>to it. mixtapes are a way that djs can supplement the rather large expense
>of buying new vinyl, etc..
>//////////////////////////*****************//////////////**************//////

Hey...I just wrote to Brian B.asking him about having a mixtape area.  Other
lists around the country do, and I suspect that this question of copywrite
and $$$money for the Dj's is the thorn which keeps this from happening.
First of all (most) of the Dj's aren't paying a royalty to the makers of the
records they are buying...So I hate this sanctimonious whimpering about
copywrite. This is the underground remember???? I have purchased has many
tapes as I have copied (about 150)  I also buy records (about 300 hundred)
and have spent I don't know how much going to parties during the last four
years....I remind you to look at the tapes you've purchased...Most say "For
Promtional Purposes Only"--What trading tapes is about is promoting this
music and promoting the dj.  I have often traded for the tape of a dj I
haven't heard...then, loved the tape, then, went out to hear that dj; Mark
Farina, Doran,and John Howard to name a few, and I'll bet the same is true
for you. It's also true the Dj doesn't buy the records solely to make a
tape.  The records are purchased, played at parties, where the Dj's real
income comes from..Anything else is gravy...not to mention that they get
significant breaks in buying records over the amateur,like myself, who is
just playing at home or for free.

  The day it becomes about copywrite and money, and Sony and BMI...the scene
is in serious trouble. The short half-life of Rock'n Roll epitomized by
Elvis, is enough said here. In the end, there is no putting the Genie, back
in the bottle.
Dj's will make tapes, people will buy some, and tape others.  TApes which
particularly move me, I buy because I want a better recording or I want the
graphics on the box. I the more music you buy, or buy records, or buy
tickets to a party ultimately ends up contributing to the music. In the
Olympic spirit, i say, "let the trading begin."

                              ............ SpinSilver    aka   Robertj


"Always remember, you're unique. Just like everyone else.

Precedence: bulk

Yah, I think you're right.  But, do all mix tapes cost $15 I am new, havn't
bought one yet)?  That's a rip off!  Of us AND the DJ! If the DJ only get's a
small cut, then where do the $ go to?  Probably not the record store!  Indie.
tapes of local _bands_ don't go for that much!  And they have to pay
recording studios and stuff to get it made!  Just my .02

!!!tuO ecaeP

-Juhstyn


meclay wrote
<<I for one would like to go on record as discouraging the formation of a
large collective of copying DJ mix tapes that are currently for sale...

My reason is that it costs to produce and distribute these tapes and
DJ's make very little money back on them as it is... it's been my
experience that a lot of them are given to friends & promoters anyway...
SO I'm saying scrounge a bit, dig deeper and support your local DJ
favorites with the extra cash....

 I feel it's fine to copy tapes that are out of production or were not
released for sale btw... like someone's dat made at a party....

 I would be more in support of the pass around and copy if some way was
implimented to make sure that some $$ support made it to the DJ's via
collections  etc. but I still suspect that the stores selling the tapes
also need every $ they can get...

 Someone can correct me if I'm off base here - but this is my immediate
impulse....


Mike (who has sold 4 tapes of his own and knows I needed the $$$)>>

In a message dated 96-07-30 12:37:47 EDT, you write:

<< 
 [Dang - I composed & sent this message to your old
 address, then paged down through my in-box & found
 your messages, giving your NEW address....sorry to
 clutter up your mom's mailbox....hope she doesn't mind!]
 
 R>>

A.O.K., my friend!

 <<______________________________
 
 Thanks so much for your message.  I was really
 interested in reading your comments - I often find myself
 thinking similar things in little bursts so it feels
 really good to see it all laid out at once.
 
 You said in the P.S. that you've used this discussion
 to help you define things for yourself - this makes me
 excited!  The process of setting things out in words
 is so important to me - often I think that I know how
 I feel about something, but when I decide to sit down
 & talk or write about it in detail, so much more comes
 out, especially in terms of making myself refine and
 reconsider my own definitions.....>>

Ahh! An open mind!  So hard to find/maintain!  Keep on reconsidering!  This
get's complicated, though, because you never know where you stand.  But I
guess searching is better than standing when you don't know where you stand,
or just assume you know!

<< Sometimes I get caught up in my own monologues, and
 feel like I can see into the whole system of how society's
 been set up (American society, at least, I have no
 experience with others) and what I see is really ugly,
 and it feels like a trap I can't escape from...so all
 the logic I see behind it adds up to nothing but a
 sort of twisted, hurting feeling.  This feeling seems
 to perpetuate itself, and I get sad, and wonder why
 my thoughts about these things even matter, since I cannot move
 them into action, outside myself...>>

I feel this way often myself.  But keep in contact with people like us, here
and elsewhere, and the feeling doesn' last long!  This list is breathing new
life in to my soul;  seeing all the happy people out to make a diff. really
touches you when you let it!  Especially because there are folx here who are
actually interested in working for change, not just noticing the problem.
Keep in contact on this point.  We all need your ideas about what can be
done!  Oh, and check out my x-favorite web site (now it's hyperreals culture
archives--including this list!!!!) if you want to sink in those feelings of
pointlessness...http://www.angst.org/.  I take it all 1/2 heartedly, but they
do touch something dark which most won't admit about life.
 
 <<Where is the place for idealism in this?  I try to shape
 my own life as best I can, but is this "enough" ?  And
 what would "enough" be, anyway?  [This concept itself seems
 to be a consumer/marketplace creation....]>>

Idealism IMHO should piont almost only at self.  Live your own ideal, cuz you
have the best chance of achieving that.  Being ideal about society helps, but
you can only really change yourself.  Which leads me to education.  Education
is another idealist-prone area that needs to be handled carefully.  Idealism
here turns people off, especially when they don't agree.  Position yourself
so that the uneducated know that you are willing to change your mind if they
say something that makes _you_ see the light.  This allows them to feel the
same way.  I have found that people will never change their views in front of
you(something I actively try not to do, and OFTEN fail!).  They will fight
forever on their piece of ground, even when they know you are possibly right.
 Then, if you don't push it and they leave the conversation on a posative
note, they may apply what they heard in their next interaction.  People like
to be right, don't like to be wrong.  So if you make them doubt themselves,
then they will attach to that feeling and use the info that made them feel so
to make themselves stronger in the next argument.  Or they ignore you.  

<<Sometimes I spend so much time just thinking, thinking, thinking
 and the things I think about still seem to slip through
 my hands....>>

WRITE THEM TO ME!!! I am a flake, but I'll try to respond every time if I
can!
 
<< Eeek! As I'm writing this, I find myself thinking that
 there is absolutely no way I can send it to you - I don't know you;
 this rant seems really juvenile compared to your specific
 words about specific problems; you may not care or know
 what to respond to what I'm saying; etc., etc., etc....
 
 But that is not in the spirit of the message you just
 sent - and that is not true to the feelings that made
 me respond.>>
 
  You fight laziness (not sending it would be easy) AND  you have, IMHO the
right attitude!  Fuck'em if they put you down.  That's not why you put your
ideas foreward, you do it to test the ideas.  Any idea is worth putting to
the flame test, and if they hit you hard with words, well, look hard at WHY!
You may even find yourself wrong.  If more people knew this, fewer people
would hit so hard, and more things would change.

<< I guess I just simply want to thank you for
 working through your own definitions so publicly.
 There are so many slogans out there - vampiricly
 sucking meaning out of words, feelings, ideas....
 "just do it,"  "no fear"...it makes me feel hollow,
 if I don't make the effort to determine what's
 real and what's not real, for MYSELF, one thought
 at a time....>>

Thank you, and thank "Bob" you can see the reasons for your feelings of
hollowness.  I think the general public also feels those emptinesses, but
they think the slogans and products associated with them are what will fix
them!  They _believe_ the hype!
 
 <<What you've said is true, and it's so good to see it out there.>>

Thank you soooo much!!  I have _much_ respect for you breaking your own mold
and studying yourself!  I know I have a long way to go to be the person I
can/want to be, I had a serious depression/denial phase I am just starting to
climb out of!  Getting dumped and seriously disrespected (even after I
forgave) by my former best friend/ girlfriend of YEARS showed me that slump I
was in.  The catylist for change, however has been RAVES!!!, this list being
key in my rave life (I've been too broke to go out for like the last 2
weeks...and I live 1-1.5hrs from the bay, so just getting to free parties
costs.
 
 <<Take care,
 Rhea
  >>

I will, but only if you will!!!

Encuraging/edly yours,

-Justin

Most cost around $15.  A lot of stores take the tapes on consignment, so
stores get a lot of money as well.  I don't know about big name DJ's like
Dan or Jeno.  I don't know how they get paid for tapes?  Does anybody else
know?  My friend told me that Dan gets mucho dinero every week from his mix
tape sales.  I know that hip hop tapes go for less because the records are
less expensive to buy.

At 02:23 AM 7/31/96 -0400, you wrote:
>Yah, I think you're right.  But, do all mix tapes cost $15 I am new, havn't
>bought one yet)?  That's a rip off!  Of us AND the DJ! If the DJ only get's a
>small cut, then where do the $ go to?  Probably not the record store!  Indie.
>tapes of local _bands_ don't go for that much!  And they have to pay
>recording studios and stuff to get it made!  Just my .02

>!!!tuO ecaeP

What can I say -- it was a great party, a *rave*.  Music, decorations,

with that!), lights, people, awesome.  And then a rainbow in the morning --

music all night long," this was a special treat.  I hope we keep
expanding the variety without losing any of the great sounds that have
brought us here.

to know!) . . .

Subject: Trainspotting Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

        Just saw Trainspotting, very cool movie definitely worth seeing at a
movie theater. I recommend the AMC Kubuki 8, it' a really nice place
complete with arcade, clean modern bathrooms, parking, a snack bar & coffee
shop(pastries, express o, ...etc), nice roomy comfortable seats, cup
holders, and big screens.

        The movie is very real to life as far as the drug stuff goes, how it
portrays life in Scotland for these characters, and the brief view of the
rave scene.

        Though my recent bout with H wasn't administered via IV, though I
have done it that way many years ago. I can speak from personal experience
when I say that the drug stuff; especially the IV/Heroin stuff is so real
that it provoked an emotional reaction from me. God, I'm still kind of
reeling from it, all those needles, the visual appearance of the fake
Heroin, the things the characters say about the drug, the withdraw scene(a
little over-exaggerated/stretching the truth), the characters themselves,
...etc; are all relativity true & accurate; with the obvious exception of
the characters themselves. Though I'm sure that the author drew on people
from his real life, as they were very believable. I'm sure you or someone
you know could say, hey I knew someone like that.

        I strongly related to three of the characters; the 1st being the
main character, then Spud, and the one adult character who died. It had
ending which left me satisfied and feeling good, as well as one which was
believable. In other words you could almost see it as a true story.

        Make sure you see it whether it be in the movies or on video, though
not an Academy Award Winner, not exciting, it was an extremely interesting,
fun film with excellent characters, that reflects our times, and it's peoples.

Peace
Brian

I'm going to have to agree alittle with Mike Clay. As someone that will
soon be playing out as a DJ. Records get expensive. I often will spend
about $50-$60 on 4 maybe 5 records which sometimes there might only be 1
track on there that I like. Alot of times too DJ's will spin at a party for
free.  I'm all up for getting mixtapes out to whoever wants them, but that
should be up to the DJ who get them for free.  Some DJs might not care if
people get there mixtapes for free. That way if people like them, they will
goto an event that there spinning at and hopefully the DJ get's paid.

If there is going to be a mixtape swapping thing, maybe there should be a
list of DJs that do not care if people copy or get there mixtapes for free.
There might even be a list of certain mixed tape that DJ will give out and
some the might want to charge for. The price for an average cassette of
good music is not asking to much. Some DJ's don't even let people record
them at a party. They make there own tapes.

Just remember some DJs might only be a DJ and not have any other job and
depend on the DJ spot at parties and the sales of their mixed tapes. You
can't always assume they have another job. If you want to swap tapes then
maybe ask for Demo tapes. Those are usually the ones that get handed out
for free. You might even offer to give them a blank tape or even $5 bucks
so they can get more tapes.

My $.02 worth


Tim (knucklehead)
