From: "Michael E. Clay" <meclay@netcom.com>
Subject: Mix tapes, Software & Corp. US (SRR)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9607310842.A23757-0100000@netcom3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ok ok since it has come up.... (stepping up to soapbox)....

  Many on this list love music & software AND have no particular desire
to fuel "big business" in America (ala Nike etc.)... others note that
DJ's don't observe copyrights when they play records out and even a
"noted" visual artist has been known to show a tape or two with "NOT
FOR PUBLIC PERFORMANCE" plastered all over the box AHEM..... But if
I "shared my income" with them - they'd have to pay me ;-)


  My take on this is 1) we're all a "den of thieves" and 2) it's become so
common to steal income producing property that we do it without guilt and
usually without thinking.... BUT someday if YOU become the artist that
everyone is stealing from YOU WILL NOTICE BIGTIME... it's all a matter of
whose  income is being pilfered theirs (that's fine) or YOURs (Hey wait
a minute!).....

  Now since we've established our guilt as thieves why not act as "Robin
Hood" I always say.... that is steal from the rich BUT give to the poor..

  So whenever I steal ahem "copy" a tape, software, or video (ok ok I'm
a thief too) I ask myself am I "Robin Hood" or simply a robber baron?

In the case of software: if I pirate from Microsoft or Adobe I'm living
off the big corporation and the lost to them won't be great... some  would
say they "owe some pro bono" stuff  to society anyway... Robin Hood...
If I steal from a small  garage based say music software company that's
struggling to get by... NOT Robin Hood... I've become the robber baron...

  So if you copy one of Sony's tapes it's stealing but at least it's from
a LARGE corporation that can take the loss....  but if you copy a small
DJ's tape... YOU might even make more than they do and stealing from the
small guys is NOT in the grand tradition of the "noble thief"....

 So as I always tell my Intro Computer classes... as you copy that floppy
or tape etc... ask yourself 1)  am I stealing something of (market)value? If
tape software etc. is out of production ie not being sold anyway NO go
ahead copy away - no foul.... 2) If it is of market value: big guy or
little guy? If the owner is a really big guy... understand it is stealing
BUT ok I'm Robin Hood.... HOWEVER if the owner is a really little guy
struggling to get by ALWAYS buy from them....

 AND NO: small recording operations and stores can't always compete with
Tower on cost and make all tapes cost $8... they aren't moving enough
quantity....

 Until we get it... THAT WE MUST (as in HAVE TO!!!) SUPPORT THE LITTLE
GUYS the ONLY other way to do business in AMerica will be BIG (as in
MEGA corporation)... and you all *** know*** where that leads......

End of today's lesson

***Off my soapbox****

Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

okay, just a quick little question.  This isn't really meant to be taken too seriously
but it is a possibility. :)

Some one said killing animals and eating them is bad Karma, and a lot of you seem
to feel sorry for the animals.  Now me being the meat eater that I am and having the
vegetarian girlfriend that I do, I have thought about this a little.

What about killing the poor innocent plants??  Could they not in some way that we
don't understand have feelings too.  Just because we can't communicate with them in
any way doesn't mean they do not feel pain.

just a thought.   :)

jay

What you say IS TRUE.... but we can't hear the tiny plant screams... We
can measure them with electronic measuring equipment however...

Advanced Masters often move to the level of conciousness where they will
not eat anything that means the death of the living thing involved....
That is they will eat fruit that falls from a tree or milk from an
animal or unfertalized eggs... but they will not kill an animal or even
an ENTIRE plant to eat it.... chosing instead to eat only small parts
of plants such as fruit, seeds etc that can be taken without killing
the plant....

That is where this concept of karma and conciousness about killing eventually
leads but most of us are not there YET ;-)

Mike

From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: RE: meat vs. veggies
To: Jay Wiley <jwiley@cisco.com>, sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hear Hear!
 There was a great Bloom County series a few years back in which Binkley   
becomes gradually increasingly enlightened, and begins to change all his   
habits to prevent killing.  He quits meat, then he quits using any   
leather products, then he realizes that by walking around he crushes   
countless innocent insects, and soon he winds up hanging from a tree by a   
rope with a bandana over his face to avoid inhaling and killing innocent   
bacteria in the air.
 I think this issue, like so many, has no absolute answer; we all fall   
somewhere on a continuum of what's an acceptable level of sacrifice and   
inconvenience.  Everyone, to survive, exploits the environment to some   
degree.  Happily, it seems like most vegetarians view their choice as a   
personal choice, and don't condemn the carnivores of the world.  This   
makes me very happy.

I should add that I commend and support the vegetarians out there; it's   
not an easy change to make, and if you have the will, more power to you.
 -Roy


 ----------

Subject:  meat vs. veggies

okay, just a quick little question.  This isn't really meant to be taken   
too
seriously
but it is a possibility. :)

Some one said killing animals and eating them is bad Karma, and a lot of   
you
seem
to feel sorry for the animals.  Now me being the meat eater that I am and
having the
vegetarian girlfriend that I do, I have thought about this a little.

What about killing the poor innocent plants??  Could they not in some way
that we
don't understand have feelings too.  Just because we can't communicate   
with
them in
any way doesn't mean they do not feel pain.

just a thought.   :)

jay

Yo was up?

Had to step to the bathroom, did I miss anything?  Any good parties happen
this weekend?  I figured it was a good weekend to take off because the
calandar was a little light on fun happenings.  I decided to stay home and
add to my giant ball of lint.  I should be in Guiness within a a year or
two at this rate.  Only problem is, I seem to have lost my kitten...;^)

______________________
Oops, there I go spewing sarcasm again...sorry!
______________________

Believe it or not I actually had a rockin' time and I didn't go to FnF.  I
was on a houseboat trip on Lake Shasta and it was a blast.  This is the
third year of putting together this trip and while slightly stressful
trying to keep track of 21 fucked up people, it's quite enjoyable.

In fact, Saturday night while most of you were partying at FnF, I was
creating a little sub-FnF-party on Lake Shasta with all the required
ingredients.  I threw in a live tape of Ethan (Mad, 2/12/96) and that got
everyone rocking.  I put up a green pin-spot behind everyone and they were
all tripping on their dancing shadows on the shore.  As the energy peaked I
sat down and literally focused all my energy to the FnF party.  At least
one or two people responded back.  Actually, I believe I over shot FnF,
because I started picking up weird vibes from India; I think Bill and Gaby
must have been channeling too.  ;^)

There were liberal servings of nudity, music, and general debauchery on
this trip.  And while I kind of lamented missing the party(s) here
(FnF/Theta), I knew it wouldn't get me down.  In a way, we were all kind of
partying together, even if I didn't get to stand in line to hug Ethan.  ;^)

I look forward to seeing the pictures though...

Peace!

Tony

ok...last thing and then i'll shut up for a while i promise:

on the VEG topic:  I've been vegetarian all my life, and I have a LOT of
respect for those of you who started out nonveg who have switched to veg
on your own.  I think that must take a lot of clear thinking and
willpower.  Since I've been vegetarian since birth, I never understand
people who say you can't get good tasting food or nutrition if you are
vegetarian.  Of course I eat and cook lots of Indian food.  
If any of you want some good vegetarian Indian food recipes 
I can share them with you, or reccommend a great cookbook.

peas (it's good for you ;^)),

to it? A moustrap springs shut when a mouse steps in, but no one in their
right mind would try to defend mousetraps from slavery and exploitation...

and even human operate this way to a certain extent... our brains our so
complex that we actually think we're conscious... ;)

inside the trap are brushed (which causes the trap to close).  A primitive
nervous system??  I don't haven't come to any conclusions on how I feel about

I do the question of eating meat.

herbivores like to use.

Well, I enjoy a certain amount of meat in my diet, but I've found
a way around the moral issue by sticking to animals that have died
from natural or accidental causes.  Roadkill, (under 12 hours fresh)
can be very good if properly spiced.  And you can gather up all those 
flies on the windowsill for a crunchy snack. 

In the future, we will be able to genetically engineer animals to
have the innate *desire* to be eaten (ref: Hitchhiker's Guide to
the Galaxy).  Until then, all we can do is feel sorry.  Considering 
the current use of pesticides in agriculture, I don't think
most vegetarians have a very strong moral basis for their diet.

Lee

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Subject: moderation in all things, even meat and veggies
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i shall give my humble opinion on vegetarianism.

the best lesson i learned from a wise old man (my dad) was "moderation in
all things".  this lesson, combined with my personal philosophy, causes me
to believe that there is no substance nor action that, when in the proper
proportions, is inherently bad. (insert your flame here!)

when i think about that in terms of eating, i come to the following
conclusion for me: being vegetarian, for me, is not moderate.  it says to me
that "there are some types of food that are bad in some way, regardless of
their proportion."  i cannot agree with that statement.  yes, vegetarianism
may be fine for some people, but it does not work for me.

i make my best attempt to not be excessive (difficult as that is, especially
at a good rave) and choosing to sytematically exclude one food to the
inclusion of another does not work with my personal philosophy.  i choose to
eat all types of foods and be healthy with all of them.

i think it is a little odd that humans feel they can escape the food chain.
i eat other organisms.  when i die, another organism will eat me (i refuse
to be buried in a coffin.  i will be buried at sea, where my tissue may be
recycled).
i may die tomorrow, having been eaten by some animal while i am in the
wilderness.  being part of the life cycle and the food chain, i am fine with
that.  just as humans are able to systematically kill animals to eat them,
other animals are able to kill humans and eat them.  organisms are made to
eat each other.

ok, now all you vegetarians, please don't flame me too hard, for i respect
your decision to eat exclusively non-meat products.  i just need to speak my
piece.

love to you all (may you be eaten and enjoy it!)-

matt l

Personally, I think $15 is a lot for a tape, but that seems to be the going
rate at stores. Even if the DJ wants to charge less, often the stores will
push for $15 so all the tapes cost the same...

There are other ways of distribution, however (ie the FnF website) and
speaking for myself, if someone asks me for a tape at a party and I happen
to have one on me I'll give it to them. I also don't particularly care if
anybody copies my tapes. I love to hear stories of where the copies have
travelled.

Joe

>Well, where do you draw the line between "knowing" something and "reacting"
>to it? A moustrap springs shut when a mouse steps in, but no one in their
>right mind would try to defend mousetraps from slavery and exploitation...
>IMO, the venus trap just has a more complex mechanism. I also think animals
>and even human operate this way to a certain extent... our brains our so
>complex that we actually think we're conscious... ;)
>
A Venus Fly trap has little thingies in his mouth or trap (whatever you
call it) that closes when it feels something in there, it then spits out
some kind of juice stuff that drains the life out of a fly and it sucks it
dry. Then takes that fly juice and consumes it into itself. The fly dies
slow and probally painful too. I've notice if you put something else like
for example a small metal object, it my close on it but it doesn't do
anything to it.  How does it know the difference.

Again, I'm not taking sides. I recently saw a bunch of Venus flytraps and
they got me thinking about alot of things about plant having feelings or
not. Take an animal or human, you cut an arm or leg off it doesn't grow
back (some reptiles do, so disregard those) and it hurts them. Well tree
get there limbs cut and if you treat it like a wound and put tar or
something on it, it won't grow back. Sometimes it will even die because it
was hurt.  Some even bleed. There really isn't a safe why to make sure your
not hurting something whether it's plant or animal. Animals do cry out when
hurt, but we may not be able to hear the plant cry out.

The thing Mike brought up about some wait until fruit falls from a tree and
what not is probally the only safe assurance that you are not hurting
anything, plant or animal.

This can be just as bad as any other topic..ie..politics, religion..etc....
people have strong beliefs and we should respect them. As far me, I like
meat and veggies. I could probally do with out hamburgers, hot dogs,
chicken and pork because there are some really great veggie subsitutes out
there,  but steak and beef ribs for me are hard to leave behind now. I have
alot of respect for those that change to veggies and stay with it.

That's it for me on this matter. For one, I really don't want to get a
flame going and for two this can go on forever. So to those veggie people
and meat people out there please respect each other, you don't have to
agree, just respect there choice.

Subject: Totally not rave related,  but interesting
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last evening,  I get a page from this talk show host Art Bell (KSFO-560)
who wanted to have me be his guest on his radio show.   So,  just before
I head out to my favorite campsite up on Mt Tam,  I call him back.

He asked me to go to a quiet spot and call him back,  so I head up to
Pan Toll campground and phone him from there (Actually,  he called me
back).

The interview lasted 4 hours,  and 20 million people were listening to
his program on 300 radio stations all over the USA.

He took callers who asked me questions (primarily about phone hacking)
and I was given an opportunity to give out my URL....   Also,  during the
show,  Art Bell put up a link from his pages to mine.

The show was incedible.   AOL was knocked OFF_LINE due to the amount
of traffic it caused.   Sorry about that,   all you AO Smell users.

Ha Ha Ha!!   That was really a kick....   AOL shut down due to massive
amount of people getting onto Art's web site.

Of course,  the WELL handled this massive amount of traffic,  but my
Aux site at "vcomm.net" didn't fare so well..

Anyway,  the next day,  I didn't really get that much of an increase
in mail.... Perhaps about 60 more messages a day,  but WOW,  my web site
hit count went off the scale.

For instance,  the Forbes ASAP article increased my hit count to about
1200 hits/hour... Not that bad actually,   then it settled down to about
150 -200 hits/hour.

Today,  I check my stats...

Daily Access Statistics


Today, there have been a total of 24230 accesses by 2940 unique hosts to crunch.
The total traffic generated by this page was 176957 kilobytes of information.

There have been 2423 accesses per hour, and at this rate, crunch will get
58152 accesses today.

So,  just to let you all know...

Anyway,  nuff said,  lets change the subject back to raving,  see you all
at Crysilis...

Crunchman

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (bowowow yippee yo yippee yay....)
Subject: NRR - NON RAVE RELATED - World leaders try to control the Internet.
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WARNING: NON RAVE RELATED!!!

I found this extremely interesting, especially the last part.  

------------

July 30th, 1996 5:29PM EDT

PARIS (Reuter) - The world's major powers closed ranks to combat terrorism 
on Tuesday, urging other nations to join forces with them but side-stepping 
a row over U.S. demands for sanctions against what Washington calls 
"terrorist states".

Foreign and security ministers from the Group of Seven industrial nations 
and Russia approved a list of 25 practical measures to defeat bombers who in 
separate recent incidents have attacked the Atlanta Olympics and tourist 
sites in northeastern Spain and may have downed a TWA Boeing 747 near New 
York's Kennedy International Airport.

(snip)

The package included pledges to reinforce police cooperation and training, 
share intelligence, ease extradition and legal assistance, dry up sources of 
funding and weapons and strengthen national anti-terrorism legislation.

The ministers also vowed to prevent extremists from using the Internet 
computer network to plan attacks and spread bomb-making instructions.

(snip)

-------------

What I find interesting about this is the concept that somehow the political 
bodies of the world will attempt to monitor the traffic on the 'net in a way 
that allows them to intercept and track the sources of specific information. 
 This just smacks of a Big Brother mentality, but one that, at least to me, 
is rather ludicrous.  How do they imagine they'll be able to prevent ANYONE 
from using the 'net for ANYTHING?  With encryption in it's many forms, an 
individual could easily put together a message that simply could not be 
deciphered in any appreciable amount of time by any government agency.  
What's the point?

The 'net has warped space and time.  Now everything, all information, all 
knowledge, all people, all places, are directly in front of you, accessible 
in seconds (minutes for some folks, hours if you're on AOL or Prodigy ;)).  
Borders in the physical world do not exist here.  Any border or limitation 
in this world is easily overcome by the next wave of hardware and software.

I commend the nation's leaders for their concern, but they need to deal with 
the real world and stop putting so much energy into grappling with a thing 
far beyond their understanding and more powerful than all of them put 
together.  They should control the substances used to make bombs rather than 
the information for making them.  It's still impossible to stop the terror, 
but they will have a better chance of stemming the flow of that stream than 
they would have drying up the ocean of 'net information, or slowing the 
expansion of a universe already in the throes of it's own virtual Big Bang 
by throwing bits of legislative paper at it.

S

On Wed, 31 Jul 1996, matthew d. p. k. lanier wrote:

> the best lesson i learned from a wise old man (my dad) was "moderation in
> all things".  this lesson, combined with my personal philosophy, causes me
> to believe that there is no substance nor action that, when in the proper
> proportions, is inherently bad. (insert your flame here!)

moderation in *all* things?  no disrespect to your dad or anything but I
don't see the wisdom in this.

> when i think about that in terms of eating, i come to the following
> conclusion for me: being vegetarian, for me, is not moderate.  it says to me
> that "there are some types of food that are bad in some way, regardless of
> their proportion."  i cannot agree with that statement.  yes, vegetarianism
> may be fine for some people, but it does not work for me.

this assumes that you view animals as food (some people don't). 

say hypothetically you managed to get through life without ever eating
meat (as some list people have stated they have).  eating animals would
probably seem pretty barbaric and unneccessary.

> i make my best attempt to not be excessive (difficult as that is, especially
> at a good rave) and choosing to sytematically exclude one food to the
> inclusion of another does not work with my personal philosophy.  i choose to
> eat all types of foods and be healthy with all of them.

> i think it is a little odd that humans feel they can escape the food chain.

I don't think vegetarians are trying to escape the food chain, as you put
it, I think they are re-evaluating how they fit into it.

> i eat other organisms.  when i die, another organism will eat me (i refuse
> to be buried in a coffin.  i will be buried at sea, where my tissue may be
> recycled).
> i may die tomorrow, having been eaten by some animal while i am in the
> wilderness.  being part of the life cycle and the food chain, i am fine with
> that.  just as humans are able to systematically kill animals to eat them,
> other animals are able to kill humans and eat them.  organisms are made to
> eat each other.

think about the behavioral characteristics of animals that eat other
animals (typically predators), and then the animals that live on a
plant-based diet.  draw your own conclusions... 

> ok, now all you vegetarians, please don't flame me too hard, for i respect
> your decision to eat exclusively non-meat products.  i just need to speak my
> piece.

hopefully you won't take this as a flame (it isn't intended to be), it's
just my take on things.  

Andy

Subject: NRR:  Is Bill Gates the Anti-Christ?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Somebody sent me this I thought you all might get a kick out of it...

The real name of "the" Bill Gates is William Henry Gates III.
Nowadays he is known as Bill Gates (III).  By converting the letters of his
current name to the ASCII-values and adding his (III), you get the following:

           B       66
           I       73
           L       76
           L       76
           G       71
           A       65
           T       84
           E       69
           S       83
           I        1
           I        1
           I        1
            --------------
                  666 !!!

Some might ask, "How did Bill Gates get so powerful?"
Coincidence? Or just the beginning of mankind's ultimate and total
enslavement???

Before you decide, consider the following:

M  S  -  D  O  S     6  .  3  1

77+83+45+68+79+83+32+54+46+50+49 = 666

W  I  N  D  O  W  S  9  5

87+73+78+68+79+87+83+57+53+1 = 666


Coincidence? You decide...

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~ ~~~ ~~ ~ ~
David Ginsberg
Chancellor's Office - Information Systems
200 California Hall
University of California
Berkeley, CA 94720-1500
Phone:  (510) 643-7313,  Fax: (510) 642-9483
....................................
There is an easy answer to your problem that is neat, plausible, and wrong.

Subject: Re: meat vs. veggies
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Meat vs. Vegies hunh?

Well if you want to see a respectful way to kill something for the
benefit of you and yours, check out _The Gods Must Be Crazy_ where a
long apology and explanation is given before the actual killing (very
enlightening and entertaining movie on alot of levels).  Keep in mind
that life and death are a cycle and killing is not necessaily BAD.

What is necessarily bad is the way we raise/slaughter/process meat
for the most part as well as the way we grow/process fruits, vegies,
etc...

What is necessarily bad are most peoples dietary habits (mine
included)--vegetarians tend to be better at this because they have gone
out and sought information on the subject rather than help maintain the
status quo but I know meat eaters who eat very healthfuly and
vegetarians who don't.

Also, how much does what our bodies have gotten used to over a lifetime
influence what our bodies can adjust to?

And just to fan the flames a little, what about enslaving and
improsoning animals?  How many people think locking up a horse so we
can have fun riding on it's back or attaching a till to an oxen is
okay?  Sure we take care of those animals, provide for them but then
don't we do the same for those in our prisons--which is supposed to be
a punishment?  How many pet owners out there?  I do have a cat that
lives with me but he's free to do as he pleases--a permanently open
door and I think he gets the better part of the deal anyway.  Of course
I did forceably relocate him a year ago, but we discussed it and he
agreed, though he bitched the whole way.

Oh yeah, rave-related?  Isn't everything?

Tim

On Jul 31, 11:25am, Andy Thomas wrote:
> Subject: Re: moderation in all things, even meat and veggies
>
> On Wed, 31 Jul 1996, matthew d. p. k. lanier wrote:
>
> > the best lesson i learned from a wise old man (my dad) was "moderation in
> > all things".  this lesson, combined with my personal philosophy, causes me
> > to believe that there is no substance nor action that, when in the proper
> > proportions, is inherently bad. (insert your flame here!)
>
> moderation in *all* things?  no disrespect to your dad or anything but I
> don't see the wisdom in this.

Of course there are exceptions like peace, love etc. but in general being
moderate about most things seems like a good thing to me. But then again
pointing out all exceptions would make teaching lessons in life very
cumbersome.

>
> > when i think about that in terms of eating, i come to the following
> > conclusion for me: being vegetarian, for me, is not moderate.  it says to
me
> > that "there are some types of food that are bad in some way, regardless of
> > their proportion."  i cannot agree with that statement.  yes, vegetarianism
> > may be fine for some people, but it does not work for me.
>
> this assumes that you view animals as food (some people don't).

But then again most of the natural world around us does (including the
venus fly trap).

[snip]
> > i eat other organisms.  when i die, another organism will eat me (i refuse
> > to be buried in a coffin.  i will be buried at sea, where my tissue may be
> > recycled).
> > i may die tomorrow, having been eaten by some animal while i am in the
> > wilderness.  being part of the life cycle and the food chain, i am fine
with
> > that.  just as humans are able to systematically kill animals to eat them,
> > other animals are able to kill humans and eat them.  organisms are made to
> > eat each other.
>
> think about the behavioral characteristics of animals that eat other
> animals (typically predators), and then the animals that live on a
> plant-based diet.  draw your own conclusions...

I think it's a little simple to assume that only carnivores are aggressive
while herbivores are not, and that eating meat makes humans aggressive.
First of all, most carnivores in nature do not kill for fun, rarely kill
there own like we do. In fact herbivores can hurt/kill when protecting there
offspring, territory, herd etc. Ever seen an angry elephant? Wouldn't
like to be near one of those.

[snip]

The Frying Dutchman

--

Precedence: bulk

Eric Hill <ehill@best.com> writes:
> I think there's something in DJ mixtapes that go beyond the records that are
> on it and the money they make off of it. Is anyone going to go so far to say
> that a DJ doesn't add anything to the music through mixing?

Well, a DJ obviously adds value, but then again, so do the
artists. I'm sure that some artists don't mind that DJs sell
mixtapes, but I'm sure that others do, and with good
reason.  Selling mixtapes and mix-CDs can be big business,
and a lot of the artists out there aren't making a hell of a
lot of money.

I think about this stuff every time I make a tape.  I try to
give away enough free copies that I'm not actually making
money on the deal, but that doesn't really resolve the moral
ambiguity.  It just means that I'm not profiting off of the
moral ambiguity.

Any other thoughts?

-Sho

Hey everyone!  

I just thought of a tapes idea.  A collective of DJ's selling/trading tapes
of themselves!  This would bring the cost within reasonable ranges, while
directly supporting the ones who spend their creative energies!  Tapes are
cheap, and every DJ I have ever met has taping equiptment.  So, why deal with
distributors and stores if we can do it ourselves?!  Besides, this allows a
pool of "bootleg" tapes to be heard by all.  This would be excelent for
newbies like me to get a taste of the oldskull...something I wish I had
experienced.  There would need to be an agreement between all involved to
respect the wishes of DJ's and setting price protocols and methods, ofcourse!
Where could this be enacted?  On this site? 

Peace!

-Juhstyn

matthew wrote:
> when i think about that in terms of eating, i come to the following
> conclusion for me: being vegetarian, for me, is not moderate.  it says to me
> that "there are some types of food that are bad in some way, regardless of
> their proportion."  i cannot agree with that statement.  yes, vegetarianism
> may be fine for some people, but it does not work for me.

Here's a different slant. This is simplifying things a bit, but being
vegetarian, for me, is partly a matter of ethics and partly a matter of
convenience. The easiest way for me to make sure that my eating doesn't
unduely support mistreatment of animals is not to eat animal products.
(That's the theory, anyway. The occasional bit of mayonnaise and cheese
slips through. :)

Sure i could go to the effort of locating sources for "free-range"
animal products and checking with farms that the marketing label
"free-range" actually means "treated well". But why bother when my
local supermarket has tofu and soy milk? (And Subway has Garden
Burgers. Mmmmmm. :)

Now is the ethical position that "my eating shouldn't support undue
mistreatment of animals" immoderate? It depends on your definition
of moderation.

Jeremy

> >Well, a DJ obviously adds value, but then again, so do the
> >artists. I'm sure that some artists don't mind that DJs sell
> >mixtapes, but I'm sure that others do, and with good
> >reason.  Selling mixtapes and mix-CDs can be big business,
> >and a lot of the artists out there aren't making a hell of a
> >lot of money.

True, but the target audiences of vinyl releases and mix tapes/cds
are not identical.  If I purchase a 12", I'm probably looking for a
tool to mix with.  But if I buy an hour long mix tape or cd, then
I'll probably be listening to it while I do other things.

Personally, I'd be delighted to find myself on a mix tape -- high
sales of such a release can only mean good things for the included
artists.

I certainly see no *loss* one might incur from being featured, but
if the mixing is bad, that's another story ;)

	Sami

Hey everyone!  
     
I just thought of a tapes idea.  A collective of DJ's selling/trading tapes 
of themselves!  This would bring the cost within reasonable ranges, while 
directly supporting the ones who spend their creative energies!  Tapes are 
cheap, and every DJ I have ever met has taping equiptment.  So, why deal with 
distributors and stores if we can do it ourselves?!  Besides, this allows a 
pool of "bootleg" tapes to be heard by all.  This would be excelent for 
newbies like me to get a taste of the oldskull...something I wish I had 
experienced.  There would need to be an agreement between all involved to 
respect the wishes of DJ's and setting price protocols and methods, ofcourse! 
Where could this be enacted?  On this site? 
     
Peace!
     
-Juhstyn

________________________________________________________________________________

My Private Response to JuhStyn from his previous mail...AndyW

-----------------------------------------------------------


I think it's Pure Acid mixtapes.  I've seen them at LA raves several times.  
They're really heavy on the black lights and usually have a host of motorized 
day glow trail machine things behind the counter.  Really cool people.  Plus 
they're helpful in picking tapes out if you're a moron (like me-self) who know 
what they're looking for but are bad at describing it (it goes ....nicla, nickla
nickla nickla and then kinda gets swallowed before the bass kicks in with this 
Bom-badadadada Boooooom....).

Almost all of their tapes come in dayglow one color sleeves.  Totally classic 
stand.  Secret Tip: Most stands like that haggle if you're poor, the salesperson
is into what you're into or buying a whole boat of crap.  It is kinda weird that
we don't have that that much here.  

It would be doubly cool if the DJ's were running their own conglomerate booth 
with their own tapes at some of the bigger shows (Juggernaut anyone?).  That 
way, all the profits would end up in the right place, with no middlebeings, and 
the savings could be passed on to you: the beat addict.

AndyW

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jul 31 18:30:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA16079; Wed, 31 Jul 1996 18:30:39 -0700

> Hey everyone!  
>      
> I just thought of a tapes idea.  A collective of DJ's selling/trading tapes 
> of themselves!  This would bring the cost within reasonable ranges, while 
> directly supporting the ones who spend their creative energies!  Tapes are 
> cheap, and every DJ I have ever met has taping equiptment.  So, why deal with 
> distributors and stores if we can do it ourselves?!  Besides, this allows a 
> pool of "bootleg" tapes to be heard by all.  This would be excelent for 
> newbies like me to get a taste of the oldskull...something I wish I had 
> experienced.  There would need to be an agreement between all involved to 
> respect the wishes of DJ's and setting price protocols and methods, ofcourse! 
> Where could this be enacted?  On this site? 
>      
> Peace!
>      
> -Juhstyn

> My Private Response to JuhStyn from his previous mail...AndyW

> 
> 
> I think it's Pure Acid mixtapes.  I've seen them at LA raves several times.  
> They're really heavy on the black lights and usually have a host of motorized 
> day glow trail machine things behind the counter.  Really cool people.  Plus 
> they're helpful in picking tapes out if you're a moron (like me-self) who know 
> what they're looking for but are bad at describing it (it goes ....nicla, nickla
> nickla nickla and then kinda gets swallowed before the bass kicks in with this 
> Bom-badadadada Boooooom....).
> 
> Almost all of their tapes come in dayglow one color sleeves.  Totally classic 
> stand.  Secret Tip: Most stands like that haggle if you're poor, the salesperson
> is into what you're into or buying a whole boat of crap.  It is kinda weird that
> we don't have that that much here.  
> 
> It would be doubly cool if the DJ's were running their own conglomerate booth 
> with their own tapes at some of the bigger shows (Juggernaut anyone?).  That 
> way, all the profits would end up in the right place, with no middlebeings, and 
> the savings could be passed on to you: the beat addict.

Date: 07/30/96 12:54 AM
From: Bradley J. Gong
You may recall last year's Darwin Award winner: The man who found out
moments before making a 300 MPH dent in an Arizona cliff that the JATO unit
he'd strapped to his car could not be turned off once it was turned on.

There's been a lot of controversy recently about whether the Darwin Awards
are real or just a great urban legend.  If they don't exist, why not?

And there are some excellent candidates among this year's rumoured
nominations:

Darwin Awards

These are nearly always granted posthumously. This citation is bestowed upon
(the remains of) that individual, who through single-minded self-sacrifice,
has done the most to remove undesirable elements from the human gene pool.

--------------------------------------------------------------
[San Jose Mercury News]

An unidentified man, using a shotgun like a club to break a former
girlfriend's windshield, accidentally shot himself to death when the gun
discharged, blowing a hole in his gut.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[Hickory Daily Record, 12-21-92]

Ken Charles Barger, 47, accidentally shot himself to death in December in
Newton, N. C., when, awakening to the sound of a ringing telephone beside
his bed, he reached for the phone but grabbed instead a Smith & Wesson .38
Special, which discharged when he drew it to his ear.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[News of the Weird, 18 May 93, San Jose Mercury News]

A 24-year-old salesman from Hialeah, Fla., was killed near Lantana, Fla., in
March when his car smashed into a pole in the median strip of Interstate 95
in the middle of the afternoon. 

Police said that the man was traveling at 80 MPH and, judging by the sales
manual that was found open and clutched to his chest, had been busy reading.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[Unknown, 25 March 1993] A Vapid Death

A terrible diet and room with no ventilation are being blamed for the death
of a man who was killed by his own gas. There was no mark on his body but
autopsy showed large amounts of methane gas in his system.  His diet had
consisted primarily of beans and cabbage (and a couple other things). It was
just the right combination of foods.

It appears that the man died in his sleep from breathing from the poisonous
cloud that was hanging over his bed. Had he been outside or had his windows
opened it wouldn't have been fatal but the man was shut up in his near
airtight bedroom. He was ``...a big man with a huge capacity for creating
[this deadly
gas].'' Three of the rescue workers got sick and one was hospitalized.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[Reuters, Mississauga, Ontario]
Man slips, falls 23 stories to his death.

A man cleaning a bird feeder on his balcony of his condominium apartment in
this Toronto suburb slipped and fell 23 stories to his death, police said
Monday.

Stefan Macko, 55, was standing on a wheeled chair Sunday when the accident
occurred, said Inspector D'Arcy Honer of the Peel regional police.

"It appears the chair moved and he went over the balcony," Honer said.
"It's one of those freak accidents. No foul play is suspected."

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[UPI, Toronto]

Police said a lawyer demonstrating the safety of windows in a downtown
Toronto skyscraper crashed through a pane with his shoulder and plunged 24
floors to his death.

A police spokesman said Garry Hoy, 39, fell into the courtyard of the
Toronto Dominion Bank Tower early Friday evening as he was explaining the
strength of the building's windows to visiting law students.

Hoy previously had conducted demonstrations of window strength according to
police reports. Peter Lauwers, managing partner of the firm Holden Day
Wilson, told the Toronto Sun newspaper that Hoy was ``one of the best and
brightest'' members of the 200-man association.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[AP, Cairo, Egypt, 31 Aug 1995] CAIRO, Egypt (AP)]

Six people drowned Monday while trying to rescue a chicken that had fallen
into a well in southern Egypt.

An 18-year-old farmer was the first to descend into the 60-foot well.  He
drowned, apparently after an undercurrent in the water pulled  him down,
police said.

His sister and two brothers, none of whom could swim well, went in one by
one to help him, but also drowned. Two elderly farmers then came to help,
but they apparently were pulled down by the same undercurrent.

The bodies of the six were later pulled out of the well in the village of
Nazlat Imara, 240 miles south of Cairo.

The chicken was also pulled out. It survived.

 --------------------------------------------------------------
[Times of London]

A thief who sneaked into a hospital was scarred for life when he tried to
get a suntan.

After evading security staff at Odstock Hospital in Salisbury, Wiltshire,
and helping himself to doctors' paging devices, the thief spotted a vertical
sunbed. He walked into the unit and removed his clothes for a 45-minute tan.

However, the high-voltage UV machine at the hospital, which is renowned for
its treatment of burns victims, has a maximum dosage of ten seconds.  After
lying on the bed for almost 300 times the recommended maximum time the man
was covered in blisters.

Hours later, when the pain of the burns became unbearable, he went to
Southampton General Hospital, 20 miles away,in Hampshire. Staff became
suspicious because he was wearing a doctor's coat. After tending his wounds
they called the police.

Southampton police said: "This man broke into Odstock and decided he fancied
a quick suntan. Doctors say he is going to be scarred for life."

I'm Glad you mentioned our (humans) dentition indicates we are omnivorous.  I
was told once by a well meaning vegetarian that "Because chimps are 98%
genetically identical to us and are vegetarians, we are supposed to be
vegetarians."  While we are 98% genetically identical to chimps I had to
inform her that 1.  Chimps are omnivorous and even hunt other monkeys as a
food source.  2.  There have been documented cases of canibalism among
chimps.  3.  chimps while usually peaceful are cabable of being extremely
violent and aggressive.  As you pointed out a vegetarian lifestyle is
possible but you must be careful to get all the required nutrients.     Jeff

Herbavores are docile (and stupid too).  How much brain power does it take to
munch away at a plant all day long.  My point is that without the need to
cooperate and communicate during a hunt the evolutionary pressure for
reasoning and problem solving (not to mention language) is absent and we may
never have evolved to the point where we can even question our eating habits.
:)    Jeff

	greetings.  i got the following articles today, and 
	i will be getting more.

	again, i don't work for nike per se, except as an 
	employee of a company who nike has contracted for
	a while.  this is not necessarily in their defense 
	that i post this; one should always question what
	one reads - be it in the /guardian/ or /village
	voice/ to major newspapers and press releases.

	if it is worth anything to any of you, i do know 
	some people here who actually know what's going on
	in their overseas factories.  the person i talked
	to has been to many of them.  this person is a very
	heads-up guy, and a good person.  i strongly doubt
	he would flat-out lie to me.  he told me that 
	conditions are good in those factories, and better
	than most of the rest of the factories in their
	communities.

	take it all with a critical eye, though... question
	authority and all that.

ninja250 -- analog synthesis -- chaotic good -- the internet is my ashtray

"i hate anything that ends with .exe" - patrick sean farley

LABOR DEBATE -- Yet again the seemingly  inexplicable guns of journalism 
have gone off.  This time, however, foreign service reporters  Keith B. 
Richburg and Anne Swardson offer sanity  instead of fiction. What follows 
are excerpts  from their July 28 Washington Post article,  "U.S. Industry 
Overseas: Sweatshop or Job  Source?":

"It is one of those yes-you-do, no-I-don't- debates where the truth is 
difficult to  ascertain not only in the United States but in  Serang, a 
gritty industrial center 50 miles west  of Indonesia's capital, Jakarta. 
What is clear  is that Indonesia is booming and poverty is  falling, 
relative to its impoverished past, and  much of the boom has come since 
American and  other companies began investing there a decade  or so ago. 
Many of the 120,000 Indonesian  workers who produce Nike shoes, most of 
whom  come from impoverished rural backgrounds, say  factories like 
Serang's provide a chance not  only to earn but to save money and to send 
the  extra cash back to families.

"Per capita income in Indonesia has more than  tripled in the last 20 
years. The decline in  poverty has been one of the most dramatic in  
recent years; according to the World Bank, 15  percent of the population 
lived at the lowest  level of poverty early this decade, down from 29  
percent 10 years before.

"The Serang factory closes for about 10 days  each year for Muslim 
holidays and most of the  workers return to their villages to see family, 
 drop off the money they have collected and, for  some of the young women, 
to find husbands.   Traditionally some women never return from the  
holidays. At that plant, Nike officials and the  plant's Taiwanese owners 
say 94 percent of the  workers came back after the most recent break.  `If 
it were that bad, they wouldn't come back,'  said a Nike official. `They 
vote with their  feet.'"   

-----------------------------------------
ON OTHER FRONTS

NIKE TECHNOLOGIES AWARDED -- Nike won the  Environmental Technology Award 
for creating and  using technologies that reduce environmental  impact. 
The award was accepted by NEAT's  director, Sarah Severn, at the Sports  
International Trade Show in Chicago. The sold- out event played host to a 
large number of  retailers including Nike accounts such as  Stadium Sports 
of Sweden and Rebel Sports of  Australia. Because environmental 
responsibility  is increasingly becoming a focus for  international 
business, the organizers of the  `96 Show inaugurated the first-annual ET- 
 Environmental Tech Awards.  The ET awards are  jointly sponsored by 
Sports International,  Outdoor Retailer and The International Sports  
Plaza of Atlanta. Each year the Environmental  Technology Awards will 
recognize one large ($100  million plus revenue) and one small (under $10 
 million) company that has created or utilized  specific technology 
designed to preserve the  environment. Nike was recognized for Regrind and 
 Reuse-A-Shoe in addition to several other  proprietary technologies.

The "Good Times" virus is a memetic virus, that is, the warning message is
the virus. So, by spreading the warning, you are spreading the virus. BTW,
this is about the 15th time this has come up on SFraves in the last two
years. It should be put in the FAQ or something. ;)
Tim

van is sensitive to turning the head unit's volume most of the way up.  I was driving 
down the freeway (my hotrod 70 Ford van is real loud), hit this spot on the tape, 
turned the volume up as to here the detail above the motor, and bam...monster feedback.
Like I said, only a problem in a 300 horsepower vehicle where you sit next to the engine.

> Herbavores are docile (and stupid too).  How much brain power does it take to
> munch away at a plant all day long.

Apparently more than most of us have!  Instead we make our lives
complicated, stressful, filled with fear and hate when we could just
be kicking back enjoying the simple life.  Gee, we must be smart.

>  My point is that without the need to
> cooperate and communicate during a hunt the evolutionary pressure for
> reasoning and problem solving (not to mention language) is absent and we may
> never have evolved to the point where we can even question our eating habits.

Interesting, but hunting can't be the only "evolutionary pressure for
reasoning and problem solving"?  What about a stereo?  Surely, Nature
intended for us to invent such a thing--hell we already had food who
needs to hunt, but you can't be expected to wait around for a good
thunderstorm to rock the house!

On the origins of man I think I prefer the idea the Nefilim from the 12th
Planet imprinted their genetic code onto homo erectus and thereby
produced homo sapien--the perfect little worker to till their land and
mine their mines.  Only why didn't they leave any stereos behind--those
bastards, just because we took back our planet!

Tim (past his bed time)

Hey, since I mentioned a stereo, does that make this rave related?

Greetings,

> This would be a good "list it yourself" on a website, where people would
> send email to the DJ who is selling it requesting it. That or a periodical
> email/usenet post by The Keeper of the List?

I would be willing to work with some people on setting up site space. 
I've got a RealAudio server.  we can encode the tapes and put them up,
this would allow people to listen to them on the net, assuming they had
the realaudio player.

The best thing would be to have the mix tape with a playlist so that the
original artists can be credited.

My initial feelings about selling them over the net are not real
positive right now, though.  I just don't feel real comfortable with all
the intellectul property issues involved.

If anybody is willing to help organize, I've got the web space and the
server.
